HEADLINE: Anger Grows in Middletown Over Teachers' Strike 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS and ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Dec. 6 

 BODY:
At first, it felt like a snow day in June.
 But one week into a strike that has thrown 10,500 students out of class and 228 teachers behind bars, frustration is turning to anger in this New Jersey town, which not long ago gained international attention as having one of the largest Sept. 11 death tolls. 
 With no resolution in sight, the Middletown teachers' strike is emerging as one of the most bitter and disruptive local labor battles in recent years. Union officials say the mass jailing of teachers is the first in this country since 1978 and represents the first time in two decades that New Jersey teachers have been incarcerated for walking off the job. 
Picketing teachers have been booed and cursed by passing drivers; death threats have flooded the local school board office; and at least four educators, disgusted by the court proceedings, have resigned on the spot rather than go to jail.
Parents have become increasingly infuriated by the demands of caring for idle children. Several have vowed to pull their children out of Middletown's school system. "Let them stay in jail," said Stephanie Billings, 27, a mother of two who grew up here. "We're just sick of this. They broke the law. Now they have to pay the price."
With an additional 99 teachers ordered jailed today and the distrust and bitterness mounting, those on both sides of the issue say they are stunned by how quickly a contract dispute turned into a nationally televised civil war.
Defiant teachers, cuffed wrists thrust in the air, liken their cause to the 1960's struggle for civil rights. Before she was led away by police officers on Wednesday, Barbara Guenther, a history teacher, told a Superior Court judge why she was defying his back-to-work order. "I try to teach my students this country is fair and just," she said as many of those in the courtroom cried. "In this process, the law is not fair and just. Sometimes good people have to stand up to fight an unjust law."
The pace of contempt-of-court hearings increased today, with a third judge added to the proceedings. All three judges increased the amount of jail time given to striking teachers, in some cases doubling sentences to two weeks. Judge Clarkson S. Fisher Jr., who has been presiding over the case since Nov. 29, said he was prepared to impose even harsher penalties if the teachers did not return to work.
Saying that "more onerous sanctions" might be necessary, he seemed to be threatening the mass firings requested by the Middletown school board.
The strike has been troubling for students, especially those who have watched news broadcasts showing teachers being led to jail. "It made me very sad," said Samantha Tartaro, 17, who wept when she saw her favorite elementary school teacher in handcuffs. "I like my teachers. I don't want them to be in prison."
But in more than two dozen interviews this week, parent antipathy toward the striking teachers was nearly unanimous. Citing a troubled economy and soaring layoffs, many said they thought the teachers were asking for too much. "A good teacher can never be paid enough, but the truth is they're the highest paid in Monmouth County and I don't know any employer these days that gives full benefits," said Bonnie Acosta, 43, whose daughter, Maggie, is a ninth grader. "Maybe they should travel to the Bronx or Bed-Stuy and see those schools. Then they'll realize they have a gem of a job." 
Some parents said they had supported the teachers' demands until they went on strike. Working parents like Jo-Ann Werner said they were too overwhelmed by child care concerns to worry about the teachers' monetary needs. A mother of two who works full time as a secretary, Ms. Werner said she and her husband were tired of juggling time off or asking relatives to baby-sit for their daughters, 6 and 15, during the day. At the same time, their home has become a neighborhood hangout for other displaced children.
"The first day it was great, but I've got seven kids eating me out of house and home," she said. "They're bored and I'm losing my mind. I've had enough of this strike." 
The main sticking point between the union and the board is health benefits. Teachers and secretaries currently pay a $250 annual flat fee for family health benefits and up to a $1,400 deductible. The board wants union members to pay a percentage of their health care premiums. 
But many teachers say their walkout has more to do with dignity than dollars. Over the years, and especially during a week-long strike in 1998, union members have said they have been treated poorly by the district, which, with 17 schools, is the largest in Monmouth County. The struggle, many believe, is also about fighting a board intent on breaking the union. 
Jennifer Loughlin, a literature teacher who resigned today rather than go to jail, said she would seek a job in another district. "I'm totally disheartened by the treatment of the Board of Education and the lack of support for teachers in our community," she said as she left the courthouse in tears. "I can't continue to work in a district that has no respect for us."
Incarceration is clearly having the desired effect on some of the strikers. Today, for the first time, eight women came before the court asking to be let out of jail. One woman was desperate to go to her son's wedding, another said the stress of detention had worsened her high blood pressure and another fretted about the 2-month-old daughter she had left with her 72-year-old father. 
Judge Fisher set them free, although he ordered one of the women to return to jail on Monday, after the marriage of her son.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Striking teachers in Middletown, N.J., gathered at the Hall of Records in Freehold this week to explain in Superior Court why they had ignored a back-to-work order. In all, 228 of the teachers have been jailed. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)(pg. D5)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Europe:Interest Rate Unchanged 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The European Central Bank left its main interest rate unchanged, a decision that was widely expected one month after it slashed rates by half a percentage point in the face of strong pressure to stimulate the Continent's sagging economy. The central bank has made only 4 rate cuts this year, in contrast with 10 by the United States Federal Reserve Bank. The European bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, said, "The conditions are there for economic growth to improve in the course of 2002."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE GLOBAL CAMPAIGN; 
U.S. Official Praises China for Its Cooperation in Rooting Out bin Laden's Terror Network

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
A top American antiterrorism official wound up two days of talks here today by praising the Chinese for their cooperation in fighting Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's terror network, and said he was hopeful that the F.B.I. would soon be allowed to open a liaison office in Beijing.
 "The Chinese share our resolve to shut down the global terror network linked to Osama bin Laden," said the official, Gen. Frank Taylor, who became the State Department's ambassador at large for counterterrorism after his retirement from the Air Force. "We're pleased with the cooperation we have received from China since Sept. 11." 
 Still, it appeared that the scope of collaboration against global terror might be limited. General Taylor said that his meetings with senior foreign policy, military and banking officials here focused on the immediate struggle against Mr. bin Laden and his network, Al Qaeda.
He said he did not raise broader issues -- on which agreement was less likely -- like extending the antiterror battle to Iraq, which the United States suspects is trying to develop weapons of mass destruction, or trying to shut down the Hamas organization in the Middle East.
Also, General Taylor said he made clear that the United States would not support Beijing's effort to paint Uighur Muslim nationalists in China's Xinjiang region as terrorists. China has been criticized for trampling on people's rights as it tries to stamp out ethnic separatism in the region, but Chinese officials insist that Uighur militants have received outside training and aid. 
Some Uighurs had been discovered with the Taliban forces in Afghanistan, General Taylor said, and some have committed acts of violence inside China. But he said that "the legitimate economic and social issues" facing people in northwest China "need political solutions, not counterterrorism." 
"The United States hasn't changed its values," he said. "We continue to hold very dearly our concern in areas such as human rights." 
In any case, General Taylor said, "our focus now is in rooting out Al Qaeda, and we've got a lot of work to do." He said the United States believed that the group had cells in more than 50 countries, but declined to say whether these included China. 
General Taylor said the main contribution by China so far had been in the diplomatic arena -- especially its cooperation in passage of a strong resolution in the United Nations and its support for the creation of a new government in Afghanistan.
He said that a bilateral working group had been set up to improve vigilance in the financial sector, but that there was no evidence that terrorist groups had deposited money in Chinese banks. The two countries have also established channels for sharing information and intelligence on terrorist activities and have agreed to hold formal antiterrorism consultations twice a year.
General Taylor said the Chinese had promised to give "positive consideration" to the American request to open a legal attache office in the American Embassy here, which would be run by the F.B.I. Similar offices in Moscow and elsewhere have aided the efforts of law enforcement agencies against organized crime, money laundering and other criminal activities.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
2 Big Chip Makers Raise Forecasts

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Intel and Advanced Micro Devices raised their financial forecasts for the current quarter today, saying that their microprocessors that power personal computers were selling better than expected. 
 The two companies, leading competitors in the PC chip market, said that computer makers had bought more of their newest chips than projected in October. 
 Though corporations continued to show frugality in their spending, analysts said, retail shoppers had begun to open their wallets again during the holiday season and buy computers. 
Intel, the world's largest chip maker, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it expected sales of $6.7 billion to $6.9 billion in the quarter -- an increase over its October estimate of $6.2 billion to $6.8 billion. Intel shares, which fell 45 cents, to $34.16, before the announcement, rose as high as $35.22 after hours. 
Surprising demand for the Pentium 4, its newest line of chip, contributed to the new forecast, Intel said. Andy D. Bryant, the chief financial officer, said the company was making all the Pentium 4 chips it could, but acknowledged that its factories could not keep up with orders. "Right now supply is tight," Mr. Bryant said in a conference call with analysts. "We're doing all we can to meet our customers' needs." 
Despite the shortages, Mr. Bryant said he saw a return to normal business patterns this quarter, if at lower levels. As in most years, he said, the number of microprocessors shipped in Asia and Europe will increase over those in the third quarter while the North and South American market will remain roughly flat. 
Many chip industry executives and analysts think the bottom in a precipitous sales decline occurred in September, when revenue fell 44 percent compared with September 2000. While Intel's announcement offered evidence to support that notion, Mr. Bryant cautioned analysts that a return to boom times depended on an economic turnaround. "The economic indicators remain weak," he said, "and we will continue to be cautious until we see a recovery in the worldwide economy." 
Intel and Advanced Micro have conducted a punishing price war that cuts heavily into both their profits. Intel said increased shipments, more than higher prices, would enable it to meet or slightly exceed its gross profit margin projections. 
But Advanced Micro, which holds about 22 percent of the desktop market, said today that the average selling price of its chips increased during the quarter, boding well for improved profit. 
The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it expected revenue to increase 10 percent or more from last quarter, when it reported revenue of $765 million. Trying to recover from a steep loss last quarter, the company indicated that sales of its PC chips had risen sharply after the introduction of its Athlon XP microprocessor, which some say outperforms more expensive Pentium 4 chips. 
Advanced Micro said it expected PC chip revenue in the fourth quarter to exceed its previously strongest period, the first three months of 2001, when the figure was $661 million. For that to happen, PC chip sales must sharply improve from last quarter's $467 million.
An Advanced Micro spokesman, John Greenagel, said, "The entire story of the quarter right now is proving to be the Athlon XP processor." The company said it expected to turn a profit again in the second quarter of next year, when the full effect of factory closings and job cuts is felt.
A.M.D. stock rose one cent, to $16.25, in the regular session. After hours, it traded as high as $18.
Analysts cautioned against using today's forecasts as a benchmark for the health of the PC industry. 
Eric Rothdeutsch, a managing director with Robertson Stephens, said Advanced Micro benefited from the price and performance of its Athlon XP chips compared with Intel's offerings. As for Intel, he said a better-than-expected transition to the higher-priced Pentium 4 chips had increased sales figures, adding that Intel had been too cautious in its original projections. 
"I would not extend this to say there is robust PC demand," Mr. Rothdeutsch said. --------------------

Sun Says It's on Track
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 6 (Bloomberg News) -- Sun Microsystems said here today that its orders this quarter were coming in as expected, yet it declined to predict if revenue would meet forecasts because so much business comes at the end of the period.
Sun, whose servers power Internet sites and corporate networks, said that work force reduction costs would result in a charge of at least $500 million this quarter. Sun's chief financial officer, Michael Lehman, said the company still expected to return to profitability in the fourth fiscal quarter ending next June.
Sun shares fell 42 cents, to $14.15, in regular session trading today and settled at $14.18 after hours. 
The company is expected to have a loss, excluding certain costs, of 4 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales are forecast at $3.08 billion.

HEADLINE: Auction Houses Are Set Back By Conviction In Price-Fixing 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
When Sotheby's and Christie's first conspired in the mid-1990's to fix the commission rates charged to sellers at their auctions, they were reacting, at least in part, to a desperate financial situation.
 In the throes of fierce competition, both auction houses were hemorrhaging money by promising the sellers commission-free deals, multimillion dollar financing, black-tie parties, elaborate vanity catalogs and donations to their favorite charities. 
 Now, after the conviction of Sotheby's former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, on Wednesday for his pivotal role in the conspiracy -- designed to illegally stifle the competition and reap millions for the venerable companies -- the economic situation for the houses looks many times worse.
Seldom has a scheme seemed to yield as little, in the end, for its participants as this one has. The $4 billion a year high-end auction business, controlled for centuries by the two companies, finds itself more cash-strapped than ever. 
Both companies have had to pay hundreds of millions of dollars in legal settlements, lawyers' fees, and, in Sotheby's case, fines stemming from the collusion.
They are also facing a shaky economy with a dwindling supply of multimillion-dollar art coming on the market, an upstart competitor with deep pockets poking at their duopoly, and reputations that might have been deeply damaged by the scandal and seamy revelations that emerged during Mr. Taubman's 16-day trial in Manhattan federal court.
While Christie's is privately held by Francois Pinault, the French luxury-goods millionaire, Sotheby's, publicly traded, was again the talk of sales rumors yesterday. Although a spokesman for Mr. Taubman said he had not begun to actively consider selling his still-controlling interest in the company, it has passively been on the market for several months.
Ronald Baron, chairman of the Baron Fund and Sotheby's largest outside shareholder, said in his annual report on Sept. 30 that he would probably sell his Sotheby's holdings next year. 
Financial analysts do not consider auction houses a desirable investment now. "The problem is profitability," said James M. Meyer, chief investment officer of Tower Bridge Advisers, a Pennsylvania investment firm. "Auction houses are a trophy franchise."
A possible buyer, he said, could be Phillips de Pury & Luxembourg, the newly aggressive No. 3 in the auction world. "A potential buyer has to be either Phillips, who has been throwing millions of dollars into buying its way into the art world, or someone like Taubman, who wants to buy their way into a powerful position in art and social circles." 
But there are some art-world observers who believe memories are short and that the bruises Sotheby's and Christie's are experiencing will quickly fade, particularly given that they remain the biggest game around for the sale of high-priced art and furnishings.
Other observers, though, are not as optimistic. They believe that after one of the biggest art world scandals in decades, the halcyon days of the glamorous auction world will never be the same. 
"There's going to be skepticism in the auction industry for some time," said John C. Coffee Jr., a law professor at Columbia University. 
But he and others pointed to the sophistication of the auction houses' customers and their commitment to the auction mechanism as the best way to do business. These factors, they say, could help the companies right themselves and carry on.
"Auctions are still the best way of determining fair market value," said Alexander Forger, a lawyer with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, who was an executor of the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis estate, which was sold at Sotheby's in 1996 for $13.1 million. "There's no question of the validity and integrity of public auction."
Mr. Taubman and his protegee and chief accuser, Diana D. Brooks, may face prison terms of up to three years, but for the auction market, Mr. Forger said, the trial, "was just a bump in the road."
The companies, which have been dismissing staff members, now have under 2,000 employees each worldwide. They each generate about $2 billion worth of sales annually.
A large part of their sales are built on personal relationships that their experts have nurtured over the years with the world's richest collectors.
Their stock in trade is the establishment of a trust that allows a client to feel comfortable selling a multimillion-dollar art collection through a particular expert and house.
Throughout Mr. Taubman's trial, though, details of secret negotiations and other matters cast the houses' reputations for probity in a dubious light. There were secret meetings in the back seat of Ms. Brooks's car at Kennedy International Airport and at Mr. Taubman's apartments in London and New York to discuss competitive matters, including raising and fixing commission fees to sellers so that they were non-negotiable.
And even after top officials from the companies shook hands on a corrupt deal, they often cheated on it to take business from each other. 
Four people were admitted or indicted conspirators -- Ms. Brooks and Mr. Taubman from Sotheby's and Sir Anthony Tennant, the former chairman of Christie's, and Christopher M. Davidge, Christie's former chief executive. Sir Anthony, indicted with Mr. Taubman, refused to travel from London to stand trial.
But according to trial testimony, others in the two houses had also discussed fixing fees. Mentioned in testimony were the jewelry experts John Block, a former head of jewelry at Sotheby's who is now chief executive for Phillips in North America, and Francois Curiel, who is chairman of Christie's in Europe. They were identified in testimony as having discussed increasing buyers' fees in 1992.
Another former Sotheby's employee now on the board of Phillips, Lord Camoys, also wanted to enter into the collusion, according to Ms. Brooks' testimony. He talked to Sir Anthony about meeting to discuss commission rates, and when Ms. Brooks found out she stopped him. 
(Simon de Pury, chairman of Phillips, said yesterday that he declined to comment about the fate of Mr. Block and Lord Camoys. Andree Corroon, a spokeswoman for Christie's, declined to discuss Mr. Curiel's future at Christie's, saying only, "We do not comment on any internal personnel matters.") 
The trial's damage to Sotheby's and Christie's did not stop with fixing fees. Discretion is an important part of how the houses do business. Yet throughout the trial details of agreements with prominent collectors were projected on a large screen for jurors to evaluate and others were mentioned in testimony. 
Most details were used to underscore the fact that even after officials at Sotheby's and Christie's had agreed among themselves to stop negotiating sellers' commissions along with certain kinds of financing, they went ahead with that sort of dealmaking as if they had never made the commitment.
During the trial, highly confidential consignment agreements for major estates, including those of Mrs. Onassis and Pamela Harriman, a political personality and a United States ambassador to France, are now a matter of public record. 
Who knew that in 1995, when Christie's agreed to sell property belonging to Mrs. Harriman, it had agreed to give her a $14 million guarantee, regardless of the outcome of the sale, and to cover the tab for shipping and insuring the art. The deal, according to the once-private consignment agreement, also included a promise to feature her $10 million to $15 million Picasso on the cover of its Impressionist and modern art sales catalog. 
Even though the sale is six years old, this information is most useful to other potential sellers as they approach both houses.
To win the Onassis estate, Sotheby's waived its seller's commission unless the sale totaled $10 million, after which point it would share a portion of the profits above that figure. The auction house also agreed to give the executors a say in the photographs to be used in the catalog and the way the property would be exhibited at Sotheby's.
Some observers said the damage from the release of the details from these sales could be contained, mostly because auction house customers still had few other places to turn.
"Some people may be horrified that these arrangements are now out in the open, but everybody knows special deals were struck," said William B. Warren, a lawyer at Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood. There were also the mystery loans made by Ms. Brooks that were revealed. One for $240 million, made in 1998 and identified by a Sotheby's code name -- the flower loan -- went to Wolfgang Flottl, a Austrian-born financier who had been a major buyer and seller at auction for years.
Ms. Brooks made another loan, for $105 million, a year later, according to the testimony of William S. Sheridan, Sotheby's chief financial officer. And his story painted an unflattering picture of ineptitude.
At the time, a mystery telephone bidder known simply by his paddle number, L036, went on a shopping spree at Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art in May 1999, buying works by Monet, Rodin and Signac. At its sale of art from the estate of Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, the philanthropist and socialite, the buyer bought a $60.5 million Cezanne. 
But, according to testimony, the loan, which was extended so that the bidder could make the acquisitions, was not repaid in a timely manner. 
After the sale, Sotheby's sold the Cezanne at a loss to Stephen A. Wynn, the casino owner. 
Until the details of the loan surfaced in court last week, information about the buyer was scant. Mr. Sheridan declined to identify him other than to say that he had never bought million-dollar art before and had a rich mother.
Days later, according to officials at Sotheby's, one buyer who met Mr. Sheridan's description was William Gerry, from Locust Valley, N.Y. A call to his house was answered by a housekeeper who said he was out of the country for four or five months and she did not know where he was. 
There are many in the art world who believe that the auction houses, scarred and policed as never before, have learned their lesson. 
But they also face a new era of unbridled and intense competition. Perennial No. 3, Phillips boasts deep pockets from its parent company, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. As long as Phillips is willing to buy $100 million worth of art to sell at auction each spring and fall, said Mr. Meyer, the financial adviser, that takes away business from Sotheby's and Christie's.
Hurting Sotheby's bottom line will not make it more attractive to a potential buyer of Mr. Taubman's holdings, he said, or to those of Mr. Baron, the large shareholder.

HEADLINE: Competing for Better Government 

BYLINE:  By Stephen Goldsmith; Stephen Goldsmith, mayor of Indianapolis from 1992 to 1999, is chairman of the Manhattan Institute Center on Civic Innovation and professor of public management at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.

 BODY:
My first week as mayor of Indianapolis, I visited angry sanitation workers threatening job actions because of my pledge to privatize municipal services. Soon those threats turned to picketing, demonstrations and occasional sabotage by union workers.
 Yet just five years later, both the union and I were joint recipients of an award for cooperation. Knowing how we turned this situation around might prove helpful to Michael Bloomberg and New York City's unions as they struggle with declining revenues and an increased need for city services. 
 Both city officials and union leaders need to recognize that a city cannot grow economically, and public employees cannot succeed, if a city's tax base flees, if poverty becomes more concentrated and if the quality of public services declines.
In Indianapolis, I distributed to city employees unflattering advertisements about our city that had been paid for by economic development officials in neighboring communities. To my surprise, the president of the Indiana state chapter of the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees understood the need for change. He was open to the idea of competition, if not necessarily privatization.
Simply put, bureaucratic monopolies are bad for taxpayers and bad for public employees. When government insists that competition is off limits, it communicates to public workers that they are inferior. Competition creates the conditions for increased productivity and new partnerships in which the private sector provides some functions while public employees concentrate on what they do best -- and where they are most needed.
For example, in many cities and states today, private companies are contracted to do "back-office" work like collecting parking-ticket revenue, processing toll-road payments or operating print shops. This allows more money to go to more visible public workers like police and firefighters. The aim is not to privatize the work for the sake of privatization, but to serve the public better with existing resources.
Of course, this sort of transition may mean some shifts in the work force. Private contractors for public services often hire city workers, but not always all of them. To win support for change, city leaders must pledge to do what they can to minimize immediate forced layoffs.
Demographic trends may make this goal more realistic. As the first baby boomers reach retirement age, the size of the public sector work force will decline. Thus there will be a natural opportunity to put more functions out for bid while also thinning the ranks of the public sector, making it more productive.
This process is not easy. Incentives for early retirement help, as does outplacement assistance. But most important is a commitment from city hall to put as many displaced workers as possible in other public jobs. This requires both union and management leadership to rethink seniority rules, job classifications, pay scales and other issues, for they all affect employee mobility.
This kind of transformation will depend on a motivated work force that is allowed to make its workplace decisions. Rigid job descriptions, layers of unnecessary middle management and lack of authority often prevent workers from being efficient and effective. Pay systems and work rules must be structured to allow for -- and to reward -- productivity.
Smart unions understand this. In Indianapolis, we asked our garage mechanics to bid against private contractors for city business. They agreed, and their bid included a proposal to thin the ranks of management by 75 percent and to share in any profits of the new arrangement. They won the contract, and as a result they had an incentive to increase productivity -- and profits -- by absorbing the work of colleagues who were retiring.
None of this can work well unless there is a spirit of trust and cooperation between labor and management. Too often in the public sector, these relationships become little more than a framework for grievances and lawsuits. In Indianapolis, we chose another way. Our labor-management team addressed many issues unrelated to compensation, from race relations in the workplace to equipment safety. Regular meetings between top union and city officials, including the mayor, helped ensure that middle managers understood that we were on the same team.
The private contractor that won the bid to operate our wastewater treatment plant, for example, agreed to work in partnership with the public employees union. Together they produced a remarkable record over five years, increasing pay and minority subcontracts and virtually eliminating grievances and accidents.
New York City, of course, is not Indianapolis. The New York Police Department alone, with almost 50,000 employees, is about seven times the size of the entire Indianapolis municipal work force. But Mr. Bloomberg need not reinvent the entire city government at once. And the principles we applied in Indianapolis are equally valid in New York.

HEADLINE: Giuliani to Appeal Decision On a Work-for-Shelter Policy 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Nearly two years ago, a state judge ruled that the Giuliani administration could not bar adults from shelters if they failed to meet work requirements and other welfare eligibility rules. 
 Now, with less than a month left in the term of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, his administration has filed notice in court that it will appeal the judge's order. 
 The move, which gives the city nine months to complete an appeal, comes at a time of record population in the city's homeless shelters, rising unemployment, and the end of federal welfare benefits for thousands of families. And it could force the incoming administration of Michael R. Bloomberg to take a stand on a Giuliani-era policy that was roundly criticized. 
Steven Banks, the Legal Aid lawyer for the Coalition for the Homeless, said the filing on Tuesday had created "a human hot potato for the incoming administration."
"In a city still trying to recover from the reverberations of Sept. 11," he said, "it certainly seems like certain lame duck officials are attempting to leave a legacy of a policy that would deny and terminate shelter for very vulnerable New Yorkers."
Mr. Bloomberg declined through a spokesman, Jerry Russo, to comment yesterday. 
The ruling the city is appealing applied only to single adults, but lawyers for the homeless have argued successfully that it also should prevent the city from ejecting homeless parents from shelters and putting their children in foster care if they fail to meet the stringent welfare requirements. 
An appeal revives the underlying debate: Should shelter, as a 1981 consent decree maintains, be the ultimate safety net for those so poor, troubled or "socially dysfunctional" that they slip through the cracks of other systems? Or, in an age of welfare reform aimed at ending dependency, should shelter be governed by the same work rules and eligibility conditions as public assistance?
In his February 2000 ruling, Judge Stanley L. Sklar of State Supreme Court in Manhattan wrote: "The simple bureaucratic error which might send an individual out into the street, because he or she was unable to understand or to cooperate with these requirements might be the error which results in that individual's death by exposure, death by violence, or death by sheer neglect. The risk is simply too great to take." 
At the time, the mayor vowed to appeal and predicted a quick reversal of the decision, which he explained as "Justice Sklar clinging to his desire for a city of dependency." Instead, the city seemed to shelve efforts to modify the consent decree, which is the bedrock of the city's right to shelter the truly homeless.
Martin Oesterreich, commissioner of the Department of Homeless Services, recently resigned to become executive director of the Liberal Party after his widely praised efforts to keep services going in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attacks. Thomas Rozinski, acting interim commissioner, referred questions to City Hall, which did not return calls for comment.
City figures show an average nightly total of 29,480 people in the shelters as of mid-November, including 7,566 single adults, up from about 7,000 at this time last year, and 12,404 children in families, an increase of nearly 60 percent from 1998. 
The immediate concern of advocates for the homeless is a shortfall of beds for homeless men this winter. Patrick Markee, a senior policy analyst at the Coalition for the Homeless, said that while cold weather typically drives an additional 500 homeless men to the shelters, the city has planned to add only 233 beds.
"When you deny shelter to a homeless person," he said, "that's a person that ends up on your sidewalk."

HEADLINE: Hitting The Trifecta 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Shortly after Sept. 11, George W. Bush interrupted his inveighing against evildoers to crack a joke. Mr. Bush had repeatedly promised to run an overall budget surplus at least as large as the Social Security surplus, except in the event of recession, war or national emergency. "Lucky me," he remarked to Mitch Daniels, his budget director. "I hit the trifecta."
 Lucky him, indeed. The Enron analogy will soon become a tired cliche, but in this case the parallel is irresistible. Enron management and the administration Enron did so much to put in power applied the same strategy: First, use cooked numbers to justify big giveaways at the top. Then, if things don't work out, let ordinary workers who trusted you pay the price. But Enron executives got caught; Mr. Bush believes that the events of Sept. 11 will let him off the hook. 
 Earlier this year Mr. Bush used projections of vast budget surpluses to push through a huge, 10-year tax cut. Most of that tax cut went to people with incomes of more than $200,000 per year. Now Mr. Daniels tells us that the budget -- not just the budget outside Social Security, but the whole enchilada -- will be in deficit through 2004. Since the administration's phony budget math ("fuzzy" just doesn't cut it at this point) gets phonier the further you go into the future, this means that we have effectively returned to a state of permanent deficit. 
However, with television busy reporting from the caves of Tora Bora, this revelation -- which shows that the tax cut was sold on utterly false premises -- wasn't even considered headline news.
Administration officials insist that the economic slowdown and the war on terror, not the tax cut, are responsible for the red ink. But this is flatly untrue: antiterror spending is a minor factor, and the persistence of projected deficits into the indefinite future tells us that it's not caused by the recession either.
Anyway, they're missing the point. Opponents of the administration's plan always warned that it was foolish to lock in a giant tax cut on the basis of hypothetical surplus projections. They urged, to no avail, that we wait to see the actual budget results. Now their warnings have proved prophetic -- and ordinary Americans will suffer because they were ignored.
The administration now says that the tax cut was necessary to fight the current recession. But nobody is questioning the $40 billion in rebates actually paid out so far, and few would complain about another round of temporary tax cuts for the year ahead. It's the huge further tax cuts that will take place after 2002 -- tax cuts that are now the law of the land -- that are the problem. But we're supposed to accept those future cuts as a fait accompli. Hey, Mr. Bush hit the trifecta.
Meanwhile, the return of budget deficits has real, nasty consequences. Prescription drug insurance is, of course, dead. Bolstering Social Security? Don't be silly: payroll tax receipts are being used neither to acquire assets nor to pay down federal debt; instead, they are subsidizing deficits in the rest of the government. 
And austerity rules, even in areas you might have thought were of the highest priority. Money to rebuild New York? Sorry, no. The government's own experts say we need $3 billion to guard against bioterrorism? Cut the number in half. Tax cuts are more important.
Meanwhile, state and local governments, savaged both by recession and by new security expenses, are firing teachers and slashing services. How about some revenue-sharing from the feds? Never mind.
Whenever they were asked, voters said that the "compassionate" parts of Mr. Bush's campaign promises -- securing Social Security, providing more money for prescription drugs and education -- were more important to them than tax cuts. But they were assured that there was enough money for everything. Those assurances were false -- but the tax cut is sacrosanct, while the rest is expendable. 
Mr. Bush could try to undo some of the damage, by canceling future tax cuts for the top income bracket. Instead, he wants to accelerate those cuts. That's the moral equivalent of the big bonuses Enron gave to executives just days before it went bankrupt.
Horse racing is a zero-sum game; so, it seems, is budget politics. Mr. Bush hit the trifecta; the great majority of Americans lost, big time.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Has His Doubts On Stadiums 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg expressed doubts yesterday about whether the city should agree to help pay for new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets in the current fiscal climate.
 "We'd all like to have stadiums," he said. "The question is, how can we afford it?" 
 Building stadiums has been a dream of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, an avid baseball fan. Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he would do as much as possible to put deals together before leaving office at the end of the month, but acknowledged that the final decision would be Mr. Bloomberg's.
"I won't take away his option, long-term, of making the decision," Mr. Giuliani said. "I don't think it would be right."
In 1993, during his days as a mayor-elect, Mr. Giuliani was outraged when his predecessor, David N. Dinkins, signed off on a plan to build a stadium for his favorite sport, tennis, during the last month of his term. As mayor, Mr. Giuliani has avoided the product of that plan, the Arthur Ashe Stadium at the National Tennis Center in Queens. 
Earlier this fall, Mr. Giuliani pushed to forge baseball stadium deals. Then the World Trade Center was attacked and suddenly he had no time for stadium negotiations. Also, the city's weakening fiscal outlook made a large subsidy for such a structure more difficult to justify.
Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would look at the mayor's proposals for baseball stadiums, but added that he had to study whether taxpayer money should be used to help pay for them. 
"I think everybody understands we have to modernize our facilities," he said at a news conference, separate from one held by Mr. Giuliani. "We have to have the best facilities for sports, for entertainment. We have to have housing, we have to have schools, and there are conflicting needs." 
Mr. Bloomberg added: "I don't yet know the numbers, whether you could justify stadiums at this time. Clearly we're going into very difficult economic times, and we're going to have to make some choices, and it's just too premature for me to give you a definitive answer."

HEADLINE: House Supports Trade Authority Sought by Bush 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
The House today passed legislation that gives the Bush administration a stronger hand to negotiate trade agreements, awarding a hairbreadth wartime victory to President Bush that the same chamber twice denied the Clinton administration.
 Bush administration officials and Republican leaders squeezed their party ranks, relying on several longtime trade-wary lawmakers, one late vote switch, and the House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, who often does not vote, to eke out the 215-214 victory. 
 Just before the vote, Mr. Hastert made an impassioned appeal on the House floor "not to undercut our president at the worst possible time," a plea that several lawmakers later said persuaded them to defy influential interests in their home districts to back Mr. Bush.
The bill was seen as an important test of Mr. Bush's political strength. He lobbied for it right up until the final vote, arguing that he needed it both on substantive grounds and to demonstrate American solidarity to foreign leaders. He passed the test, but just barely. 
If the bill is passed by the Senate, where support for trade is considered firmer, Mr. Bush will have so-called trade promotion authority, allowing him to reach foreign trade agreements that Congress can accept or reject, but not amend.
Administration officials argue that the new authority will help them negotiate global and regional accords to free trade in agriculture, manufactured goods and services. Without that power, they say, other countries might prefer to leave the United States out of trade agreements rather than see them subjected to Congressional tinkering.
"Trade Promotion Authority will give me the flexibility I need to secure the greatest possible trade opportunities for America's farmers, workers, families and consumers," Mr. Bush said after the vote. The president had spent much of the last three days lobbying House members in the White House and on Air Force One.
The United States has not reached any major multinational trade agreements since the North American Free Trade Agreement and the World Trade Organization were created more than seven years ago, when the president had what was then called fast-track authority. 
Congress denied President Bill Clinton enhanced negotiating authority twice in the late 1990's, though Mr. Clinton was able to negotiate commercial agreements with China, Vietnam, Jordan and other nations that Congress ultimately approved.
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States Trade Representative, has worked all year to pressure Republican leaders and some reluctant administration officials to hold the vote, which many predicted would fail. Mr. Zoellick said the added authority would make it far easier to achieve the administration's two top trade priorities: broadening Nafta to include Central and South America and completing global trade talks that were started in Doha, Qatar, last month.
"The president has tried to restore momentum for trade," Mr. Zoellick said, "and this House has now given us the authority to do that."
Democrats overwhelmingly opposed the measure, as many generally pro-trade Democrats voted no. Many complained that the bill failed to mandate that trade agreements set labor and environmental standards as well as tariff and quota levels, a demand that reflects staunch opposition to traditional trade liberalization by unions and some environmental groups.
But Republicans managed to peel off enough Democratic support -- a total of 21 votes -- to make up for defections among their own party members. One factor was an eleventh-hour promise by House leaders to spend at least $20 billion to help the unemployed, many times what they had agreed to devote to post-Sept. 11 welfare assistance as recently as last week.
"It is an abomination that they would be bringing up all of these ideas for worker relief, as inadequate and poor as they are, in order to buy votes," said the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, who led opposition to the bill and helped draft a Democratic alternative, said the Republican victory was Pyrrhic. Republicans, he said, failed to address deep-seated concerns about the direction of trade policy, potentially reducing chances of passing any trade agreements reached under the new authority.
"It's clear that Republican leadership was willing to offer other things that had nothing to do with the bill since they would not offer solid trade policy," Mr. Rangel said.
Multinational companies, including many high-tech firms, strongly supported trade authority, as did most major farm groups. Export-oriented industries expect that new trade agreements will make it easier to sell or produce goods in foreign markets. Some also hope that reciprocal tariff cuts by the United States will reduce import prices and help their bottom line.
A few major business lobbies called this the most important vote of the year. The Information Technology Industry Council, a lobbying group, told lawmakers that it would count their vote on trade authority twice when tallying how supportive they were to the high-tech cause -- potentially costing those who voted against the measure a lucrative source of campaign contributions.
But some Republican and Democratic lawmakers face pockets of intense opposition to trade accords in their home districts. Unionized workers and businesses that have been harmed by imports, including citrus, textile and steel producers, have mobilized against them. Many especially oppose giving the president open-ended authority to negotiate trade deals as he sees fit.
To overcome such resistance among Republicans, Mr. Bush and Republican leaders twisted arms through the final gavel. 
The administration put especially heavy pressure on several North Carolina and South Carolina Republicans. Representatives from those states often vote no on trade agreements because of strong textile interests at home. But their districts are also full of conservatives eager to support the president during a war.
Mr. Bush invited Cass Ballenger of North Carolina to dinner at the White House Wednesday night. Mr. Zoellick spent much of the afternoon talking to Robin Hayes of North Carolina. The two still professed that they would vote against the measure even as the floor debate began this afternoon.
But Mr. Ballenger hovered with party leaders in the well of the House chamber until the final moments, prepared to vote yes if Republicans needed his support to avoid defeat. They did, and he did.
"I felt it was my duty to support the president," Mr. Ballenger said afterward. "But I'll tell you it was not the smartest vote I've made in my life." Mr. Hayes also voted yes to help close the gap.
Even with those late recruits, Republicans were still at least a vote shy. With the time allotted for voting expired and Democrats shouting across the aisle to bring down the gavel, Mr. Hastert and other Republican leaders repeatedly circled Adam Putnam of Florida, urging the 27-year-old freshman to tow the party line. He ultimately voted no.
Asked how he felt afterward about choosing between the demands of citrus farmers and pressure from the president, Mr. Putnam said, "It made me want to throw up."
Ultimately the man who saved the day for Republicans was Jim DeMint of South Carolina. He first voted no, as he often has on trade issues. But with the tally at 214-214, he handed over a green card signaling that he would switch to yes. House leaders promptly declared the vote complete.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Intel and Advanced Micro Raise Financial Forecasts
Intel and Advanced Micro Devices, the dominant competitors in the PC chip market, raised their financial forecasts for the current quarter, saying that their microprocessors were selling better than expected.
 Intel expects sales of $6.7 billion to $6.9 billion for the fourth quarter, up from earlier forecasts of $6.2 billion to $6.8 billion. Advanced Micro expects revenue to increase by 10 percent or more from last quarter, when it had sales of $765 million. Page C3. 

Biotechnology Companies to Merge
Millennium Pharmaceuticals said that it would buy COR Therapeutics, the maker of the heart drug Integrilin, for about $2 billion in stock in one of the largest mergers of two biotechnology companies. The acquisition gives Millennium the first drug it will sell itself. Shares of COR soared $8.46, or 43 percent, to $28.20, but investors pummeled Millennium's stock. It fell almost 17 percent, to $29.56, down $5.89. C3.

Carmakers Oppose New Fuel Rules
Automakers argued against changes to federal fuel economy standards at a Senate hearing, but the Sept. 11 attacks appear to have recast the debate into one about national security as well as environmental concerns. C6.

House Passes Trade Legislation
The House passed legislation that gives the Bush administration a stronger hand to negotiate trade agreements. A1.

Big Board Has Backup Trading Floor
The New York Stock Exchange said that it had a fully equipped alternative trading floor ready to go somewhere in New York City in the event of a disaster like the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. B10.

New Unemployment Claims Drop
The number of workers filing new claims for state unemployment benefits fell for the fifth week in the last six, and factory orders rose 7.1 percent in October. C2.

Bronfman Resigns Vivendi Post
Edgar Bronfman Jr., who turned his family's liquor business into one of the biggest United States entertainment companies, resigned, a year after selling Seagram to Vivendi Universal for $34 billion. Mr. Bronfman, 46, who held the title of executive vice chairman, will leave his post at the end of the first quarter of next year but will remain on the board. C6.

Stocks End Session Narrowly Mixed
Stocks were little changed. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 15.15 points, to 10,099.14. The Nasdaq composite index was up 7.43 points, to 2,054.27. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.25 points, to 1,167.10. C7.

Little Progress Seen on Air in Planes
The airlines and federal regulators have done little to address mounting questions about the air quality in commercial planes, a government study has found. A27.

Merrill and Unilever Settle Dispute
Merrill Lynch and Unilever settled a dispute over the management of $1.4 billion held in a Unilever pension fund, ending a monthlong trial. World Business, Section W.

Entire Crossair Board Steps Down
Crossair's board resigned en masse, making way for a new supervisory board to oversee the restructuring of the airline into a successor to Swissair. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Recent Events Recast Debate on Fuel Economy 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Domestic automakers argued against changes to federal fuel economy standards at a Senate Commerce Committee hearing today, but the events of Sept. 11 appear to have recast the usual debate about automotive fuel economy into one about national security as well as environmental concerns.
 Fuel economy standards "may now play a more significant role in our discussions regarding efforts to decrease U.S. dependence on the importation of foreign oil," said Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican. "I hope next year we can take some action," he added. 
 Senator Byron L. Dorgan, the North Dakota Democrat, said, "We would be ill-advised, given the time and place, to do nothing." 
But what that action will be remains unclear in this initial hearing, which will seek to find a proposal on fuel economy to add to the Senate's energy bill.
Today, most auto industry officials argued against toughening corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE, standards in the short term, and also argued against a bill proposed by Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat, and Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, to close the regulatory disparity between passenger cars and light trucks. 
CAFE standards, first put into effect in the 1970's, currently require each automaker to average 27.5 miles per gallon on the passenger cars they produce and 20.7 m.p.g. on minivans, S.U.V.'s and pickup trucks. These standards have not been significantly altered in more than a decade and automakers are permitted to inflate their mileage figures by as much as 18 percent through various loopholes. 
During the hearing, the top official of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Jeffrey W. Runge, said his agency would begin looking at improving fuel economy again, after several years during which such research was not financed.
Mr. Runge said the agency's determinations would be aided by a recent study by the National Academy of Sciences that said a 40 percent fuel economy improvement could be made within 10 to 15 years, but Mr. Runge added that the earliest changes would probably not come until model year 2005. 
Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, who was chairman of the hearing, said the Senate would probably choose its own course. 
Officials at General Motors argued that short-term fuel economy requirements would impede the company's work on technologies like the fuel cell, a clean, hydrogen- powered system that many believe will eventually supplant the internal combustion engine. 
"CAFE is actually an obstacle to the realization of this vision," said Thomas J. Davis, group vice president of North American development for General Motors. 
"A near-term shift in CAFE pulls engineering resources back to incremental advantages in internal combustion engine systems and to reduction in vehicle power, weight and size," he added. 
But G.M. and other automakers, many of whom have produced prototypes of vehicles powered by fuel cells, have conceded that numerous hurdles remain to retrofitting an industry built around the internal combustion engine. 
"I think it's important for all of us to understand that some of the arguments we're hearing are very similar to arguments we were hearing when this program was first proposed" in the 1970's, said Senator Kerry. 
David Friedman, an engineer and analyst with the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental group, told the senators, "Forty miles per gallon is possible with existing and emerging technologies."
"Increasing fuel economy standards to 40 m.p.g. in the next 10 years would be the most effective, fastest and least expensive path to reducing our future dependence on oil," Mr. Friedman added.
But even the Honda Motor Company, the most independent of the big automakers on environmental issues and one that did not openly oppose CAFE increases, said the 40 m.p.g., 10-year target was not feasible. 
A common argument against further fuel economy improvements, besides their potential expense, is that they make vehicles unsafe by making them lighter, and studies have indeed shown that -- while S.U.V.'s are not necessarily safer than passenger cars because of rollovers -- larger vehicles tend to be safer than smaller vehicles of the same type.
But many current technologies are not weight related, like hybrid electric-gasoline engines already used by Honda's Insight and by the Prius from Toyota Motor, improved engine valve or transmission technology, or even altered tire design. 
"The 1,800-pound Civic of the mid-1970's now weighs 2,600 pounds and gets 40 m.p.g. versus 32 m.p.g.," said Clarence M. Ditlow, director of the Center for Auto Safety. 
It is too early to tell from today's initial hearing whether Sept. 11 or the new National Academy of Sciences report will be swing factors in the debate.
Several of the senators spoke of fuel economy in light of the conflict in the Middle East. Senator Snowe said the country currently imports 10 million barrels a day from abroad, much of it "from one of the most unstable regions in the world." 
"Two weeks ago OPEC was threatening to curb production in order to drive up prices. Fortunately for us, Russia thwarted that," she said.
Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, said, "Mark my words, with everything that is going on in this world with regards to terrorism, sooner or later the terrorist is going to try to sink a tanker in the Strait of Hormuz, and when that occurs, and that free flow of oil out of the Persian Gulf ends, you're going to have another great energy crisis."
Senator McCain said Sept. 11 argued for both new CAFE standards and for drilling in the Alaska National Wildlife Refuge.
"We need to address the issue, but exactly how is not clear," he added.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Selig Defends His Plan of Contraction to Congress

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, told the House Judiciary Committee today why baseball needed to eliminate two teams and why its economic system led to a $519 million loss last season.
 He tried to persuade Congress not to strip Major League Baseball of part of its antitrust exemption as it applies to team movement or contraction, as is being considered in a bill sponsored by Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan. 
 "Sounds like baseball is in a terrible fix," Representative Melvin Watt, Democrat of North Carolina, said.
"We have significant problems," Selig said. 
"It's in that fix despite having that antitrust exemption?" Watt said.
"Our economic problems are obvious," Selig said.
Watt, growing impatient, wondered why the commissioner simply could not personally impose a cure for his 30-team industry.
"What are you all waiting for?" he said, almost plaintively.
That brought Selig to his earnestly repeated mantra: he cannot expand revenue sharing or put a salary cap into effect without the approval of the players' union. So far, he has not been able to achieve approval for either.
The explanation did not satisfy Watt.
"So, you'll eliminate two teams this year, two the next year, two the next year and two the next year?" Watt said. "At what point will it stop?"
A little exasperated, Selig said: "It will take myriad solutions to fix our problems. Contraction is one of them."
While Selig received occasional tongue lashings from committee members -- one threatened the revocation of a cherished tax break if baseball did not fix its problems -- he was also chided several times by Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota.
Ventura, another witness, governs the state that is home to the Twins, who lead the list of presumed contraction candidates. He has vowed not to consider public financing for a new Twins stadium unless baseball fixes its economics.
Selig testified that losing the antitrust exemption would rattle baseball's geographic stability, possibly leading to teams moving without any way for baseball to stop them.
But, Ventura said: "What's the difference between a team leaving in the middle of the night or being contracted and disappear? I don't see how eliminating these teams will change the system." He added, "I bet we'll be taken off the list" -- of contraction candidates -- "if we agree to build a new stadium, and some other teams will make the list."
Underlying some of the committee members' questions to Selig was the doubt that baseball had disclosed all of its financial figures, that there were profitable numbers lurking beneath baseball's public bottom line.
This suspicion was stoked by Conyers, the committee's ranking minority member, who complained that baseball did not deliver all the information he had demanded. The notion of not-so-full disclosure received more urgency when Steve Fehr, a player agent and outside counsel to the Major League Baseball Players Association, testified that baseball lawyers had threatened to seek penalties against the union if it discussed the specifics of baseball's financials.
"The problem is not the numbers on the page, but the numbers off the page," Fehr said. "If we could just give our analysis of baseball's financial information, you'd see a different situation. We're not being allowed to."
He said a confidentiality provision in the collective bargaining agreement prevented the union from discussing specifics. But a baseball official subsequently said that was not true, that the union could discuss anything that has been released publicly. Selig said that baseball did not, however, provide Conyers with information about current collective bargaining.
The severest challenge to Selig's insistence that the numbers fully and accurately reflected baseball's damaged economic model came from Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, who argued that the commissioner was not being cooperative.
"Despite having the antitrust exemption, you won't give us the information that you would sue the union if they would give it to us?" she said.
"You have all the numbers," Selig said.
"Let me remind you," Waters said, "you are under oath."
Selig escaped Waters's next level of anger when her time for questions expired.
All along, Selig insisted that the numbers were accurate.
"The idea that somehow what I have presented today is not an accurate picture of the industry's economics is utter nonsense," he said, adding that the union has had every team's audited statements since 1985, and all the revenue sharing audits done annually since 1997.
Selig was so adamant that the numbers had not been finagled with that he brought Mike DiLecce, the Ernst & Young partner in charge of Major League Baseball's audit, to a post-testimony news conference.
Selig scoffed at the notion that even the elite auditing firms could be wrong, as they were in Enron's financial collapse.
"I'm responsible for a lot," he told reporters, "but don't make me responsible for Enron. I have no idea what happened here. But I know our bankers don't doubt our numbers."

HEADLINE: Using Battle of Terrorism for Victory on Trade 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
President Bush won a major victory on trade in the House of Representatives today by updating a time-honored argument: Wartime is no time to undercut the president. This is especially true now, Mr. Bush and his allies argued, when the world is watching for any sign that an embattled America is pulling up its drawbridges.
 Like the outcome of the presidential race that ended a year ago next week, his margin of victory could not have been narrower. He won streamlined trade negotiating authority by only one vote, 215 to 214. Even getting that required his Republican allies on the floor of the House to twist arms after the official clock had run out. 
 But that single vote was enough to win a political battle that President Bill Clinton, fighting members of his own party, had twice lost. 
Perhaps more important, Mr. Bush has finally broken a political deadlock that has afflicted Washington for seven years, a deadlock over which branch of government -- the executive or legislative -- should have the greatest control over how the United States negotiates the rules of globalization. 
"This is one of those votes that is partly about substance, but also about power and perceptions of power," said Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute, and a veteran of the trade wars that have polarized Democrats and Republicans for the past two decades. "There was a perception that if the vote went against the president, he would be undercut, and we would be seen as withdrawing from the world. I don't think that was true but the perception was there."
Mr. Bush won for several reasons.
The first is that his argument about trade as a weapon against terrorism, while a stretch, actually worked. His trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, made the case that the war against terrorism hinges on building coalitions, and that coalitions in the modern world are built on trade first and ideology second. While it pains Mr. Bush's team to admit it, this is an echo of the argument Mr. Clinton made time and again. 
"The difference is that the war made it clear that we really do need coalitions," a senior White House official said. "Every argument has its context, and the context of this one was a war in which we clearly need the help of developing nations around the world."
Mr. Bush's use of the patriotism card bred more than a little resentment among Democrats. Since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, they have been in disarray about how to oppose the president on substantive issues without seeming out of tune with the bipartisan chorus of the times.
It was a testament to the emotional resonance of the trade issue that 189 Democrats voted against the president, even under the circumstances. The opponents and their allies in the labor and environmental movements have long argued that free trade accords simply encourage American companies to open factories in developing nations with little regard for the environment or minimum labor standards. 
(The 21 Democrats who voted for the bill were almost all members of a small coalition of Democrats who have tried, largely unsuccessfully, to cure the party's traditional allergy to free trade agreements.)
Still, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the New York Democrat, tried at the last moment to reach a compromise with the White House about how to deal with those labor and environmental issues. He took to the floor to protest the White House's effort to paint opponents of the bill as unpatriotic. 
"We don't believe that under our government, and the democratic way that we expect to legislate," Mr. Rangel said, "that what we are doing is undercutting the president of the United States." 
Representative Sander M. Levin, a Michigan Democrat, agreed, saying, "This debate is about trade, not about terrorism."
But the second reason that the Democrats lost is that they have yet to figure out a way to turn their fears of trade into an effective legislative strategy at home, or an effective foreign policy abroad.
The reality of the post-cold war era is that trade agreements have become the basic treaties negotiated among nations. That is why Mr. Bush is so eager to use his new authority to negotiate a Free Trade Area of the Americas: Like Mr. Clinton, he sees it as a way to cement the links among democracies, weak and strong. 
And so when individual agreements come up for a vote, they almost always pass because the strategic cost of defeating them is simply too high.
The evidence is overwhelming. Two years ago, Congress voted by a large margin to let China into the World Trade Organization, even though that meant ending the annual review of its human rights record. 
Just in the past 18 months, Congress has also approved trade accords with Vietnam, an old enemy that is gradually reintegrating with the West, and with Jordan, a rare economic success story in the Middle East. And it used a trade agreement with African nations -- even an accord riddled with protections for American industry -- to remake American relations with an entire continent.
"It was always the strategic arguments that made the difference in the end," Charlene Barshefsky, Mr. Zoellick's predecessor as trade representative, argued recently. "They are the only way to trump the other concerns."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE APPROPRIATIONS; 
Republicans in Senate Win Round on Curbing Spending

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Republicans won two early skirmishes tonight in their effort to block $7.5 billion in additional spending for domestic security and $7.5 billion in aid to New York, measures that provoked a veto threat from President Bush.
 By identical 50-to-48 votes, Democrats mustered majorities to designate those needs as "emergencies." But under Senate rules, they needed 60 votes. Had they won, they would have protected not merely the items themselves, but the entire military spending bill from a point of order that would kill it. 
 It was unclear how the issues would be resolved. Republicans planned to offer on Friday an amendment that would strip the extra $15 billion from the $352.6 billion measure. But the Democratic majority that held firm tonight, losing only Senator Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, may also stick together on Friday. 
That result would leave the Republicans with the unpalatable alternative of making the point of order that would kill the whole Senate bill, a step that would conflict with their argument today that a military spending bill, including a 5 percent pay raise, was needed right away. It is not obvious whether they would be willing to go that far.
Under an early version of the amendment, which was withdrawn, New York would lose not only the $7.5 billion but also $2 billion elsewhere in the bill. Under the bill now, New York would get $17 billion, enough after $3 billion spent so far to meet the promise of $20 billion Congress and Mr. Bush made earlier. 
Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the senior Republican on the Appropriations Committee, said of both provisions, "There is no need for the money now." And he argued that it would look bad for the Senate to challenge the president when Mr. Bush had made his views clear. 
But Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said, "There is no time to wait when it comes to the homeland defense investments that are so important to us as we look at restoring confidence, restoring safety, restoring the kind of opportunities that we need in this country." He also contended that the spending would boost the economy. 
On the New York money, Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, said it was "an inexplicably absurd moment" for the Senate to debate whether what happened in his state was an emergency. 
New York's other senator, Hillary Rodham Clinton, said the state was rebuilding but added: "We can't do it without America's help. When New York City was attacked, America was attacked." 
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant minority leader, replied that the money would come eventually. "I think everyone in the Senate wants to help New York," he said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Clouds Loom for New York, But Bloomberg Stays Sunny

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
The ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria, where the Citizens Union was holding its holiday dinner the other night, was rustling with the concerns heard all around New York these days. The city's fiscal situation seemed as perilous as anyone could remember. Washington was resisting pleas for help. New York's government was in transition, and the region was on high terrorist alert again.
 Everyone in the room, shoulder to shoulder with veterans of government service, seemed apprehensive. 
 Everyone, that is, except Michael R. Bloomberg. 
"The best is yet to come!" he declared in a peppy and sunny speech that made it sound as if happy days were already here again. Mr. Bloomberg warned his audience against pessimism -- "There is always a danger of looking at the downside, of looking at the part of the glass that is not full" -- and made just one fleeting mention of the problems that will be piled on his new desk on Jan. 1.
As a rule, chief executives taking office during bad times begin their tenure by announcing just how bad they have found things. It is a tactic intended to lay the blame on the predecessor, insulate themselves from future damage and prepare constituents for unpopular decisions that, they hope, will be forgotten or forgiven before the next election.
"The days of wine and roses are over," Gov. Hugh L. Carey said in his first State of the State speech, in the midst of the state's 1975 fiscal crisis. George W. Bush took office suggesting that the seeds of a recession had been planted by Bill Clinton. 
Mr. Bloomberg has yet to do anything like that -- in fact, he has struck pretty much the opposite tone -- and it has become perhaps the most striking aspect of the style of this largely unknown man who will be New York's next mayor.
Indeed, despite considerable evidence that there is good reason to be worried and that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is leaving behind more than a few budgetary and management headaches, Mr. Bloomberg has been New York's cheerleader, pitting himself against a cast of Cassandras and sounding more optimistic than Mr. Giuliani himself. (And certainly more than his very gloomy fellow Republican in Albany, Gov. George E. Pataki.)
Democrats and Republicans alike, accustomed to the behavior of people who, unlike Mr. Bloomberg, have made a career in politics, have been intrigued by the mayor-elect's approach and have been waiting for him to begin preparing New Yorkers for what most fiscal experts believe will be a very difficult patch of years.
"What he's going through he's never gone through before," said William Eimicke, a political science professor at Columbia University. "He hasn't been in the game."
Professor Eimicke, who worked for Mr. Carey when he was governor, described himself as both surprised and charmed by Mr. Bloomberg's reaction to the fiscal problems he faces. E. J. McMahon, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative group, praised Mr. Bloomberg's approach, saying it was important for someone new to the job to display confidence in his ability to manage New York through these problems. 
Still, Mr. Bloomberg's unorthodox response is not without risks, both to his own political reputation and to his ability to manage the city in the years ahead. If he proves to be wrong in his measure of the severity of New York's difficulties, he may very well find himself absorbing the bulk of the blame for the kind of calamitous problems that many fiscal experts think his city is about to endure.
Mr. Bloomberg, after warning against alarmism now, may find it difficult to persuade New Yorkers to endure the kind of sacrifices that seem likely in the years ahead. In particular, his approach could make it much tougher for him to push the city's unions to accept the low- or no-raise contracts that fiscal experts say New York will need to negotiate.
"You run the risk of people not taking seriously the nature of the economic shortfall that's ahead," said Richard Schraeder, a longtime Democratic consultant who managed the mayoral campaign of Mr. Bloomberg's opponent, Mark Green. "That's the last thing that you want to do."
To a certain extent, Mr. Bloomberg's deportment suggests the constraints he must feel given the central role Mr. Giuliani played in getting Mr. Bloomberg where he is today. While Mr. Bush had no trouble assailing Mr. Clinton last year, it would arguably not be good form for Mr. Bloomberg to begin assailing the popular departing mayor who endorsed his candidacy, at least not quite this soon. "How would it look if he turned around and started to blame him for this situation?" said Hank Morris, a Democratic consultant. "It would seem impolite."
Mr. Bloomberg's demeanor is also very much in keeping with his fundamentally confident nature, evident to anyone familiar with his years at Bloomberg L.P. or who has read his autobiography. Mr. Bloomberg is not the kind of person who would want to begin his administration as the dark cloud to Mr. Giuliani's sun, or to do anything further to alarm New Yorkers who already are, understandably, on edge.
Mr. Bloomberg's political consultant, David Garth, who was at Mr. Carey's side in 1975, said he had not encountered a politician quite like Mr. Bloomberg. "To go through a campaign like this, when you're starting way behind, to come through that, it takes a hell of a lot of optimism," said Mr. Garth, who himself has a fairly dark view of the city's immediate future.
Some advisers say Mr. Bloomberg is simply expressing his genuine view of the city's fiscal situation, speaking more like the businessman he was than the politician he is. He is not alone in doing that. Mr. McMahon, for one, said he did not believe that the situation facing New York City was as bad as it was 25 years ago, noting, as Mr. Bloomberg has, the fundamentally strong nature of the city's economy before the Sept. 11 attack.
Some of Mr. Bloomberg's advisers, in discussing the candidate's measured reaction, argued that the attack on the World Trade Center and the extensive attention paid to the financial problems it has caused the city might spare Mr. Bloomberg from the obligation of delivering too much bad news to New Yorkers. 
In truth, these days Mr. Bloomberg is sounding quite a bit different than he did on the campaign trail. Before the attack, he presented a distressed view of New York's economy and argued that his business background made him particularly qualified to lead New York through an economic downturn. "It is going to be hard times and somebody has to manage it and somebody has to make decisions," he said in an interview on July 31.
After the attack, he switched his appeal in a significant way, saying that his experience in private enterprise qualified him to help lead New York in rebuilding its downtown.
Given that switch, there are a number of politicians who think that Mr. Bloomberg will eventually shift his tone, perhaps with his inaugural speech, in a way that would recollect Mr. Carey, who endorsed Mr. Bloomberg's candidacy. "What Carey did was he prepared the public for tough days ahead, and he did it in a forthright matter," said Raymond B. Harding, the head of New York's Liberal Party who at the time served as a senior adviser to the Democratic governor.
But Mr. Bloomberg's advisers said that as of now, there are no plans for such a speech. 
Professor Eimicke, one of a number of people who are watching with fascination the education and evolution of this new arrival to New York government, said he was increasingly confident that Mr. Bloomberg would stay this course, even if it hurt him politically in the long run. "Part of the reason he has succeeded his whole life," Professor Eimicke said, "is that he has a lot of confidence."
