HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DOMESTIC FRONT; 
Ridge Promises Security Funds For States in Next U.S. Budget

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
A day after the nation's governors asked Congress for an immediate $3 billion to fight terrorism, Tom Ridge, director of homeland security, promised that President Bush's budget proposal next year would include "substantial down payments" to the states for security.
 Mr. Ridge spoke as questions of how much domestic security should cost after Sept. 11 have proliferated on Capitol Hill and as states, facing recession and budget shortfalls, are grappling with how to pay for new responsibilities to help guard borders, bridges, dams and nuclear power plants. 
 Mr. Ridge, in appearances before news executives and state legislators, assured local officials that they would be given federal help. But he did not indicate how much money the president would propose and he put the states on notice that they would have to share the costs.
"We can't do it all," he said. "The responsibilities and costs from area to area within homeland security have to be shared in this national system. But the federal government is prepared to step up and make some substantial down payments in the budgets ahead."
Mr. Ridge also set down a series of challenges to the states to adjust to the new concerns raised by terrorism. He called on them to examine whether they were running enough response drills and whether police officers and firefighters could communicate across localities. He suggested that the states upgrade computer security and asked whether they had cataloged the vulnerability of critical sites.
He spoke as officials at every level are beginning to grapple with what a long-term commitment to increasing security will mean and what it will cost. In a sign of the mood, the program for the meeting of the National Conference of State Legislatures here was crammed with panels on topics like cyberterrorism, bioterrorism in the Capitol, disaster coordination and tourism recovery.
"Everybody's feeling their way," said Andrew Fleischmann, a Democratic state representative from Connecticut. "Everybody wants to do things that are helpful and figure out the constructive response. But nobody wants to do things that are unnecessary or redundant."
On Wednesday, the National Governors Association released a preliminary survey of domestic security costs, estimating that they would run the states $4 billion in the first year.
With states across the nation facing budget shortfalls, state lawmakers were also looking for suggestions that federal assistance would be forthcoming, asking for additional money for the Coast Guard and public health.
"Every state will have to be relying on federal funding," Dave Kleis, a Republican in the Minnesota Senate, said in an interview after Mr. Ridge had spoken. "It's essential."
Mr. Kleis said Minnesota had been particularly hard hit because it is a hub for Northwest Airlines, which is suffering a sharp drop in traffic.
Mr. Ridge did not include specific sums but said he was seeking more money in the budget proposal to help police forces and fire departments, to defend against bioterrorism and to share information on threats. He said he planned to produce a multiyear plan for domestic security.
"We know," Mr. Ridge told the lawmakers, "you will need financial support from the federal government and we plan to address that."

HEADLINE: A New Boom: Somewhere Over the Rainbow?; 
The Economic Evidence Is So Dismal, Yet the Forecasts Are So Hopeful

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The economy sinks, but the nation's forecasters grow more optimistic. A vibrant upturn is just around the corner, they insist, certain to arrive by spring. In the world of forecasting, the upturn has been just around the corner for months.
 Forecasts are often wrong. The economy has too many complicated moving parts, and despite all the sophisticated forecasting techniques, too little is known about how the parts interact. Any forecaster acknowledges as much. Yet the great majority persist in their optimism, magnifying the positive data and minimizing the layoffs, the rising unemployment rate, the outright refusal of business to invest, the numbing indebtedness of millions of Americans. 
 Listen, for a moment, to the optimism of John Lipsky, chief economist at J. P. Morgan Chase, and one of America's most prominent forecasters. "Household incomes are growing more slowly, and that is a powerful negative," he said. "But October retail sales were strong, and that made it almost certain that consumption will accelerate in the fourth quarter." 
A leap of faith is required for such optimism, and such leaps of faith have been commonplace since the early 1970's, far outweighing pessimism -- even after the Labor Department's announcement yesterday that 800,000 jobs had disappeared in October and November, the most for a two-month period in 27 years. "These job losses are a consequence of prior weakness, not a reason for gloom looking forward," said Ian Shepherdson, chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics, a Wall Street forecasting operation.
For most of the past decade, a booming economy justified the optimism. So did good salesmanship. Many of the forecasters work for Wall Street investment houses, and their sunny readings of the daily economic data encouraged investors, helping to make stock prices surge. But in fact the optimism has much deeper roots, stretching back generations to theories and beliefs that originated in the earliest days of modern economics, in the 18th century. 
These theories and beliefs have outlasted the various doomsday pronouncements about capitalism's prospects. The fall of Communism and the decades of prosperity since World War II have only reinforced the faith in a free market system's in-born tendency to repair itself. The Depression, in this view, was a fluke, an accident, a result of mistakes.
And now, optimistic forecasting is swamping a minority view that the current recession, more than any of the nine others since 1945, could endure, dooming the economy to contraction or very sluggish growth for months or years. The recession is already eight months old, half the age of the longest downturns since the war. Japan's bleak experience -- a decade of virtually no economic growth -- suggests to some people that America, too, is not immune.
But so far the optimism entrenched in mainstream economics guides the forecasts, and they are persistently upbeat. "The consensus view sounds plausible to me; I have even been trying to get some funds back into the stock market," said Deirdre McCloskey, an economic historian at the University of Illinois in Chicago. "Still, I do not believe that economists understand the business cycle. I say to my mom, 'Don't worry, there will not be another Depression,' and she says, 'Why not?' And I say I don't really know why not."
Ms. McCloskey's faith -- and the concensus forecast -- have their origins in the writings of Jean-Baptiste Say, a French economist in the early 1800's, who gained fame as a popularizer of Adam Smith's "Wealth of Nations," capitalism's seminal treatise, published in 1776. A "law of markets" that bears Say's name is still the theme song for those who count on the economy to repair itself. Say himself never wrote or uttered or fully subscribed to what came to be known as Say's law, which is expressed in just five words: "Supply creates its own demand."
That is being tested in the current recession. Too much supply, particularly in the high-tech sector, brought the economy down. (The stock market sell-off also helped.) Companies found themselves producing more goods and services than consumers demanded. So they cut way back on spending for the tools of production -- computers, machinery, factories, trucks, office space. And the downturn commenced.
Something similar happened in the Depression, and Say's law failed to kick in. But overcapacity was much greater in the 1930's, economists today contend. This time the excess is less and is already disappearing. Computers are becoming obsolete, vehicles are wearing out, older factories are being closed. Soon corporate America will be motivated to step up investment.
The cost savings from purchasing modern equipment will play a role in motivating investment, goes the optimist's scenario. So will the potential return from replacing old equipment with newer, more efficient models. And so will expectations. Over the decades, economic growth has averaged 2 percent a year or so. Corporate executives know that if they hold back too long on investment and expansion, they run the risk of falling behind competitors. So they take a chance and expand, and as they do, the companies that make the tools of production hire more workers, who spend their wages. Supply, in sum, creates its own demand. As employment and spending rise, companies purchase more tools to expand production, and the recovery is under way. In this way of thinking, government's role is to stay clear of the private sector.
"The problem comes if you get into a situation where expectations reverse," said David Collander, an economist at Middlebury College. "If companies do not believe the demand will be there, then you have to convince them it will be. That is what I believe the forecasters are doing now, trying to make everyone comfortable that demand will be there. This is a case where the forecasters are actually influencing the economy. If they are wrong too often and people start forming their views outside the normal corridor, that is when you get a serious recession."
Counting on Say's Law, the forecasters make their leap of faith. Citing the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate cuts, plunging fuel prices, a still healthy housing market, the recent spike in the stock market, adequate retail sales, and the promise of fiscal stimulus, the forecasters speak with increasing optimism of an upturn soon.
"As businesses begin to rebuild their inventories and increase investment," Mr. Lipsky said, "it is natural that they will increase employment, and that will increase spending and away we go."
Say's Law failed in the Depression. As opposed to the Saysians who saw the Depression as an anomaly, some maverick thinkers began to argue that economists had failed to consider that supply was not a sufficient source of demand. Neither business nor the consumer would spend, and the economy, instead of moving up toward full employment, settled in at a high level of unemployment and pessimism. 
John Maynard Keynes, the British economist, explained the new dynamic, and the importance of demand rather than supply in restarting the economy. Perhaps more than anyone else, Keynes popularized Say's Law, mostly as a foil for his own theories about the role of government in supplementing demand to get business investment going again.
After the war, consumer demand came back with a roar and forecasters became accustomed to Americans who never sat on their money, as so many Japanese are doing today. Supply and demand fed on each other, and a purer Say's Law gave way to an amended "compromise version, a mongrel Say's Law," as Laurence Ball, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, put it.
Keynesian economics, meanwhile, faded into the background, except for a hard core who argue today that in this recession -- after years of debt accumulation and inadequate incomes -- demand is in danger of failing again, pulling supply down with it. "In 1945, American households were rich beyond any previous historical memory; they had this enormous stock of government savings bonds," said James K. Galbraith, an economist at the University of Texas at Austin. "Now their wealth is eroding, and their debt position is incomparably worse."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Crisis Deepens In Argentina; Aid Is Sought

 BODY:
The Argentine government scrambled yesterday to keep its economic crisis from spinning out of control as pressure mounted on its public finances, its securities markets, its banking system and its currency, now pegged to the American dollar. 
 Domingo Cavallo, the government minister brought in by President Fernando de la Rua to manage the economic crisis, flew to Washington to try to persuade the International Monetary Fund to release $1.3 billion in cash that the country desperately needs to stave off default on its $132 billion in debts. 
 The fund withheld the cash earlier this week, saying that Argentina -- plagued by a severe recession, weak tax revenues and spending that has proved to be stubbornly hard to cut -- had failed to meet its own goals for balancing its national budget. 
At a news conference last night, Mr. Cavallo said his talks with the I.M.F. would continue over the weekend, according to the Reuters news agency.
Other multilateral aid to Argentina, including about $1.1 billion in loans from the World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank, has also been frozen. Release of those funds depends on the outcome of Mr. Cavallo's talks with the I.M.F., officials said.
Ordinary Argentines have grown increasingly nervous about the mounting crisis in recent days, not least because of rules imposed earlier this week that prevent bank depositors from withdrawing more than $250 a week in cash, though they remain free to spend money using checks and credit cards.
Long lines appeared again at banks, and tellers working in a large bank in downtown Buenos Aires told Reuters that every second customer was asking to convert pesos to dollars.
The exchange rate is officially pegged at one to one, but many people fear that the peg will be abandoned and the peso devalued; local money changers were asking for 1.12 pesos for each dollar on Friday, Reuters reported.
Mr. Cavallo has repeatedly insisted that the peg will stay, and has trumpeted aspects of his economic plans that would make the consequences of a devaluation painful for the country as signs of his resolve. More likely, analysts said, would be a move to scrap the peso entirely and use dollars exclusively as Argentina's currency. 
The Argentine stock market has rallied sharply in recent days. The Merval index rose more than 25 percent this week, though it gained less than 1 percent yesterday.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Rate Jumped Last Month On Surge of Layoffs 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
A vast wave of job cuts in November sent the unemployment rate up sharply, to 5.7 percent from 5.4 percent the previous month, the government reported yesterday, suggesting that the current recession will be more painful than many forecasters had expected.
 Companies eliminated more than 300,000 jobs in November and have cut nearly a million jobs in the last three months, the fastest pace of reductions in more than 20 years. The layoffs have come in an unusually wide array of businesses -- from the normally stable service sector to typically volatile manufacturing industries -- as profits have plunged across corporate America. 
 The report, depicting a nation in which millions of families are struggling more than they have in nearly a decade, added more heat to the debate in Washington between Republicans and Democrats over competing economic stimulus packages. And despite the bleaker outlook, negotiations broke off yesterday in Congress in partisan rancor. Page B6. 
"This is another miserable employment report," Brian M. Jones, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, said. "There's really nothing good you can say about it."
Since October of last year, the unemployment rate, which is adjusted to take account of normal seasonal variations, has risen from 3.9 percent, a 30-year low, to its highest point now in more than six years.
"Today's unemployment numbers are troubling, and they underscore that we must act to ensure America's economic security," President Bush said in a statement released by the White House. Mr. Bush said the Senate should quickly pass a bill consisting mostly of tax cuts for businesses and well-off Americans, which Republicans say will increase investment and lift the economy. 
Democrats want to increase benefits for jobless workers more than Republicans do, saying those people need help and they would quickly spend any money they received.
"People who have lost their jobs are starting to lose hope," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader.
The dismal jobs numbers also made another Federal Reserve cut in interest rates a near-certainty when the Fed's policy-making group meets on Tuesday, analysts predicted. Since January, the Fed has reduced its crucial short-term interest rate, which affects a wide variety of credit card, small-business and home equity loans, a total of 10 times, lowering it from 6.5 percent to 2 percent.
Although the cuts have helped prop up consumer spending, they have yet to revive the economy, as businesses continue to reduce their investment after having optimistically binged on new computers, machinery and factory equipment in the late 1990's.
Compared with the official 5.7 percent rate, a broader measure of joblessness, which includes people who are not actively looking for work, rose to 6.2 percent last month, up from 4.5 percent a year ago, the Labor Department said.
The deteriorating labor market caused a surge last month in the number of people who had lost their jobs months ago and were still unable to find new work. More than 1.1 million people reported being unemployed for at least 27 weeks in November, up from 890,000 in October. The average length of unemployment rose to 14.5 weeks, from 13 weeks.
Forecasters have long emphasized that job cuts are more a reflection of where an economy has been than of where it is going. And yesterday -- when a separate survey by the University of Michigan showed a small rise in consumer confidence last month, adding to a spate of surprisingly good economic news in the last week -- bond yields moved up sharply, suggesting that many investors believe that a recovery will arrive early next year.
Reflecting the current level of uncertainty, stock prices fell yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 10,049.46, down 49.68 points.
Even if a recovery is near, however, job losses are likely to continue rising in the coming months, economists said. Companies typically wait to begin adding to their payrolls until they are confident that their revenues will begin growing again.
Indeed, analysts expect the unemployment rate to continue to move higher and remain around 6 percent for much of next year.
"Many forecasters are talking about a rebound in March," said Elaine L. Chao, the labor secretary, who acknowledged that yesterday's numbers were disappointing. "But I don't think we should necessarily expect to see an immediate increase in employment. It takes time for the economy to gear up."
For now, the economy is a long way from gearing up. In October, an index of nationwide help-wanted advertising fell sharply, to its lowest point since 1982, the Conference Board, a research group in New York, said last week.
Over all, the economy lost 331,000 jobs in November, according to the seasonally adjusted data released by the Labor Department, which also pushed up its estimate of job losses in October to 468,000, making that the worst month since 1974.
Manufacturers have suffered the most in the current recession, largely because companies have drastically cut their capital spending. The jobs report offered no evidence that the sector had reached a turning point. Since the summer of 2000, manufacturers have eliminated 1.4 million jobs, or more than one of 20 in the sector. Manufacturing lost 163,000 jobs in November, the most of any month during its 16-month decline.
"The recession isn't over," said Richard D. Rippe, the chief economist for Prudential Securities. "The hopes of the last few weeks have had a splash of cold water thrown on them."
Still, Mr. Rippe, like most Wall Street forecasters, said he expected that low interest rates and falling energy prices, together with a stimulus bill that he continues to expect from Washington, will get the economy growing again early next year.
In recent months, and especially since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the economic pain has spread well beyond heavy industry. Airlines and department stores both cut jobs last month. Temporary-employment agencies continued their huge cutbacks, reducing employment by 87,000, to 2.9 million -- 17 percent below its level early last year.
The broad nature of the recession has also caused joblessness to rise among even highly educated, well-paid workers. Last month, the jobless rate rose across the educational spectrum, although the 8.1 percent rate for people without high school diplomas remains well above the 3.1 percent rate for college graduates.
Among the few expanding industries, hospital, doctors' offices and health care companies added 32,000 jobs. Car dealers, helped by zero-percent financing deals offered on many models, increased employment by 6,000. Mortgage companies added 7,000 new workers to help them handle the demand for refinancings caused by lower mortgage rates.
Despite the recession, the unemployment rate remains lower than it was for much of the 1980's and early 90's. This relative tightness of the labor market allowed hourly wages for nonsupervisory workers to continue rising last month at an annual rate of more than 3 percent.

HEADLINE: Housing Gains In Poor Areas, Study Shows 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
A new study shows that people in the 10 poorest neighborhoods in New York City gained economic ground even faster, by some measures, than those in the city's wealthiest neighborhoods in the second half of the 1990's.
 Of course, the economic gap remains large. But the study found, for example, that average prices for single-family private homes in the 10 poorest neighborhoods increased by a startling 36.5 percent from 1995 through 1999, while average prices for single-family private homes in the 10 wealthiest areas of the five boroughs increased by 9.2 percent in the same period. 
 And in one of the poor neighborhoods, East New York, Brooklyn, the percentage price increase was even higher, 46.9 percent, according to the report, "State of New York City's Housing and Neighborhoods 2001," compiled by two professors at the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law. 
Coming at a critical time of economic tremors caused by the recession, the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 and the ensuing war, "this is good news," said Rae Rosen, the senior regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
"It sounds like documentation of the general sense we've had that the rising tide of the late 90's lifted most boats," Ms. Rosen said. "We knew the proportion of people in the city's labor force had risen. Driving down those streets, we could see the improvement. We had anecdotal impressions. But now there's documentation."
The survey backs up some anecdotal and other evidence, including a study early this year by the Columbia University School of Social Work that found that people in poor parts of the city felt more satisfied with their neighborhoods than previously and that things were generally going well.
To be sure, these neighborhoods are still poor, and the dollar values of the homes in these poor neighborhoods are still not high by New York standards. And advocates for the poor say that there is still not enough housing for the poor in the city.
Further, Ron Shiffman, director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development and a former member of the City Planning Commission, expressed concern that the improvements came at a cost, "poor people being pushed out."
The report, which has 345 pages, compiles and analyzes data from 14 city and federal sources, including the 2000 Census and the 1999 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, which was released in February 2000. The new report was prepared by Michael Schill and Glynis Daniels, the director and associate director, respectively, of the N.Y.U. real estate and urban policy center.
Among other things, the study found that property values were higher, there was more money for mortgages, housing conditions were better, more people were able to pay their property taxes on time and there were fewer families paying more than half their incomes for rent. 
In the report, the authors caution that the overall findings for a particular indicator cannot necessarily be applied to every neighborhood, because the sample for a particular neighborhood may be small. Co-op and condominium sales are also not factored into the calculations of single-family sales prices.
In addition, a double-digit percentage increase in housing value may indeed be large, but the actual dollar increase may be small. Nevertheless, the trends in all the categories are up and that is good news for those seeking signs of general economic improvement in poor areas of New York City. The report is available on the Internet at www.law.nyu.edu/realestatecenter.
The primary indication of improved conditions in the poorest neighborhoods during the 1990's was, of course, increased income. Professor Daniels pointed out, for example, that Mott Haven in the South Bronx, "was the poorest sub-borough area in the city in 1996, with a median household income of $8,644." That figure, like all income figures in the report, was based on the 1996 Housing and Vacancy Survey, and it is those income figures that were used to determine the poorest and wealthiest neighborhoods.
But by 1999, according to the next triennial Housing and Vacancy Survey, Professor Daniels continued, the median income in Mott Haven had increased to $12,000, "a jump of 39 percent, compared to an 11.5 percent increase for the whole city," in which the median income rose to $33,000 from $29,600. United States Census figures on 2000 income have not been released, except in an experimental form that raised a multitude of questions. 
In East New York, the median income had been $14,400 in 1996, but increased by 67.7 percent, to $24,154, in 1999.
Frank Anelante Jr. has watched these neighborhoods. Mr. Anelante is president of Lemle & Wolff, a development and management company for 275 buildings with about 6,000 apartments in communities like Harlem, Inwood and Washington Heights, in Manhattan, and Morrisania, East Tremont, Highbridge and Fordham in the Bronx. 
"Vacant shells have been completely renovated," he said. "You walk down the street and see occupied buildings, some with gardens, and the neighborhood becomes alive. Some buildings that had stores which were shuttered for years have been rented to local entrepreneurs."
There were other ripple effects. For example, Professor Daniels said the percentage of tenant households in Mott Haven that paid more than half their income for rent declined from 38.4 percent in 1996 to 26.4 percent in 1999. And in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where 38.8 percent of households had been paying more than half their income for rent in 1996, the figure dropped to 27 percent in 1999. For the entire city during the same period, there was only a slight drop, to 24.3 percent from 25.3 percent.
Professor Schill cited the "improved economic viability of private housing in the poorest neighborhoods," saying that "part of the reason is that they had so much farther to go. Their upside potential was tremendous because they entered the decade with depressed values, and because the city was actively investing in the communities."
For example, from 1995 through 1999, sales prices for buildings in Mott Haven with five or more units -- the predominant housing type in a community that remains the city's poorest -- rose by an average of 141 percent, while in central Harlem they rose 123 percent. In Chelsea and Greenwich Village, Professor Daniels said, overall prices increased -- though certainly from a much higher base -- by 67.7 percent and 64 percent, respectively.
From 1996 through 1999, the city's poorest communities generally had bigger percentage increases in the flow of mortgage money than did the wealthiest areas. In fact, 9 of the 10 poorest areas attracted more mortgage money in 1999 than they had in 1996. 
The biggest increase occurred in central Harlem, where the total dollar amount of home-purchase loans grew 637 percent, to $47.9 million in 1999 from $6.5 million in 1996.
Rosario Salazar, 34, is worried. The whir of a sewing machine punctuates Ms. Salazar's sentences as she sits in the compact kitchen of her two-bedroom apartment (one bedroom partitioned for the children) in Bedford-Stuyvesant. "We used to pay $450 for rent," she said. "Now it's $1,000."
Ms. Salazar, a seamstress, was laid off from her job at a purse and wallet factory on Sept. 29. She has lived with her husband, Rigoberto, 31, a textile factory foreman, and their three children -- Maria, 13, Margarita, 11, and Bonifacio, 5 -- in the three-story, three-unit, wood-frame row house with beige siding on Kent Avenue for 12 years.
"The neighborhood is definitely changing," Ms. Salazar said, "a lot of houses being fixed, families moving in. I don't think there's going to be anything anywhere near here that we'll be able to afford. Twelve years here, and then to have to move to another neighborhood that is in worse shape and is dangerous, that scares me."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
Hope Against Hope

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
The Hamas suicide bombings in Jerusalem last weekend were terrorism at its bloody worst, killing 25 innocent civilians. A military response by Israel was inevitable, and it came: air attacks on Palestinian police stations and on the headquarters of Yasir Arafat, pressuring him to arrest terrorists.
 From Israel's point of view, there is just one problem with that response: Force alone will not stop terrorist attacks. And from America's viewpoint, it will not keep the Israeli-Palestinian conflict from becoming ever more desperate -- and dangerous to our interests. 
 Prime Minister Ariel Sharon used military force as the answer to terrorism just two months ago, when he sent tanks and troops into Palestinian territory to invest the major West Bank cities. The operation supposedly broke the back of terrorism. But it did not.
Then, on Nov. 23, Mr. Sharon sent Israeli aircraft to kill Mahmoud Abu Hanoud, a senior leader of Hamas. He was a principal planner of terrorist attacks, it was said, and removing him would safeguard Israel. To the contrary, as every knowledgeable person understood, Hamas retaliation was certain. It came last weekend.
Reliance on force to solve this conflict is futile and tragic on both sides. The Palestinians' second intifada has been one of the most self-defeating strategies in memory, bringing death and misery to Palestinians and no political gain.
The only way to security for Israel and a humane life for Palestinians in their own land is political. No matter where the fault for past negotiating failures lies, there is no other path.
Think about Mr. Sharon's implied threat to force Mr. Arafat out of the Palestinian leadership -- perhaps to destroy him physically. Would that make Israel more secure? Hardly. Hamas would play a larger role in any successor leadership.
One of the most important facts on the ground is that Hamas has been gaining strength among the residents of the West Bank and Gaza. The latest poll shows 31 percent support for Hamas and smaller Islamist groups, up from 23 percent a year ago. Support for Fatah, the Arafat organization, has fallen from 33 to 20 percent.
Why Hamas has gained popularity is no secret. Palestinians have suffered, and are suffering, indignities that would drive Americans or any other people to rebel. Israel has steadily colonized their land, doubling the number of settlers since the 1993 Oslo agreement. Under Prime Minister Sharon, it has destroyed the Palestinian economy, confined people to their towns and villages and carried out assassinations. 
"It's a system that suffocates you slowly, slowly," Saleh Abdel Jawad, professor of political science at Bir Zeit University, told James Bennet of The New York Times. "It paralyzes your life, daily. And the people arrive to the point of explosion, and they cannot explode. And then one of the suicide bombers explodes instead of them."
The Palestinians see no hope now for a meaningful political process. The promise of Oslo turned to dust with the unending Israeli colonization. And Mr. Sharon has made plain that he opposes the removal of Jewish settlements and the creation of a Palestinian state with the contiguous territory that would make it viable.
The Sharon approach, in short, is all stick and no carrot. Even many Palestinians who firmly believed in a two-state solution -- Palestine living in peace alongside Israel -- have lost their faith in negotiations.
Israelis fear that Palestinians now really want not a two-state compromise but the elimination of Israel. That may well be more true now than a few years ago. But the irony is that Israeli policy has played a part in bringing it about. In trying to solidify its presence in the occupied territories, Israel has weakened the security of its pre-1967 borders. 
That any political move now can break the cycle of violence is a frail hope. But there is only one way to nurture that hope. It is to begin real peace negotiations without conditions, giving Palestinians a stake in the future. That depends on American leadership. 
The reality was succinctly stated by the distinguished Israeli writer Amos Elon in The New York Review of Books two months ago. Since 1967, he said, "Israel has been unable to resolve the painful paradox of increasing military power and steadily decreasing national security. The reasons for this continuing paradox are political: the attempt by one people to rule another against its wish."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TOURISM; 
Attacks Called Costly to City Tourism Industry

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
The president of the city's convention and visitors bureau told state legislators yesterday that tourism-related businesses would probably lose much more than $4 billion over the next two years because of the shrinking economy and the lingering impact of the terrorist attack on Sept. 11. 
 The tourism official, Cristyne L. Nicholas, said that the business losses would probably mean thousands more people being laid off at restaurants, on Broadway and at cultural institutions as well as a decrease in city, state and federal tax revenue that she estimated at $797 million. 
 In her first tourism industry projections, Ms. Nicholas said that research had shown two disturbing and somewhat unexpected trends. The first is that while New Yorkers and suburban residents helped prop up many tourism businesses in the weeks after the attacks, visits are again beginning to drop off sharply. For example, Broadway attendance is down 14 percent after climbing up in October. The advance sales, where tickets are sold at full price, are down even more sharply. 
The second factor is that out-of-state visitors appear to be not only afraid of flying, but also afraid of coming to New York in particular. 
"The city's tourism outlook has taken a dramatic turn for the worse," Ms. Nicholas said. "In short, the tremendous gains that the city's tourism industry has enjoyed over the last five years have been erased."
Ms. Nicholas's predictions came as officials at the New York City Partnership were releasing findings from an equally dire economic impact study that suggested that the travel and tourism industries were likely to lose $7 billion to $13 billion in revenues and will lose 25,000 more jobs by 2003. In addition, a survey in the report suggested that travel to the city from Britain and Canada would decline about 40 percent in the fourth quarter, as compared with the fourth quarter of last year. 
Ms. Nicholas, who said that the city would need to market itself, proposed a $25 million increase in the state's contribution to the NYC & Company budget, an expansion of the Jacob Javits Convention Center and a week free of sales tax in January. Ms. Nicholas did not specify where the $25 million would come from, but city and state officials have bandied about using some portion of the hotel surcharge tax to increase NYC & Company's budget. NYC & Company's $12.6 million budget dwarfs that of other major cities that are more accustomed to marketing themselves. The Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Agency, for example, had a budget of $153 million in 2001. Las Vegas was able to shift $13 million alone toward a post-Sept. 11 advertising effort.
In 2001, the city contributed about $5.6 million and the state contributed $630,000 to NYC & Company's budget. The rest of the $12.6 million budget comes from corporate sponsors, program income and membership dues. Among tourism destinations, the spending by NYC & Company ranks 16th, behind Kissimmee, Fla., San Antonio, Los Angeles, Orlando, Fla. and other cities. 
In response to a question, Ms. Nicholas indicated that neither had she received help with estimates from the state, nor did she have any idea whether Gov. George E. Pataki would include the $25 million in his proposed budget. Ms. Nicholas said that in 2001 she expected visits to be down 14 percent, or by about 5.3 million people and spending to be down by 12 percent, or by a little more than $2 billion. While Broadway, museums and zoos were beginning to show signs of recovery, Ms. Nicholas said that they have again slipped back to the poor attendance levels seen after the attack.
In 2000, a record-setting 37.4 million tourists visited New York and contributed $17 billion to the industry. This year, Ms. Nicholas said she expects visits to be down 14 percent, or about 5.4 million people, to 32 million, with similar results in 2002.
Hotel occupancy rates are expected to decline 12.1 percentage points in 2001 to 72.5 percent after hitting a record-high 84.6 percent in 2000. At the same time, the average room rate is expected to decline 13 percent to $206 a night in 2001, from $237 in 2000. Occupancy is supposed to decline further in 2003 to 68.5 percent, while room rates drop to $181 a night.
Kathryn S. Wylde, the president and chief executive of the New York City Partnership, the city's chamber of commerce, said that she is concerned about the ways in which New York City is getting hit harder than other parts of the country. 
Ms. Wylde said many international tourists -- who, studies say, spend three times more than domestic visitors -- have the misconception that much of the city is in rubble. She pointed out that while retail sales in Manhattan were down 40 percent in September, the same sales numbers were down only 14 percent citywide and 2 percent nationwide. 
"The closer you get to ground zero, the bigger the impact," Ms. Wylde said, adding, "Our projections are also based on timely interventions to turn things around, such as marketing the city and dealing with security issues. If that does not happen, we will have an even larger hole in our economy."

HEADLINE: New York City Boom Helped Poorest, Too 

 BODY:
The surging economy of the late 1990's helped New York City's poorest gain economic ground even faster, by some measures, than it helped the wealthy, a new study by two New York University professors shows.
 The average prices for single-family homes in the 90 poorest neighborhoods increased by a startling 36.5 percent from 1995 through 1999, while average prices for single-family homes in the 90 wealthiest areas of the five boroughs increased by 9.2 percent. 
 The economic gap still exists, of course, and the dollar value of the homes in poor neighborhoods is low by New York standards. Still, economists welcomed the news, which comes at a critical time of tremors caused by the recession, the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 and the ensuing war in Afghanistan.
Article, Page D1. 

CORRECTION-DATE: December 12, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of a computer entry error, a brief front-page summary article on Saturday about the economic gains of the poorest New Yorkers during the 1990's misstated the number of poor and wealthy neighborhoods compared in a study by two professors. The 10 poorest were compared with the 10 wealthiest, not 90 and 90.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Manhattan Prosecutor Criticizes Caymans Tax Pact

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, is critical of the agreement that Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill signed last week with the Cayman Islands to share information that would help the United States track down suspected income tax evaders, calling it "a sham."
 A variety of tax experts were also critical of the agreement, which calls for the Cayman Islands to cooperate with American tax investigators, starting in 2004. They say it gives those now cheating on their taxes 25 months to move their assets to another tax haven and seal the records of their cheating from investigators. 
 Mr. Morgenthau called Tuesday for the Bush administration to cut off the Cayman Islands' access to the United States banking system immediately, saying that was the only effective way to end decades of tax evasion and other felonies by Americans using Cayman Islands accounts. 
"What's bad is people are going to think the government is doing something when this is just a fig leaf," said Mr. Morgenthau, who disclosed last summer that Federal Reserve data show that $800 billion is being held in Cayman Islands accounts for Americans, an amount equal to roughly one-third of all domestic bank deposits.
Tax experts also criticized the agreement because it did not apply to cheating on estate, gift and state-level taxes. Still, some of these experts said the agreement, though flawed, should be seen as an important step, even if it is small, in the right direction by a government notorious for its decades-long embrace of American tax criminals.
These criticisms were dismissed as laughable by Mark A. Weinberger, the Treasury Department's senior tax policy official, who hailed the agreement.
"Obtaining this agreement in the most important financial center in the Caribbean," Mr. Weinberger said, "is an import step in advancing our cause of enforcing our tax laws globally, and we hope and expect that this will be a catalyst for other countries to step up" and sign similar agreements.
Last week, Mr. O'Neill praised the Cayman Islands for "emphatically demonstrating that those who engage in tax evasion or other financial crimes are not welcome" by signing the agreement.
David Ballantyne, the Cayman Islands attorney general, said that while the criticisms were harsh, they were not unexpected.
"Despite our efforts, there may be people who are unsure about the moves that the Cayman Islands is making," he said. Whatever may have gone on in the past, he said, "we are now moving in the direction of cooperation on criminal matters."
Aides to Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, who was critical of Mr. O'Neill last summer for not acting aggressively against tax cheats using offshore accounts, said the agreement should be seen as a step in the right direction.
Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee, said that "two years is too long to wait for the noose to be cinched on tax havens," but that the Treasury Department's hands were tied because the 2004 deadline was originally set by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in its efforts to crack down on tax havens.
Mr. Grassley said that he wanted "tax havens to fall like dominoes as we approach January 2004."
Mr. Morgenthau and other critics, however, said they were troubled that the agreement covers only income tax cheating and only beginning in 2004. Tax evasions now under way in the Cayman Islands can never be disclosed to the Internal Revenue Service or the Justice Department under the agreement.
Gideon Rothschild of Moses & Singer, who helps clients establish lawful offshore accounts, said the agreement was an early warning to tax cheats that the era of secret offshore bank accounts was going to end eventually.
The 25-month delay gives tax cheats ample time to move their money to another tax haven, said Jack Blum, a Washington lawyer who specializes in financial frauds.
"They have written this in a way so that the people who have been violating the law can get themselves out from under the mess by moving to another jurisdiction where there is no agreement," Mr. Blum said. "This is simply astonishing."

HEADLINE: Conference Panel Reaches Accord on Education Bill 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
After months of behind-the-scenes negotiations, a House and Senate conference committee has tentatively agreed on a bill that gives federal authorities an unprecedent role in requiring schools to ensure a minimum level of education for all students.
 The bill, the legislative answer to President Bush's initiative on education, allows states to define minimum levels of proficiency on reading and math tests and gives them 12 years to do so at a more or less steady pace. 
 States must report progress toward the proficiency goals by race, ethnicity, sex and learning disability and for those with limited English, in a clear federal effort to pressure states to close gaps in achievement that have persisted despite 36 years and more than $130 billion in federal aid for poor schools.
Amy Wilkins, an education policy analyst at the Education Trust, a nonprofit organization in Washington that advises urban school districts, called the final bill "a piece of solid legislative work," and she said she expected that while 100 percent of some groups might not reach the proficiency goals in 12 years, there was ample room for improvement. 
"We're so far from a hundred now," Ms. Wilkins said, "that the next six years of pushing toward a hundred would not be a bad thing, even if we have to revisit the issue again." 
The bill, which formally authorizes the Elementary and Secondary Education Act for the next six years, represents a remarkable coalescing of Democratic and Republican interests in overhauling public education and a turnaround for the Republican Party. In 1995, the Republican platform called for abolishing the federal Department of Education. With this bill, shaped by a Republican president and written with bipartisan support, the federal government is taking an untested direct role in forcing school improvement.
The conference committee, which is made up largely of members of the House and Senate education committees, will probably ratify the consensus bill on Tuesday, sources on both sides of the aisle say. In recent days the bill had been delayed by an effort, led by Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, to transform special education into an entitlement program, which would guarantee a level of federal financing for those eligible. Supporters of the effort said they would continue the fight next year.
Among the major differences in the bills the two chambers passed last spring were the criteria for judging school performance under the testing program and options for children in failing schools. The Senate wanted to make the National Assessment of Educational Progress, administered to samples of students in 42 states, the benchmark for gauging the rigor of state exams, while the House wanted to give states the flexibility to use other tests to verify state results. The final bill mandates the National Assessment.
The bill also offers some immediate relief to parents of children in schools already failing under existing federal law. Beginning in September, school districts must allow children in failing schools to transfer to successful public schools or provide tutoring after school, at the school or with private companies, nonprofit organizations or religious schools.
David Schnittger, an aide to the House education committee, said that "3,000 public schools nationwide at this very moment would fall into that category." He estimated the subsidies could amount to $500 to $1,000 each child.
While the Senate bill allowed demonstration projects that would have given as many as seven states unprecedented flexibility in spending substantial federal education money, the final bill says 5 percent of the federal allotment not designated for poor schools could be used for experiments in flexibility. While the language of the final bill was not available today, members of the conference committee said it created restrictions that would direct more Title I money to the very poorest schools. Currently, states use not only poverty but also geographical and political considerations in distributing Title I money, which serves about a third of all eligible children.
"We have made sure that the scarce funds that we do have are going to be targeted on the neediest children," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the Senate education committee. He estimated that Title I money for New York City schools would increase 30 percent. "We're holding children accountable, schools accountable and parents accountable, but we're also going to provide help and assistance."
Senator Kennedy said that an extra $3.6 billion to $3.7 billion that the bill authorizes for public schools might help schools prepare for the new testing and accountability regimes, but he noted that the recent economic recession had shrunk state education coffers by $12 billion.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ISLAM ABROAD; 
Europe's Muslims Seek a Path Amid Competing Cultures

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
Shazia Mirza is by most any standard a good Muslim. She is fasting this Ramadan, as always. She prays. She never drinks alcohol or eats pork. Yet three Muslim men jumped her, one actually wringing her neck, after she told this sly joke in a comedy club here about a pilgrimage she took to Mecca: 
 She was milling in a mixed crowd of men and women when, her joke went, "I felt a hand on my bottom. I ignored it. I thought: 'I'm in Mecca. It must be the hand of God.' " 
 Ms. Mirza, 26, may be Europe's sole female-devout-Muslim-stand-up-comic -- a job title that might seem contradictory on several levels. She says it is not. "If you aren't able to laugh at your own religion, at yourself, then there is a weakness there," said Ms. Mirza, the British-born daughter of Pakistani immigrants. 
Her comedy is about a single, complicated issue: living the dual life of a religious Muslim as well as an engaged citizen of secular Western culture, in her case Europe. This is an idea without much history behind it: There are some 15 million Muslims in Europe, a steadily increasing population, most of them migrants who settled here, then gave life to new generations, only since World War II. 
Now the terror attacks in the United States seem to be widening a split that has long existed among Europe's Muslims: those, like Ms. Mirza, who believe in an accommodation between Islam and life in the West and those, like her three attackers in the club, who are quick to see heresy. 
For all the worry among non-Muslims about a clash of cultures since Sept. 11, the reality is that moderate Muslims in Europe are the majority by far. In Britain the terror attacks "shook up people," said Dilwar Hussain, a researcher on Muslims in Europe for the Islamic Foundation in Leicester. 
"They felt they had to take a stand, to reaffirm what they are saying, that we are British, that there is no competition between being British and Muslim at the same time," he said. "You can have a national value and a religious value. They don't need to clash." But often they do, and, in many ways, this tension defines the life of Muslims in Europe.
They are a diverse group, sharing not a single language or culture: Pakistanis in Britain; Turks in Germany; Northern Africans in France; Arabs scattered in several places. They are entrepreneurs, tired retirees who came to Europe four decades ago as factory workers, oil-state tourists buying a few weeks of freedom from their tight regimes at home, bright students whose brains fully encompass two cultures.
Yet, for all the moderation, there is an undercurrent of extremism, too, even among those Muslims born in Europe. Since Sept. 11, investigators have found evidence of what they say are Al Qaeda terror cells and other radical groups in places like France, Spain, Belgium, Bosnia and Germany, where some men went on, the authorities say, to plan the attacks in New York and Washington.
Those attacks -- along with the war in Afghanistan, a Muslim nation -- have unearthed old resentments even among moderate Muslims. Simply, many Muslims feel like second-class citizens in Europe (a common worry is that Turkey will never be allowed into the European Union because it is a Muslim country). 
The question, with so much suspicion now cast the way of Muslims, is whether that anger may now expand.
"When something like this comes along," Mr. Hussain said, "it adds greater credence to those people who say the twain shall never meet."

Clashing Currents in Bosnia
For Senad Lepirica, the point was driven home one recent night when he, a Muslim, was punched in the nose by another Muslim. It was October in the small, central Bosnian town of Bugojno. There was a party at the sports center, and Mr. Lepirica, 23, went outside at one point to show affection to his girlfriend, whom he had not seen in several months.
"They came to us from the mosque, two guys," he recalled. "They said, 'You can't be here.' I asked, 'Why? It's a public place.' They said, 'It's in front of the mosque.' "
One of the men hit Mr. Lipirica. Soon they were on the ground wrestling -- not just two men, but two visions of Islam.
Like Mr. Lipirica, most Muslims in the Balkans -- Bosnia, Serbia, Macedonia, Albania -- consider themselves the most moderate in the world: They are of European Christian stock, converted half a millennium ago when the Ottoman Empire rolled west from Turkey. Despite fears of an Islamic invasion of all of Europe, the brand of Islam that survived, then weathered 50 years of Communism, is manifestly hands-off -- a model, they say, for how Muslims can coexist elsewhere in Europe. 
But since the war in Bosnia, which upended society in four years starting in 1991, charities from the Middle East have been working to remake Bosnia's Muslims in their image: to persuade them to abandon drinking, a widespread lack of observance, a European style of life. In the war, they sent arms and fighters to help Muslims when the West would not.
They have been building mosques, not in the ornate Ottoman style common in the Balkans but with the austere lines of the Saudi desert. It was one of these mosques that had just opened, across the street from the sports center in Bugojno. 
The question is whether this is a danger in any way. The mosque's young imam, Salih Indzic, says not. He politely apologized for the behavior of the man who punched Mr. Lepirica as not only wrong but also contrary to Islam. 
"The Koran says that one cannot be forced to believe," he said. 
All the same, Middle Eastern charities have poured in hundreds of millions of dollars into Bosnia. The Saudi High Commission for Relief for Bosnia, a charitable foundation of the Saudi Arabian government, which paid for the Bugojno mosque, has spent roughly $500 million in Bosnia on humanitarian and religious projects. The aim, Bosnian and foreign officials maintain, is not merely aid, but to spread a more rigid Islam, Wahhabism. 
"They are trying to fully change the real nature of Bosnian Islam," says Senad Pecanin, publisher of Dani, a newspaper in Sarajevo that has written against the Saudi influence. "They are collecting mostly young people, uneducated, without jobs." 
There are also fears that religious centers like this attract extremists. In a wave of arrests around what Bosnian police said was a terrorist threat against Western peacekeepers, NATO squads raided commission offices on Oct. 26 and detained two local employees. Local police arrested another Arab employee the next day. All were released without charges. 
Common sense suggests that Bosnia might be ripe ground for extremists: The borders are porous. Lawlessness is widespread. The economy is bad. Yet the war in the 1990's, in which ethnic and religious groups fought for supremacy, also seems to have made Bosnia's Muslims wary of absolutes. 
"Anyone who thinks with his own brain," Mr. Lepirica said, "can see that the war here happened because of fundamentalism, in politics, in religion and in nationalism." 

An Amalgam of Beliefs
Tayyiba Ahmad, 26, a second-generation Pakistani Muslim in London, rejects the common wisdom these days about her religion: that Islam equals extremism. She is arguably more devout than her parents. In college, she began reading the Koran closely. She started wearing a hijab, the head scarf that denotes modesty among Muslim women. She wears it still, if lightly. 
"To be honest, it makes things a little easier," she said. "You don't have to worry about your hair."
Yet Ms. Ahmad, now a barrister, acknowledges that she is living a life that would not please some Muslims. For one, she is a woman who works and expects equal rights. She also practices not Islamic law, but British family law. 
"There is no conflict," she said. "Within Islam there is a set of guidelines for the way a good society should function, and the starting point is the individual. Then comes the family. Then comes society as a whole."
"The conflicts arise when individuals do not respect humanity, do not respect each other and do not help one another," she said. 
Some experts say that people like her are at the forefront of a kind of new European Islam. In part, this has been shaped by places like Britain, where some two million Muslims live. Most are Pakistani but, as in Europe as a whole, they are from scores of different countries, and all practice Islam in their own way. 
And so, some experts argue, Islam transplanted to Europe is by necessity shearing itself from its cultural roots, basing itself more on the Koran than on local practice from their home countries. 
"That will eventually have a broad impact in Islam," said Peter B. Clarke, an expert on religion at King's College, University of London. "When you get into customs, you run into all sorts of problems with modernity. I'm not afraid of strict Islam. I'm afraid of cultural Islam."
The forces against such a change are strong. 
"Any modernization in the verses means backwardness in the principles," Abu Hamza al-Mazri, an influential Egyptian sheik who preaches from a mosque in northeastern London, said in an interview. "There is no such thing as a European or American Islam."
But Ms. Ahmad does not see her life as a retreat: Her religion is, as she describes it, a rudder toward a deeper a cultural, religious, even political existence. She is active in demonstrations against the war in Afghanistan. She has been lobbying to change British law to allow Islamic women who divorce still to collect a customary gift from groom to bride not now recognized in Britain. 
But, she emphasizes, this melding of Islam and Britain must take place very much on Britain's terms.
"I'm not in an Islamic country," she said. "Therefore I must work within the system."

Protection for Opponents
Not all Muslims hold so textured a view. On a chilly morning in the comfortable German city of Cologne, two young Turkish Muslims described why they chose to worship at the mosque of the Caliphate State, Germany's most radical Islamic group. 
"It is very simple," said one of the men, who is 26 years old. "Islam and democracy are incompatible. You can't have the two in the same place." His friend agreed. Both were born in Germany. Both have decent jobs, as chemists.
There are more than two million Turks living in Germany, and most reject radicalism. The Caliphate State -- a self-declared Islamic state within the German state opposed to Turkey's secular government -- is small, with only 2,000 or so members. Yet, even there, extremism has found a place. 
Little angers non-Muslim Europeans more than the fact that groups like the Caliphate State are not merely permitted to exist, but are even protected by laws their members claim not to believe in. That point was underscored at a rare news conference the Caliphate held recently. The group's spokesman, Ismael bin Yassar, acknowledged that his group had met with Osama bin Laden, if only once, by chance, in 1996. And he repeated the group's opposition to democracy. But, he said, he did not believe Germany would ban the group, as is being debated there. 
"I think that the religious freedoms in this country would not allow that to happen," Mr. bin Yassar said. 
The fear among non-Muslims is not only that a terror attack might be planned in their midst, as may have been the case in Hamburg, an affluent and cosmopolitan city that investigators say was used a base to plan the Sept. 11 attacks. 
But many Muslims say their distinct experience in Europe -- a continent shaped in many ways by the fight against the Ottoman Empire -- is one of the forces that pushed them closer to Islam. 
Turks, for example, first arrived in numbers in 1961 as "guest workers" in German factories. The theory was that they would make money and go back to Turkey. But many stayed, had children, then realized they were no longer accepted back home fully as Turks. And Germany, some say with bitterness, has always accepted them only as "guests" -- and Muslims around Europe complain about a similar alienation. 
Islam became an kind of identity "to deal with this paradox of 'Am I a Turk in Germany or a German in Turkey?' " said Mehmet Soyhun, a theologian in Cologne. 
Werner Schiffauer, a professor who wrote a book about the Caliphate State, said that embracing a more devout Islam was a way that some young Turkish Germans rebelled both against their parents and what they saw as the secular consumerism of a Germany that didn't accept them anyway. They "beat their parents with their own weapons," he said. "They were better Muslims than their parents."
Most, for now, seem to think they can be good Muslims in the West without compromising their faith any more than Christians or Jews do. 
But, with so much hostility against Muslims after the terror attacks, experts say Europe itself is also facing a test: accepting that whatever terrible acts may be done in the name of Islam, Muslims are now an inseparable part of the continent.
"If someone sees this as a problem," said Mr. Pecanin, the publisher in Bosnia, "then I'm afraid there is no future for any of us."

The Force of Islam

HEADLINE: National Briefing Northwest: Alaska: Budget Reserve In Danger 

BYLINE:  By Matthew Preusch (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Unless oil prices rise sharply, the state's $2.4 billion in savings will run dry in July 2004, economists said. After two years of high prices, oil leveled off this year at $18 a barrel, widening a fiscal gap that will require the state to draw 40 percent, or about $1 billion, of the annual budget from its budget reserve fund. The state has no sales or income tax, so about 80 percent of its general fund comes from oil and gas revenue, and production has been declining at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska's largest source of oil. Since 1991, the state has had to dip into its reserves all but two years. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Foundation Deals Setback To Hewlett-Packard's Plans
The family foundation that is the largest shareholder of Hewlett-Packard, with 10.4 percent of the company's outstanding shares, said it would vote against the proposal to buy Compaq Computer.
 The move was a setback for Hewlett-Packard and its chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, but the company vowed to press on with the proposed acquisition. Page A1. 

Jobless Rate Jumps to 5.7 Percent
The nation's unemployment rate jumped to 5.7 percent last month from 5.4 percent in October as companies eliminated more than 300,000 jobs. The increase suggested that the recession will be more severe than many analysts had forecast. A1.

The unemployment rate in Canada rose to 7.5 percent in November, its highest level since mid-1999, with large losses in computer and electronics manufacturing and in the transportation sector offsetting gains in retailing. C3.

The Test for AOL's New Leader
The reputation of Richard D. Parsons, AOL Time Warner's newly designated chief executive, as a politically gifted and gracefully diplomatic corporate advocate, will be tested when he confronts Washington regulators. Issues covering cable television ownership limits, cable and broadcasting cross-ownership rules and Internet access are likely to come before policymakers during his tenure. C2.

Tax Pact With Caymans Criticized
An agreement that Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill signed last week with the Cayman Islands to share information that would help the United States track down suspected income tax evaders is being criticized by the United States attorney for Manhattan and by tax experts as ineffectual. Page C3.

Enron Reply on Stock Gains Ordered
A federal judge in Houston gave Enron a week to respond to a request made by a New York bank to freeze more than $1 billion reportedly gained by Enron executives who sold millions of shares before the energy company collapsed. C4.

Trade Firm Executive Pleads Guilty
Gary Farberov, an executive of a currency trading firm that had its headquarters in the World Trade Center and that was accused of defrauding clients out of $110 million, pleaded guilty in federal court in Brooklyn to money laundering and agreed to forfeit $5.1 million from offshore bank accounts. C4.

Schwab to Close Venture in Japan
The Charles Schwab Corporation said that it would shut its online trading joint venture in Tokyo in February. The venture, Charles Schwab Tokio Marine Securities, faltered from its start in April 2000, when technology stocks started to decline and the new-share market started to dry up. C3.

Morgan Stanley Challenges Lawsuit
Morgan Stanley contended in court papers that a former bond saleswoman whose sex-discrimination complaint prompted the federal government to sue the firm three months ago was disruptive and insubordinate. C14.

Argentina Seeks Funds From IMF
An Argentine minister, Domingo Cavallo, tried to persuade officials of the International Monetary Fund to release $1.3 billion to help it through an economic crisis and said meetings would continue over the weekend. C3.

Gains in Poor Neighborhoods Found
A new study shows that people in the 10 poorest neighborhoods in New York gained economic ground faster, by some measures, than those in the city's wealthiest neighborhoods in the second half of the 1990's. D1.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Collapse of the Taliban

STRONGHOLD FALLS -- Two months after the American bombardment of Afghanistan began, Taliban forces abandoned their last stronghold in Kandahar. The surrender, reported by anti-Taliban leaders entering the city, appeared to complete the collapse of the radical Islamic group that ruled Afghanistan. But confusion was widespread in the streets of Kandahar, with rival warlords competing for control, some Taliban fighters still defiant and the fate of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, unclear. A1

CAVE WARFARE -- Anti-Taliban Afghan fighters appeared stalled in their drive to capture a complex of mountain caves held by Osama bin Laden loyalists and to begin a full-scale search for him there. B2

Questions of Diplomacy

PAKISTANI AID TO TALIBAN -- One month after the Pakistani government agreed to end its support for the Taliban, its intelligence agency was still providing safe passage for weapons and ammunition to arm them. A Pakistani intelligence official acknowledged that an Oct. 8 shipment contained arms for the Taliban, but he said that it was the last officially sanctioned delivery and that the Pakistanis had since lived up to their commitment to the Americans. OPTIMISM ON ACCORD -- The senior American diplomats for Afghanistan said that despite grumbling from some members of the Northern Alliance, they were confident that the interim Afghan government patched together in Bonn would succeed. B4

The Path of Al Qaeda

REBEL LEADER'S DEATH -- Investigators piecing together the assassination of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the Afghan rebel leader, say they believe the plot was carried out by members of an Al Qaeda cell based in Europe and acting on command from Osama bin Laden. B1

A FOCUS ON SOMALIA -- A senior State Department official said the United States had begun surveying the waters and airspace around Somalia in hope of preventing members of Osama bin Laden's network from establishing a foothold there. B3

AFGHAN WOMEN SEEK RIGHTS -- Almost 40 prominent Afghan women, backed by American and European groups, gathered this week in Belgium to stake their claim to a role in rebuilding their country after years of living either in silence at home or in frustration abroad. B3

In an unusual agreement, ABC and CBS joined to buy the tape for $80,000 then broadcast it on their morning programs. B3

The View From Europe

TENSIONS AMONG MUSLIMS -- The terror attacks in the United States seem to be widening a split that has long existed among Europe's Muslims: those who believe in an accommodation between Islam and life in the West and those drawn to a more radical view. B1

CRITICS STILLED -- European criticism of the United States and the war in Afghanistan has quieted rather suddenly, in part because the Taliban have been overthrown so much more quickly than anyone expected. B5

Security and the Economy

AID PLAN FAILS IN SENATE -- Backed by a veto threat from President Bush, Senate Republicans killed a Democratic plan to provide $17 billion of aid to New York and a similar amount of money for programs to combat terrorism. The vote was a victory for Mr. Bush and a setback for Senate Democrats, who had tried to provide more money than the president sought for New York and for anti-terrorism activities. A1

DELAY IN AIR SECURITY -- Congress was unrealistic when it set a deadline of next December for screening all checked baggage for bombs, private and government experts testified. B6

ECONOMIC PLAN STALLS -- House Republicans broke off bipartisan negotiations on an economic recovery package, reducing the chances that Congress and the Bush administration will reach a deal this year. B6

DAY OF INFAMY RECALLED -- President Bush invoked the memories of Pearl Harbor as inspiration for America's war against terrorism and defiantly threatened the Al Qaeda leaders holed up in the caves of Tora Bora in eastern Afghanistan. B1

NO ANTHRAX AT FED -- Federal authorities said they had found no evidence of anthrax contamination at the Federal Reserve's headquarters, a day after Fed officials said that a batch of mail sent to the agency had tested positive for anthrax. B7
