HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: LAST STRONGHOLD; 
TALIBAN ABANDON LAST STRONGHOLD; OMAR IS NOT FOUND

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE with NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
Two months after the American bombardment of Afghanistan began, Taliban forces today abandoned their last stronghold in Kandahar.
 The surrender, reported by anti-Taliban leaders entering the city, appeared to complete the collapse of the radical Islamic group that had ruled Afghanistan. But confusion was widespread in the streets of Kandahar, with rival warlords competing for control, some Taliban fighters still defiant, and the fate of the Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, unclear. 
 Two rival Pashtun factions that moved into the city today engaged in firefights with each other and looted stores, opposition officials said. The gun battle appeared to mark the collapse of an agreement for the peaceful handover of Kandahar, brokered by Hamid Karzai, the Pashtun leader destined to head the country's new interim administration. 
Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the head of American military operations in Afghanistan, denied reports that Mullah Omar had fled Kandahar, but acknowledged that he did not know the exact whereabouts of the reclusive one-eyed cleric. "I do not have reason to believe that Omar has in fact escaped Kandahar," General Franks said from his headquarters at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla. "We simply don't know, right now, where Omar is."
He added that the fact that his whereabouts was unknown "does not lead me to believe that he's vanished."
The Times of London reported late tonight that a Pashtun commander said that Mullah Omar had been captured and was being held by one of the rival factions. A spokesman for the United States Central Command, Maj. Ralph Mills, said the military command had seen the reports regarding Mullah Omar but was unable to confirm them. The Foreign Ministry of the interim Afghan government said it had no knowledge of such a capture. 
As Kandahar changed hands, completing the Taliban's fall from power, two essential American war aims remained unfulfilled: the elimination of the accused terrorist Osama bin Laden and the capture of the Taliban leader who harbored him as he defied the United States.
How long it might still take to achieve those objectives was unclear. Though the Taliban have collapsed, they may retain the ability to wage a guerrilla war while the hunt for Mr. bin Laden and Mullah Omar continues -- and even beyond that. Efforts to storm a network of caves in eastern Afghanistan where Mr. bin Laden may be hiding stalled today, and the mystery regarding his whereabouts deepened.
In the Kandahar area, United States marines attacked Taliban troops fleeing the southern city as the hunt for Mullah Omar intensified. The attack took place early today when marines in heavily armed, light-armored vehicles, who were deployed to block Taliban and Al Qaeda supply and escape routes, killed seven people and destroyed three vehicles. One carrier-based F/A-18 fighter-bomber also joined the strike.
The military did not release the location of the attack or other details to reporters in Afghanistan, saying only that the incident began when the marines were confronted with a vehicle rushing toward their roadblock, and that some of those killed were moving on foot.
It was the first reported offensive engagement involving the marines since Nov. 27, when two Cobra helicopters and Navy F-14's attacked a convoy of 15 Soviet-era military vehicles headed toward the marines' forward base about 80 miles southwest of Kandahar.
As Taliban forces by the hundreds tried to break out of encirclement today, the marines and Special Operations forces in the area became fully engaged in combat, and the Pentagon, which had already added heavy equipment to the nearby operating base, seemed poised to throw even more marines into the fight.
Several hundred Marine infantrymen remained afloat on Navy ships in the North Arabian Sea, prepared to reinforce the 1,300 marines already in action around Kandahar.
As some Taliban surrendered to opposition Afghan forces, General Franks said at a news conference that marines had engaged small numbers of armed Taliban on the ground and from the air.
Inside Kandahar, fighting between the forces of two commanders, Mullah Naqib Ullah and Gul Agha Shirzai, was reported. But it had stopped by nightfall. 
Under the agreement negotiated by Mr. Karzai, who is to become Afghanistan's new leader on Dec. 22 if the conclusions of negotiations in Bonn are respected, Taliban soldiers had been expected to lay down their arms and surrender the city to Mullah Naqib's soldiers.
But Mr. Shirzai views Mullah Naqib, who has often changed sides, as a lackey for the Taliban. After his forces entered the city, Mr. Shirzai, a former governor of the province who has said he is eager to have the job again, was said to be occupying the governor's mansion tonight.
Mr. Karzai's aides played down the problem, though it now appeared that two commanders were vying for control of the city.
"There was compromise between the two commanders," said Abdul Malik, Hamid Karzai's brother-in-law. "They wanted to share the power. And in order that there should not be any conflict, it was decided that they should both go to Kandahar."
"The complete surrender of the city hasn't taken place yet," Mr. Malik said. "But the situation is peaceful now."
Ahmad Rateb Popal, a cousin of Mr. Karzai's who was an intermediary in negotiations with the Taliban, said the surrender had also failed to accomplish another critical goal: disarming the Taliban.
"A lot of these soldiers left without being disarmed," he said. "They all slipped out in the night and this morning. It's a big danger. It's not good for the city, and it's not good for Hamid. It should have been more well organized."
The situation in Kandahar today was so chaotic that General Franks said it could be two or three days before conditions were stable enough to get an accurate assessment.
"We do not yet have a sense of comfort that there is stability in the city, and I don't expect that we will have a sense of comfort for perhaps two or three days," he said.
More than 1,300 marines are deployed at a forward base about 80 southwest of Kandahar. But with hundreds of Taliban either surrendering or trying to escape the city, General Franks said he was considering moving part of the American force to another location in Afghanistan to cut off their retreat.
He said he had not ruled out sending marines into the city itself, although that was not the plan. 
Mr. Popal, the cousin of Mr. Karzai, said Mr. Karzai had made a mistake in quickly changing his position on whether Mullah Omar should be granted amnesty.
The future Afghan leader is under enormous, conflicting pressures. Many Pashtuns would see the arrest and trial of Mullah Omar as a humiliating bow to American power. But members of the Northern Alliance, with whom Mr. Karzai will soon have to govern in Kabul, want the Taliban leader to be severely punished.
Mr. Karzai initially hinted that an amnesty might be possible if Mullah Omar renounced terrorism. But after Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said that was unacceptable, Mr. Karzai took a harder stand against Mullah Omar.
"He should be very careful," Mr. Popal said. "The Pashtuns are looking very seriously at what he's saying about Mullah Omar and the way he's handling the situation in Kandahar. The way he has made his statements and changed them, that will create mistrust."
Mr. Karzai's handling of the amnesty issue provoked anger among members of the Northern Alliance, which has battled the Taliban for six years. 
While Northern Alliance leaders were silent on the subject, midlevel commanders said they supported an amnesty for soldiers but not senior leaders, particularly Mullah Omar. 
"Karzai is taking the side of the enemy of people of Afghanistan," said Abdullah Tawhidi, the Alliance's deputy security minister. "If this is the case, if he is going to support Mullah Omar, we do not follow him." 
Most Kabul residents questioned joined the criticism. "If he makes a deal, if he compromises with the enemy," said Muhammad Yunis, an unemployed pharmacist, "there is no way for us to support him."
In an interview with the Qatar-based television network Al Jazeera today, Mr. Karzai repeated his new position that Mullah Omar should be arrested and tried. "I have urged him to stop the bloodshed and ban terrorism," he said. "But unfortunately his response was not positive, showing no pity whatsoever for the Afghan people." 
In eastern Afghanistan, attacks by opposition forces around a cave complex believed to hold up to 2,000 of Mr. bin Laden's die-hard loyalists stalled today.
The soldiers attacking the complex, known as Tora Bora, had made progress on Thursday, moving about two miles forward in fierce skirmishes including hand-to-hand fighting. They captured several caves above the valley floor, along with ammunition, equipment and at least half a dozen pickup trucks. 
But there was little progress today, commanders conceded. "Yesterday we captured two caves, but we lost them today," said a frontline commander, Hajji Moussa. The Afghan fighters are from the Eastern Shura, which has replaced Taliban rule in the Jalalabad area. 
American warplanes, including giant B-52's, have been heavily bombing the area for eight days and nights and continued today, sending huge plumes of smoke higher up the mountains. Afghan commanders said four American Special Operations military advisers had arrived at the front on Thursday and directed the bombing overnight.
Al Qaeda fighters -- believed to be mostly Arabs, Chechens and Pakistanis -- appeared unlikely to surrender easily. Their radio communications, in Arabic, sounded confident, almost cocky, today, taunting the Afghan fighters to "send us the international forces."

HEADLINE: Wheeling, Dealing and Making Side Deals; 
Vow to Scrap Latin Textile Deals Wins Vote on Bush Trade Powers

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
The Bush administration hailed Thursday's photo-finish vote on presidential trade powers as a sterling -- though slender -- victory for free trade. But in return for crucial support, House Republican leaders quietly agreed to weaken one of the Clinton administration's most-prized trade accords.
 In a letter to Jim DeMint, a South Carolina Republican who switched his vote in the final seconds to give the White House a 215-to-214 win, three top Republican leaders promised to use "whatever means necessary" to cancel some textile export preferences Congress had granted Caribbean, Central American and Andean nations. In doing so, the lawmakers agreed to bolster textile manufacturers in Mr. DeMint's district. 
 Such protectionist side commitments are not uncommon when Congress considers trade agreements, and they are often defended as half-steps back to clear the way for a great leap toward open borders and expanded commerce. The concessions to Mr. DeMint helped reassure several other Republicans in textile districts who cast their votes to give President Bush trade promotion authority, a power the Bush administration says will allow the United States to join major global and regional free trade initiatives.
But perhaps because the margin in the House was so slim, the price of a victory this time was steep: critics say the proposals contained in the side letter -- if agreed to by the Senate -- effectively gut a central provision of the Caribbean Basin Trade Preference Act, a showpiece effort by the Clinton administration to help some of the world's poorest nations sell more textile and apparel products to the United States.
The promise may also complicate trade negotiations with the developing world.
Textiles are the most sensitive trade issue for poor nations because they depend on basic manufactured goods to provide jobs. Washington pledged to consider speeding the elimination of barriers to textile trade as part of negotiations begun in Doha, Qatar, last month. And the United States has come under pressure to grapple with its textile lobby as part of negotiations to free trade across the Americas.
The Bush administration is also being pressed by Pakistan to loosen quotas and reduce tariffs on imports of textile and apparel from that country, a concession to a partner in the war against terrorism that may become more difficult to finesse after the Republican horse-trading.
"This will definitely send a signal to the developing world as the U.S. tries to go forward with negotiations," said Lael Brainard, a former Clinton administration adviser on international economic issues who helped arrange a compromise on textiles that made possible the Caribbean trade accord last year. "These were very striking concessions to make, especially to members of the president's own party."
Charles B. Rangel of New York, the ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee and an opponent of the bill that gave new trade power to Mr. Bush, said his opposition turned to outrage when he learned of the arrangements to bring Republicans on board.
"This letter is a betrayal of all the reasons we have trade," said Mr. Rangel, a sponsor of the Caribbean deal. "It comes at the expense of hundreds of thousands of Caribbean workers as well as their governments who trusted that when the United States gives its word in trade matters, that word means something."
Robert B. Zoellick, the United State trade representative, called the DeMint concession "necessary to achieve a large good." He said the value of having the broader trade powers greatly outweighed the cost of backtracking on textiles.
He also blamed Democrats for opposing the new trade powers in overwhelming numbers and then condemning Republicans for making the deals necessary to get the package through the House, where Republicans hold a slight majority.
"If we had a few more Democrats voting with us, we could have avoided this compromise," he said.
House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert; Dick Armey, the majority leader; and Tom DeLay, the majority whip, made the promise to Mr. DeMint after the time for voting on trade promotion authority had expired. Opponents outnumbered supporters in the electronic tally by several votes. With Democrats shouting to end the voting and declare defeat, Mr. DeMint and the House leaders engaged in animated discussions on the floor before Mr. DeMint got his letter. Mr. DeMint, who had voted no, then switched his vote to yes.
In the letter, Mr. Hastert assured Mr. DeMint that no new trade bills would pass the House until Congress had taken action to make sure that any apparel assembled in the Caribbean or Andean areas for export to the United States is made from fabric that is dyed, printed or finished here.
Though the preferences have been in dispute for months, the Customs Service had ruled that Congress authorized Caribbean nations to dye, print and finish their own fabric and export final products to the United States free of duties and quotas as long as they purchased raw fabric from American producers.
Mr. DeMint fought to make the Caribbean nations buy higher-value-added fabrics before turning them into clothing for export. North and South Carolina are leaders in dyeing, finishing and printing.
He was not alone. Senator Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina also fought the preferences. He held up the nomination of Kenneth Dam, the deputy Treasury secretary, and several other top Treasury officials this spring to press the administration to overturn the preferences. He eventually allowed those nominations to proceed without forcing Bush administration officials to cooperate.
Administration officials refused to budge on the matter before Thursday's vote. Mr. DeMint met President Bush at the White House on Wednesday to discuss the terms of his support for the broader trade bill, an aide said. He consulted numerous times with Mr. Zoellick. But the letter agreeing to his terms was presented only after it became clear that trade promotion authority would fail without him on board.

HEADLINE: Three Bad Calls In the Election? Not a Problem For Union Chief 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Randi Weingarten, the hard-charging president of New York City's teachers' union, gambled mightily when she endorsed Alan G. Hevesi in the Democratic mayoral primary this summer, and sure enough, Mr. Hevesi placed dead last.
 That did not stop Ms. Weingarten from backing another candidate, Fernando Ferrer, in the runoff, and when he lost, endorsing Mark Green in the general election. Mr. Green was defeated by Michael R. Bloomberg, whom Ms. Weingarten had painted as a dilettante. 
 Ms. Weingarten, it seems, should still be scraping egg off her face, but in fact, she appears neither daunted nor damaged by her missteps. She was one of the first people whom Mr. Bloomberg visited after his victory, and he publicly promised that day not to punish Ms. Weingarten's union or others for supporting his rivals. Shortly thereafter, Mr. Bloomberg named Ms. Weingarten to his transition committee, further suggesting that she was not on his enemies list.
As if to emphasize that she was not about to slink off the political stage into obscurity, Ms. Weingarten made waves last week by renewing her union's demand for a 22 percent wage increase despite the economic problems that followed the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's withering response only seemed to add fuel to her fire. Two days later, she joined striking teachers at Roman Catholic schools on their picket line, drawing yet more attention to her own goal of getting the city's 80,000 public school teachers higher salaries.
Why has Ms. Weingarten emerged seemingly unscathed from three bad calls in the mayoral race? The easy answer, associates say, is a combination of Mr. Bloomberg's hold-no-grudges attitude and Ms. Weingarten's ability to avoid burning bridges and to redraw alliances quickly when the tides turn, using a mixture of personal charm and political savvy.
"She has always had a good sense of the big picture," said Robert Berne, the vice president for academic and health affairs at New York University and an expert on the school system. "The combination of her pragmatism and Bloomberg's reaching out has led to an interesting moment." 
Others say that Ms. Weingarten has worked more diligently than her predecessor, Sandra Feldman, at maintaining close relationships with other union leaders and finding a significant role in the overall city labor movement. As chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee, which coordinates bargaining for all municipal unions, she has additional visibility and influence.
Nor are Ms. Weingarten's unsuccessful endorsements likely to hurt her within the ranks of her union, the United Federation of Teachers. The members overwhelmingly re-elected her in April, and in an earlier vote, they extended the length of a president's term to three years, from two. Opposition within the union has been weak, and the coalition that tried to defeat her last spring has been working closely with her lately, delegates say, after she lobbied them to do so.
"There was disappointment and a lot of disgust right after Election Day, when Green lost," said Marian Swerdlow, a longtime delegate and social studies teacher at Franklin Delano Roosevelt High School. "But a lot of members would like to believe that Bloomberg's reaching out to her is a really good sign and that she's landed on her feet."
George Arzt, a political consultant who advised Peter F. Vallone and then Mr. Ferrer in the mayoral race, pointed out that Ms. Weingarten was hardly the only person who endorsed more than one losing candidate in what proved to be a completely unpredictable race. So many people switched their endorsements that none are likely to suffer grave consequences, Mr. Arzt said.
"No one really knew which horse to get on," he said. "Look at Ed Koch: he was with Vallone, Ferrer, finally Bloomberg. This was a very, very unusual year."
Notably, none of Ms. Weingarten's endorsements in the mayoral race were particularly passionate. She waited until mid-August, less than a month before the Democratic primary, to back Mr. Hevesi, and did little campaigning on his behalf. Her endorsement of Mr. Ferrer came only after an even larger union, District Council 37, backed him. By the time she got around to endorsing Mr. Green, it was clear from remarks she had made about him throughout the campaign that Ms. Weingarten -- a member of the Democratic National Committee -- was merely fulfilling political obligations.
"I read those endorsements as very careful, lukewarm statements about the candidates," Mr. Berne said. "None of them would have prevented her from doing what she did in the next round."
In an interview on Monday, Ms. Weingarten said her endorsements of Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Ferrer were heartfelt, and she pointed to past endorsements of candidates who won -- Charles E. Schumer in 1998 and Hillary Rodham Clinton last year. "I tend to be a risk-taker, and sometimes risks work out, sometimes they don't," she said. "The mayor-elect understands that the U.F.T. follows its convictions. He also knows that when we say we want to work with him, we mean it."
Also in Ms. Weingarten's favor is the fact that Mr. Bloomberg is a novice politician, a Republican in a city of Democrats who needs all the support he can get, said Joseph P. Viteritti, a research professor at New York University. "He can't play the game of not dealing with people who didn't support him," he said.
He added that the relationship could be mutually beneficial, because Ms. Weingarten has signaled recently that she is willing to reverse longstanding union positions and support two ideas that Mr. Bloomberg advocates: increased mayoral control of the school system and bonuses for teachers in schools whose test scores improve.
"It's not what Rudy Giuliani wanted," Mr. Viteritti said of Ms. Weingarten's new positions, which are more cautious than similar proposals by Mr. Giuliani. 
"But it's a very significant sea change in the thinking of the union. Bloomberg may realize it's in his interest to have her across the bargaining table."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE STIMULUS PACKAGE; 
Republicans Break Off Talks On Measures to Spur Economy

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
House Republicans broke off bipartisan negotiations on an economic recovery package today, reducing the chances that Congress and the Bush administration will reach a deal this year, even as the latest statistics showed a surge in unemployment.
 Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and his party's point man on the economic stimulus bill, issued a terse statement this morning saying he was canceling negotiating sessions planned for today and through the weekend. He then flew home to California. 
 His decision prompted criticism from Democrats, who said it was outrageous at a time when workers are suffering. That brought a counterattack from Republicans and the administration, who said the talks' cancellation was the justifiable consequence of a decision by Democrats to play politics with the economy. 
Democrats want the stimulus package to focus on helping low-income workers and the unemployed. Republicans are pushing for tax cuts, largely to benefit businesses. The two parties have been at a standoff for nearly two months, but had seemed to make progress this week when Mr. Thomas offered concessions and Democrats signaled that they would respond in kind.
Members of both parties said negotiations might still resume next week, perhaps with more direct involvement by President Bush. But among Democrats and Republicans alike there was increasing talk that the concessions being demanded by their counterparts made walking away from a deal more attractive than a compromise, especially if the economy shows signs of rebounding.
The negotiations have been suffused by what members of both parties called hostility between Mr. Thomas, known for a sharp tongue and quick temper, and the Democratic leadership, especially Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate majority leader, who Republicans say is more interested in his party's electoral prospects than in helping the economy.
Republicans said Mr. Thomas was especially infuriated by a decision by Senate Democrats that any economic plan would have to win the support of a substantial majority of their caucus, or perhaps as many as two-thirds of the 50 Democratic senators. They said Mr. Thomas viewed the Democratic position as demanding an outright victory, making a compromise impossible.
The Republican Congressional leadership and the administration jumped in on Mr. Thomas's side today, seeking to blame Mr. Daschle.
"Senator Daschle has offered nothing except more unrealistic demands," said J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the House speaker. "It seems to me that the Senate majority leader is trying to kill this negotiation before it even starts."
Paul H. O'Neill, the treasury secretary, said Mr. Daschle had created "an impossible hurdle" for the negotiators in insisting that any deal be supported by most Democrats.
"By refusing to respond to the president's repeated call for action, Senator Daschle is delaying America's economic recovery and threatening Americans' job security," Mr. O'Neill said in a statement.
Mr. Daschle said that by abandoning the negotiations, the responsibility for economic suffering now rested with the Republicans.
"They've walked out on the talks, they've walked out on unemployed workers and they've walked out on America's economy," he said. "And that is an outrage."
Some members of both parties said they would resist any deal that gave too much to the other side, with Republicans adamantly opposed to Democratic calls for more spending and Democrats determined to block a second big tax cut this year.
"I think, increasingly, Republicans are not willing to take a bad package, and it may very well be that the result will be no package," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas.
Alice M. Rivlin, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who was the White House budget director under President Bill Clinton, said that many liberals would prefer no bill to a deal based on the Republican tax cut legislation passed by the House in October. That bill cut taxes in the coming year by nearly $100 billion, with more than 70 percent of the benefits going to companies. 
Among its provisions was one that would eliminate the corporate alternative minimum tax and allow companies to claim, immediately, 15 years of accumulated tax credits from the minimum tax.
But with the ranks of the jobless growing, there is political peril to both parties should Congress go home this year without enacting some measure to help the economy.
Late in the day, Mr. Thomas issued a second statement saying that there is "already a large area of common ground between Republicans and Democrats" and that Republicans would restart negotiations -- if Mr. Daschle would drop his insistence that a large majority of Senate Democrats approve any compromise.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Panel Backs Putting Hefty Duties on Imported Steel 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
A federal trade panel recommended hefty duties on steel imports today, clearing the way for President Bush to protect troubled domestic steel companies but almost certainly raising the price of cars, appliances and other steel products.
 The Bush administration sought today's ruling by the International Trade Commission, making it likely that the White House will carry out the most sweeping protections for American steel makers since the 1980's. 
 Coming just a day after the House agreed to grant Mr. Bush expanded powers to negotiate free trade agreements abroad, the ruling gives Mr. Bush leeway to appease a politically influential constituency that staunchly opposes open trade -- and to reward workers and businesses in West Virginia, Pennsylvania and other swing states that some Bush advisers view as crucial to winning presidential elections. 
Each of the six members of the trade panel recommended that Mr. Bush protect 16 steel product lines -- accounting for about four-fifths of imported steel -- with tariffs from 5 percent to 40 percent. Some members also suggested using quotas or a combination of quotas and tariffs to help the industry.
Those recommendations are generally less than what the industry considers adequate. But the trade law gives Mr. Bush wide latitude to impose penalties as he sees fit, a decision he must make by February.
"The industry welcomes the I.T.C.'s recognition that tariff-based remedies are necessary at this time," said Thomas J. Usher, chairman and chief executive of the USX Corporation. But he urged Mr. Bush to adopt higher tariffs than the ones recommended by the trade panel, calling them "the only remedy that will give America's steel industry the chance to restructure."
Steel makers pressed the Bush administration to initiate the action against imports using a potent trade law, called Section 201, under which it is considered relatively easy to show damages from imports. The Clinton administration repeatedly declined to invoke that law to help steel makers.
Some 25 American steel companies have declared bankruptcy in the last several years, with many blaming their demise on a flood of low-priced imports and appealing for emergency government assistance to fend them off. The industry has asked for tariffs on many steel products of up to 50 percent, saying that the resulting higher sales at higher prices would help American steel makers generate more than $10 billion in industry profits that could be used to put them on firmer financial footing.
Earlier this week, leading steel makers also asked the Bush administration for $13 billion in federal aid to help pay pension and health care benefits for retirees. They said the aid would help as many as six major steel makers, including USX-U.S. Steel Group and Bethlehem Steel, to merge into a single and more resilient entity.
In essence, the industry is asking for a belt-and-suspenders bailout from the government -- reducing import competition while also providing financial aid to help compete with imports.
The administration is unlikely to give the industry everything it wants. Administration officials are noncommittal about any direct financial aid for steel makers, and Mr. Bush may well choose to impose lower tariffs or quotas than the industry would like.
The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, has said that the administration will impose protective trade barriers only if the steel industry consolidates to reduce its own overcapacity.
Some economists argue that any protections for steel are a waste of money. The trade panel recommended duties on trade products like flat-rolled and slab steel, which are basic materials for a wide range of consumer goods like refrigerators, microwave ovens, car fenders and fire extinguishers. All those items are likely to increase in price -- unless companies that make them take a blow to their profits.
Gary Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said he had studied the impact of imposing 20 percent tariffs on most steel imports -- about the average of what the commission recommended but well below what the industry wants. He found that they would cost consumers $2.4 billion a year when they were first imposed, falling to about $1.2 billion in the fourth year, when they are scheduled to be phased out. His total comes to more than $7 billion.
He also estimated that import barriers would save 7,300 jobs next year, meaning that Americans would end up paying $326,000 for each steel worker retained.
"This is why trade protection is an incredibly expensive way to save jobs," Mr. Hufbauer said. He said it might make more economic sense to give direct aid to steel makers to help them lay off workers or pay benefits than to impose the tariffs.
Any substantial tariffs are also bound to offend some of America's leading trading partners. Canada, Mexico, Russia, Brazil, Japan, South Korea and several European countries export steel to this country, and their companies would be hit hard.
The Japanese minister of economy, trade and industry, Takeo Hiranuma, said today that the trade panel's decision was "a call for a de facto ban on imports." He called it "truly regrettable."
The European Union trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, said a 40 percent tariff on steel imports would virtually close the United States steel market to the rest of the world.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE APPROPRIATIONS; 
Senate Rejects Increase in Aid For New York

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
Backed by a veto threat from President Bush, Senate Republicans on Friday killed a Democratic plan to provide $17 billion of aid to New York, along with a similar amount of money for various domestic programs to combat terrorism.
 The vote was a political victory for Mr. Bush and a major setback for Senate Democrats, who had tried to provide more money than the president sought for New York and for antiterrorism activities. 
 The Senate vote was 50 to 50. Sixty votes were needed to approve the Democratic plan, because it called for spending in excess of limits previously set by Congress. 
Democrats had said the $17 billion in their plan, combined with $3 billion already spent in aid to New York, would fulfill a federal promise made to the state in the week after the attack on the World Trade Center.
The New York senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, both Democrats, said they now expected that the state would receive $9.5 billion under a compromise devised as an alternative to the $17 billion proposal.
The money for New York and for antiterrorism programs was part of an amendment to the annual spending bill for the Defense Department. The Senate passed the bill late Friday, just a few seconds before midnight, by a voice vote. In the House, as in the Senate, Republicans rallied to Mr. Bush and blocked Democratic efforts to provide more money than he wanted.
Mr. Schumer and Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate Republican leader, predicted that Mr. Bush would seek additional money for New York in the current fiscal year when he submits his annual budget request to Congress in January.
"There is almost a universal belief," Mr. Schumer said in an interview, "that the administration will come back early next year with a request for a supplemental spending package that includes many of these same items. So why not do it now? The only answer is macho. The administration wants to be able to say, 'We're doing it, we're in charge.' "
The vote was the second significant victory for Mr. Bush in two days. On Thursday, over strenuous objections by many Democrats, the House passed a bill that would give the president broader power to negotiate international trade deals. The Senate is expected to take up the measure next year.
The $9.5 billion of aid to New York envisioned under the Senate compromise includes $5.8 billion to remove debris and repair public works at the site of the World Trade Center; $2 billion for community development grants; $140 million to reimburse New York hospitals; and $10 million for mental health services to children in New York.
The central issue in the debate on Friday was not just money but also the ability to control the domestic political agenda.
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, and other Democrats had wanted to provide a total of $35 billion for aid to New York and for various programs to prevent terrorism in the United States. But Mr. Bush threatened to veto the whole bill if it included more than $20 billion for those purposes.
Democrats said Republicans were delaying urgently needed improvements in domestic security, gambling with public health and safety, and exposing Americans to the risk of more hijackings, more anthrax and still other forms of terrorism.
Republicans said they wanted to give Mr. Bush an opportunity to assess the nation's needs and to submit a coherent set of proposals to beef up border security, prevent bioterrorism and protect airports, seaports and nuclear power plants.
Tom Ridge, director of the White House Office of Homeland Security, said on Thursday that Mr. Bush would propose substantially increased spending for security in his budget request next month.
In political terms, there is a vast difference between the two approaches. Mr. Bush would look weak if Congress forced additional spending on him now, over his objections. By contrast, if he makes similar proposals in January, he can plausibly take credit for seizing the initiative.
A bill passed by the House last week would provide nearly $7 billion in new aid to New York. The administration supported that measure, opposing the extra money in the Senate bill because "the total cost of recovery efforts in New York is not yet known."
Whether senators will pay a political price for voting against additional spending to help New York and enhance domestic preparedness may depend on events. Republican lawmakers could pay a penalty at the polls if another terrorist incident occurs before Congress provides further money. But voters may see the debate as a petty squabble if no more acts of terrorism occur. 
The rejection of the Democratic plan on Friday, combined with two Senate votes on the same legislation on Thursday, was a major defeat for Mr. Byrd, the Appropriations Committee chairman, who has served in Congress for nearly a half-century.
Mr. Byrd made clear in debate today that he saw the issue as a struggle over who would set domestic priorities.
"If we back away every time a president threatens a veto," Mr. Byrd said, "then the chief executive of this nation will reign supreme. He will be the emperor, no matter what his political party. He will be king. It seems to me to be a rather arrogant attitude on the part of the administration to say, 'We will tell you how much money we need.' "
Democrats said they were not surprised by their failure to round up 60 votes for their spending plan. Still, Mr. Byrd said, "The vote sends a message that it's more important to win a political battle than it is to win the war against terrorism."
One of Mr. Byrd's closest friends in the Senate, a Republican, said in reference to a series of votes against the spending: "Senator Byrd has never lost three votes in a row. He's in a state of shock."
Backing away from a veto fight with Mr. Bush, Senate Democrats agreed to scale down their proposal so it totaled $20 billion, the maximum acceptable to him. Within that sum, Democrats rearranged the money to provide $9.5 billion for New York -- $3 billion more than Republicans had initially proposed.
Senator Lott hailed the Senate's action as a vote of confidence in Mr. Bush's judgment. "We are now at war," Mr. Lott said. "We've got men and women on the ground and in the air and at sea in this war against terror. We should not revert to political positioning."
In the Senate, as in the House, some Republicans said they would have supported extra money for New York and for antiterrorism programs if the White House had not put pressure on them.
The Senate vote on extra money for New York and for domestic security generally followed party lines. Senator Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin was the only Democrat who voted with the Republicans. 
"I strongly support funding to help the country recover from the tragic events of Sept. 11," he said. "But only a fraction of the money Congress approved earlier for recovery has been expended. It is premature to circumvent budget limits to provide additional spending."

HEADLINE: A Vote for Free Trade 

 BODY:
By a single vote margin, the House of Representatives on Thursday gave President Bush the negotiating power he will need to broker trade agreements vital to the health of the global economy. It is a shame that only 21 Democrats voted for the measure. Senate Democrats, less beholden to protectionist interests, should now hasten to support President Bush's request and reassemble a bipartisan consensus for freer trade. 
 There are few more meaningful ways for America to aid the world's neediest than by remaining a steadfast advocate of economic liberalization. Poor countries desperately need developed nations to lower their tariffs for textile and agricultural imports. Though some domestic competitors in those sectors may suffer, America's overall economy also benefits from an expansion in trade. 
 Every president since Gerald Ford has exercised the kind of trade promotion authority just approved by the House, though President Clinton was unable to renew his after it lapsed in 1994. The law binds Congress to a straight up-or-down vote on any trade deals made by the president. Without this streamlined process, Mr. Bush's ability to engage other countries in complex trade negotiations is much diminished.
The bill passed in the House rightly directs Mr. Bush to place environmental and labor standards at the center of trade negotiations. Robert Zoellick, the United States trade representative, has proved his willingness to do so. Countries must not be allowed to violate basic international labor standards or to dilute their own laws to attract investment or benefit from trade. 
For more than a half-century, Democratic and Republican administrations alike have rightly endeavored to liberalize the world's economy and lower barriers to trade. This commitment is as important today as ever before, particularly as the nation seeks to rally the world in a war on terrorism. President Bush needs the negotiating power to lead the new round of multilateral talks agreed to by 140 countries last month, as well as to forge a free trade zone for the Americas.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-8

Moscow's NATO Influence Is Questioned by Rumsfeld
A proposal by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin to expand Russia's role in NATO decision-making became caught up in a clash of views in meetings this week between Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, diplomats said. Secretary Powell, backed by the president, prevailed, though a number of details are still to be worked out. Russia's proposed integration would fundamentally alter the structure of the Western alliance. A1

Israel Attacks Again in Gaza
Israeli and Palestinian security officials met for talks, but a stalemate continued. Israeli warplanes flattened two police buildings in Gaza City to press Yasir Arafat to act more firmly against Palestinian militants, and militants rallied in Gaza to warn him to do no such thing. On Israeli television, Mr. Arafat lashed out at the Bush administration as tilting toward Israel. A3

Disagreement on Bioweapons
A three-week review of the Biological Weapons Convention of 1972, signed by 144 countries, ended in Geneva amid debate on how to strengthen controls. The countries could agree only to reconvene next November. A7

7 Charged in Yacht Killing
Seven men described as small-time criminals were arrested and charged with the murder of Sir Peter Blake, the world champion yachtsman, who was shot dead on Wednesday aboard his vessel, the Seamaster, in a Brazilian harbor. A6

New Leadership in Sri Lanka
Voters chose the main opposition party to lead a Parliament coalition. The United National Party has promised to pursue peace talks with Tamil rebels and seek an end to the 18-year ethnic conflict. A8

Shanghai Mayor Steps Down
Xu Kuangdi resigned suddenly to take the post of party secretary at the Chinese Academy of Engineering in Beijing. The move may be part of a personnel shuffle by President Jiang Zemin to protect his political legacy ahead of the Communist Party Congress in 2002, when he will step down as party leader. A4

World Briefing A6

NATIONAL A9-12

Senate Republicans Pare Democrats' Antiterror Plan
Senate Republicans, backed by a veto threat, killed a Democratic plan to provide $17 billion of aid to New York, along with a similar amount of money for various domestic programs to combat terrorism. Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, both Democrats, said they expected that New York would get $12.5 billion under a compromise devised as an alternative. A1

Dispute on Civil Rights Panel
Democratic-leaning members of the United States Civil Rights Commission barred President Bush's newest nominee to the commission, Peter Kirsanow, a Cleveland lawyer, from being seated and prevented him from voting. The move was part of a dispute over the expiration of Commissioner Victoria Wilson's term. A10

EDUCATION

New Jersey Strike Ends
Middletown teachers agreed to honor a back-to-work order and return to the classroom Monday without a new contract. A judge then ordered 225 union members freed from jail. D1

Tentative Deal on Education Bill
House and Senate negotiators agreed on a bill that gives federal authorities an unprecedented role in requiring schools to ensure a minimum level of education for all students. A9

Scientists differ on the cause of the unseasonably warm weather. A10

Bloomberg Begins Building His New Inner Circle
Mayor-elect Bloomberg named three deputy mayors: Marc V. Shaw, a veteran government official; Dennis Walcott, longtime leader of the New York Urban League; and Patricia E. Harris, a corporate confidante from Bloomberg L.P., Mr. Bloomberg's information services company. D1

Poor Made Gains in 90's
A study found that people in the 10 poorest neighborhoods of New York City gained economic ground in the second half of the 1990's faster, by some measures, than those in the city's wealthiest sections. Still, the gap between rich and poor remains large, and advocates for the poor say they do not have enough housing. D1

Final Approval of Nassau Budget
A protracted struggle to enact Nassau County's 2002 budget concluded as a state oversight board approved the final changes made by County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, who scaled back a proposed 15 percent tax increase to 9 percent. D1

HEADLINE: Charles Schwab Will Close Its Online Venture in Japan 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
The Charles Schwab Corporation, the American discount brokerage concern, said today that it would shut its online-trading joint venture in Tokyo in February.
 The venture, Charles Schwab Tokio Marine Securities, faltered from its start in April 2000, just in time for technology stocks to melt down and the new-share market to dry up. Since then, Japan's economy has skidded into a recession and Japanese retail investors are even more reluctant than usual to buy equities. 
 The online venture managed to gather just 9,000 accounts; some of those who still remain will be sent to a rival, DLJ Direct SFG Securities, a joint venture of Credit Suisse First Boston and Sumitomo Bank. The Schwab venture lost 3.7 billion yen ($29.8 million) in the year ended March 31, 2001.
"It is unfortunate that the economic conditions prevailing in Japan and around the world have depressed our competitive prospects at such a key time," the venture's president, Richard Kenny, said in a statement. Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance owns 35 percent of the venture.
Schwab joins a growing list of foreigners to pull out of Japan's moribund market. Last month, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter closed its only consumer branch here, which had been open less than a year. Societe Generale of France also said recently that it would shut its online operations here, and Merrill Lynch is pruning its retail network.
All three had been among the foreign players who bet that Japan's stock market would recover sharply after collapsing in 1998. At first they were right, as stock prices revived in 1999, but the gains were swiftly erased when American stocks swooned last year and pessimism spread abroad.
The Schwab venture came late to an online brokerage market cluttered with dozens of companies. Early entrants like Matsui Securities and Monex Securities established brand names and cornered parts of the market, including day traders. Schwab, however, never distinguished itself from the pack for Japanese retail customers, who now execute half their trades online, analysts said.
"They came in too late and missed the window of opportunity," said Kristine Li, who follows Japan's brokerage industry for Lehman Brothers in Tokyo.
Ms. Li estimates that Matsui, Monex, DLJ Direct SFG Securities and E*Trade Japan control 60 percent of the online trading market here, with another 15 percent going to online arms of the country's three largest conventional brokers, Nomura, Nikko and Daiwa.
A price war has driven commissions down 90 percent since they were deregulated in 1999.

HEADLINE: With Tourism Down, Hotel Rates Fall, Too 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES; EVELYN NIEVES is chief of the San Francisco bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
THE tourists, so many of them based in other, earlier time zones, begin stepping out in Union Square before dawn. They mosey into the cafes when the morning fog is still on the ground, wait for Macy's to open when the corner newspaper kiosks are still padlocked, line up for the Mason-Powell cable car before most San Franciscans have had their first cup of nonfat latte.
 But lately, the throngs of tourists that are so much a part of life in San Francisco have thinned. The hotels are half full. At high noon, the wait for the cable car is only five minutes. 
 On a typical weekday last month, well after the morning's brittle sweater-weather had warmed into another lovely shirt-sleeve afternoon, the streets of Union Square were as quiet as a library. So were the once too-crowded souvenir shops of Fisherman's Wharf, the restaurants of North Beach and the trendy hotel bars in Nob Hill.
San Francisco's tourist industry, the lifeblood of its economy, is in dire straits. Even before Sept. 11, the dot-com bust had put a damper on business travel, causing hotel occupancy to drop 11 percent in the first eight months of the year from the same period last year. But since Sept. 11, tourism in San Francisco, as in every destination that depends on air travelers, has been seriously affected. Only three out of five hotel rooms in the city had paying customers in September, or an occupancy rate of just under 60 percent, down from 88.5 percent for the same time last year, according to the latest available figures from the Convention and Visitors Bureau. 
It has become so bad that Gov. Gray Davis has begun a $5 million ad campaign to get Californians to take trips in-state, with much of the campaign focused on the tourist-dependent Bay Area. (When the governor announced on Nov. 1 a "credible threat" by terrorists to destroy one or more of California's four main bridges, hotels and restaurants in San Francisco saw a further drop in clientele. The governor was obliged to cross the Bay Bridge and visit the Golden Gate just to show that they were indeed safe.)
San Francisco, which is accustomed to having more than 80 percent of its hotel visitors arrive by plane, is trying to lure nearby residents to spend a night or a weekend in the city.
Mayor Willie Brown is even considering a plan that would have city officials call Bay Area residents and invite them over for a bite and a bed.
For tourists, the drop means a good deal. The Convention and Visitors Bureau has put together two collections of winter hotel packages, one in effect through December, the other running from January to March. The first offers hotel rates beginning at $63 a night, with amenities such as shopping discounts, restaurant credits, free parking and attraction passes. The second, focused on romance, has overnight package rates starting at $79, with perks that might include champagne, bathrobes and breakfast in bed.
"November and December is our slow season traditionally," said Laurie Armstrong, vice president for public relations for the Convention and Visitors Bureau. "So we're optimistic that this slowdown will pick up again."
If it does, San Franciscans could go back to the good old days of grudgingly accepting tourists as part of the landscape. Their absence is oddly unsettling, like seeing an empty space in the corner where grandmother's old recliner used to be.
"I never thought I'd say this," said a vendor at Fisherman's Wharf as he looked around the near-empty streets, "but I miss the tourists in their shorts and T-shirts, gaga over everything. I miss their happy faces."

HEADLINE: Exception: War 

BYLINE:  By Joshua Micah Marshall; Joshua Micah Marshall is a senior correspondent for American Prospect magazine.

 BODY:
 THE STRANGE DEATH OF AMERICAN LIBERALISM
By H. W. Brands.
200 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $22.50.
 Could the war on terrorism revive trust in government? Maybe even big government? Political commentators are asking whether relying on muscular federal action to prevent terrorism and save the economy might cause Americans to trust government in other ways as well. H. W. Brands could scarcely have predicted the events of Sept. 11 when he wrote "The Strange Death of American Liberalism." But the issue now raised so often -- the connection between national emergencies and government activism -- is the centerpiece of his argument about the demise of liberalism.
For Brands, the author of books on Theodore Roosevelt and Benjamin Franklin, the question is less why liberalism died than how it ever managed to come about at all. He argues that 20th-century liberalism was a grand historical anomaly made possible by the cold war. No more cold war, no more liberalism. 
Distrust of government has always been the default setting of American politics, Brands says, with one very big exception: wartime. When national security is at stake, Americans are willing to tolerate a temporary but vast expansion of federal power. Thus, during the cold war, when America was trying to lead the world by example, domestic reformism became a part of foreign policy. Ending discrimination and ending poverty were no longer the concerns just of do-gooders. They were another front in a global struggle.+
Brands is right to place the cold war at the center of our understanding of the late 20th century. The cold war had a way of stacking contrary political impulses against each other to create a mutually reinforcing and remarkably stable political whole. Liberal internationalists could suddenly agree with virulent anti-Communists on many points of foreign policy. Eisenhower and Nixon Republicans could find conservative reasons for endorsing a moderate liberalism. Most important, the cold war persisted long enough to convince two generations that the politics it spawned was a natural state of affairs. There are legions of aging, liberal baby boomers who believe that some amalgam of memories from the 1950's and 60's amounts to the normal order of things. If Brands can puncture that shortsighted nostalgia, so much the better. 
Unfortunately, he nips and tucks the historical record too often to be convincing to those who aren't already convinced. Take what is arguably the single largest expansion of federal power in American history -- the adoption of the Constitution in 1789. It occurred while the country was at peace, not war, but this goes almost unmentioned. And progressivism, another great wave of reformism with centralizing tendencies, is all but argued out of existence. Everyone agrees that Americans are more skittish about government than Europeans. But their attitudes are more complex and ambivalent than Brands allows.
The book's real weakness, however, is its one-dimensional rendering of liberalism itself. For Brands, liberalism is all about bigness and power and centralized control. Equality, solidarity and rights-consciousness tag along like bit players in the drama. By seeing liberalism so totally through the prism of statism, Brands comes close to declaring what is simply a truism: that cold war liberalism was a product of the cold war and couldn't go on without it. But if liberalism is to have any meaning for understanding our past or our future, we should see it as one manifestation of a broader tradition of American reform, one that has often, but by no means always, been identified with the power of the state.
In his book's final pages, Brands writes that if history is any guide, "another serious threat to American security" will be necessary to change the public's skepticism about big government. After Sept. 11, just such a threat is at hand. But since the American tradition of reform has never simply been about an overweening state, a revival of liberalism, at least as it existed during the cold war, is by no means certain.

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Wall Street 

BYLINE:  By Robert J. Samuelson; Robert J. Samuelson, a columnist for Newsweek and The Washington Post Writers Group, is the author, most recently, of "Untruth: Why the Conventional Wisdom Is (Almost Always) Wrong."

 BODY:
 RAINBOW'S END
The Crash of 1929.
By Maury Klein.
Illustrated. 345 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $27.50.

THE END
OF GLOBALIZATION
Lessons From the Great Depression.
By Harold James.
260 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $39.95.
 The attacks of Sept. 11 have only deepened the parallels between present-day America and the America of the 1920's. In the early 20's, Americans also felt assaulted by alien forces -- radicalism and Bolshevism imported mainly by immigrants. There was terrorism then, too. These are eerie extensions of similarities between the two periods that until now have been largely confined to economics and popular psychology. In both periods, Americans enjoyed astonishing prosperity. In both, novel technologies mesmerized the public. In both, the stock market rose to unanticipated heights. In both, the faith that the economic system had permanently changed for the better led to self-congratulatory labels: the "new era" in the 20's and the "new economy" in the 90's. We know what happened to the 20's; the 90's endgame is still unfolding. 
No one guessed in 1921 -- just as no one guessed in 1991 -- that the country would soon experience astonishing prosperity. Economic downturns in both years darkened the public mood. The severe 1920-21 slump is usually classified as a depression, with unemployment averaging almost 12 percent in 1921. The depression resulted mainly from the huge inflation unleashed by World War I that set in motion a spending frenzy (buy now to beat price increases) and caused the Federal Reserve -- created only in 1913 -- to raise interest rates. New technologies helped propel the subsequent boom. In the 20's, the spread of electricity -- by 1927, 63 percent of households had it, up from 16 percent in 1912 -- stimulated markets for new appliances: irons, toasters, stoves, washers, vacuum cleaners and, most conspicuously, radios. Along with the spread of movies, radio's arrival fostered a new national pop culture and politics. Even more transforming were cars. Production exploded. From 1920 to 1929, car registrations tripled to 27 million. The hunger for mobility spurred satellite industries, from filling stations to road construction to motels. 
The story of how this prosperity fed a stock market mania has been told many times, most notably in "Only Yesterday," the 1931 classic by Frederick Lewis Allen; "The Great Crash, 1929" (1955), by John Kenneth Galbraith; and "Once in Golconda" (1969), by John Brooks. But for those who want a refresher, Maury Klein's "Rainbow's End" is a worthy successor, well written, entertaining and detailed. Klein, a historian at the University of Rhode Island, shows how optimism gradually spawned financial euphoria. Market setbacks were temporary; people bought on the dips; and warnings about speculative excesses were dismissed as old-fashioned. Sound familiar? 
There are other parallels. By 1998, about 49 percent of households had stock, up from 32 percent in 1989. A similar growth occurred in the 20's, though (because surveys were rare and not always reliable) the exact dimensions remain unknown. Klein cities one estimate that toward the end of the decade, about 15 million Americans (out of 122 million) owned corporate stocks or bonds, up from 500,000 two decades earlier. Mutual funds, then known as investment trusts, barely existed before the 20's. Their number had quadrupled by 1926. Rising stock ownership, Klein writes, dampened hostility toward corporate enterprise. This, too, happened in the 1990's.
Then as now, a thin line separated genuine economic enthusiasm from market manipulation. In the 90's, stock analysts touted profitless Internet stocks whose shares already traded at astronomical prices. This helped the analysts' investment firms win underwriting deals (the sale of new shares) from which they earned lucrative fees. Yet many analysts believed their outlandish predictions. In the 20's, wealthy investors often organized secretive "pools" that, through concerted buying, stimulated enthusiasm for a stock and drove up its price. The pool would then quietly sell at a profit, enthusiasm would wane and the stock's price would drop. Still, many leading Wall Street figures -- including pool operators -- were true bulls, believing in the market's inexorable rise. 
Klein's major failing is that he does not connect the stock market crash of 1929 to the Great Depression. Instead, he declares that the crash "ranks high on the list of unsolved puzzles for scholars" who have been unable to determine "what role, if any, it played in bringing on the grinding depression that followed." This is misleading. In recent decades, a huge amount of academic research essentially absolves the crash. Klein ignores this research. By itself, the 1929 crash did not so weaken confidence and consumer buying that it caused the Depression.
The Great Depression differed from ordinary economic slumps in many ways: its severity (economic output in the United States dropped about 30 percent between 1929 and 1933); its length (unemployment in 1939 was still 17 percent); and its international character (almost all industrialized countries suffered). Among scholars, the prevailing view is that the global financial system after World War I was inherently unstable. The attempt to restore the prewar gold standard -- paper money backed by government gold reserves -- led to a series of banking crises, because domestic and international investors doubted that the gold commitment could be honored. The stock market crash signaled the onset of an American recession. It became the Great Depression because once a setback occurred, a financial system based on gold was so shaky that normal recovery was difficult and, perhaps, impossible. Depositors withdrew money from banks, which caused banks to fail. Credit and international trade shriveled, causing economic weakness to spread and snowball. This happened in Austria, Germany, Britain and France as well as the United States. 
"The End of Globalization," by Harold James, a historian at Princeton University, represents the latest contribution to this new consensus. James shows in great -- if sometimes dry -- detail how the Depression led to the breakdown of the liberal international economic order of the late 19th century, characterized by open trade, a free flow of money among nations and heavy migration. Here, too, there may be disturbing parallels. The Sept. 11 attacks suggest that today's globalization could founder because large groups around the world reject it and will try (literally) to destroy it. 
What undermined globalization in the 1920's was the nationalistic residue of World War I, which fostered trade protectionism and immigration restrictions. The Depression compounded these pressures. Deflation -- falling prices -- meant that debtor countries, often dependent on a few raw material exports, couldn't earn enough to repay their debts. By the mid-30's, many countries had resorted to trade restrictions and foreign exchange controls to protect domestic industries and pay for essential imports. The Great Depression's simple and overriding lesson is that economic forces, if sufficiently powerful, can transform the social and political landscape in ways once unimaginable. In turn, the Depression represents a root cause of World War II because it discredited democracy in Germany and by humbling democracies in Britain, France and the United States weakened their will to deter Germany.
Neither Klein nor James asks whether the crash and the Depression could have been averted by shrewd leadership. But both books tell similar stories of confusion and disarray. Political, business and financial leaders around the world grappled with problems they barely understood. Even had they understood, their power -- to affect financial markets, banking systems and trade flows -- was so fragmented that the practical prospects for controlling events were limited. This is a parallel that need not apply to our own time. But it might, and that is a sobering possibility.

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES; 
The Mission District: Affordable and Fun

BYLINE:  By MARK BITTMAN; MARK BITTMAN writes for the Dining section of The Times.

 BODY:
I KNOW of no other North American neighborhood where you can have as much fun and eat in as many different, affordable restaurants as you can in the Mission District of San Francisco. The dot-com boom bought tons of new money here, and two years ago, when pioneering yuppies had gentrified the Mission -- or ruined it, depending on your perspective -- I began visiting regularly. There were a few restaurants I already knew: the venerable Taqueria, the 10-year-old creperie called Ti Couz, and the newer Universal Cafe (actually in nearby Potrero Hill), Delfina, and the Slanted Door. 
 Now the Mission is as alive as it has ever been, a multi-ethnic attraction for young people, affluent and not, who come for the clubs and the shops, the busy, crowded, milling, Manhattanlike scene, and especially the restaurants. Though I dined late when I was in San Francisco, each of the restaurants mentioned here was packed or close to it, as if in defiance of the national mood and the locally struggling economy. 
 None of these places are expensive, and most have spent little on decor. Velvet curtains, old mirrors and high ceilings with exposed mechanicals are the norm. The crowd is generally young -- very young -- as are the servers and chefs (often the owners). 
The energy and noise levels are high but not off the charts. The food, for the most part, is terrific and, in a happy development in the last few years, the wine-by-the-glass offerings are tremendous.

Andalu
The only consistently Iberian aspect of the two-month-old Andalu is that the plates are small; the food is supremely eclectic. The bar is topped with seltzer bottles, the high ceiling is painted sky, hung with huge paper lanterns. Like many Mission storefronts, it's three or four times as long as it is wide, with a mezzanine section overhanging the back. 
Andalu is a tad less noisy than some ofthe competition, but it's no less crowded or hip: the jade-green glass tabletops sparkle, there are high communal tables with stools in the bar area, and the smart, efficient servers are uniformly dressed in jeans and black shirts. 
The menu, which changes daily, lists "small plates" and "smaller plates," thelatter meaning side dishes and little bites -- spicy cashews, fries with gremolata (the lemon-garlic condiment traditionally served with osso buco), olives, a vegetable side dish or two. A couple of "small" plates plus dessert should be enough; this food is hearty. 
To wit: green salad with duck confit, fresh, creamy goat cheese, and pomegranate seeds; crunchy, hot polenta fries with a light tomato dipping sauce; brandade -- salt cod creamed with loads of garlic and potatoes -- topped with lemon-garlic mayonnaise; steak tartare; crisp-sauteed skate with garlic mashed potatoes; portobello mushroom with bone marrow and bread crumbs; and a few pieces of suckling pig on a gratin of potatoes. With these my three companions and I drank a fine viognier from Bonterra Vineyards ($43) in Mendocino, chosen from a lovely wine list that includes some 40 wines by the glass. 
There were less successful dishes, like a wild mushroom pot pie that was simply dull and an underseasoned lamb "osso buco" (a cross-cut of shank) with chickpea puree. And desserts were uneven: fresh doughnut holes -- served with hot chocolate that could have been thicker and richer -- were soggy and underdone. But a "salad" of cooked pear, fresh shortbread cookies and mint was original and successful. 

Alma
A nuevo-Latino restaurant whose food does not rely heavily on either sugar or chiles -- as so many do -- Alma seeks a balance between the nuevo and the Latino. Four ceviches -- fish marinated with acidic ingredients to "cook" it, served cold -- top the menu, and we ordered "un poco de todo," a sampling of scallops in a delicious sauce of cucumber and lemon spiked with palm oil; fine tuna with scallions and spicy coconut milk; squid and octopus in lime and squid ink; and striped bass with onions and orange. 
Of the first courses, a crab-and-corn flan with annatto cream and salsa verde was the most attention-grabbing: it was tender, subtle and devoured in three minutes. Spinach and queso blanco empanadas needed salt despite a complex chile sofrito; spinach salad was topped with crisp plantains and a sweet persimmon vinaigrette. 
Alma's wine list totals 40 bottles, drawn entirely from Iberia and former Iberian colonies. I enjoyed a full-bodied, rough-and-soft red from the Douro region of Portugal, the 1998 Quinta do Vale ($39).
Each of the four main courses we sampled had something to recommend it: a simple grilled pork chop was served with wonderful garlic-scallion mashed potatoes and a fiery jicama cabbage slaw; expertly seared local halibut was topped with irresistible slow-cooked onions; grilled hanger steak, served with a creamy gratin of potatoes and hearts of palm, sported a smoky bacon-chile sauce; and duck breast with sweet plantains had a rich, deep sauce of red wine and pomegranates, along with braised lacinato kale, a superior gardener's variety. Not that you will need them, but yucca fries, scented with cumin, are worth ordering. 
Desserts did not measure up: ice creams were rich and creamy, but chocolate jalapeno is an unsuccessful combination that I thought went out with 80's fusion. The cinnamon ice cream that accompanied a good apple crisp was delicious, but the crisp itself was unexciting, as was banana bread pudding. 
Alma's design is typical Mission, a mishmash of Western cliches: a cavernous space with white stucco walls in back washed blue in front, Moroccan blown-glass light fixtures, rustic wood trim and a Victorian mirror. Two huge windows provide a vista of the street scene. 

The Slanted Door
Despite being called a Vietnamese fusion restaurant, implying that it serves Westernized Vietnamese food, the Slanted Door in fact is similar to the best restaurants in Ho Chi Minh City. Its cuisine is modernized Vietnamese influenced by the more sophisticated cuisines of Thailand and China. 
The place looks good: like Andalu, it's narrow and deep, with a mezzanine section. The floors are cherry-stained; the bar is green wood, the tables faux marble. Although the Slanted Door looks informal, both service and the presentation of the food compare favorably with those of more expensive Asian restaurants. 
Along with Delfina, the Slanted Door is one of the first places in the Mission recommended to out-of-towners, and with good reason: the food is consistently fine. A shredded salad with green papaya, tofu, carrots and celeriac is flavored with a sweet-sour-hot dressing and rau ram, a Vietnamese herb not unlike cilantro; its flavors are clear and clean. Soup with won tons of shrimp and pork and fresh egg noodles is close to ideal, the stock flavorful and soothing, the won tons and noodles fresh, tender and tasty. And glass noodles (mung bean thread) with crab meat is subtle despite its flavoring of black pepper, garlic, nam pla (Southeast Asian fish sauce) and cilantro. Less exciting, but only by comparison, are daikon rice cakes with a good soy dressing; squid stir-fried with Thai basil and tofu; and shrimp with caramelized onions, a traditional Vietnamese dish. 
Here, too, desserts are not up to the rest of the food. With the exception of a creative and delicious jackfruit ice cream, I found them unexciting. 

Foreign Cinema
The best looking of this group of restaurants, Foreign Cinema is not just a good idea -- in its inner courtyard, old movies are projected onto a neighboring building -- but a good restaurant. New chefs -- John Clark and Gayle Pirie, a husband-and-wife team -- have boosted the level of the food considerably since I first ate there over a year ago. 
You enter through a long hallway, pass a couple of bars, then either walk directly into the courtyard, which has drive-in movie speakers set near the tables, or to the dining room and kitchen. The room is huge (the building once housed a department store), two stories high with windows overlooking the courtyard -- I caught glimpses of "Ivan the Terrible" while I ate -- a central fireplace and the projector-equipped mezzanine. Some tables are covered, others are polished black marble, with black chairs. It's a swank, swell place. 
Much of the food is very good but there are inconsistencies: cured sardines were magnificent, as was duck liver crouton with pear salad; eagerly anticipated beef tongue salad was left unfinished and pronounced unexciting. Super-garlicky brandade fared better; the top was nicely browned, and it was served with a few caper berries, a nice touch. Main courses varied. Sliced pork loin with lavender was sensational, and the accompaniments lavish: treviso (a kind of chicory), earthy mashed potatoes, wild mushrooms and bacon. Similarly winning was sea bass with fried potatoes, cranberry and green beans, a couple of pieces of artichoke, and two sauces, one green the other aioli -- talk about a plateful. But fettuccine with chanterelles, sage, squash, butter, pecorino and bread crumbs was muddy, even boring, and grilled steak with peppercorns not much better. 
Desserts displayed similar ups and downs. Lemon eclair with strawberries did not live up to its promise, but double chocolate ice cream was delicious; sorbets of Muscat grape and tangerine were creamy and intensely fruity; chocolate pot de creme was disappointing. 

Luna Park
A neon sign outside ("Luna Park -- Kitchen and Cocktails") signals this big open room with high ceilings, polished cement floor with area rugs, booths made of pews and the nearly requisite velvet curtains. The service is informal but professional, and youthful. You could think of it as a new-age diner, given the high-quality food that is anachronistically inexpensive. A small wine list -- about 40 bottles -- includes a smattering of French wines (I had a Bandol white for $20) along with those from California. 
My favorite dish was a "sandwich" of breaded pork cutlets stuffed with mushrooms and Gruyere, served with a pile of slender green beans, mashed potatoes with a hint of garlic, and fresh apple-cranberry sauce; obviously this isn't haute cuisine, but the combination was appealing. Whole sand dabs -- local flatfish -- were fried and served with a bearnaiselike sauce on a bed of spinach and roasted potatoes. Split, flattened and pan-grilled chicken -- crisp, tender and juicy -- came with grilled Brussels sprouts, a heaven-sent preparation. 
Desserts shine here. S'mores feature homemade graham crackers with a cup each of fudge and marshmallows sitting over individual candles; you combine them yourself. Bananas Foster -- caramelized bananas with banana ice cream and rum -- were a bit sloppy but delicious. And coconut cream pie was perfect.

Bill of fare: lively, eclectic
The Mission is a fairly large neighborhood, but the area under consideration here is small, bordered roughly by Guerrero to the west and Mission to the east, and running from about 16th to 23rd Streets; you can easily walk from place to place in 10 to 15 minutes.
The problem is getting there. If you are anywhere near a BART (subway) stop, there are stations on Mission at both 16th and 24th Streets. Driving isn't bad, but parking is; ask if a restaurant has valet parking. Cabs are not plentiful. 
All credit cards are accepted, except where noted below. Reservations are recommended, but at lunch you can just stroll in. Smoking is not permitted in California restaurants. 
Andalu, 3198 16th, at Guerrero; (415) 621-2211. Dinner only, closed Sunday. Dinner for two with wine, about $60. 
Alma, 1101 Valencia, near 22nd; (415) 401-8959. Dinner only, closed Sunday. MasterCard and Visa only. Ceviches about $4 each, four for $11; other starters are around $6, and most main courses $15 to $17. Dinner for two with wine, about $70. 
The Slanted Door, 584 Valencia, near 17th; (415) 861-8032. Lunch and dinner daily. Visa and MasterCard only. Dinner for two with wine, $75. 
Foreign Cinema, 2534 Mission, near 21st; (415) 648-7600. Dinner only, closed Monday. The film schedule is at www.foreigncinema.com. Valet parking, $8. Smoking is permitted in the courtyard except when it is covered by a tent (which it is from now until spring). Dinner for two with wine, $90. 
Luna Park, 694 Valencia, near 18th; (415) 553-8584. Lunch Monday through Friday, dinner nightly. With a $17 Trimbach pinot blanc, two could eat here for about $70. 
 MARK BITTMAN
