HEADLINE: Sitting Down With Frank Lloyd Wright 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE CURTIS; WAYNE CURTIS is a contributing editor at Preservation magazine.

 BODY:
IN the early 1940's the Iowa businessman Lowell Walter wrote to Frank Lloyd Wright asking that he design a home for him. Wright's reply -- in its entirety -- read: "My dear Mr. Walter: We will design a dwelling for you. Send further details. There will be no basement nor any attic."
 Wright's correspondence is now neatly encased behind glass at Cedar Rock, the home Wright eventually designed for Walter. And Wright's economical letter points up the aggravation of trying to get a grip on his genius. His structures, more than not, tend to be defined by what they lack. 
 No basement nor any attic, of course. But Wright's list of other taboos is legendary: no unsightly structural beams obstructing corner views, no bric-a-brac on shelves, no interior trim, no light fixtures hanging from the ceiling. ("Consider everything in the nature of a hanging fixture a weakness, and naked radiators an abomination.") No plastering, no paint, no gutters, no downspouts. No unneeded rooms, no unnecessary detail or ornament. Nothing in "pessimistic" blues or purples, and no colors from "the ribbon counter." No double hung windows. No interior doors and no garages. 
What's left? A Wright-fueled cultural-industrial complex manufactures increasingly lavish accounts of his legacy -- I recently saw a coffee table book large enough for a dining room table -- yet, for me at least, the Wright industry has long failed to answer that one simple question. 
So on a two-week road trip several years ago from the southern plains to New England, I plotted to visit as many Wright buildings as possible. With a copy of "Wright Sites," a handy guidebook published by the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy, I sketched out a Wright marathon from Oklahoma to New Hampshire. It would require stamina and good fortune (some places are open only a few days each month). Luck was with me. I managed to get inside 11 Wright homes and buildings, and saw another dozen or so from outside. 
Yet showing up on the doorstep of a Wright masterwork with tour ticket in hand turned out to be the easy part. Tours of many Wright buildings proved to be nearly as impenetrable as the coffee table books. I would be shown inside. I would briskly follow a guide who was impressively capable of walking, talking and pointing at the same time. Just as I was getting a dim sense of the place, the exit door would close behind me and I would find myself standing on a gravel walkway still spinning from the speed of the tour. I often left a Wright home with the same mental image I had earlier acquired from book and magazine photos.
Architectural historians note that Wright was famous for subtle sleights of hand, and I looked forward to being conned by these. For instance, he often obscured his entryways to force visitors to closely examine his houses before entering. He also cleverly manipulated interior spaces, making a room seem larger, for example, by obliging people to enter through a claustrophobic hallway. 
But on the tours we were usually led inside as a lowing herd, sometimes following an entrance sign hammered into the lawn. And any claustrophobia tended to come from the nearness of my fellow travelers, who pressed in from every direction no matter how large the space. 
Other distractions: There was the lady in the wide-brim straw hat at Fallingwater, Wright's renowned work in southwestern Pennsylvania, who inhaled theatrically each time she entered a room, giving rise to concerns that she was succumbing to advanced respiratory failure. There was the guide in Chicago who kept losing his patter and, after wandering silently for some seconds across the empty plains of his memory, would repeat a few sentences of his spiel to jump-start his recollection.
And then there were the blue paper booties. Twice we were asked to slip paper booties over our shoes, as if preparing to enter a silicon chip laboratory. This is all well in principle -- no one wants to muddy the floor -- but it added more than a paper's thickness of distance between me and the home. At Taliesin, Wright's home and studio in the verdant Wisconsin hills, I found myself warily edging across a highly polished stone floor as if on a moon walk, arms outstretched for balance yet mindful that I not touch the walls. In the weirdness of it all, the house got lost. 
My search for Wright evolved into something like the children's game of "getting warmer, getting colder." Most of the time, distracted by docents and other pilgrims, I felt as if I were getting colder. But during a few exceptional moments I thought I could feel Wright's breath on the back of my neck. 
At Taliesin, our group entered the extraordinary living room, a sort of laboratory where he tinkered with ideas that would become staples of modern home design. Here we were invited to sit in the original chairs as our guide described Wright's innovations -- his use of uneven stone on the walls, his selection of patterns in the carpet to echo the landscape outside. 
But the most lasting impression came when we were told how he had slyly enhanced the sense of overhead space: by lopping several inches off the legs of the Marshall Field's chairs in which we sat. In unison, we all looked up. Experiencing this was far more memorable than noting it from the far side of a red rope.
The Chicago suburb of Oak Park, Ill., serves as a sort of de facto Frank Lloyd Wright National Park -- it's home to Wright's first studio and more than two dozen early Wright buildings. The Wright Plus Housewalk, which allows visitors to see some of the interiors, is held here each year on the third Saturday in May. At any time of year, though, knots of visitors walk the streets with guidebooks, regarding the place with the sort of quiet reverence one might expect to witness in a redwood grove. 
At Unity Temple there, one of Wright's earliest and most audacious buildings, my self-guided tour featured a small tape player with headphones and a disembodied voice that ushered me from room to room. When in the heart of the temple, the voice instructed me to sit in a pew. And there I sat, while several minutes of Bach were piped through the headset, blessedly free of commentary, as the building performed its quiet magic. This was one of the highlights of my Wright expedition. (Alas, the tape has been discontinued in favor of printed handouts).
One of Wright's early Prairie-style homes in Oak Park, the Edwin H. Cheney House, is now a bed-and-breakfast, with three guest rooms. With my reservation in hand, I arrived early on a spring evening and was greeted by the innkeeper. I was the sole guest, and after showing me my room, he handed over the keys and left for a meeting. 
I wasted no time in undertaking a full reconnaissance of the home, striding through the rooms and consuming the place in huge, avaricious bites as I sought to inventory its distinctive features. Not 15 minutes had passed before I was beset by a sort of architectural indigestion, compounded by that unique numbness familiar to those who visit too many museums in too short a time.
Defeated, I made my way to the living room where there was a pool table and a radio. I found a blues station and turned it up. I shot several racks. And as the house faded into the background over the next couple of hours, something curious happened. It came into focus -- its perfect scale and proportions, its respectful use of natural materials, its impeccable design as a sort of Parthenon of modern living. The place felt tailored to my size and mood.
It was at that moment that I found what I was looking for: goose bumps, an homage to Wright's genius. 
Perhaps his greatest sleight of hand was making his houses resistant to tours and picture-taking and the nattering of guides. Wright designed them for living.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Pasadena

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN; RICK LYMAN is a cultural correspondent in the Los Angeles bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
That Pasadena is more than a sleepy haven for Midwestern transplants and middle-class commuters is pretty old news by now. The little old lady from Pasadena has grandchildren who are old ladies by now.
 Indeed, the renaissance that transformed the retail and dining strip along Colorado Boulevard into one of the most crowded and energetic night-life destinations in Southern California is well over a decade old, which puts this small, palm-lined city in the position of continually trying to reinvent itself, or at least find fresh ways to keep it buzzing. 
 The latest effort is a three-square-block development that opened in September called Paseo Colorado, a mix of retail, commercial and residential spaces along Colorado Boulevard between Marengo and Los Robles Avenues. Its Mediterranean theme is intended to complement the red-tile roofs and craftsman bungalows of the surrounding area. TrizecHahn, the designer, is also behind the recently opened Hollywood and Highland development several miles to the west in Hollywood. 
Paseo Colorado was billed as a nearly 13-acre urban village, a network of open-air walkways, fountained plazas and elegant staircases, with shops and restaurants lining secluded courtyards and storefronts. If the resulting complex feels a bit more suburban shopping mall than urban commercial strip, at least the project works as a magnet to extend the bustle of Colorado Boulevard a few blocks farther east. Its central design element, an open swath that carves the development in two, opens a wonderful esplanade connecting Pasadena's beautiful Beaux-Arts city hall with its stately Civic Auditorium a few blocks to the south.
If you ignore the clatter of skateboarders and the presence of standard-issue mall shops, Paseo Colorado can even act as a pleasant starting point for a meander through Old Pasadena, an eight-square-block area where tattoo parlors still sit alongside aromatic ethnic cafes and pricey boutiques. 

Events
The grand event on Pasadena's calendar remains the annual Tournament of Roses -- beginning at 8 New Year's morning with the Rose Parade through the center of the city and culminating with the Rose Bowl football game. The game is on Jan. 3 instead of Jan. 1 this time, because it is being played for the national college championship. A limited number of game tickets will go on sale Tuesday at 8 a.m. Pacific time through Ticketmaster, (213) 365-3550. They will cost $150 each and are limited to two a call. 
Tickets to the parade route's 125,000 grandstand seats are on sale through Sharp Seating, (626) 795-4171 ($35 to $80), and Marsden Brothers, (310) 454-3511 ($58 and $62). But it's also possible to claim a curbside spot on the parade route, which runs east along Colorado Boulevard from Orange Grove Boulevard through Old Pasadena to Sierra Madre Boulevard, where it veers north for a few blocks to its terminus at Villa Street. The trick is that city law prohibits staking a claim to a piece of the curb until noon on New Year's Eve (folding chairs and sleeping bags only), and some stretches fill up almost immediately. The Pasadena police operate a hot line, (626) 744-4598, about the rules and best tactics. From Dec. 28 to Jan. 3, information will also be available at (626) 793-9911. The theme of the 2002 parade will be "Good Times," with Regis Philbin as grand marshal. 
Of course, there is more to Pasadena than football and rose petals. The Pasadena Playhouse, a top regional theater, will present Neil Simon's "Biloxi Blues" from Jan. 11 to Feb. 24, followed by the Los Angeles premiere of David Hare's "Blue Room" March 8 to April 21. Tickets run $29.50 to $44.50 and can be ordered at (626) 356-7529. The playhouse, at 39 South El Molino Avenue, is just off the eastern edge of the Colorado strip; www.pasadenaplayhouse.org. 
The Pasadena Civic Auditorium's musical series will present the Moscow Classical Ballet's version of "The Nutcracker" from Dec. 19 to 23, followed from Jan. 30 to Feb. 3 by a dual production of "Swan Lake" and "Spartacus" by the Moscow Grigorovich Ballet. Tickets for "The Nutcracker" are $21 to $57, and for 'Swan Lake/Spartacus" $26.25 to $67, at www.pasadenamusicals.com and the auditorium, 300 East Green Street; (626) 449-7360. 

Sightseeing
The Colorado strip is bracketed by two of the region's most interesting museums. At the Pacific Asia Museum, 46 North Los Robles Avenue a half-block north of Paseo Colorado, (626) 449-2742 and at www .pacificasiamuseum.org, a show of hauntingly beautiful Japanese baskets, "Bamboo Masterworks From the Lloyd Cotsen Collection," runs through Jan. 13. But the small, slightly ramshackle museum has a fascinating permanent collection of Chinese ceramics, Southeast Asian and Indian sculpture, Buddhist art from the Himalayas and South Asia and Japanese decorative arts. General admission is $5, and it is open Wednesday through Sunday. 
The Norton Simon Museum, a much grander institution, sits on a gentle bluff about a mile to the west at 411 West Colorado Boulevard; (626) 449-6840, www.nortonsimon .org. An extensive and impressive remodeling of the galleries and gardens was completed in October 1999. The permanent collection features Old Masters, Impressionists and Southeast Asian art. Through Feb. 11, it also has "Pop Culture!" an exhibition of works by Warhol, Lichtenstein, Oldenburg and others. The museum is open every day but Tuesday. General admission, $6. 
One of the real jewels of Southern California, the breathtaking Huntington Library, Art Collections and Botanical Gardens, is a short drive to the southeast, at 1151 Oxford Road in the suburb of San Marino; (626) 405-2100, www.huntington.org. The nearly 150 acres of gardens contain more than 14,000 species of plants. The Huntington's art collection is home to Gainsborough's "Blue Boy," while its library displays a Gutenberg Bible from 1455 and the Ellesmere manuscript of "The Canterbury Tales" from 1410. General admission is $10. Closed Monday and holidays.
A few blocks north of downtown, the Gamble House, 4 Westmoreland Place, (626) 793-3334 and www .gamblehouse.org, is one of the finest examples of the American Arts and Crafts style. It was built in 1908 as the retirement home for David Berry Gamble, a scion of the Procter & Gamble fortune. Tours of the house, with its rich wood interiors, stained-glass windows and interlocked balconies, are given noon to 3 p.m. Thursday through Sunday. Tickets, sold from 10 a.m. (11:30 on Sunday), are $8, $5 for students and those over 65. 

Where to Stay
Those wishing to be close to the action in Old Pasadena can try the Sheraton Pasadena, 303 East Cordova Street, (626) 449-4000, fax (626) 584-1390, www.sheratonpasadena .com, about two blocks off Colorado Boulevard and not far from the new Paseo Colorado. The modern five-story hotel has 317 rooms in traditional decor, a heated outdoor pool, a tennis court, fitness room and business center. Double rooms start at $99 and run as high as $225 on the Club Level, which requires a key to access. 
Budget: The Econo Lodge Pasadena, 2860 East Colorado Boulevard, (626) 792-3700, fax (626) 792-0244, has 33 rooms on three floors. All rooms have a refrigerator. Rates start at $44, with a large room with a hot tub going for $79 or $89.
A few blocks closer to Old Pasadena is the Comfort Inn, 2462 East Colorado Boulevard, (626) 405-0811, fax (626) 796-0966, with 54 rooms on three floors wrapped around a lawn. The hotel also has an outdoor pool, hot tub and sauna. Doubles: $73 to $160 around New Year's.
Luxury: The Ritz-Carlton, Huntington Hotel and Spa, 1401 South Oak Knoll Avenue, (626) 568-3900, fax (626) 568-1842, www.ritzcarlton.com, is on a refurbished 1908 estate amid lush gardens. The 392-room hotel is vaguely like the biggest Mediterranean villa you've ever seen, except bigger. Doubles, decorated in traditional English style, start around $250, although the hotel also offers many discount packages with spa treatments, champagne and restaurant vouchers. Suites begin at $475. 
In South Pasadena, the Artists' Inn and Cottage is a bed-and-breakfast in a Victorian house and nearby cottage at 1038 Magnolia Street; (626) 799-5668, www.artistsinn.com. There is a full breakfast, of course, and tea and sweets at 4 p.m. Each of the nine rooms -- costing $115 to $205 -- has its own theme, either a specific artist (the Van Gogh Room is based on "Van Gogh's Bedroom") or a style (the Expressionist Suite "reflects the pure colors of Matisse, Picasso and Dufy"). 

Where to Eat
Pasadena has a lively, eclectic dining scene, with small, ethnic places tucked away here and there. An excellent example of the upscale storefront restaurant typical of the downtown district is Bistro 45, 45 South Mentor Avenue, (626) 795-2478, in a pretty Art Deco building a half-block south of Colorado Boulevard. It has a spare interior and simple white tablecloths in three inviting dining areas. The food is French bistro fare with California-style preparations. A popular appetizer is the crispy New Zealand calamari with a spicy red mustard dip ($8.45), and a popular main course is Canadian Duck Two Ways -- a leg confit and rare seared breast ($25.45). Dinner for two with wine is about $120. Closed Monday.
In a growing restaurant district along South Arroyo Parkway, the bustling Arroyo Chop House, 536 South Arroyo Parkway, (626) 577-7463, is the antithesis of light, fussy California fare. This steakhouse has big, modernist booths and hanging plants; it features large portions of prime aged beef, double-cut chops and huge lobsters. Dinner for two with wine is around $120. 
Yujean Kang's is one of the best Chinese places in the Los Angeles area. In a nondescript storefront just off Colorado Boulevard, at 67 North Raymond Avenue, (626) 585-0855, the small, unpretentious restaurant is frequently crowded with large families. Among the many popular appetizers is minced chicken in a lettuce cup ($6), and main courses include fresh fish sauteed in a spicy sesame sauce with asparagus ($15). Dinner for two with wine shouldn't cost more than $75.
In the heart of the Colorado Strip is the American-bistro-themed Cheesecake Factory, 2 West Colorado Boulevard, (626) 584-6000, part of an intensely popular Southern California chain (there can be long waits). Favorites on the eclectic menu include an avocado egg roll appetizer ($7.95) and the Cajun jambalaya pasta entree ($15.95). The 35 flavors of cheesecake start at $5.75 for a plain original slice and go up to $6.95 for one topped with fresh strawberries. Dinner for two with wine, about $65.
The Pie 'n Burger, 913 East California Boulevard, (626) 795-1123, an unadorned storefront a few blocks west of the California Institute of Technology, is essentially one long, undulating Formica counter facing a tiny kitchen and a line of milkshake and soda machines. Always crowded, it prides itself on its burgers (beef, chicken, turkey or vegetarian), chili, shakes and fresh pies. A hamburger costs $4.95; fruit pies are $2.75 a slice.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 49

LENGTH: 456 words

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z. 

 BODY:
When looking back at the end of a year, we usually regard the 12 months that have just passed as a series of momentous events, a parade of notable individuals or a gallery of compelling images. But these are not the only ways to capture the arc and rhythm of a year. For this special issue, The Times Magazine has chosen a different lens: ideas. Presenting 2001 as the latest volume in the encyclopedia of human innovation, "The Year in Ideas" offers not a summary of the year's major news stories but a catalog of 80 notions, inventions, conceptual swerves and philosophical leaps that mattered this year and may well continue to matter in years to come. 
 Of course, not every idea that makes its mark on a culture is necessarily a big one or a good one. (Remember supply-side economics? New Coke?) Certainly, 2001 is no different. It was a year that was marked both by advancements and by backward thinking, by major breakthroughs and by ephemeral obsessions. Our catalog trys to capture this variety. Frivolous ideas are given the same prominence as weighty ones; the diabolical sits side by side with the noble. 
In its attempt to chronicle our pell-mell culture in all its guises, this encyclopedia is far less august than its leather-bound forebears. (Thanks to some outlandish headline contortions, however, it is as alphabetically comprehensive as any Britannica.) The intention here was not to be authoritative; it was to recapture the childhood delight of paging through a World Book for the first time. Indeed, if you feel that some of the year's important ideas are missing from this catalog, you are probably right. At the same time, we would be surprised if you didn't encounter for the first time at least a dozen intriguing new ones.
Such a playful approach may seem like a strange way to document a year that has witnessed so much tragedy. Yet the grim events of this fall should not overshadow the many ways the human mind keeps pushing our world in bold new directions. A few years ago, at the height of the Internet boom, it became commonplace in Silicon Valley to believe that a single great idea could change the world. Even though our world has hardly turned out to be as utopian as those thinkers imagined, the Net prophets were definitely on to something. For ideas -- big and small, good and evil -- are the engines of history. They inspire progress and they justify cruel regimes. A new idea that permeates the culture can quicken the pulse of our daily lives; it can also bring that culture to a standstill. Indeed, a quick flip through this encyclopedia, we think, will make the case that 2001 was, for better or worse, a year bursting with ideas -- from noble to vulgar, from crucial to trivial, from A to Z.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Air Taxis

BYLINE:  By Richard Siklos

 BODY:
Even before the threat of terrorism made commercial flight in the United States a particularly anxious affair, frustration among business travelers over curbside congestion and flight delays was simmering. A growing number of affluent travelers -- mostly high-level executives -- were enjoying travel by private jet, and fractional ownership schemes were making the trend more affordable. In May, United Airlines surprised the aviation world by ordering 200 small jets and announcing plans to enter the fractional business itself. As one United executive put it at the time, "We had to do something -- our first-class cabins are emptying out." 
 United is not alone in pursuing the new small-plane, short-haul services dubbed "air taxis." Because of recent breakthroughs in the development of small, low-cost aircraft, a vast new network of air taxis could soon emerge for economy-class passengers as well. The author James Fallows made the case for the air-taxi idea in his book "Free Flight: From Airline Hell to a New Age of Travel," published in June. As Fallows explained, 98 percent of Americans live within a 30-minute drive of a small airport. The 5,400 best-equipped of these airstrips could handle 500 million takeoffs each year, yet currently they handle just 37 million. A new generation of small aircraft -- led by the Eclipse 500 jet -- should soon make air-taxi businesses operated out of these airfields economically feasible. Scheduled to make its debut in early 2004, the Eclipse 500 -- designed to take five passengers at 400 miles per hour -- is less than a quarter the price of a typical corporate jet. 
 After the Sept. 11 attacks, existing charter aircraft companies reported a burst in business. One proponent of next-generation air taxis, Richard Noble, recently told a trade publication: "The concept of the air taxi is more valid than ever. People want to travel with people they know. And these aircraft are too small to be dangerous." Richard Siklos

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
American Imperialism, Embraced

BYLINE:  By Kevin Baker

 BODY:
This year a new conservative movement, led by William Kristol's Project for the New American Century, formed around a single idea: support for a new, proud American imperialism. The debate on whether America is an imperial power is over, P.N.A.C.'s scholars insist; the American empire is real. The challenge now is to figure out what to do with it.
 "We had better get used to seeing ourselves as others see us," says Tom Donnelly, P.N.A.C.'s deputy executive director. "It doesn't matter if we don't consider ourselves an empire. Others see us as impinging on their lives, their space, their way of life. If we are going to protect our enduring interests, in the Middle East and elsewhere, then we have to do something about it." 
 So far, that something mostly boils down to spending more -- a lot more -- on the military. P.N.A.C. has deluged the Bush administration and Congress with articles and press releases calling for vast increases in the defense budget, and expressing suspicion about Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld's ideas on "reforming the military." They claim that military spending fell to less than 3.5 percent of the nation's gross domestic product during the Clinton years, "back to pre-World War II levels." The new imperialists would like it to return to its cold war average of 10 percent of G.D.P., increasing the defense budget by at least $75 billion to $100 billion per year.
"We'd better understand the full range of tasks we want our military to do, from Balkans-like constabulary missions to no-fly zones to maintaining enough big-war capacity," Donnelly contends. The P.N.A.C. wants it all -- a military that can confront China over Taiwan, throw up a missile defense, remove Saddam Hussein from power, fight two conventional wars at the same time and effectively hunt down terrorists, drug lords and guerrillas.
Donnelly refers longingly to the strategies and tactics of the old British Empire, back when it was policing the Raj and maintaining the Pax Britannica. But the American empire is different, he says, in that it holds no territorial ambitions. 
"The fundamental difference between America and other, past empires is that we don't issue writs in Washington that we expect others to follow," Donnelly says. Rather, our new manifest destiny is to disseminate our values. "We have seen the spread of liberty in our own country as our power spreads, as well as around the world," he says. "As we have grown more powerful, we have extended rights to women, to racial minorities, to everyone." These are the values -- along with free-market capitalism -- that the American empire should stand for, the new imperialists maintain.
In Afghanistan, Donnelly speaks of "economic development" and long-term diplomatic engagement aimed at "not just winning the war, but creating a stable peace." He rejects talk of an "easy-exit strategy" and demands that we commit American troops to a peace-keeping force and take the lead in building "some sort of state structure in Afghanistan." 
Historically, America's most ambitious imperialist projects have been undertaken during some of the more progressive periods in American history. Conservatives have generally been more skeptical of attempts to impress American values upon foreign nations. So it's no surprise that the debate over imperialism has exposed deep fissures in the national conservative movement. Donnelly's most intractable opposition comes from other conservatives -- including much of the administration's foreign policy establishment. Bush's foreign policy, after all -- at least prior to Sept. 11 -- has been based upon a partial global disengagement; a self-interested, "realistic" unilateralism. P.N.A.C.'s analysts criticize the "almost contemptuous rejection" with which the administration has backed out of international agreements.
Kristol sees domestic political advantage in the imperial strategy; in an essay, he and Robert Kagan promise that the new imperialism will make the Republican Party "once again the party of Reagan -- a party that stands for that 'distinctly American internationalism' that we believe a majority of Americans embrace." Kevin Baker

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
Using Forms Ingrained in Ballet To Help the Body Move Beyond It

BYLINE:  By ROSLYN SULCAS; Roslyn Sulcas's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about ballet dancers who go on working even in their spare time.

 BODY:
THE word "ballet" doesn't instantly come to mind when looking at the work of William Forsythe. The dancers of the Frankfurt Ballet, the company he has directed since 1984, move in undefinable ways, their bodies arcing and convulsing around invisible forms, their limbs swerving in contrary directions and their movements apparently refracted from one part of the body to another with no implicit reference to any predetermined dance vocabulary. Nonetheless, for many dance lovers, the American-born Mr. Forsythe is the choreographer who is most important to the present and future of ballet, because he has immeasurably enlarged our notions of what the art form can do both physically and theatrically. 
 This view holds more currency in Europe than in the United States, where the breadth of Mr. Forsythe's oeuvre is little known. The handful of his ballets -- "In the Middle, Somewhat Elevated," "The Second Detail," "Herman Schmerman," "The Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude" -- that are scattered through the repertories of almost every major ballet company in the world offer one particular aspect of his work; they are what Mr. Forsythe refers to as the "ballet ballets." 
 Mr. Forsythe studied at the Joffrey Ballet School in New York after attending Jacksonville University in Florida and danced briefly in the Joffrey corps before joining the Stuttgart Ballet in 1973, at age 23. He has lived in Germany ever since, making his first ballets for Stuttgart under Marcia Haydee's direction and becoming the company's resident choreographer, then leaving in 1980 to pursue a freelance career. While some early ballets for Stuttgart and the Joffrey Ballet were seen in New York in the late 70's and early 80's, Mr. Forsythe's ground-breaking works for the Frankfurt Ballet have been presented in this country only on tours in 1987 and 1988, and in 1998 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Beginning on Friday and continuing through Dec. 20, the Frankfurt Ballet returns to the Academy to perform three works -- "Enemy in the Figure," "Quintett" and "Woolf Phrase" -- that encompass the last 13 years of Mr. Forsythe's career and demonstrate something more of the breadth of his canon.
Made in 1989, "Enemy in the Figure" uses balletic lines and is set to a ticking, brooding score by Thom Willems, the Dutch composer who has collaborated with Mr. Forsythe since 1985, playing an important role in his artistic development. Like "In the Middle, Somewhat Elevated," which Mr. Forsythe created for the Paris Opera Ballet two years earlier, "Enemy in the Figure" evokes the contemporary dynamism and aesthetic of George Balanchine's plotless, pared-down "leotard" ballets, pushed to new extremes. But the work, largely performed off point, takes ballet further by incorporating some of the compositional techniques that Mr. Forsythe and his dancers were starting to develop in the course of creating new work.
One of these is called "isometries," which Mr. Forsythe described as "learning to develop a feeling for transferring the shape or form of one part of the body to another part, so, for example, the curve of an arm might be translated onto the whole body or the line between waist and neck." In "Enemy in the Figure," the dancers move in angled, disjointed configurations, their ballet-trained limbs mutating into entirely unexpected shapes, their bodies appearing as polyphonous instruments that can generate movement from any point, rather than taking impetus (as ballet teaches) from the legs and arms around a vertical body.
But the steps are only part of the picture. The work is also thrillingly, wildly theatrical. Making use of an undulating wooden screen positioned diagonally across the stage, a rope that pulses irregularly across the floor and a floodlight on wheels that is guided by the dancers, Mr. Forsythe creates a dark and mesmerizing poem about vision and perception, form and chaos, with remarkable economy of means. "The rolling light happened to be onstage from an opera production when we were rehearsing," he said recently. "It turned out to be an interesting way of manipulating the space, and of revealing and concealing the dancers. It's not always obvious: sometimes light can conceal by illuminating something so brightly that other things are obscured by contrast." 
In "Enemy in the Figure," the lighting (which Mr. Forsythe designs for all his work) is an explicit visual element, analogous to decor or props and as integral to the ballet as the steps. His interest in lighting and how he deploys it to carve out theatrical space is new in ballet and has exerted an enormous influence on a generation of choreographers, particularly in Europe.
YET in "Quintett," from 1993, the dancing is paramount and shows further developments in Mr. Forsythe's choreographic style. To a haunting score by Gavin Bryars, the dancers move on unsteady, buckling limbs, their movements dissolving into and collapsing upon one another in a poignant series of encounters and solos. Their swooping, liquid movements are the result of techniques that trace a muscular process as it passes through the body: here, balletic form is visible but the steps themselves are not, as if their dynamics have been erased, leaving mere vestiges of their shapes. The removal of the physical dominance that ballet technique offers engenders a curious sense of vulnerability that has much to do with the context of the ballet's creation: Mr. Forsythe made it for his terminally ill wife, the dancer Tracey-Kai Maier, "as a kind of love letter that she never saw; she was too ill." (Ms. Maier died of ovarian cancer in 1994; she was 32.)
Mr. Forsythe reaches into what might be called the balletic unconscious in "Quintett," moving his dancers' bodies around the idea of codified ballet steps ("tracing a space around an arabesque rather than doing the arabesque," he offered as an example), creating startlingly complex interactions between dancers that often appear to defy physical logic.
In the recently created duo "Woolf Phrase," Mr. Forsythe constructed the dance passages (which are interspersed with spoken text from Virginia Woolf's "Mrs. Dalloway") "around the rhythm of Woolf's language." Here, his engagement with the language of ballet appears even more distant. "There isn't a real ballet step in it," he said. "But it does require a ballet technique." Epaulement, the alignment of head, shoulders and hips that is crucial to ballet, Mr. Forsythe said, "has to be in the hands and head."
As Mr. Forsythe suggests by these comments, his current engagement with the language of classical dance is much looser and less recognizable than it has been in the past. But all of his work retains a deep structural relationship to that form: his development of a distinctive movement vocabulary has emerged directly from his original balletic orientation. Thinking beyond ballet's means of carving out shapes in space, Mr. Forsythe used what he knew to make his dances.
The art of ballet is recombinatory: Mr. Forsythe's simple and profound insight is that the elements can be put together in unforeseen ways. "I use ballet dancers and the knowledge in their bodies," he said. "When you speak about the vocabulary of classical dance, you're talking about ideas." Those ideas are always present in his work, even when their physical enactment is not.

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
A World Tour With Pina Bausch as Guide

BYLINE:  By JACK ANDERSON 

 BODY:
PINA BAUSCH has been choreographing travelogues.
 That may seem a strange thing to say about this intensely serious exponent of the neo-expressionist form of German dance known as Tanztheater, a choreographer known for works showing men and women engaged in endless power struggles. 
 Ms. Bausch is still interested in power struggles. But for slightly more than a decade, she has also created what can be called choreographic travelogues, some with power struggles in them. Last month, during the 2001 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, her Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch offered "Masurca Fogo" ("Fiery Mazurka"), which was inspired by Portugal, as well as by Brazil and Cape Verde, countries once controlled by Portugal. 
The first travelogue New Yorkers saw was "Palermo Palermo," an evocation of Palermo, Sicily, which came to the Academy in 1991. Five years later the American West, and California in particular, served as source material for "Nur Du" ("Only You"), which she showed in America only in Western cities. "Der Fensterputzer" ("The Window Washer"), inspired by Hong Kong, was danced at the Academy in 1997. Like most of Ms. Bausch's pieces, the travelogues are collages of movement and speech to taped collages of popular and classical music.
Artists, including choreographers, are often stimulated by specific places. And local cultural organizations frequently commission works from visiting artists. But contracts seldom require such creations to be about those places. Ms. Bausch's travelogues both concern a specific region and are sponsored by organizations in that region. "Masurca Fogo," for instance, was a co-production involving EXPO Lisbon 98 and the Goethe-Institut Lisbon, while "Nur Du" was made possible by universities in California, Arizona and Texas.
Some dancegoers might wonder if these commissions simply provide ways for Ms. Bausch to take her company globetrotting. But whatever the motivations for devising them may be, these productions have genuine artistic substance.
Ms. Bausch has become the choreographic equivalent of a travel essayist. Visiting places, she does not merely describe their attractions, as a guidebook might. Nor does she glamorize them in the manner of those old Hollywood movie shorts in which, as the sun sank in Technicolor splendor, smiling natives danced blissfully away, oblivious to all social and economic problems. Instead, Ms. Bausch choreographically comments on places in her own idiosyncratic manner.
The often bleak "Palermo Palermo" began with the startling image of a collapsing wall, as if to point out that the Sicilian city of Palermo, although rich in art and history, is also a gritty place with highly visible rubble. Contrasts in costuming between stark black clothes and fancy attire suggested extremes of poverty and wealth. And quarrels between men and women indicated that Ms. Bausch can find struggles everywhere.
Men and women got along (or failed to get along) in peculiar ways in "Nur Du," which I saw in Berkeley, Calif. Lovers taunted one another. A woman kept pouring water into the plastic bag her male partner wore over his head. A man and woman embraced in a chair with a lighted stick of dynamite beneath it. But both the dynamite and the love affair fizzled.
Such emotional complications had their genuinely humorous aspects. So, too, "Der Fensterputzer" and "Masurca Fogo" emphasized a comic strain that has never been totally absent from Ms. Bausch's choreography, although it can be obscured by a prevailing somberness.
"Nur Du" depicted California. Yet Ms. Bausch avoided the strident California-bashing to which some intellectuals are prone. Of course, she recognized how odd California can be. Scenes in which dancers kept taking off their clothes to gaze at their bodies with pleasure or horror mocked the obsession with physical fitness shared by many Californians. A man in a dress flounced and preened as if he were pining to be a glamorous movie star. Another man portrayed a transvestite hairdresser obviously bored by the women who came to his beauty salon.
Ms. Bausch was often poking fun. Yet her jokes seemed more affectionate than scathing. And the work's final solo suggested genuine compassion for unfortunate people. The eloquent choreography showed a man lurching about, frantically waving his arms like the wings of a fatally wounded bird. This male dying swan could symbolize all emotionally wounded mortals.
MUCH of "Die Fensterputzer" appeared festive. The stage was covered with red flowers and dancers tossed them into the air to suggest fireworks displays. Slide projections of a city skyline and bustling ensemble choreography celebrated the energy of a great metropolis. 
That metropolis was Hong Kong, a city that has experienced political transition. No one can predict what may happen next there. Appropriately enough, therefore, Ms. Bausch devised some ominous scenes. A man ran like a desperate fugitive. Later, a man trying to pass through a metal detector kept setting off alarms while stern inspectors had him remove his clothes, item by item, until the offending metal object was found: a filling in a tooth. Yet Hong Kong is not the world's only city in which there may be fugitives or security problems. And the overall tone of "Die Fensterputzer" was just genial enough to make one suspect that Ms. Bausch is cautiously optimistic about Hong Kong and, possibly, other troubled cities.
As for the new "Masurca Fogo," it was, at least for Ms. Bausch, almost unabashedly sensual. It did have its unnerving moments: for instance, a scene in which a man forced a woman's head into a basin and had her pick up fruit with her teeth. More often, however, "Masurca Fogo" affirmed eroticism. One performer told a corny dirty joke in English, the dance sequences were usually vigorous and a samba blazed with choreographic heat.
Yet moralist that she is, Ms. Bausch warned that passion can be threatening as well as liberating and that the senses have their dangers as well as their delights. Remarkably realistic films of a violent storm at sea were reminders that great natural forces of all kinds can get out of control. During the conclusion, dancers were curled up onstage, as if asleep, while films were projected showing enormous flowers opening and closing. The flowers, though lushly beautiful, were so huge that they appeared to engulf the dancers, just as people can be overwhelmed by erotic desires.
The fact that the travelogues since "Palermo Palermo" have grown generally lighter in tone prompts a few speculations. Has Ms. Bausch somehow come to feel that she must be softhearted out of politeness to the organizations and localities that sponsor her pieces? Or is she really mellowing?
The quirkiness of her travelogues surely indicates that she has not become a booster allied with any community's Chamber of Commerce. Rather, these works imply that Ms. Bausch is an inquisitive traveler who looks around her, fascinated by what she sees, and filters these sights through her artistic sensibility. 
Because, like all travelers, she brings her own intellectual baggage with her, she may inevitably remain preoccupied with power struggles. Yet her concern for the follies and foibles of places as dissimilar as Portugal and China may have broadened her sympathies. She can still castigate cruelty, but she appears willing both to smile a little and to weep a bit at certain manifestations of human foolishness. Traveling around the world, she finds streets everywhere littered with broken hearts. She sighs over some of them. But she choreographically turns others into funny Valentines.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Philadelphia Gets A New Concert Hall A Century Aborning

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
FIVE days, more or less, until the opening of a new hall for the Philadelphia Orchestra, but who's counting?
 Well, in a city that time often seems to have forgotten, the countdown began some 34,000 days ago -- before Wolfgang Sawallisch, Riccardo Muti, Eugene Ormandy and Leopold Stokowski -- in 1908, when Karl Pohlig was the orchestra's music director. It was proposed then, as it has been many times since, that the orchestra, founded in 1900, should vacate the Academy of Music, built in 1857, in favor of a hall with adequate symphonic acoustics. 
 The modern push began in 1986, when the orchestra announced a project for a new hall and set about raising money, with an eventual goal of $140, million to finance it. It selected a site on South Broad Street, a block from the academy. The campaign limped along for almost a decade with waning support and with little enthusiasm for a design presented by Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown in 1987. 
"There's a long list of reasons the hall never happened," said Joseph H. Kluger, who became the orchestra's executive director in 1989 and its president in 1991. "We originally tried to go without support from the public sector. We arrogantly made the statement that we could do it all on our own. The original project was led by a small group of corporate leaders who were not successful at building consensus."
In 1995, after fund-raising leveled off at about $100 million, Edward G. Rendell, then the mayor of Philadelphia, stepped in. He galvanized public and private support as part of his effort to revitalize the city's center and create an Avenue of the Arts on South Broad Street, near City Hall. The next year, the Regional Performing Arts Center was formed to take over the hall project, which, in a new, grander design by Rafael Vinoly, grew to include a second theater and sizable public spaces all under a big glass barrel vault.
The regional center has almost finished raising the money, now $265 million, and constructing the building, the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, named for Sidney Kimmel, who made the largest single donation, some $30 million. Along with the 2,500-seat Verizon Hall, intended for the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Philly Pops and visiting attractions, it includes the 650-seat Perelman Theater, to accommodate chamber music, dance, drama and other presentations. The public spaces include a roof garden, atop the smaller hall but protected from the weather by the glass vault.
Verizon Hall opens on Friday with a gala variety show featuring the Philadelphia Orchestra only peripherally. The orchestra plays a program conducted by its music director, Mr. Sawallisch, on Saturday. And on Sunday the center presents a daylong open house, billed as the official opening.
A considerable obstacle in all of this was that grand old hall, the 2,900-seat academy, which for many is the most beloved building in all of Philadelphia. With its gas lamps on a noble exterior and its warm, plush interior, it is lovely to the eye (as those who saw it in the film "The Age of Innocence" may recall). It is even adequate to some musical purposes: opera, for example, for which it was designed. But for an orchestra -- for the orchestra, that is, one of the city's leading cultural institutions and long one of the finest ensembles anywhere -- playing onstage, it has never afforded an adequate acoustical environment.
Despite some $30 million in recent improvements, the sound that finds its way across the proscenium is muffled -- blanketed, it can seem -- and wildly uneven. Sections, even individual instruments, jut out angularly where blend is needed. Musicians and critics have said as much for decades, yet even now, many in Philadelphia disagree.
"When Ormandy was the music director, no one complained about the acoustics," said Leonore Annenberg, who, with her husband, former Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg, has contributed many millions of dollars to the orchestra, much of it earmarked for the academy. "My ear is not attuned so finely, but I can never understand what they're talking about. The academy's acoustics are fine."
Other longtime supporters of the orchestra were also slow to support the project, though not necessarily for the same reasons. "Our concern from Day 1 was never about whether we needed a new hall," said Rebecca W. Rimel, the president of the Pew Charitable Trusts in Philadelphia. "Everybody agrees we do. The issue, and I'm sure I became boring on the subject, was what we could afford: if we build it, will they come, and can they pay for it?"
Indeed, despite turning responsibility for the project over to the center, the orchestra has had its financial ups and downs in recent years. It is running a $4 million deficit for the current fiscal year -- caused partly by expenses involved in the move -- on a budget of $35 million. But it has an endowment of $75 million and expects a net increase in revenue of $2 million a year with the new hall. This is to be accomplished, despite a drop of 400 in seating capacity, largely by raising ticket prices for the best seats.
"We are confident, while not cocky, about the future," said Richard L. Smoot, the chairman of the board. "The net worth of the orchestra continued to rise through the 1990's. Musically, we're in great shape, and there is a lot of energy going into dealing with the current challenges."
In any case, there was never a plan to jettison the academy, which has long been overcrowded with events. Opera, ballet and touring attractions have competed for whatever scraps of performance and rehearsal time the orchestra has left unfilled. The last of the current round of renovations is still to come: raising the roof above the stage to accommodate trappings for Broadway-style shows, for another $10 million.
Although the orchestra is to retain ownership of the academy, it, too, will be managed by the regional center. The orchestra plans to use it only for the annual ball celebrating the anniversary of the building, a highlight of the Philadelphia social season.
Might problems of access arise for an orchestra accustomed to first claim on its own building now that another agency sets the terms for it and other constituents? Almost inevitably.
"It's a big source of negotiation," said Leslie Anne Miller, the regional center's president. "The framework is built in, but as in any marriage, we will have work to do. Getting the agreements signed has been a tough process, but it will pale in relation to working out living arrangements."
Yet almost by definition, the issue that more than any other engages the imagination of the audience as well as the orchestra is acoustics. The acoustics of the new hall are the province of Russell Johnson of Artec Consultants, which has met with acclaim for concert halls in Dallas, Birmingham, England, and elsewhere. Mr. Johnson does not subscribe to the theory of venerable auditoriums like Carnegie Hall or Symphony Hall in Boston that one acoustic fits all.
"We know and everybody knows that if you build a concert hall today, you're going to have amplified rock, dance, string quartets and chorus," he said. "Even the symphony orchestra today plays a fascinating variety of music and is broadening the kind of music it is programming."
He therefore builds variability into his schemes: in this case, there are reverberation chambers from floor to ceiling that can be opened or closed, systems of fabric in the hall and in the chambers that can be deployed or retracted, and a stage canopy that can be raised or lowered. This is a complex and mildly controversial matter. Just how practical some of the adjustments are is open to question. Musicians are often loath to spend the time and effort needed to experiment with a wide variety of settings to achieve a desired result -- and a highly specific one: Mr. Johnson suggests that acoustics might be tailored even to individual pieces within a single program and adjusted accordingly.
"The average music director is not deeply fascinated," he admitted, "but once he hears what can be achieved. . . ." Until convinced, many musicians would be likelier to do what they have always done -- adjust their own sound to suit the circumstances -- than to toy with the acoustics.
Indeed, this is an issue with particular resonance here, for there is every reason to believe that the vaunted Philadelphia sound -- the warmth and richness that have prevailed through so much of the orchestra's history, especially in the strings -- is largely a product of the academy's acoustic deficiencies. The players have had to dig into their instruments and project to the audience simply to make themselves heard. Transfer that sound to a hall like Carnegie, and the results can be overwhelmingly rich and reverberant.
None of which is reason enough to continue to live with wretched acoustics. But there is a question of how the orchestra's sound may change in its new home.
Mr. Sawallisch does not seem unduly worried. He attributes the Philadelphia sound mostly to the ability of the players to hear one another, which allows for a "personal touch" in their interactions. It is certainly true that the best sound in the academy is not in the house but onstage.
"At the academy, the orchestra onstage can hear each other very well," Mr. Sawallisch said. If that remains true in the new hall -- and there are cautionary examples of halls in which the audience hears well but the orchestra does not -- he expects no diminution in the Philadelphia sound.
The classic model for a hall with excellent acoustics has been a shoe-box shape. (But it is far from infallible, as concertgoers at Avery Fisher Hall know too well.)
"We wanted to obliterate the shoe box," said Willard G. Rouse III, the chairman of the Regional Performing Arts Center, "but we couldn't, for acoustical reasons."
They at least modified it. From the time the new design was first presented, the publicity has pointed out that the shape of the auditorium, softened with curves, was like that of the body of a cello.
Why a cello? "It's not a cello," Mr. Vinoly, the architect, said unromantically. "It's a room, but a room rethought as an instrument, another version of a box but much more intimate than a formal shoe box. There are essentially no straight lines."
In this matter, as in many others, architect and acoustician do not necessarily agree, and Mr. Johnson holds to the fanciful notion of a cello, as unpredictable as the results may be. "Will the cello be a problem?" he asked. "I don't know yet."
The new hall will have a pipe organ, the dream, it seems, of every European conductor and many others. For the moment it is merely a facade, but by 2005, it will be a large Dobson instrument. An organ, conventional wisdom holds, can only enhance the acoustics of any hall. As so often, Mr. Johnson rejects convention.
"We started from the notion that a concert hall really should have a pipe organ, and we accepted what comes with it," he said. "In complex structures, sound is absorbed and energy is lost. An organ will take the basic numbers down a notch" -- a crucial number being reverberation time. The problem is obviously not insurmountable, however, for many of the finest halls have organs.
WHEN all such matters are attended to, even the best acoustical design can suffer from faulty execution, as Carnegie Hall learned forcibly in 1995, when it was discovered that a layer of deadening concrete had inadvertently been left right under the stage floor in the renovation of 1986. As it happened, when a reporter visited the very much unfinished Verizon Hall a month before the opening, the stage floor was being nailed down, plank by plank.
No concrete, surely? "Concrete is absolutely there," Mr. Johnson said, and sure enough, a layer of white was partly visible. But a grid of boards placed edgewise between it and the actual stage floor allowed for almost six inches of crucial air space above it.
Now, assuming that a great deal of finishing has been done since then, all that remains is to give the hall a road test.
"The most amazing thing," said Mr. Vinoly, whose experience with concert halls and the primacy of acoustics has been limited, "is that these things are made or broken in one night." In this case, a night a week or so from now, putting a sudden end to an excruciatingly long wait.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Dropper Popper

BYLINE:  By Jaime Wolf

 BODY:
This is the toy for the ex-dot-com millionaire reduced to living in his mother's basement. This is the toy you can keep on your desk to remind you of the quality of resilience in hard times. This is the Austerity Toy. 
 Simply speaking, the Dropper Popper is half a rubber ball. Imagine an old-fashioned Spalding handball hacked down the center with a machete. You may ask what you can do with such a thing. The ingenious, counterintuitive and deeply pleasurable answer is this: you bounce it. 
 Turning the half-ball inside out produces a slightly deformed, near hemispherical shape. (See illustration above.) The rubber's desire to return to its original form creates a high surface tension and structural instability. When you then drop the half-ball onto a flat surface, hollow-side down, the inverted part pops back out, slams into the floor and causes the toy to bounce high into the air.
An introductory physics textbook can provide a technical explanation, involving potential mechanical energy, of how exactly the Dropper Popper works -- and why it actually bounces higher in the air than the distance from which it is dropped. No science, however, can adequately account for the surprise and delight produced each time by the phenomenon of bouncing half a ball.
The Dropper Popper is sold in the United States by Petra, a company best known for importing wooden toys from Europe. Made from a rubber compound in marbleized color schemes (orange and yellow; black and blue), it is sold here for $3.50 at Kar'ikter, a shop with branches in New York City and San Francisco that specializes in toys and gadgets exemplifying modern design.
In these depressed economic times, the Dropper Popper is both a toy and a symbol. Of course we will bounce back. Sometimes, it seems, half a ball is better than one. Jaime Wolf

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Global-Warming Lawsuits

BYLINE:  By Stephen Mihm

 BODY:
Imagine for a moment that you're a citizen of Tuvalu, an island nation in the South Pacific. Your home will soon disappear beneath the waves, an early casualty of rising sea levels linked to global warming. The people largely responsible for your plight -- the oil-burning, carbon-dioxide-spewing citizens of the United States -- are thousands of miles away and show no signs of lending a hand. What do you do? A growing number of environmental advocates, alarmed by the Bush administration's repudiation of the Kyoto Protocol, have this advice: take 'em to court. 
 The idea of filing lawsuits to recover damages from emissions of carbon dioxide is the brainchild of Andrew Strauss, a professor of law at Widener University in Wilmington, Del. In a controversial paper delivered this summer at a conference in London, Strauss explored the "litigation possibilities" for filing suit against the United States. Though Strauss is the first to admit that there are serious obstacles to bringing such a case, the mounting evidence that global warming is a real and present danger has lent momentum to his idea. 
 There are plenty of candidates for the role of plaintiff: countries as diverse as Bangladesh, the Netherlands and China will suffer if sea levels rise. But as Strauss notes, finding aggrieved parties won't be a problem; what will be difficult is finding a court willing to take the case. After all, it's not clear what court would have jurisdiction over such a novel proceeding. International law is famously complex and has never handled anything on this economic scale.
Nevertheless, Strauss has a few proposals. One promising avenue, he thinks, would be for the plaintiff nations to file a case before the International Court of Justice, the legal arm of the United Nations. There's only one hitch: typically, the court can hear the case only with the assent of the accused nation. More promising, perhaps, is for the General Assembly to ask the U.N. court for an "advisory opinion," a decision that is not legally binding but would give environmentalists a public-relations victory. The battle over global warming, Strauss explains, "is a battle in the court of public opinion, so such a decision would strengthen your negotiating position." 
Another option is to force the United States before the World Trade Organization. Countries that abide by the Kyoto Protocol could argue, with some legitimacy, that the cheap-energy policies of the United States constitute an unfair competitive advantage. Affected countries could then impose so-called countervailing duties on goods made here. The U.S. would then have to go before the W.T.O. to try and have the duties removed, forcing a potentially embarrassing hearing that might not work out in its favor.
Strauss doesn't expect immediate success. "There will be different generations of this litigation as it unfolds," he says. But as the world becomes increasingly entwined with international legal tribunals, courts and binding treaties, it may one day become difficult for one country to wreak environmental havoc on the rest without paying a price. Should that come to pass, no country -- not even America -- will be able to live as an island unto itself. Stephen Mihm

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Nonromantic Dating

BYLINE:  By Susan Dominus 

 BODY:
Since the code of courtly love swept through 12th-century France, romance has been understood to entail a certain amount of languishing, anguishing and wallowing. Perhaps it is that culturally ingrained expectation of pain that has allowed the current system of dating (and dumping) to persist without rival for this long. But this year, signs have begun to emerge that our idea of romance, with all its attendant anxiety, is finally facing competition from more practical models of courtship. 
 Rabbi Yaacov Deyo of Los Angeles has trademarked the concept of Speed Dating, evenings in which singles spend seven minutes talking to a potential date before a bell rings, at which point they move on to the next prospect. Singles are instructed to use those precious minutes to discuss meaningful topics (career choice doesn't count; CD and movie preferences do). After each speed date, the daters note their interest -- yes or no -- on a piece of paper they'll turn in at the evening's close. If there's nervous waiting by the phone, it lasts only a day, at which point the suitors receive official phone calls letting them know who is interested. 
 It's all about as romantic as a job fair, but then, seeking serendipity can be tiresome, too. Let the die-hard romantics peruse the crowds at museums and bookstores and dinner parties, waiting like very patient tornado chasers for lightning to strike -- Speed Dating self-selects for the pragmatists, the sober realists, the people who want to see the numbers working for them. Once a social curiosity, Speed Dating has expanded this year into a full-fledged industry, with more than 30 new spinoffs working to maximize their clients' romantic chances -- in some cases by reducing all that endless chitchat down to an economical three minutes.
Just as Speed Dating was taking off among Jewish singles, young Christians in conservative circles were developing their own alternative to romance. Known as courtship, it might also be described as the hunch-based marriage track: once two singles of passing acquaintance sense they're well suited, they agree to pursue a relationship, meaning they'll see each other more frequently in groups and in the company of their parents. The declared intention, all along, is to wed, but until they exchange vows, they're forbidden temptations like hand holding, much less soulful walks on the beach or candlelit dinners. 
Speed Dating tries to maximize the number of intimate investigations over the course of an evening, while courtship, ideally, narrows that number down to one over the course of a lifetime. What the two systems share is an effort to manipulate the odds, instead of hoping for giddy happenstance, in the pursuit of a soul mate. SUSAN DOMINUS

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Positive Asymmetry

BYLINE:  By Todd Lappin 

 BODY:
The United States defense establishment has awakened to an unsettling paradox. America's military power vastly outstrips that of most potential adversaries, but unrivaled military superiority does not make the U.S. invulnerable to attack. Instead, Pentagon planners now realize, conventional military dominance only encourages potential adversaries to look for "asymmetrical" ways to neutralize our strengths by exploiting our vulnerabilities. 
 The events of Sept. 11 -- in which a handful of hijackers armed with box cutters transformed several civilian airliners into precision guided missiles -- provided a horrific testament to the destructive power of asymmetric threats. In response, some national-security experts now argue that the U.S. should take advantage of all the resources -- military and civilian -- that can be brought to bear as part of a broader national-security policy designed to halt the spread of terrorism. The challenge, in other words, is to fight an asymmetrical foe asymmetrically by using those U.S. assets that can best undermine the social, cultural and economic factors that foment extremism. 
 In a paper published earlier this year, Steven Metz, chairman of the regional strategy and planning department of the U.S. Army War College Strategic Studies Institute, defined this policy as "positive asymmetry," or "using differences to gain an advantage." In the current conflict in Central Asia, we have several nonmilitary assets that could play a significant role in shaping the outcome of the campaign.
The most obvious of these is food. Given the agricultural bounty of the American heartland -- and the chronic food shortages that plague Afghan and Pakistani refugee camps -- the United States could use food in Central Asia as a powerful weapon to demonstrate our commitment to humanitarian values. A massive operation designed to inundate the region with American-grown rice and wheat could save lives, win hearts and minds and alter fragile allegiances in America's favor.
Wealth is another asymmetrical asset. As the richest country in the world, the U.S. can always throw money around; in Central Asia that might mean buying the allegiance of opportunistic regional foes. "This is a war where simply buying off a few warlords may be cheaper and much more effective than launching Tomahawk missiles at them," says Peter Singer, a military-affairs analyst at the Brookings Institution. "We certainly have the budget to pay more than the Taliban can."
Hollywood can be enlisted to join the campaign. Though American cultural hegemony is often a source of resentment in the Middle East, Hollywood filmmakers are extremely adept at manipulating images to capture the attention of a global audience. Those skills can be used to buff up America's image in hostile parts of the world.
Positive asymmetry means enlisting not just armed soldiers but also a broad cross section of America's best and brightest -- including Iowa farmers, Wall Street financiers and Tinseltown producers -- to contribute to the war on terrorism. TODD LAPPIN

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Precautionary Principle

BYLINE:  By Michael Pollan 

 BODY:
New technologies can bring mankind great benefits, but they can also cause accidental harm. How careful should society be about introducing innovations that have the potential to affect human health and the environment? For the last several decades, American society has been guided by the "risk analysis" model, which assesses new technologies by trying to calculate the mathematical likelihood that they will harm the public. There are other ways, however, to think about this problem. Indeed, a rival idea from Europe, the "precautionary principle 2/3" has just begun making inroads in America. 
 The problem with risk analysis, which came out of the world of engineering and caught on during the late 70's, is that it hasn't done a very good job predicting the ecological and health effects of many new technologies. It is very good at measuring what we can know -- say, the weight a suspension bridge can bear -- but it has trouble calculating subtler, less quantifiable risks. (The effect of certain neurotoxins on a child's neurological development, for example, appears to have more to do with the timing of exposure than with the amount.) Whatever can't be quantified falls out of the risk analyst's equations, and so in the absence of proven, measurable harms, technologies are simply allowed to go forward. 
 In Europe, a different approach has taken hold. When Germany, for example, discovered in the 70's that its beloved forests were suddenly dying, there was not yet scientific proof that acid rain was the culprit. But the government acted to slash power-plant emissions anyway, citing the principle of Vorsorge, or "forecaring." Soon, Vorsorgeprinzip -- the forecaring, or precautionary, principle -- became an axiom in German environmental law. Even in the face of scientific uncertainty, the principle states, actions should be taken to prevent harms to the environment and public health. 
Germany's idea has since gone international. It has popped up in the preamble of the U.N. Treaty on Biodiversity and was written into a slew of protocols and rules issued by the European Union in the 90's. It informs treaties like the 2000 Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety, which allows countries to bar genetically modified organisms on the basis of precaution. The idea has not prevailed over risk analysis, however, at least not yet. The E.U.'s ban on American beef treated with hormones, for example, is based on the precautionary principle. But since world-trade rules are based on risk analysis rather than precaution, and the health risk of eating hormone-treated beef has not been proved, the World Trade Organization has ruled that the ban is illegal. 
What explains the W.T.O.'s resistance to the precautionary principle? It doesn't sound like a revolutionary idea. Indeed, it sounds like common sense: better safe than sorry; look before you leap. But, in fact, the precautionary principle poses a radical challenge to business as usual in a modern, capitalist, technological civilization. As things stand, whenever questions are raised about the safety of, say, antibiotics in livestock feed, not until someone finds the smoking gun can anything be done about it. When President Bush earlier this year challenged the Clinton administration's tougher standards for arsenic levels in drinking water, he did it on the grounds that "the science isn't in yet." (He subsequently relented.) The problem very often is that long before the science does come in, the harm has already been done. And once a technology has entered the marketplace, the burden of bringing in that science typically falls on the public rather than on the companies selling it. 
If introduced into American law, the precautionary principle would fundamentally shift the burden of proof. The presumptions that flow from the scientific uncertainty surrounding so many new technologies would no longer automatically operate in industry's favor. Scientific uncertainty would no longer argue for freedom of action but for precaution and alternatives. 
Just how revolutionary an idea this really is is just now dawning on thinkers tied to American industry. In April, a fellow at the Hoover Institution published an attack on the precautionary principle, calling it, quite rightly, "a wolf in sheep's clothing." The Bush administration has adopted a hard line in international negotations. In the spring, its delegates to the Codex Alimentarius Commission, the world body that sets food safety standards for world trade, scuttled an agreement rather than allow precautionary language into a single footnote.
Critics argue that the precautionary principle is "antiscientific." No and yes. No, in the sense that it calls for more science in order to dispel the uncertainties surrounding new technologies and to develop less harmful alternatives. And yet there is a sense in which the idea is "antiscientific," if by scientific we mean leaving it to scientists to tell us what to do. For the precautionary principle recognizes the limitations of science -- and the fact that scientific uncertainty is an unavoidable breach into which ordinary citizens sometimes must step and act. MICHAEL POLLAN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Slow Food

BYLINE:  By Lawrence Osborne 

 BODY:
What do the Vesuvian apricot, the Delaware Bay oyster and the Loire salmon have in common? According to the Italian journalist Carlo Petrini, founder of the Slow Food movement, they're all "endangered" foods. And like rare zebras, butterflies and rhinos, these exotic, traditional foodstuffs require an organized effort to defend them. Slow Food is that movement. Slow Food activism is curious but simple: the idea is to protest the spreading evils of fast food and the bland, unhealthy cuisine of the globalized economy by going back to the locally grown, "authentic" food that our grandparents cherished. Why eat mass-produced and plastic-tasting Monterey Jack, Slow Food activists cry, when you can eat a hand-made and zesty chevre from a tiny village in Corsica -- and support a Corsican farmer too? 
 The Slow Food movement, which is just now making inroads in America, is a gastronomic version of Greenpeace: a defiant determination to preserve unprocessed, time-intensive food from being wiped off the culinary map. And like anti-W.T.O. activism, the movement is a protest against globalism. But Slow Food activism doesn't take the form of street demonstrations. Instead, activists are encouraged to savor organic cabbages and dissect the joys of truffles in their kitchens. Protest was never this much fun. 
 Perhaps that's why Petrini's movement, with its cute snail logo and its charming manifestoes against the evils of fast-food hamburgers, has 65,000 adherents in 45 countries worldwide -- with 6,000 "party members" in the U.S. alone. Each of the nearly 580 branches worldwide is known as a "convivium." A look at one of the movement's writings provides a clue to its passions. "We are enslaved by speed," it reads, "and have all succumbed to the same insidious virus -- fast life, which disrupts our habits . . . and forces us to eat fast foods." And it goes on: "Our defense should begin at the table with Slow Food. Let us rediscover the flavors and savors of regional cooking." The movement now sponsors something called the Ark of Taste -- a project that gives a sort of preservation status to traditional livestock breeds, cheeses, cereals, charcuterie, herbs and fruits.
For the prosperous European middle class, and for an increasing number of its North American counterparts, the Slow Food movement's heady mixture of righteous politics and splendid self-pampering has proved as deliciously irresistible as Chinantla vanilla from Mexico or indigenous-bee honey made in Turkey. It's revolution with a spatula, not a Kalashnikov. LAWRENCE OSBORNE

HEADLINE: DINING OUT; 
A Lot of Italian Fare, but Little Elbow Room

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA BROOKS 

 BODY:
WE did not expect our dinner at Mike's Ristorante in Norwalk to turn into a discussion on economics, but that is what evolved. Not Greenspan variety, mind you, but the day-to-day accounting involved in running a restaurant and keeping it solvent and, one would expect, profitable.
 When the four of us sat down, we were charmed by the look of Mike's, with its clean, neat Italian cafe touches. 
 As we studied the menu, a waiter brought us two baskets of bread and, before we could peek inside the paper covering, whisked the baskets away. That was a foretaste of the disorganized service to come. 
The bread basket's disappearance was followed instantly by the arrival of four heaping dinner-size plates of salad, a lovely medley of fresh, diverse greens enveloped by dressing. By the time the warm toasted bread slices reappeared, most of the salad had been consumed.
After such big salads, we did not feel like ordering a bunch of starters, but settled on antipasto all' Italiano. We reasoned that at $11.50 there would be enough for nibbling by all of us. "No, no," the matron said. The antipasto was mostly a repeat of the salad. She recommended the prosciutto and mozzarella ($13.50) instead.
We complied and the prettily-arranged platter was one of the high points, with slices of fluffy soft and tender cheese and tomato resting on a bed of paper-thin Parma prosciutto. It was the only dish that evening that seemed arranged with the forethought of eye appeal.
As a backup, we added an order of funghi alla contadina, which arrived saucepan-hot, pungent with garlic, olive oil and sliced mushrooms. Robustly delicious.
The specials were recited, but they were also listed on a board that we could walk over to and study.
When the entrees appeared, we were still enjoying the appetizers, which posed a problem for the waiter and us as we juggled to make room for the additional large plates.
Meanwhile, the restaurant had filled up. Only one table was occupied when we arrived at seven o'clock, and by 8, another table for four and a long table seating 12 people were all full. That was the entire seating capacity of the restaurant.
When we left at 8:45 p.m., not a table had changed occupants. That is what prompted our discussion of restaurant economics. How can a place this tiny make it?
First, there is the matter of prices. While Mike's resembles the comfy neighborhood Italian restaurant that brings out nostalgic bleats in many diners, the prices are those of a much tonier establishment: appetizers run from $7.50 for bruschetta to $13.50 for our mozzarella/prosciutto platter, with most starters $10.50.
Entrees were mostly priced at $22.50. Gamberi alla scampi, at that price, consisted of five jumbo shrimp and a lot of angel hair pasta with garlic, parsley, white wine and lemon -- tasty, but pricey.
Scaloppine marsala con funghi at the same price was generous -- as all Mike's dishes are -- but the escalopes of veal were extremely tough. Toscan pansotti Napoletana consisted of a few pasta pockets submerged in a voluminous, freshly made garlic-cherry tomato sauce loaded with roasted garlic buds. It was hefty and hearty, with nothing subtle about it.
Our best choice was petto di pollo contadina. The chicken breast with roasted peppers, big hunks of artichoke hearts and mushrooms was wholesome, if basic.
Our bill, which included four entrees, two starters, three desserts and two glasses of wine, was $173, which included tax and tip.
Mike's has a wine and beer license and a limited wine selection that begins at $18. The only dessert made on the premises was an almond-saturated tiramisu, which was overpowering. 
It is a tough restaurant world out there, we concluded, stating the obvious. To compete, prices, kitchen capability and service all need to be in sync. But can anyone make it seating a mere 20 to 24 patrons, we wondered? Only Mike's can answer that -- but we hope the pretty little place will survive, improve and prosper.

Mike's Ristorante
50 Main Street, Norwalk.
(203) 838-3256.

Satisfactory
