HEADLINE: The Only Game in Town, for Now 

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA GROARK 

 BODY:
FOR 11 years, Florence Mignone and Fernand Audette have enjoyed a friendship based on gambling, a hobby that has taken them to Atlantic City, Las Vegas and Connecticut.
 But on a recent weekday morning, as they sat side by side in front of 50-cent slot machines at Mohegan Sun Casino, the two Melville, N.Y., residents admitted they soon may be parting ways. With the prospect of casinos opening in New York, Ms. Mignone said she would probably prefer to gamble in her state because the casinos would be closer to home. Mr. Audette thought otherwise. 
 "I'd come here," he said as he puffed on a cigar. "I like it over here." 
Just how New Yorkers like Mr. Audette and Ms. Mignone will react to the possibility of casinos opening in the Catskill region is of great interest to Connecticut casino executives and budget officials in Connecticut, which receives more than $300 million in slot revenues each year. In October, New York Gov. George Pataki signed a bill that would allow three Native American casinos to be built in Ulster and Sullivan counties, creating more competition for New York gamblers who constitute as much as 20 percent of the customers at Mohegan Sun and the nearby Foxwoods casino.
While casino and state officials said it is too soon to predict what type of impact New York casinos could have on Connecticut, at least one analyst said he believed they would have to affect Mohegan Sun and Foxwoods.
"Casino gaming in New York State would definitely impact those two casinos in Connecticut," said Marvin Roffman, a gaming analyst and president of Roffman Miller Associates, a Philadelphia money management company. "The only reason why the Indian reservations are doing great is because they are the only game in town."
Harry Curtis, a managing director at Robertson Stephens in New York, is even more specific. 
"It will certainly be no more than 10 percent and probably less than 5 percent of their revenues, and that's within the first six months," Mr. Curtis said. "And then after 12 months, I think that the impact will be minimal."
But, he said, it depends on what is built in New York.
"At the outset, what may get built is relatively modest and so the initial impact may be at the low end of that range," he said. "Over time, if it's one casino with anywhere from two to three thousand slot machines in the Catskills, I don't think it would have a long-term impact on the Connecticut casinos."
Casino gaming has flourished in Connecticut since the Mashantucket Pequots opened Foxwoods in 1992. Benefiting from a monopoly on casino gambling in New England and Foxwoods's location between New York and Boston, the tribe made national headlines as it attracted tens of thousands of gamblers to its casino each day. When the Mohegans opened Mohegan Sun four years later, Connecticut earned the distinction of playing host to two of the country's largest casinos that together take in more than $1 billion in gross revenues annually.
Thanks to an agreement that gives the state 25 percent of each casino's slot revenues, Connecticut has benefited as well. For the fiscal year ending June 2001, the state's share of the slot revenue totaled $332 million.
But the tribes have been aware of their tentative monopoly on gambling in New England and have long kept an eye on the possibility of other casinos opening in places like Massachusetts and New York. A few years ago when the Mohegans began to raise money for their $1 billion expansion, the first phase of which opened this fall, the prospect of other casinos opening was routinely mentioned.
"We always knew that New York was a place where gaming might take place," said Mitchell Etess, Mohegan Sun's executive vice president of marketing and whose family used to run the Grossinger's resort in the Catskills.
Yet Foxwoods or Mohegan Sun officials said they were somewhat surprised when New York's legislature did a quick turnaround on the subject this fall. Earlier this year, the New York Senate passed a bill that would have authorized the governor to negotiate a compact for casinos in western New York, but the legislation was not approved by the state House of Representatives, according to Mark Hansen, spokesman for New York Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno. After the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the State Legislature resurrected the issue. This time, they passed the bill, which also authorized the three casinos in Sullivan and Ulster counties and lifted the state prohibition on slot machines.
"All of a sudden we found ourselves in a position where we had to find a tremendous amount of additional revenue going forward to support the state's programs and meet our responsibilities," Mr. Hansen said. "It was seen as a way to increase revenues for the state."
Just how soon a casino would open in Ulster or Sullivan counties is hard to say, since there are several regulatory hurdles that must be overcome before construction can begin. But at least one tribe, the St. Regis Mohawks, has begun to take the first steps toward developing a casino. On Nov. 15, the Mohawks signed development and management agreements with the Park Place Entertainment Corporation, which owns, manages or has an interest in 28 gaming properties including Bally's and Caesars.
The tribe intends to build a $500 million casino and resort in Thompson, a Catskill town in Sullivan County. When finished, the project would include a 750-room hotel and a 130,000-square-foot casino, according to a statement released by Park Place.
Before construction can begin, the federal government must agree to take land into trust for the tribe. In addition, the tribe must negotiate a compact with Mr. Pataki, and the National Indian Gaming Commission must approve the tribe's management agreement with Park Place.
By comparison, after the Mohegans were federally recognized in 1994, it took about two-and-a-half years for them to realize their dreams of opening a casino. One of their biggest hurdles was securing the National Indian Gaming Commission's approval.
If built, the casinos would provide another option to gamblers from the New York metropolitan area, who comprise between 15 and 20 percent of Foxwoods's and Mohegan Sun's customer base, according to casino officials.
Since the New York casinos could be years from reality, Marc Ryan, secretary of the Connecticut Office of Policy and Management, said it is too soon to determine what effect they could have on the state, which is already experiencing a decline in revenues thanks to the slumping economy.
"Once something is more solid, then we would probably start looking at the impact," he said. "But it really depends on where the casinos are located. To the degree that they are located in the Catskill Mountains or somewhere in that area I think that would obviously have an impact on the visitorship to the two casinos in Connecticut and would probably impact our slot revenues."
But, he added, one factor that must be taken into consideration is whether Connecticut's casinos have reached their saturation point. The Mohegans' Sun Burst expansion nearly doubled the size of their casino, adding another 115,000 square feet of gaming space. Mr. Ryan said state officials are watching whether the slot revenues continue to grow or level off.
"The more important question is, is there enough business to go around, so to speak," he said.
Robert DeSalvio, executive vice president of marketing for Foxwoods, said there is.
"If in fact the casinos are built in the Catskill area, the net effect here will be that it will slow the rate of growth of our penetration into the New York metropolitan area, but certainly won't stop it or see it go backward," Mr. DeSalvio said. "And the reason is that we feel we have not even come close to reaching our full potential from the New York metro market."
In addition, he said once people have been exposed to casino gambling, they tend to look for other places to wager their money. That, in turn, could create new customers for the Connecticut casinos.
"We think we could qualify as a very reachable drive, and that the area of southeastern Connecticut is very attractive because of not only the casino option, but the wonderful collection of tourist type assets that we have in the region," he said. 
In addition, just because someone is from New York does not mean it will be more convenient to go to Sullivan or Ulster Counties to gamble. It all depends on where a person lives, Mr. Etess said. 
"Let's say you live on Long Island, that doesn't mean that you are going to go gambling in the Catskills just because it's in New York," he said. "So that doesn't necessarily mean we are going to lose 20 percent of our business right away because a New York zip code has gaming."
Plus, Mr. Etess said, Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun are such large resorts, it will cost a developer about $1 billion to build something on a similar scale.
"One of the reasons that we got our financing and went to Project Sunburst when we did was to raise a barrier of entry to prospective competition," he added.
Still, some people, like Charles Pitti of West Babylon, N.Y., said they would welcome casinos in New York. Watching his wife feed coins into a slot machine at Mohegan Sun, the Long Island resident said the Connecticut casinos are too popular.
"You have so many people playing the machines there's not enough area to play," he said. "It's overcrowded."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Charity Begins With Sept. 11, and Ends There

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
EXECUTIVES at some of Long Island's largest nonprofit and philanthropic institutions say that dozens of social-service or cultural programs are endangered because of the impact of Sept. 11 on local fund-raising activities.
 Agencies that rely on individual and corporate philanthropy are finding that their usual end-of-the year fund-raising is coming up short. Regular contributors are saying that they have already given what they can spare this year to help the victims of the terrorist attacks. Other factors, including the weakening economy and disruptions in the fall fund-raising schedule, are causing a number of administrators to consider paring their costs, or canceling programs outright. 
 Sharon Markman, the director of development of the Family Service League in Huntington and the president of the Long Island chapter of the Association of Fundraising Professionals, said, "Some individuals and corporations either don't have the same amount of dollars to spend this year, because of the economy, or have reallocated some of their dollars to efforts aimed at helping Sept. 11 victims." 
More frequently, the effects of Sept. 11 on the Island's nonprofit sector have been indirect but no less serious. For example: 
*Nearly $5.6 million in state money earmarked for some 60 Long Island agencies is now in political limbo, with a growing likelihood that perhaps only a fifth of it will ever materialize. 
*Scores of fund-raising events scheduled for the fall and the current holiday season have been postponed, scaled back or canceled. Efforts to reschedule them have been hampered by the anthrax threat and fears of opening unsolicited mail.
*Individual donors, feeling bearish, are taking longer to send in their checks, often for amounts pledged in flusher times.
Sandy Oliva, the executive director of the Nassau County Coalition Against Domestic Violence, said that she did not know when, or if, her organization would collect the $70,000 it received last year from the budgets of individual legislators, money it was counting on again this year to finance 2002 programs. 
"We're going on faith and hoping the state funds come through late," Ms. Oliva said. "Otherwise, we'll have to reduce services."
The method of financing programs through the discretionary budgets of individual legislators, known as member item budgeting, has grown in recent years, said John T. O'Connell, the chief executive of the Health and Welfare Council, which represents some 300 private and government-run agencies on the Island. 
Mr. O'Connell said that if state money was not forthcoming, a number of social-service programs could be eliminated. "We're talking about losing programs that help people with breast cancer, legal services for battered women, nursing services for people with AIDS, socialization programs for seniors, and many others," he said. 
The terrorist attacks came just as nonprofit groups were beginning their fall fund-raising. Many decided to cancel golf outings, dinners and marathon runs scheduled for the rest of September, said Tracey Gittere, the managing director of Legendary Events, a Garden City company that plans and produces corporate and social functions. Because of the logistical challenges and complex planning required for the events, and because of the uncertainty over how long it would take before people were ready to attend social events again, many fund-raisers scheduled for later in the fall, even in the winter, were canceled, too. "Millions of dollars were not raised," said Ms. Gittere (pronounced GIT-tree). 
Theresa Regnante, a vice president of the United Way of Long Island, said charities that rely on special events for fund-raising were particularly hard hit. "Executives who bought a table for $5,000 last year are saying no this year," she said.
The tighter fund-raising environment is likely to have an impact on cultural and environmental groups in particular, said Ms. Markman of the Association of Fundraising Professionals. "If there is to be any diminution of funds, it's perhaps going to impact the arts and the environmental groups first," she said. "When people have to make choices, they are more likely to feed the hungry or help people in need than to send a contribution to a museum or a symphony."
Some foundation administrators and local philanthropists are saying they are tapped out. Local fund-raisers "are telling me that corporations are telling them not to even both to apply," Ms. Regnante said.
But that is not always the case. Lisa Platania, the director of community relations at Computer Associates in Islandia, said that the company had stepped up its giving this year in response to Sept. 11, but not at the expense of support for community programs. As she put it: "The disaster did not cut back on our current grant making." 
Other Long Island philanthropists said they were able to contribute to relief efforts without reducing their annual gifts to local causes. One donor, a former president of a large Long Island corporation who asked that his name not be used, to protect his privacy, said, "My feeling is that these organizations were having a hard time before Sept. 11 and now need more help than ever." 
Frank Castagna, a real estate executive in Manhasset, and his wife, Rita, contribute to a number of local cultural organizations and service programs. The ones facing serious problems, Mr. Castagna said, are those with relatively short histories or those that lack deep emotional commitment from their donors. Unlike past years, he said, those organizations will not be able to count on last-minute help from the private or public sectors. 
"We have had to cut back our giving a little this year, for various reasons," he said. "And the state and local governments are not in the position this year of stepping in to extend the funding." 
Suzy Sonenberg, the executive director of the Long Island Community Foundation, which administers grants for philanthropists, including Horace and Amy Hagedorn, said there was an urgency this season for nonprofit groups. "People who have given money year after year are not giving money this year to their favorite causes or are drastically reducing their gifts, because they are giving to Sept. 11," Ms. Sonenberg said. "We know these programs are hurting, and we worry the trend is continuing."

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; 
The Mission: Helping Women and Girls

BYLINE:  By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
WHEN the Delta Minerva Life Development Center in Roosevelt wanted to hold a conference on how to prevent teenage girls in Nassau County from joining gangs, it approached the Long Island Fund for Women and Girls. Soon the center, sponsored by Delta Sigma Theta, a black sorority, had a $2,500 grant from the fund, which is dedicated to improving the status of women and girls on the Island.
 When Colonial Youth and Family Services in Mastic decided to offer workshops on parenthood and job skills for pregnant teenagers and young mothers, it applied to the fund. Linda Peck, Colonial's director of clinical services, said she was delighted to receive a $5,000 grant, which the agency will share with Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic, which had requested money for a similar program. 
 "We've been doing the program on a shoestring," Ms. Peck said. "Now we will be able to have someone come that is really good in the field and teach them." 
In the last 10 years, the Long Island Fund has awarded $310,000, and at the fund's 10th annual breakfast on Nov. 14, another $100,000 was given out for 31 projects chosen from 86 applications. The grants ranged from $1,500 to $5,000.
Diane Cohen, the fund's executive director, says that its mission is to take the ideas of local women and help make them reality. Unlike traditional philanthropies, the fund often provides seed money for new groups and addresses the needs of diverse women, as opposed to groups that focus on business or professional women. 
"What we are doing is taking very local, grass-roots groups that can't find funding other places and saying, 'You know best the local needs and you know best your interests,' " Ms. Cohen said. "Tell us what you want to do about it and we will try to fund you."
The Long Island Fund for Women and Girls was founded in 1991 by four women who were active in philanthropy and fund-raising: Emily Berkowitz, Betty Schlein, Suzy Sonenberg and Barbara Strongin. At the time there was a recession, and women's programs were often the first to be affected by budget cuts. 
The founders held focus groups and systematically spread the word, holding meetings in several neighborhoods. Hazel Weiser, the fund's co-president, said that from the beginning it was a volunteer alliance that tried to include a cross section of Long Island women. At the group's founding, she said, 4 cents of every philanthropic dollar contributed in the United States went to issues that had specific relevance for women and girls; now it is 6 cents.
"The idea is for us to connect the communities of women on Long Island with each other so that we have a united voice," Ms. Weiser said. "Our board and our grantees reflect the growing diversity of Long Island. Our voice needs to change as the issues that affect women and girls on Long Island change." 
The fund's budget has five categories: promoting physical and mental health and ensuring the safety of women and girls; building skills and abilities; fighting discrimination; increasing women's involvement in philanthropy and fund-raising; and encouraging girls to pursue nontraditional interests and careers. 
To build skills and abilities, the fund awarded the Suffolk County Perinatal Coalition $4,000 to set up a program to train low-income women to become doulas, to assist during pregnancy and childbirth.
The Women's Project in Great River will use its $2,700 grant to offer children alternatives to traditional fairy tales by developing new stories in which women are role models. 
The fund gave the Boys and Girls Club of Bellport a $4,800 grant to teach girls photography and graphics and to create a calendar featuring women as leaders in the community. East End Kids received $5,000 for a robotics and technology program for girls 8 to 14. 
The fund's seed money helped start Something Old, Something New of South Country, a fiber-arts cooperative, two years ago. Recently, the group moved into its own storefront in Brookhaven hamlet. It hopes to sustain itself by recycling donated materials, selling members' handiwork and doing custom sewing. 
Nell Bard, the director, said the cooperative was an informal group -- many of the members were disabled, elderly or immigrants -- who were sewing, knitting and weaving baskets as occupational therapy when she applied for a grant. 
For this group, the fund and the grants totaling $8,000 were a lifeline. "They really are unique on Long Island in terms of the types of things they are willing to fund," Ms. Bard said. "It's hard to find somebody to take a chance on you when you don't have anything to go on. That's a real gift to people like us." 
For the first time, in an attempt to create safe environments, particularly for girls, the fund is planning to give grants to help high school students develop their own programs to fight bullying and harassment. The fund's third annual gender-equity conference will be in March. Ms. Cohen is seeking proposals to address nontraditional career paths for women, including math, engineering, technology and the trades. 
"Women who decide college isn't for me go into very low-level secretarial jobs, whereas men have the opportunity to become electricians and plumbers," Ms. Cohen said.
One of the fund's steps in that direction was a $2,000 grant to Nontraditional Employment for Women in Hauppauge. This center, a branch of a Manhattan group, trains, places and supports women in the trades. In partnership with the Long Island Building Trades Council and the State Labor Department, the center plans to offer 16-week training sessions to prepare 80 women to apply to unions and apprenticeship programs for jobs in carpentry, electricity, plumbing and other building trades. 
"It's a start for us," said Ruth Mulford, the program director. "We being women don't have very good percentages as far as the building trades are concerned. Yet it is an occupation where women can really break out of the cycle that they are often in where they can't afford a baby sitter, they can't pay their rent, they can't afford to go to work." 
The fund's grant will be used for a physical-fitness training program. Ms. Mulford said women often don't consider building trades because the work is physically demanding and working conditions are difficult. 
"Consequently, a lot of women get locked into jobs in the supermarket, jobs in a fast-food restaurant, cleaning types of jobs," she said. "This is an opportunity where they can earn three or four times that amount of money, and they can earn while they are an apprentice." 
The fund does more than just give money. Last spring, its first Women's Product Expo was held at the Middle Country Public Library.
Last month it offered a day of educational seminars for women who want to turn hobbies into businesses. Victoria Nesnick, a retired teacher from Dix Hills who has been trying to start a Kids Hall of Fame, was one of the women who attended.
"While I was sitting there and when I left, I felt like someone had given me a treasure chest or toolbox in terms of things I could use in order to help my business to grow," said Ms. Nesnick, who puts out a magazine, trading cards and a calendar celebrating children's achievements.
At the awards breakfast last month, the fund honored five women: Joan Saltzman of Sands Point, a community advocate who contributed the seed money that started the fund 10 years ago; Veronica Rose of Long Beach, the first woman to become a master electrician in New York City; Irene Morgan Kirkaldy of Roosevelt, who refused to move to the back of a bus in Virginia in 1944, 11 years before Rosa Parks; Audrey Livingstone, the first African-American and the first woman to become president of the Long Island Board of Realtors; and Joanna Howard, a student at Westhampton Beach High School who played the young Cosette in the touring company of "Les Miserables." 
"As we have matured as an organization, we have learned how to reach out to different communities and honor women who might not necessarily get the recognition for the work that they do," Ms. Weiser said. "Every year we say this is the best year we've had yet."

HEADLINE: Food Pantries' Cupboards Are Often Bare 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
JEANETTE SCHWENDE of Shirley was waiting for her plastic bag full of canned goods and pasta at an emergency food pantry in Riverhead the other day when someone asked what brought her there.
 It seemed like a dumb question to Ms. Schwende, a 48-year-old former home health aide, one of an army of hungry people stuck at the small end of Long Island's horn of plenty. 
 "Do you know why I need the food?" she replied. "Because I'm going to die, that's why." 
Across Long Island, the need for donated food has rarely, if ever, been greater, but some food pantries, the dispensers of last resort to people who have nowhere else to go but to supermarket Dumpsters, are having trouble keeping anything on their shelves.
So dire had the situation become in the days after Thanksgiving that the Long Island Council of Churches, a Protestant group that runs food pantries in Riverhead and Hempstead, issued an urgent appeal for donations.
"Our shelves were bare for several days," said the Rev. Thomas W. Goodhue, the council's executive director. "It's been fairly bleak. The number of people coming in has been just enormous."
The brutal statistics have only begun to trickle in, but Mr. Goodhue said the number of people in real and immediate need, already increasing before Sept. 11, had swelled sharply since then.
"It's far worse than it was on Sept. 10," he said. "Now we are seeing people who are very productive and very proud who never had to ask for anything before." A limousine driver whose clients worked at the World Trade Center and laid-off airline workers were among them, he said.
The pantries, barometers of social and economic distress, are traditionally needed most by the working poor, the elderly, the sick who can't meet medical expenses and people who are either awaiting or are not able to qualify for government assistance.
On Long Island, while some food pantries are struggling to meet demand, others said they were holding up. "We haven't had that problem," said Rose Ina Brady, a spokeswoman for the St. Patrick's Church pantry in Huntington. "We've had the same number of people coming in as usual, maybe a few more but not drastically so."
In nearby Huntington Station, the number of Hispanic day laborers eating the free breakfasts provided by the Salvation Army has held steady at about 125 a day, said Capt. Mitchell Brown, the commander of the group's East Northport Corps.
But Scott Stepp, the coordinator of public affairs and development for Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, said that in some parishes, pantries had been stretched to their limits.
The Rev. Bill Brisotti, the administrator for Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Roman Catholic Church in Wyandanch, said his parish was one of them. "Keeping the pantry stocked has become more difficult," he said.
Lynn Needelman, the executive director of Long Island Cares, a nonprofit regional food bank in Brentwood, said the economic downturn, the redirection of charitable giving after Sept. 11 and the first wave of welfare cutoffs for people reaching the five-year limit on federal welfare were affecting pantries and other programs.
"We have crisis 12 months a year," she said. "But I would say it is increasing in its enormity because we have got all these factors." 
Long Island Cares, started by the singer Harry Chapin in 1980, supplies scores of Long Island food pantries, soup kitchens and emergency shelters through its 504 member agencies. Ms. Needelman said supplies come from private and corporate food drives, state and federal assistance programs, and a national food network, Second Harvest. She said she has noticed in recent weeks that food donations have begun returning to normal after falling off in September and October.
There was disagreement over whether federal welfare cutoffs would bring longer lines at food pantries. New York is one of several states with a program meant to take up the slack for people no longer eligible for federal aid. But some advocates for the poor say the transfer process to state aid, called the Safety Net Program in New York, is mired in confusion, putting some federal welfare clients at risk.
Dennis J. Nowak, the director of public relations for the Suffolk County Department of Social Services, said there were no problems in Suffolk, where about 400 families reached the federal limit this month. 
"We sent out many notices and we have interviewed hundreds of people for Safety Net," Mr. Nowak said. Once enrolled in the state program, he said, "they get exactly the same amount of benefits."
Mr. Nowak said the federal cutoffs would not have a major impact on food pantries because of the state program. But Mr. Goodhue of the Long Island Council of Churches said the council pantries were now serving people recently dropped from the welfare rolls. "We are seeing that already," he said.
Not all federal clients make the transition to the state program. In Nassau, about 170 of the 290 cases facing the cutoff were enrolled in the state program, said Rita Mathews, a spokeswoman for the county's Department of Social Services.
Ms. Mathews said that of the 120 cases not signed up for the state program, 31 were found to be exempt from the federal cutoff and 43 cases were closed because the clients did not respond to notifications of the cutoff. In other instances, the cases were not eligible for various reasons.
Mr. Nowak said that after Sept. 11, problems with computer links involving severed telephone lines in Lower Manhattan slowed benefits for weeks. He said the county department issued emergency food and shelter vouchers during the disruption.
Both Nassau and Suffolk reported increases in applications for food stamps. In Nassau in September and October, they were up 12 percent, compared with a year earlier, Ms. Mathews said. "Requests for assistance are usually tied to the economy," she said.
In Suffolk, Mr. Nowak said that food-stamp applications were up 30 percent and that applications for public assistance were up 12 percent overall. Both the county Department of Social Services and Paul Tonna, the presiding officer of the County Legislature, have recently run outreach programs encouraging people to apply for food stamps, a possible factor in the increase.
Mr. Tonna, a Republican from Huntington, has formed a task force to fight hunger, and at a task-force conference two weeks ago he said that 40,000 to 60,000 Suffolk residents who were entitled to food stamps were not receiving them. He said that food-stamp use had declined by 51 percent in Suffolk since March 1996, reflecting the overhaul of the federal welfare system.
Other factors may be driving people to food pantries. Mr. Nowak said the high cost of housing on Long Island was one of them. He cited a study by the Long Island Association, done in November for the Long Island Housing Partnership. It showed that more than half of the renters on Long Island could not afford two-bedroom apartments. Federal figures put the fair-market rent for a two-bedroom apartment at $1,230 a month.
A fact sheet Mr. Nowak provided said that a worker would need to earn about $49,200 a year, or $23.65 an hour in a 40-hour week, to afford that rent without cutting into other basic expenses, including food.
Long Island's population of Hispanic day laborers appear not to be a major factor in the increasing demand at food pantries. Nadia Marin-Molina, the executive director of the Workplace Project in Hempstead, a private nonprofit group for Latino migrant laborers, said that some Hispanic workers were remaining through the winter instead of going home as seasonal work ended on Long Island. But others are leaving for good because of changed conditions after the terrorist attacks.
"It's the fear of being in a place where anti-immigrant sentiment is increasing," she said. She said that families were also telling men to come home because of fears of anthrax and of more terrorist attacks.
Ms. Marin-Molina said she was not aware of an increase in referrals to food pantries. "These are resourceful people, and day laborers are accustomed to going without work," she said.
At the Riverhead pantry run by the Long Island Council of Churches, Preston Brown said that Hispanic workers sometimes came in for food but not in large numbers.
Late last month the church council paid $2,200 to a Brooklyn food wholesaler to fill empty shelves at the pantry, which is at 235 Sweezy Avenue. The shelves, stretched end to end, would extend only a third of the way down the aisle of a large suburban supermarket. They had been empty for four days. 
Mr. Brown, an Air Force veteran who lives in Southampton and recently began working at the pantry, said he found it distressing to turn people away for lack of food.
"We're a community service organization and we can't even help meet the needs of the community," he said. "It's discouraging when you have to refer people somewhere else. But unfortunately, sometimes we have to pass them on down the line."
Even more discouraging, he said, were the phone calls from other food pantries and from soup kitchens saying that they, too, were stripped bare and not to send anyone else to them.
Figures kept at the Riverhead pantry showed that 789 families, 338 single adults and 133 elderly people came in in the last three months, September through November. In July and August, the pantry served 328 families, 377 adults and 56 elderly people; the center was closed for seven days during that period for vacations. No other figures were available. 
Mr. Brown said that when someone in need comes to the pantry, he fills plastic bags according to family size and need. "We try to balance the diet," he said. The supplies are meant to last three or four days. Everything in the pantry is nonperishable except for the day-or-more-old bread that Mr. Brown collects at the Pepperidge Farm store at the Tanger Factory Outlet Center.
Last week the shelves were full, but Mr. Brown and other pantry workers said they were stripped bare in the days after Thanksgiving. "As soon as we put something on the shelf, it was gone," Mr. Brown said. 
Many of the people who come to the pantry are referred by the county's Department of Social Services, but some come in on their own. Mr. Brown remembered one well-dressed woman in her 50's who burst into tears as she sat at his desk. "She didn't want to ask," he said.
Mark Aley, 50, of Riverhead, a frail man who said he broke his back twice and was unable to work, came for food for himself and his 14-year-old daughter. "I'm just about out, money-wise," he said. "No got."
He came with a friend, Thomas Matula, also of Riverhead. Mr. Matula said he had a disability that made him unable to lift anything heavy. He does odd jobs when he can, he said, but "there's no work now." 
He said his government assistance didn't go far enough. "I'm living day by day, and so is he," Mr. Matula said, motioning toward Mr. Aley. "We're just making ends meet. That's about it."
Mr. Matula, who was wearing a cap identifying him as a Vietnam veteran, said he no longer received food stamps. "I got a letter, and they cut me off," he said. "They cut me off. I served for six years, and I have to come in here and ask for food. Something is wrong."
"I'll tell you straight up, I just had a beer," he said. "That was my best pleasure for the whole month. Whole month." 
Mr. Matula paused frequently to fix his listeners with a long stare. He wore an American flag pin on his hat and a faceted stud earring. There was a pack of Pall Malls in the pocket of his torn shirt.
He said he was angry that the United States was sending food abroad while people at home went hungry. "What about our own people who don't have food?" he said. "We drop bombs over there in Afghanistan with food behind it? What about our people here?" 
Another client, Ms. Schwende, said she had worked as a home health aide before becoming disabled three years ago. She has diabetes and other health problems, she said.
Her food-stamp allotment of $131 a month had just been cut off. "I needed them, but they took them away from me," she said. "They said I didn't need them anymore. I guess they thought we'd eat nuts from the trees."
Raised in Riverhead by parents she described as alcoholics, she said she no longer worked and would not know how to find a job with decent pay. "People like us didn't get no education," she said. "What are we supposed to do? Where are we supposed to go? Do they want us to die in the streets?
"I'm very happy to have a center like this," she said. "I see people in the Dumpsters. A whole lot of people are going to the Dumpsters now. I don't want to end up in the Dumpsters.
"It never used to be like this," she said. "You could live very easily. Now everything is downhill. Actually, with the World Trade Center, everything is down. Everybody's life changed for the worse."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Hotel Developers Seek to Cash In on Casino Boom

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THE phenomenal success of the Mohegan Sun casino has spawned a hotel boom in the once-rural town of Montville, Conn., where along a one-mile stretch of Route 32 two hotels have opened this year and two others are on the drawing boards, even as Mohegan Sun develops its own 1,200-room hotel tower a couple of miles away.
 The 105-unit, all-suite Best Western Cristata has opened at Route 32 and Fort Shantok Road, and a 120-unit Microtel Inn and Suites opened just south of Route 2A. Two other developers have regulatory approvals for their plans: one for a 158-room hotel on the east side of Route 32, the other for a 54-unit hotel on the west side. A fifth hotel with 120 units is planned for the same area, but just over the town line in Norwich. 
 "There's no other area of the state that's seeing anywhere near the level of development that's going on down there," said Suzanne M. Hopgood, owner of the Hopgood Group, a hotel consulting firm. 
Deborah J. Donovan of Connecticut's Mystic & More Convention and Visitors Bureau, said there had been some concern about the impact a recession and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 might have on development, but so far no effect has been discernable. 
"Even with the recent events, the occupancy in the hotels is holding up pretty well in this area, much better than we've been hearing about in the rest of the country," Ms. Donovan said. "The average occupancy rate for the region in October was 74 percent, and some of these properties have occupancy rates in the 80's and 90's. In some areas, hotels are struggling to stay at 50 percent," including some in Connecticut.
The Sun is only a few miles from its only Connecticut competition -- Foxwoods Resort Casino, across the Thames River in Mashantucket, within the town the Ledyard -- and the two casinos are driving much of the hotel business in the area. 
Ms. Donovan said she's hopeful the latest developments will benefit the entire tourism industry. "There are more rooms for people to stay, and a much greater price range for them to choose from, which allows us to market to a wider demographic range," Ms. Donovan said. "It's good for the whole area that we have these new places opening."
Josephine R. Gustavsen, the owner of Oakdale Realty in Montville, said the residential market in town was also benefiting from the presence of the casino. A three-bedroom house that sold for $110,000 a year ago would now easily command $140,000, she said.
"Someone looking for a basic house that you can get into for $100,000 -- you're just not going to find it, and there aren't any rentals available either," Mrs. Gustavsen said. "The casino employees are buying everything at the lower end of the market."
THE two casinos together draw more than 70,000 customers a day, which is spurring hotel development throughout New London County. There are plans for new hotels in a half-dozen towns as close as Norwich and as far away as Niantic. As recently as 1995, there were about 2,000 units of hotel or other lodging in all of New London County, but by the end of this year the total could top 6,400 units.
Clearly, Montville will have the most significant concentration of new and proposed hotels, however. The situation is in marked contrast to what happened around Foxwoods, where the hotel development took place on the casino property, and there are few new hotels in the immediate area.
Richard R. Hamilton, general manager of the Best Western Cristata, said that to some extent, the hotels along Route 32 in Montville are benefiting from the other development at the Sun besides the growth of the casino itself. In addition to its 1,200-room hotel, which is to open next spring, a $1 billion expansion at the Sun that was completed this fall includes a 10,000-seat arena, a convention center and a spa.
"We're already getting calls from conventions that they've booked, looking for overflow rooms," Mr. Hamilton said. On the east side of the Thames, he added, "a lot of that overflow was handled by the Mystic hotels, which weren't that far away."
David P. Johnson, head of the Konover Hotel Corporation, which developed the Microtel hotel that opened this fall, said another limiting factor around Foxwoods was the lack of city water and sewer lines, natural gas service and other infrastructure.
"It made it a lot more difficult to develop on that side of the river," Mr. Johnson said. "You've also got better highway access on the Montville side, so it's not as isolated from the restaurants and shopping in Norwich or New London."
Montville's mayor, Howard R. Beetham, said the hotels require some city services, including police and fire protection, and they have begun to produce a lot of traffic at certain times of the day along Route 32. "But the impact is confined to a pretty small area right around the highway," Mr. Beetham said. The new hotels are each assessed at $3 million or $4 million, "and they generate a lot of local jobs," he added, so the overall effect has been positive for the town.
Mr. Beetham also said he would not be surprised if some developers who have won approvals for their projects wait several months before they start construction. "I think they'll want to sit back and see what happens when the Mohegans open their hotel," Mr. Beetham said. "How much business is going to be left on Route 32 after that?"
None of the hotel managers seem particularly troubled by the planned opening of the 1,200-room Mohegan hotel in the spring, however, because they say they serve a different market.
"To some people, the fact that we're close by but not actually on the casino grounds is seen as an advantage," Mr. Hamilton said. "We've done a lot of analysis of the market, and we think when the Sun hotel opens there will be some effect, but it won't be deep and it won't be long. This market will generate enough business to keep us all full."
Mr. Johnson said the casino had disclosed that it intended to target "high rollers," the more affluent gamblers, for its hotel, while the Microtel is aimed more at the budget market -- its published rates range from $59 to $89 a night. "If they're successful at what they intend to do, I will be successful in my niche," Mr. Johnson said. "We're aimed at very different kinds of clientele."
Mitchell Etess, vice president for marketing at the Sun, said he welcomed the nearby developments, because with 35,000 people a day at the casino, the 1,200 rooms planned on the grounds will not be able to accommodate all the business.
"There are people interested in spending their money on something other than a hotel room, and less-expensive lodging is going to be appealing to them," Mr. Etess said. "We're creating more demand than we can fill. And since almost all the hotels offer shuttle service to here, the more rooms that are available in the region, the better it will be for our customers. We support it, and we think it will benefit everyone."
Mr. Etess also predicted that some outlying hotels might also see more tourism business than they are expecting. "These hotels can succeed not only as Mohegan Sun dormitories, but they're close enough to Interstate 395 to draw a lot of off-the-road customers," Mr. Etess said. 
Ms. Hopgood, the hotel consultant, agreed. The casinos estimate that 26 million people live within a three-hour drive, and many of those people are not going to have the money or inclination to travel by airline because of the economy and the threat of terrorism. 
"Those people can drive to Montville and save some money," she said. "They're not spending a day flying to Las Vegas and a day flying home, so they've got two extra days, which could very well be used driving down to Mystic and seeing some of the local attractions. Southeastern Connecticut is one of those places that is properly positioned for these times, and there aren't very many of those."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Midtown Manhattan; 
Town Houses Used by Foreign Banks Are for Sale

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
DURING the 1990's as a wave of smaller foreign banks set up operations in this country, some of them decided not to occupy space in standard, multitenant buildings. Instead, they purchased town houses where they could be the sole occupants in some of the priciest neighborhoods in town.
 The elegant buildings, many of them mansions from New York's Gilded Age, helped establish the banks' image in a crowded city, and the small spaces in the buildings provided privacy for customers who had no interest in having their transactions observed by strangers. 
 "It's an image issue, clearly," said Andrew Davidoff, the chief executive of Emmes Group, which bought the Rockefeller town houses at 13-15 West 54th Street from a Danish bank called Unibank earlier this year. "These buildings are like the ones they operate in Europe. And because they are in the Plaza district, they are close to where their clients will be when they are in New York." 
The buildings at 13 and 15 West 54th Street were owned by members of the Rockefeller family from the early part of the last century until the death of Nelson A. Rockefeller, the former governor and vice president, in 1979. Other buildings in which banks set up their American operations may have lacked the pedigree of the Rockefeller building, but many came equipped with grand staircases, paneled walls and ornate fireplaces.
Many of the banks spent heavily on renovations to bring buildings that were built at the turn of the last century up to date in heating, cooling, lighting and telecommunications. But as times change, so do tastes in real estate, and some of the bank buildings have been sold or are on the market. 
In some cases, a bank that bought and renovated a building has been swallowed up in a merger by a larger institution that regards a town house not as a cozy headquarters, but as inefficient space for a branch operation and as an asset to be converted into cash.
One that is currently for sale is owned by Banco di Napoli at 4 East 54th Street. The asking price for the building, which was designed by Stanford White and completed in 1898, is $28.5 million.
Banco di Napoli, a regional bank in Italy, bought the six-story mansion in 1994 for $12.8 million and did a complete $7 million renovation of the building, which had been originally designed as a residence for a single family.
The renovation included the addition of one floor, which, to meet landmark rules, cannot be seen from the street. The building has a total of 23,000 square feet of space.
Last year the bank was acquired by a larger Italian institution, Sanpaolo IMI Bank, which has its American headquarters at 245 Park Avenue at 46th Street. The acquiring bank is reorganizing its New York operations and, while it may retain some space at 4 East 54th, has decided to offer the asset for sale.
It would not be unusual for a bank to retain some space in a location where it is well known. Mr. Davidoff said a successor to Unibank still has operations at the Rockefeller buildings, which are connected at the rear to a modern 13-story office building at 20 West 55th Street.
He said the bigger building was what most interested Emmes in the $30 million property, although the landmark town houses are fully occupied. Typical tenants for such properties are financial services companies, for whom the cost of real estate is minute in relationship to revenues generated.
He said the private banking division of U.S. Trust had operations in an adjacent building at 11 West 54th and had broken through a wall to add space in the Rockefeller buildings. "If I had more floors, I could rent them, too," he said.
"It is my sense that bankers feel better in these kind of offices than as anonymous tenants in a multiple office building," he said.
Richard Baxter, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG, a brokerage and services company that is managing the sale of 4 East 54th Street, said Banco di Napoli followed a familiar route when it began operations in New York. After looking at the market, it decided to buy the building rather than rent space elsewhere.
"They bought the building, renovated it, and now it is being sold to recoup the profits," Mr. Baxter said. "It is a purely economic move."
THE building was built as a residence for a family named Stokes, Mr. Baxter said. However, the Stokes marriage failed before the building was finished in 1898. In 1900 it was sold to William Moore and his wife, who lived there until her death in 1955. Subsequently, it had a variety of occupants until it was purchased by Banco di Napoli in 1994.
The building is unusual for a New York town house because it is 36 feet wide, compared with the more typical 20 to 25 feet, Mr. Baxter said.
Another bank town house on the market is one currently occupied by LBS Bank, which is based in Slovenia, an independent country that was once part of Yugoslavia. The seven-story, 20,500-square-foot building is at 12 East 52nd Street and has an asking price of $14 million.
The bank needs to expand beyond the five floors it has in the building and may opt for an American-style configuration with all operations on one floor, said Noel L. Berk, a principal of Mercedes Berk Ltd., which is trying to arrange the sale in connection with Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company.
"Small foreign banks like to own their own buildings," Ms. Berk said. "It gives them an identity for 5 or 10 years, but then their needs change."
When they first come to New York, she said, the banks like to operate the way they do at home, with each division on a separate floor. But as they become accustomed to this market, they begin to see the value of integrating operations and find the town houses an obstacle to more efficient operations, she added.
"The American way of managing space is very different from Europe," said Ron Cohen, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG. "As they move to the United States, they learn there are more efficient ways to operate."
Another factor prompting foreign banks to leave their beautiful town houses for office buildings is the decline of private banking at smaller institutions, Mr. Cohen said.
A mansion with a discreet brass plate next to the front door appeals to the clientele of private bankers, he said. "They want a small, private building where they can come and meet with their advisers," Mr. Cohen said. "Unfortunately," he said, private bankers "are a dying breed. With globalization, they cannot maintain the same level of service and location."
Also on the market is a 10,500-square-foot building at 124 East 55th Street on what was once known as "bankers row" between Lexington and Park Avenues, Ms. Berk said. The building, a Tudor-style structure with original fireplaces, was owned for many years by the Bank of Chile. The bank sold it to an investment group, which ultimately found it unsuitable, she said, putting it back on the market with an asking price of $7.9 million.
The buyer of any of these buildings could easily be another bank, particularly because they are in areas zoned for commercial operations. Nonprofit organizations can occupy properties in residential areas, but profit-making companies are confined to commercial zones, Ms. Berk said. The zoning would also allow the reconversion of the buildings for residential use, she said, although many of the facades are protected by landmark designation. 
An executive of Emmes suggested earlier this year that the Rockefeller buildings could become home to someone who could come up with $20 million. 
"It is not that small foreign banks do not want to operate in mansions and town houses," Ms. Berk said. "They do, until their needs change. I have been showing these buildings to banks and consulates."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ron Cohen, left, and Richard Baxter of Insignia/ESG, which is managing the sale of Banco di Napoli, background, at 4 East 54th Street. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
A Slower Pace to Retailing's Growth in the State

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AT many a store and shopping center this holiday season, cash registers are ringing -- but maybe not as constantly as last year -- and merchants are discounting their prices and working harder to consummate sales. Outside, parking spaces can still be found.
 After four years of steady growth, the retail market in New Jersey seems to be deflating like a balloon with a slow leak. A shriveling national economy and rising unemployment coupled with the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 and the subsequent war have hammered consumer confidence and encouraged people to buy less and save more, retail consultants and brokers said. 
 "The market has reached the end of an unprecedented period of growth, and rents have peaked," said Matthew K. Harding, president of the Levin Management Corporation, a retail management and services firm in North Plainfield. Consumers are still buying, but they have shifted from luxury items to discount goods as they "buy what they need and for value," he said. 
Meanwhile, retail centers continue to open and new ones, many planned years earlier and substantially preleased, are being built, but at a slower pace. Evidence of developments on the way are three projects -- one each in Phillipsburg, Holmdel and Hamilton -- under way or about to start that will produce a total of nearly 2 million square feet. 
Stores are also closing as the bankruptcies of national retailers continue, with 26 so far this year, compared with 29 for all of last year and 31 in 1999, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade group in Manhattan. Among those that have made bankruptcy filings this year are Ames Department Stores, a discounter in Rocky Hill, Conn., and Lechters, based in Harrison, which sold dinnerware and kitchen goods. 
But retailers as a whole are still expanding, though not as aggressively as in the past, and there is likely to be demand for some of the dark spaces left by chains that went bankrupt. Still, Mr. Harding said, economic conditions "affect the push for retailer expansion."
Additionally, retailers are "more selective in where they will go," said Ted Kraus, who heads a retail consulting and publishing firm in Mercerville. Centers in prime locations are still in demand because tenants know they will draw customers, while those in secondary markets "will take longer to fill," he said.
Tenants looking for space include big box retailers like Wal-Mart, Target and Best Buy, the discount electronics chain. Grocery chains, including Wegmans, new to the state, are also in the market, as are smaller national retailers.
One is the Vitamin Shoppe, a discounter based in North Bergen. "We are looking to capitalize on the opportunities in the market left by retailers teetering on bankruptcy," said Corey M. Bialow, the company's director of real estate and construction.
This month the company will open its 100th store and the 12th in New Jersey at the Nassau Park Center on Route 1 in Princeton, and two more will open in the state by January. The company plans to add up to 50 more stores nationally in the next 18 months, six of which will be in New Jersey, Mr. Bialow said.
While the slowdown in the retail market started about a year ago, the state's dense population and diverse employment base are buffering it from drastic dips, said Jonathan Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization/TCN Worldwide, a commercial real estate services firm in Woodbridge. 
The vacancy rate for nine major shopping corridors in north and central New Jersey is now 5.3 percent, up from 4.8 percent last year, according to data compiled by his firm. "Though the current figure reflects a slight increase, it is still considered healthy by historical standards," he said, noting that a vacancy rate of 7.5 percent or below is considered strong.
Still Mr. Schultz, like other professionals, is less sanguine about next year. He expects more bankruptcies, a rising retail vacancy rate and falling rents, even though the recession is generally expected to end by the second half of 2002. 
How much worse things will get will depend in part on the final results of the holiday shopping season. While there were generally positive reports about retail sales immediately after Thanksgiving, Mr. Kraus said, profits have been small because of the discounts retailers have been offering to lure skittish consumers. His projection is that the state's retail sales for the full year "will be flat or in the negative column."
Mr. Harding said that despite the slow sales of other goods, home furnishings and home-oriented products would remain relatively healthy as families stay home to save money. Discounters will continue to do well, as will grocery chains, he added.
Developers who are armed with signed leases from tenants for big chunks of space are pushing ahead with projects. 
IN Phillipsburg, Starwood Ceruzzi L.L.C. will begin construction this month on the first 240,000 square feet of Greenwich Center, which will have a total of 326,500 square feet. The initial phase of the 49-acre project has been fully leased, said Louis L. Ceruzzi, president of the company, which is based in Fairfield, Conn. The five current tenants include a Target discount department store, with 126,000 square feet. 
Mr. Ceruzzi said the project makes sense because it has desirable tenants and because it is in "an exploding area." He pointed out that some 52,000 people with an average household income of $109,462 live within seven miles of the site -- which is along Route 22, just off Interstate 78 -- and 122,000 cars pass it each day. 
Construction on the project's remaining 86,000 square feet will start once half of that space is leased, Mr. Ceruzzi said. Completion of the entire center is expected next October. Rents are comparable to those in the area, which are $14 to $16 a square foot.
Going forward, the company's development strategy will be more conservative. "In large part," Mr. Ceruzzi said, "we will focus on projects with one to three large tenants like discounters, home improvement or grocery stores and not take on the risk of leasing smaller satellite stores, at least until the economy improves." 
In Holmdel, construction is under way on the Commons at Holmdel, a 235,000-square-foot center rising on part of a 127-acre site along Route 35 at Laurel Avenue. Tenants have signed on for 70 percent of the space, said Steven J. Denholtz, managing director and chief executive of Denholtz Associates of Rahway, which is developing the project with the Zaro Group, a real estate investment company in Ocean Township. Rents are $18 to $35 a square foot.
Mr. Denholtz said a few "minor tenants," had backed out of the project when their expansion plans were shelved, but they have been replaced. In uncertain times, "retailers are drawn to and put a premium on well-located centers," he said, adding that one attraction of this site was that other uses -- offices and residences -- were planned. 
Also, across Route 35 is an existing 295,000-square-foot center, which the partners purchased last February. It is 90 percent occupied. So far tenants at the Commons at Holmdel include Best Buy and Pier 1, Barnes & Noble and Vitamin Shoppe. It is to be completed by July.
In Hamilton, work has begun on a 1.2-million-square-foot center now that the developer has leases signed "with enough large tenants," said Donald T. Wargo. He is president of Global Property Investors in King of Prussia, Pa., which is developing the project with JDN Realty, a real estate invest trust in Atlanta. Its anchors so far are Wal-Mart and a Kohl's discount department store, a Lowes home improvement center and a supermarket. 
Ultimately, the project, Hamilton Crossings, will also include a wholesale warehouse club, several midsize stores of 10,000 to 25,000 square feet each and about 25 smaller tenants. It will rise over the next 18 months. The partners are betting that the strength of the major anchors will be a magnet for other tenants as will the 210-acre project's location along Route 130, where it intersects with Interstate 195. Demographics also support it, Mr. Wargo said, noting that some 112,000 people with an average household income of $77,000 live within five miles of the site.
Still, the partners would not consider starting another project this size today, Mr. Wargo said, adding, "The retail climate is too iffy."

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
Bright Lights, Big Retail

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
THE young professionals nesting in this mushrooming city's Newport and Avalon Cove waterfront developments can cradle their Zest in a Tommy Hilfiger soap dish. The fashionable recent arrivals in the Porto Fino or Gotham high-rise buildings can wash their hands of second-tier department stores and dry them with Ralph Lauren bath towels.
 Macy's has arrived on this former industrial shoreline. And with it, at least in retail terms, so has Jersey City. 
 Macy's, the department store chain synonymous with New York's Thanksgiving Day Parade, whose Herald Square flagship is the largest store in the world, has opened a 168,000-square-foot store in the Newport Center mall.
While hardly Saks Fifth Avenue or even Neiman Marcus, Macy's is certainly the most upscale department store in this city, whose status as virtually a sixth borough of New York has become increasingly obvious as jobs jump across the Hudson, rents rise like skyscrapers and trendier residents look around for places to lighten their wallets.
In the retail pantheon, Macy's occupies a loftier pedestal than the two other stores flanking it at Newport Center -- Sears and J. C. Penney. Even the space occupied by Macy's, which used to house a Sterns store, is inadequate in the eyes of executives at Federated Department Stores, the Cincinnati-based retail conglomerate that owns Macy's and Bloomingdale's, and they plan to build a new 210,000-square-foot store at Newport Center.
But Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers, said it was difficult to tell whether building a new store was wise with the economy waning.
"A lot of people think the recession's going to end and the economy's going to get better," Mr. Feiner said. 
John D. Morris, a retail analyst for Gerard Klauer Mattison, said that he feared retailers were overbuilding, but that it was difficult to alter construction plans at the drop of a market index. 
"It's kind of hard to turn the battleship around," Mr. Morris said.
As for the Jersey City retail market, Mr. Morris said construction of a Macy's did not necessarily signal a significant change, particularly when Sears and other retailers continued to court new customers.
"The lines are blurred," he said. "It's harder to distinguish between the kind of customer who shops at a Macy or a Sears or even a T J Maxx, for that matter."
Just in case too much arriviste significance is attached to the Macy's move into Jersey city, it is part of a broader corporate decision announced by Federated in February to dissolve the Sterns chain, which Federated also owned, and replace Sterns stores with Macy's and Bloomingdale's.
But in planning to build an entirely new store at the mall, Federated has made a commitment to Jersey City beyond its other Sterns conversions, since, as a company spokeswoman acknowledged, Federated recognizes Jersey City as an emerging retail marketplace.
Indeed, the market demographics of Jersey City -- once a bustling blue-collar town -- are rapidly changing as office, residential and hotel projects are developed, said the spokeswoman, Jean Coggan.
Ms. Coggan said the company expected the Newport Center store to divert some traffic from the flagship Herald Square, which is linked almost door-to-door to the Newport Center store by the PATH train, which stops at 33rd Street in Manhattan and Newport-Pavonia in Jersey City, though she said any overlap would be minimal.
For now, said Carl Reggie, marketing director for Newport Center, which is owned by the Simon Property Group, a mall developer based in Indianapolis, the former Sterns space would be leased to another department store or divided into smaller retail spaces once Macy's moves into the new building next year.
"I think a lot of people have been waiting for a store like Macy's to come into the area," said Michelle Alonso, a planner in the Jersey City Planning Department. "It's a place where you can get solid name brands for work. Really, I think that's it."
A prominent anchor tenant can also set the tone for an entire mall, and Ms. Alonso said the Simon Property Group was as eager as any shopper for Macy's arrival.
But Mr. Reggie said the mall could not use the arrival of Macy's to lure other more upscale tenants soon because "we're basically 100 percent leased."
Though Jersey City's incomes are rising proportionately to the skyline, local business owners lamented that new residents had not thought of Jersey City as a place to shop, dine and have fun. 
But some of that apprehension seems to be lifting. In addition to the arrival of Macy's, there has also been a proliferation of trendy boutiques, restaurants, cafes and night spots in the city's historic downtown neighborhoods, just off the waterfront. 
Parallel to the more prosperous nature of the waterfront residents, who live in sparkling new high-rise buildings, there is also an increasing hipness to the younger and perhaps less-affluent residents of the brownstones and brick walk-ups of the city's historic Van Vorst, Hamilton Park and Harsimus Cove neighborhoods.
Leslie McCall, a professor of sociology at Rutgers and a 30-something habitual acquirer of jackets who shops at the mall, said the change in the city's atmosphere was palpable.
"I always talk to my friends about Jersey City, so the conversation inevitably turns to places to eat, places to shop, places to see movies," said Professor McCall, who has kept her eye -- as sociologist and fashionista -- on Newport Center's progression.
Even with Macy's arrival, Professor McCall said she was still frustrated by the limited selection at Newport, which included such mall staples as the Gap, Victoria's Secret and the Limited.
"I think it's still extremely limited, and I think most people from Manhattan or whatever are still, 'It's Jersey City, Prof,' " she said, mocking others' disdain for her adopted hometown. "But all my friends who come out here are shocked at how nice it is."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Holiday Shopping Altered by Sept. 11

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
IN any other year, Ellen Greenberg would have already clocked a fairly hefty number of shopping hours at the Palisades Mall in anticipation of her family's observance of both Hanukkah and Christmas.
 This is obviously not any other year. "I don't want to be in a mall," said Ms. Greenberg, an Irvington mother of three. Instead, Ms. Greenberg has shifted both the extent of her shopping and where she is making her holiday purchases. While she has gone to The Westchester mall in White Plains, mostly to satisfy the cravings of her 12-year-old daughter, Ms. Greenberg's preference has been the smaller stores in Irvington, or even the shopping district of Mount Kisco. 
 "I just feel like supporting the local stores," she said. "I feel bad for any merchant in a small town who's struggling this year."
Even so, Ms. Greenberg said: "I haven't shopped much. I haven't felt very materialistic lately. This is such an incredibly sad year. My husband works downtown, and I'm trying to key down what we're doing. What I feel right now is that I want my girls to be humble and grateful for what they have."
Like many other county residents whose shopping interests and habits have altered slightly this season, Ms. Greenberg's concerns reflect still another shift in the post-Sept. 11 landscape. Whether it's issues about personal safety in crowded places like malls in the aftermath of the horror of Sept. 11, anxiety about the economic uncertainties or even a lingering mourning process that casts a shadow over customary pursuits, the current holiday shopping season is subtly different from recent years. 
"I was at the Palisades Mall, starting to shop for Hanukkah, and part of me was pleased it seemed normal and part of me wished that the holiday was closer to Christmas, because it seemed too soon to be shopping like that," said Bonnie Moss, an Irvington resident who said she had been uncomfortable at the prospect of parking in The Westchester mall's garage. "You have to celebrate. We're going through the paces, but something seems wrong."
Granted, no one is saying that the malls are empty, or that suddenly there has been a wholesale swing to local merchants.
"We were very pleased with Thanksgiving weekend," said Robert Guerra, manager of The Westchester. "Traffic and sales were both up, compared to last year."
Similarly, at the Galleria mall in White Plains, "We have seen more traffic in the past three weeks, and I've seen people carrying multiple shopping bags," said Paula Kelliher, marketing director of that mall. "I've seen more of people wanting to indulge their kids than being skeptical of spending their money." 
While Harry Potter-themed merchandise, teenage paraphernalia and trendy products keep consumers flocking to malls, there also is increased interest in trimming the holiday gift list, supporting local merchants and searching for a different kind of experience. 
"There's a sense that people are quite concerned about their future and are cutting back on big expenditures for other people," said James Gould, professor of marketing at the Lubin School of Business at Pace University in White Plains. "People are holding back."
This translates into a desire to have these holidays be about something more than acquiring the latest must-have item, with some of the county's smaller stores and downtowns benefiting from this trend. 
"We've noticed an increase in foot traffic," said Manny Ennes, owner of Roberts Department Store in Mamaroneck, and chairman of the Mamaroneck Avenue Task Force. "There have been a lot of families out there on the street, especially Saturdays and Sundays. Our business is up considerably. What I'm hearing from customers is that they're more comfortable shopping in smaller stores. People want to come in and talk, they want to feel they can have a conversation. Knowing the person behind the counter seems more important now, instead of going where no one knows you."
At Buttermilk Blue in Irvington, a home decorating and folk arts store, Barbara Coccioletti, the owner, said: "I'm seeing people coming back after a quiet fall. I think people are ready for a joyous holiday, and I think Christmas and Hanukkah will be more meaningful this year. People may not buy as much, or may just want to buy something special. 
"They're going to hold family members closer," she added. "But in the back of everyone's mind is the idea of how difficult it is to sell stuff when so many people's lives have changed and there are people at war."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shoppers along Main Street in Irvington get a jump on buying for the holiday season. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)
