HEADLINE: In Florida, a New Emphasis on Design 

BYLINE:  By BETH DUNLOP; Beth Dunlop is an architecture critic and author based in Miami Beach.

 BODY:
BACK in 1981, a developer named Robert Davis set out from Miami on a sentimental journey through Florida. He had inherited 80 acres on the Gulf of Mexico in Florida's Panhandle, and he thought he would build a nostalgic beach town there. But nostalgia soon gave way to what came to be called "New Urbanism," and the result was Seaside, a tiny resort town that has attracted wide praise for its planning and architecture. Today, Florida has become a showcase for smart -- in several senses of the word -- development, with new towns that feature buildings by an array of illustrious architects and gifted young designers.
 Florida's New Urbanist developments -- ranging from sophisticated coastal resorts to college-town neighborhoods -- invoke historic architectural styles and turn developer cliches upside down. They offer houses on narrow, walkable streets that lead to parks, gardens, shops and even, in some cases, neighborhood schools. 
 Controversial at first, these traditional-neighborhood developments, whether new towns or suburban enclaves, are now considered by many real estate theorists to be the leading edge, especially as new studies show both growing demand for taut, livable neighborhoods, undergirded by strict principles of town planning, and better investment potential, indicating that houses in such developments appreciate better than their conventional counterparts. 
These new towns include Rosemary Beach and WaterColor on the Florida Panhandle; Windsor, near Vero Beach; and the much-discussed Celebration, near Orlando. At a time when luxury sales elsewhere, even in the recently booming South Beach section of Miami, are skittish, in the New Urbanist developments, houses and cottages, apartments and town houses command a premium price with no shortage of buyers, according to the developers.
"More than anywhere else in America, development in Florida proves that architecture and urbanism can transform the whole image, the value of a place," said the New York-based architect Robert A. M. Stern, dean of the Yale School of Architecture, who has been involved in the design of two of the Florida projects. 
What is happening in the state stems from a combination of idealism and hard-nosed business acumen. Twenty years ago, Seaside was regarded as a novel experiment, and scoffed at by developers accustomed to filling beachfronts with high-rises and suburban tracts with cookie-cutter houses on cul-de-sacs.
Today, Seaside is more often a source of admiration and emulation, and the Florida Panhandle, once derided as the "redneck Riviera," has assumed a far more sophisticated identity as other New Urbanist towns grow up on the sugar-sand dunes of the Gulf of Mexico. There are three of them now, with a fourth about to come out of the ground, all within an eight-mile stretch of coastline. "I can't think of any place else within hundreds of miles that is such a center of architectural excellence," said the Miami architect and town planner Andres Duany, who with his wife, Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk, planned Seaside and the nearby Rosemary Beach. 
Next to Seaside, which is only 80 acres, is the 499-acre town of WaterColor, which embraces both the beachfront and an inland coastal dune lake. Eight miles east is Rosemary Beach, a Caribbean-inspired cottage colony. Still to come -- with groundbreaking next year -- is WaterSound, to be built on more than a mile of untouched sand dunes.
"This is not some naive 'if you build it they will come' scheme,' " said Peter Rummel, chairman and chief executive of the St. Joe Company, the giant land company developing WaterColor and WaterSound. "This is calculated, and it starts with understanding the size and shape of the market. It is state of the art in terms of where we think community development is going, and philosophically we also believe that it's the right way to build."
It is not only the Florida Panhandle where this is taking place.
Celebration, the Walt Disney Company's much-watched new town next to the theme parks outside of Orlando, has just reached the ripe old age of 5 and has a population of approximately 5,000. Haile Plantation Village Center, with about 2,000 houses in a variety of neighborhoods connecting to a village center by wooded trails, greenways and a system of public commons, began two decades ago as a more conventional planned unit development on 1,700 acres near Gainesville just five miles from the University of Florida; its developers have recently annexed 550 more acres to continue building. And Windsor, the high-end resort town on the Atlantic coast just north of Vero Beach continues to grow slowly and garner admiration; it was the subject of the Institute for Classical Architecture's fall "salon" last month at the University Club in New York.
Axiomatically, such towns cost more than a typical subdivision. Home builders grouse that adding porches, almost an absolute in New Urbanist towns (although some codes call for garden walls and courtyards instead), automatically adds $8,000 to $10,000 to the price tag for construction that does not show up in the square-foot count.
The costs range widely: an average house in the New Urbanist-inspired SouthWood, near Tallahassee, sells for $171,800, and the bottom price at Celebration is $242,910. Haile Plantation, which already has 4,000 residents, offers numerous housing choices, from a $150,000 town house in the village center to a $450,000 house facing the golf course.
Seaside's cottages -- there are 430 of them, with a handful for sale at any given time -- are typically in the $800,000-to-$900,000 range but skyrocket into the low millions for those on the beach. At Rosemary Beach, "lofts" and "flats" sell for $315,000 and up, while a 5,500-square-foot house facing the gulf is on the market for $5.5 million. With 209 buildings completed and another 156 under way, Rosemary's prices go from $300 to $1,000 a square foot.
At Seaside, beachfront lots (no houses) sell for $1.6 to $2.3 million. Across the state at Windsor, lots sell for $200,000 to $3.6 million and houses list for $895,000 up past $5 milion. Windsor currently has 129 houses and will ultimately have about 350.
The list of those who have planned the towns reads like a Who's Who in architecture. Mr. Duany and Ms. Plater-Zyberk, who is also dean of the University of Miami School of Architecture, are among America's leading New Urbanists, with some 200 town plans to their credit, including Rosemary Beach and Windsor.
Mr. Stern and Jacquelin Robertson, a New York architect and former dean at the University of Virginia School of Architecture, together designed Celebration for Disney. Mr. Robertson is now the master planner for WaterColor, while Mr. Stern has designed WaterSound.
But that is just the beginning. Seaside has become a kind of architectural shrine, with buildings by architects as disparate as the Luxembourg-born Leon Krier and the late Aldo Rossi of Italy, both classicists, as well as such comparatively avant-garde designers as Steven Holl of New York and the firm of Mockbee-Coker of Auburn, Ala. There are houses and public buildings by such New York architects as Walter Chatham, Alex Gorlin and Deborah Berke, a mixed-use complex by Rodolfo Machado and Jorge Silvetti of Cambridge, Mass., and a new chapel by Scott Merrill of Vero Beach.
WaterColor's 60-room beachfront hotel was designed by the New York architect David Rockwell, known for his memorable restaurants, including Nobu. The Cambridge, Mass., architect Graham Gund designed WaterColor's $1.2 million beach apartments.
Celebration's downtown has buildings by Michael Graves, Robert Venturi and Denise Scott-Brown, Cesar Pelli, Philip Johnson and the late Charles Moore. At Windsor, there are a chapel by Mr. Krier, a beach club by Mr. Robertson and houses by the Duany & Plater-Zyberk firm and Hugh Newell Jacobsen. At Aqua, a New Urbanist-inspired residential enclave under construction in Miami Beach, the list of architects includes the firm of Harriri & Harriri as well as Mr. Chatham and Mr. Gorlin. 
Most buildings in these new towns are not by the famous, however, but by young architects based in Florida and elsewhere in the Southeast. "One of the things I'm proudest of is having been able to help young architects when they weren't well known," said Mr. Davis, Seaside's developer. "I have a pretty good batting average at picking young architects when they were just at the start of their career."
But architectural firepower is only part of the arsenal, according to Mr. Rummel of the St. Joe Company. "It all starts with an intelligent plan that you can execute wisely," he said. "It doesn't do any good to hire great architects unless you first hire great planners. However, if you plan really intelligently and put great architecture on top of that, the top line grows."
New Urbanist planning relies on the form and design of American towns built before World War II, and the principles derive from careful analysis by Duany & Plater-Zyberk and many others. Streets are purposely narrow, grids well-defined. Neighborhoods are organized on the idea of a "five-minute walk," which ensures that residents can get to a shop or park or tennis court without getting into a car.
OUT of this derives a set of architectural expectations, based on studies of local historic prototypes. As Celebration was being developed, for example, Disney sent the architect Joseph Barnes on a trip throughout the South, asking him to photograph every interesting small-town house and streetscape he could find. Celebration's houses are based on a range of architectural prototypes, up-to-date versions of Southern small-town domestic architecture. Current sales prices range from $242,910 for a town house to $975,000 for a seven-bedroom lakefront house.
Perhaps unexpectedly, architects say they luxuriate in working in the historic vernacular prescribed at these New Urbanist towns either by a code or a "pattern book." Mr. Robertson describes it as "exhilarating and liberating, a release." He added, "It's crossbred and so curious, an architecture that is at once rustic and funky and yet imbued with grand ideas."
At the 119-acre Rosemary Beach, the code calls for a tawny paint palette and houses with courtyard gardens and "sleeping porch" balconies. House styles based on an array of prototypes found in the Caribbean and early Spanish Florida, are prescribed and building materials are stipulated -- real stucco, lap siding, wood windows -- all to ensure that there is a high level of quality throughout the beachfront town. Every plan is scrutinized by the Rosemary Beach town architect, Richard Gibbs.
"You're buying a protection scheme, almost like hiring a bodyguard," Mr. Gibbs said. "You're trusting that somebody will watch your investment. My job is to watch out for the value of everybody's construction. We aren't changing the course midstream, so we don't entertain new ideas." 
That "protection scheme" yields houses -- the range is from full-fledged beach cottages to carriage houses -- that sell for $420,000 (for a one-bedroom dwelling) to $5.5 million on the beach.
Nearby, at WaterColor, home sites average $284,600 and new houses $518,000, though the apartments on the Gulf of Mexico more than double that price. WaterColor's house designs are based on a pattern book created by the Pittsburgh architect Ray Gindroz and his firm, Urban Design Associates, who first did such a book for Celebration. The pattern books offer what is in some ways a "kit of parts," showing designers and builders what is considered to be allowable massing, detailing and construction.
Critics of the New Urbanism range from tract home builders, who argue that the economies of large-scale production offered by their approach have wider market appeal, to academics who charge that the New Urbanism deflects attention from needy center cities.
New Urbanists respond to the former charge by citing studies showing a growing preference in the marketplace for traditional town developments. To the latter criticism, Mr. Duany, Ms. Plater-Zyberk and others can point to the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Hope Six program, in which much-debased public housing projects are being turned into neighborhoods and to other in-town projects (one such is in downtown Stewart, Fla.) that have relied on the ideas of New Urbanism.
Critics have also described Florida's New Urbanist developments as not being "real" because they are resorts. And indeed a number of Florida's New Urbanist towns -- the four in the Panhandle and Windsor -- are essentially resort towns, with just a few full-time residents, though the number is growing. Mr. Duany points out that historically most Florida towns originated as resorts -- "Miami was a resort," he said -- that evolved. "Resorts have to be utopias, so they have to be better than normal. They are a laboratory to a higher aspiration."
Analysts are looking at the emerging markets of demanding buyers -- such as middle-aged baby boomers with mobility, buying either second homes or seeking new places to live where the quality of life is high. A current study by Lend Lease Real Estate Investments, the giant property management firm, asserts that buyers increasingly want the amenity of well-planned communities. 
"These may not yet be communities, in the full sense of the word," Mr. Stern said, "but they are sounder in terms of their respect for the environment. They have more green space. The architecture is more fully integrated. And ultimately, they are aggregations of houses that make visual communities and will become real communities."
Rosemary Beach has a series of town greens, as well as smaller pocket parks and its own butterfly garden. Houses are linked to parks, pools and the beach by a series of sandy footpaths and wooden walkways. Seaside -- the oldest of Florida's New Urbanist towns -- has shops, restaurants, offices, a new chapel and a school in addition to its 430 homes. Windsor has a widely admired new chapel and town center, as well as the more unusual offering of a polo field.
Two other towns built along New Urbanist principles -- Abacoa in Jupiter and SouthWood in Tallahassee -- both have outpost campuses of the state university system as additional attractions. Celebration, which Mr. Stern calls "the most important of these towns in terms of its scope," has a kindergarten-through-12th-grade school as well as a lakeside "downtown" with shops, restaurants and a movie theater.
WaterColor not only has the hotel and neighboring beach club and its inland lake with a boathouse built and a restaurant planned. It also has a 600-foot long "central park" with a linear butterfly garden, tended by horticulturalists, as its centerpiece.
"The most obvious payout is the visual, the qualitative difference that results from good design," said P. Michael Reininger, senior vice president for creative services at the St. Joe Company, developer of SouthWood in addition to WaterColor and WaterSound. "What's even more interesting than the visual is the palpable value, the experiential value. Some of it comes at an obvious and overt level, but some is at a subconscious and subtle level."
In Florida land development, St. Joe is the proverbial gorilla. The company is the state's largest private landowner, with holdings of one million acres in northwest Florida alone, roughly the size of the state of Delaware. The company owns more than half the land in at least six counties in Florida. This makes it a formidable force in both land development and environmental conservation.
Mr. Rummel was named chairman and chief executive in 1997, after heading the development arm of the Walt Disney Company. That, of course, included the creation of Celebration. As a result, he has become one of the country's most articulate proponents of the soundness of the ideas of the New Urbanism, saying "it is the right way to build long-term value."
In Florida, the idea of a patient approach to building long-term value can be an anomalous one. Developers of high-rise condominiums can sell out quickly in hot markets and move on to another site. But for builders of towns and neighborhoods, the process is much more drawn-out, creating a greater long-term responsibility for quality.
THOUGH Florida law requires that governance be turned over to the buyers within 10 years, developers like Mr. Davis at Seaside or Galen Weston at Windsor tend to retain ownership of the public and commercial buildings, making them stakeholders in their own developments.
Mr. Duany, who recently was co-author with Ms. Plater-Zyberk and Jeff Speck of the book "Suburban Nation" and who lectures and writes frequently on all aspects of the New Urbanism, has made a case study of land prices in the Panhandle. He has found that inland lots in conventional beach developments in other Panhandle destinations like Destin are selling at $13 a square foot. At Rosemary Beach and WaterColor, an inland lot goes for $57 and $61 a square foot, respectively, while at Seaside an inland lot is twice that, $119 per square foot.
The phenomenal escalation of land values at Seaside is almost the stuff of real estate legend. The earliest lots sold for as low as $15,000 in the early 1980's; today a plot in Seaside's new cemetery sells for that price. A beachfront lot goes for between $1.6 million and $2.3 million, unbuilt. Away from the beach, lots start at $300,000. Houses that cost less than $100,000 in the 80's now sell from $499,000 to $1.1 million. Offering prices at other New Urbanist towns also tend to be at premium levels.
A recent study by John Rymer, vice president of the Texas-based Morrison Homes, examined Celebration and two other traditional-neighborhood developments (Kentlands in the Washington suburb of Gaithersburg, Md., and Laguna West near Sacramento) in comparison with nearby conventional counterparts. He discovered that though the initial investment was higher per square foot in New Urbanist neighborhoods, the appreciation over three years (1997-2000) was steadily better, an overall rate of 16.7 percent compared with 14.2 percent.
"People will pay more for well-thought-out design," Mr. Rummel said. "That's because we're building environments that have enduring value."

HEADLINE: Hollywood On the Hackensack 

BYLINE:  By MARGO NASH 

 BODY:
MORE feature films had scenes shot on location in New Jersey last year than in any prior year, with film production up 16 percent over 1999, according to an annual report issued by the New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission in November for 2000.
 The total number of film projects -- including features, television movies, television series and specials, music videos, short features, industrial films, documentaries and commercials -- was 664. Together they created a record annual revenue of $69.7 million for the state economy. 
 In 2000, part or all of 93 television series and specials were shot in the state, down from 118 the year before. Joseph Friedman, executive director of the commission, said the apparent decline was misleading because the commission, which was established in 1977, classifies each title as one project, even when it is a series with several episodes. 
Mr. Friedman added that in 2000 more episodes of television projects were filmed in the state than ever, pointing out that two series -- "Ed" on NBC and "Oz"on HBO -- are filmed regularly in New Jersey.
The report noted that since 1978, 8,314 film and television projects have been attracted to the state, and production companies have spent more than $648.2 million since then.
"Most of the reason for our success is we are getting repeat business," Mr. Friedman said.
Films with footage shot in New Jersey in 2000 include Woody Allen's "The Curse of the Jade Scorpion," which used the Hoboken Terminal as a stand-in for Grand Central Station, and "Miss Congeniality," with scenes shot in Weehawken. In that movie, Sandra Bullock plays an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who poses as Miss New Jersey in a beauty pageant.
Other films that used the state as a location in 2000 were "Riding in Cars with Boys," with scenes filmed in Bloomfield, East Orange and Newark, and "Ocean's Eleven," which filmed in Atlantic City and at East Jersey State Prison in Woodbridge. Some of the inmates were extras; their salaries went to the New Jersey Victims of Crime Compensation Board.
"Family Man," starring Nicolas Cage, was set and shot in the state, filming in East Rutherford, Fort Lee and other towns.
A year ago, Variety ranked New Jersey fifth in a list of the most popular states for location shooting, after California, New York, Florida and Illinois. But the state has a long way to go to catch up to New York City, where production expenditures add more than $5.6 billion a year to the city's economy, according to the New York City Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting.
But it is expensive to film in New York. New Jersey is cheaper and has other advantages as well, producers and location managers say. These include the state's proximity to New York, its geographic diversity and its ample, low-cost studio space, including the Bayonne Military Ocean Terminal of the United States Army, decommissioned in 1999. This month, the Bayonne Local Redevelopment Authority is planning to request proposals to create a permanent film facility at the site.
The Jersey City Armory and the Teaneck Armory have also been used as studios by movie companies.
The state's population is largely enthusiastic about filmmaking in their neighborhoods, unlike New York's more cynical citizens.
"In the last year, filmmaking in the New York area has been huge," said Helen Robin, who was co-producer for "Jade Scorpion." "There are times New York has become oversaturated, and the people get cranky. But in New Jersey, filmmaking is still a thrill for people, which makes it a fun experience for us."
Mr. Allen's films are usually shot at locations within an hour's drive from New York, often in New Jersey, though that is not always apparent. "Sweet and Lowdown" had scenes filmed in New Jersey, for example.
The television series "Ed," in its second season, is about a lawyer who returns home to Ohio from New York City to run a bowling alley and a legal practice. His girlfriend is a high school teacher. Though the show has nothing to do with New Jersey, the producers have made a commitment to the state.
In the first season, they transformed the former Country Club Lanes bowling alley in Northvale into Stuckeybowl, the show's bowling alley. They also filmed scenes at Montclair High School and in a courthouse in Nutley.
This year, they used space at the Country Club bowling alley, and at other buildings on its property, to build a high school hallway set that replicates one at Montclair, complete with scuff marks, and a classroom set modeled on a Montclair High classroom. They also built a courtroom set based on the Nutley courtroom.
In 2000, "Oz" moved its studio space from Manhattan to the Bayonne terminal; this year its fifth season is being shot there. "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit," on NBC, is shot at a studio in North Bergen. And "The Sopranos," on HBO, filming its fourth season, uses locations around New Jersey.
Films made at state locations this year include "A Beautiful Mind," about a Princeton mathematician; it was made in Princeton and Madison.
For some movie makers, New Jersey is metaphor as well as location. "Storytelling," directed by Newark-born Todd Solondz, is set in New Jersey though not in a specific town.
"It is established as being a commute from New York," said Ted Hope, a producer of the film. "What the Jersey conceit provides is that the audience knows there is obviously always something else on the horizon and the promise of a true melting pot of people -- yet they have the false security of a suburban life."
"Storytelling" opens in January.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ASTORIA; 
Black, White and Blue: The Layoffs at Steinway

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE O'DONNELL 

 BODY:
Pianos, the workers at the Steinway factory in Astoria will tell you, are more like humans than you'd think. It takes nine months to build one. Its wood does not respond well to extreme cold or humidity. 
 "Left alone, memory takes effect and tears it open again," said Michael A. Anesta, personnel director and piano-making expert, as he stroked a newly bent piano rim: 18 gingersnap-thin layers of unfinished maple glued together in Steinway's giant grand piano shape. So it was off to the hot room for the newborn rim, where heat would take care of the water-soluble glue and the rest of the maple's damp memory. 
 Mr. Anesta strolled around the sprawling factory the other day and was surprisingly well received by workers, given that he had recently laid off 60 of their colleagues, bringing the staff to 540. Piano sales had slowed with the rest of the economy earlier this year; Sept. 11 was the final straw. Not long ago the company produced a dozen pianos a week; now it's 10.
"I gathered everyone together and said: 'Guys, it's not you, it's external forces. Go out and tell everyone you know to buy a piano,' " Mr. Anesta recalled. "Then I go home and throw up. It's a good night."
Since the Steinways began building pianos on the Queens side of the East River 120 years ago, the piano maker has cultivated a reputation as a family employer for generations of New Yorkers. Men (and a few women) bend and sand and stain the instruments that will take center stage at Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center and the Kennedy Center. They vacation in Las Vegas and visit their pianos in the flashy hotel lobbies. Many of them play, but only when they think no one else is around. Steinway is an intimidating place to play, with celebrity pianists dropping by and giving impromptu concerts inside the plant.
Given the appeal of making a Steinway, an applicant might wait several years before a position opens. He might then spend his first year as a sweeper before becoming an apprentice to an expert craftsman who spots flaws in a wood's grain or eyes the curve of its belly.
"You're here for one or two years and its right for you, and the next thing you know you're looking at a gold watch," said Mr. Anesta, a 15-year veteran.
The 60 laid-off workers all had less than two years at the factory. Some were sweepers. Others, like Paul Muhabir, a former sugar cane factory worker from Guyana, were machinists. He had waited five years for a friend who worked at Steinway to tell him of an opening. Now another friend has told him of a construction job in Brooklyn, and Mr. Muhabir sighs at the thought. 
"Steinway was a very nice, different type of job," he said from his home in the Westchester section of the Bronx. "We were making things that were beautiful."
Steinway said it received an unusually large number of orders Thanksgiving weekend at a sales promotion in a Westchester County hotel.
"Everybody knows the piano business is the first to get hit and the last to come back when the economy slows," said Harry Boot, president of Local 102 and a 43-year veteran piano maker. "It's not like a department store where you pick up a shirt and ring it in the cash register."
 MICHELLE O'DONNELL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many of the workers play, but only when they think no one is around. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Future of Up 

BYLINE:  By WITOLD RYBCZYNSKI; Witold Rybczynski's books include "A Clearing in the Distance: Frederick Law Olmsted and America in the 19th Century" and "The Look of Architecture."

 BODY:
I LOVE the skyscrapers of Manhattan. After all these years it's still a thrill to see them from far away, across the Hudson River, piled up like exclamation points at the center of the metropolis, or sticking out of the treetops, forming a great manmade escarpment at the edge of Central Park. They are both impressive and, for some reason, poignant. 
 I like the feeling of walking down the urban canyons created by rows of tall buildings. Their sheer variety is also a source of pleasure: the classical tempietto atop the Municipal Building, the sober Empire State, the jazzy jukebox of the Chrysler's pinnacle and the Seagram's dark intensity. More than most buildings, skyscrapers acquire distinct personalities, not only because they are landmarks but also because they resemble human figures, giant sentinels, overlooking the city below. 
 People have always been fascinated by tall structures. The history of architecture is a cavalcade of steeples, spires, bell towers, clock towers, keeps, minarets and pagodas. Whether it was the structural challenge or the symbolic effect of a building that could be seen from a distance, the attraction of towers was universal. They were places to drop unpleasant things on attackers from, to hang bells in, to call prayers from and to look out from. 
Whether it's the campanile in Venice's Piazza San Marco, the Eiffel Tower, or just a village church steeple, there is something endlessly absorbing about looking down from a high place. So what could be better than a city of towers, not just lookouts, but places of work and residence from which you could enjoy the view all the time? 
But the exhilaration inspired by raw height has been tempered since Sept. 11. While much has been written about skyscrapers recently, as the debate about how to rebuild Lower Manhattan intensifies, it is critical to step back and consider how skyscrapers contribute to a vital city.
It is true that since the terrorist attacks, the same exciting Manhattan skyline suddenly strikes many as a liability. Some are even nervous about living or working in tall buildings, although such reactions, similar to those that follow great earthquakes, will most likely be short-lived.
Yet there is little doubt that our self-confidence has been shaken. The proud towers of the city are now described as emblems not of technological prowess but merely of hubris. Reaching into the sky is rash, we are told, tempting fate or, at least, tempting malevolence. Better to hunker down, keep a low profile. But it would be a shame if, in the rush to glean some meaning from the awful events of Sept. 11, we were to give up on the skyscraper.
The skyscraper is a New York product. Chicago is often called the home of the skyscraper, but the first modern high-rise office building was built in Manhattan. The seven-story Equitable Building at Broadway and Cedar, completed in 1870, not only incorporated Elisha Otis's newfangled safety elevator, it also featured an iron-frame structure and an integrated heating and ventilation system.
It was followed by Richard Morris Hunt's Tribune Building, which rose an unprecedented nine floors across from City Hall, 260 feet to the top of its clock tower, and George B. Post's 10-story Western Union Building at Broadway and Dey Street, with a flamboyant Renaissance facade marked by alternating bands of granite and red brick. That was only the beginning. By the early 1900's, skyscrapers had soared past 50 floors.
The skyscraper began life as a businessman's brainchild, a way to squeeze greater profits from expensive downtown real estate. Yet the dramatic spires of Hunt and Post's skyscrapers (both sadly demolished) are a reminder that these commercial buildings were also secular symbols, totems of corporate and technological prowess.
But skyscrapers were not simply private icons. They came to stand for the country itself: its newness, its brash self-confidence, its unfettered freedom. Although tall buildings have sprung up around the world, the Manhattan skyline remains as unmistakably American as jazz, jeans and fast food. No wonder the twin towers were the target of terrorists.
But, terrorists or no, there are two compelling reasons to continue to build tall buildings. First, they are how we make cities. We did not have emperors and popes and kings to lay out public squares, grand boulevards and palaces. Our prosaic, practical cities achieve a distinctive monumentality in their skylines. What makes our cities unique is their upward thrust. Skyscrapers are an integral part of their character. An American city without skyscrapers would be like, well, Washington; beautiful, but oddly alien.
The second reason for building skyscrapers is that they make sense, economically and urbanistically. Tall buildings exist not because urban land is expensive, rather, urban land is expensive because many people want to work and live near one another, whether they are trading stocks or exchanging information. Tall buildings efficiently accommodate this demand. They also do something else: they allow cities to be highly concentrated and create the conditions for vibrant city life, which in turn attracts even more people. 
Skyscrapers are definitely more vulnerable to terrorism than low buildings. There was a dramatic difference in the number of casualties in the attacks on the 110-story World Trade Center towers and the 6-story Pentagon. The immediate damage caused by the impact of a Boeing 767 was probably comparable. But in one case the destruction remained local, while in the other entire buildings collapsed.
Can skyscrapers be made safer? Engineers and architects have learned to design tall buildings that resist earthquakes, and they should be able to better protect buildings and their inhabitants from the sort of intense fires that weakened the World Trade Center structures. The necessary safety measures will increase the cost of construction, but like air bags in cars they will be demanded -- and paid for -- by the users.
I remember when you could simply wander into an office building lobby and go straight to the elevators. Just as most office buildings today have security desks, in the future they will probably incorporate a range of antiterrorist devices currently found only in airports and embassies. None of this need produce ugly buildings, but there will always be a self-imposed limit to architectural hardening.
Cities thrive on openness and human interaction, and a city of bunkers would be a contradiction. Architects will have to learn how to make buildings safer and more secure unobtrusively, the way they have learned to deal with handicapped access and energy conservation.
The debate should not be about whether to build tall buildings, but how tall they should be. Most skyscrapers built today are in the 30-to-40-story range; buildings like the 110-story trade center towers, and the Sears Tower in Chicago, are in a far different category: superskyscrapers.
When they were built, the World Trade Center towers were the tallest buildings in the world. Today, constructing the world's tallest building is a dubious accomplishment, like making the world's longest salami. It's a challenge, but once you know it can be done, you ask yourself, "Why bother?" 
Some things get better as they get bigger. The dome of the cathedral of Florence is impressive precisely because it is so large; so is the nave of Westminster Abbey. But skyscrapers don't necessarily improve with height. I remember my visit to the Sears Tower, an uninspired design that only a steel prefabricator could love. After an interminable ride in a banal elevator car, we arrived at the 103rd-floor observation deck, which had all the romance of an unoccupied office floor. The view was obscured by low-lying clouds. 
One of the most evocative skyscrapers is Daniel Burnham's Flatiron Building, whose narrow shiplike prow fills a triangular sliver of ground where Broadway intersects Fifth Avenue. It is all of 22 stories high. The Flatiron is a reminder that the impact of a skyscraper is less a function of its actual height than of its soaring expression of verticality. It's not about how tall the building is, but about how tall it makes us feel. Whenever I look across the Rockefeller Center plaza at Raymond Hood's RCA Building, which shoots up like a craggy promontory, I feel exhilaration. The Sears Tower just makes me feel small.
Superskyscrapers were obsolete long before Sept. 11, as outmoded as tail fins on cars. That is why there have been none built in this country in the last 30 years. The reason has to do with economics. Wind pressure increases with height, and in a superskyscraper, extra structure is required to resist this force. More structure means more and larger columns, either on the outside where they block the windows, or on the inside where they eat up space and interfere with the offices.
But the real sticking point is the elevators. If there are not enough elevators, it takes too long to reach the upper floors, but additional elevators reduce the amount of rentable space.
The economically viable height of a commercial building is a complicated function of land value, construction costs and rents, but I suspect that it is nowhere close to 100 floors. In New York, the maximum economic height for office buildings is probably in the 50-story range. In other cities, with lower land values and rents, 30 stories is probably the limit. Apartment buildings require fewer elevators, hence they can be higher, as the 72-story Trump World Tower shows.
The dubious economic advantages of superskyscrapers have stymied recent attempts to build them. In 1989, the British architect Sir Norman Foster designed a 170-story conical tower to be built in Tokyo Bay. The collapse of the Japanese real estate market, followed by a weakening of the entire economy, has delayed this grandiose project indefinitely. 
In the early 1990's, a 125-story skyscraper was proposed for the Chicago Loop, but was abandoned when the real estate market turned soft. A few years later, the project was revived with a slightly lower 112-story design. That proposal, too, died because of financing problems.
The only place where superskyscrapers continue to be built is in Asia. Here the driving forces are booming urban growth and the desire for attention. The world's tallest skyscraper, built by Malaysia's national petroleum company, is currently in Kuala Lumpur, and even taller buildings are planned for Hong Kong and Shanghai. 
These skyscrapers, largely designed, engineered and built by foreigners, are hardly homegrown products, so it's unclear exactly what they prove. Perhaps only that records that can be bought are not worth breaking.
There have been significant innovations in the design of tall buildings in the last decade, but they are not about building higher. Many of the skyscrapers being built in Europe and Asia are what is called mixed-use buildings, with shops, restaurants and entertainment at sidewalk level, offices on the lower floors, and hotels or apartments above, to take advantage of the views. Such buildings, 24-hour buildings, hum with activity and are a sharp contrast to single-use office towers, which empty out at 5 o'clock on Friday and remain empty all weekend, sucking the vitality from their surroundings. 
During the 1970's and 1980's, while postmodern architects toyed with reflective glass, ornamental granite veneers and Chippendale tops, the interiors of skyscrapers remained largely unchanged: repetitive floors of mind-numbing uniformity, sealed spaces with flickering fluorescent lights, stale air, and acres of suspended ceilings and nylon carpeting. 
In the 1990's a new generation of office buildings appeared. Their architects were not just concerned with creating dramatic corporate symbols. Recognizing that workers in skyscrapers cannot easily step out of their offices for a stroll in the park, they brought green space into the buildings. Sir Norman's Commerzbank headquarters in Frankfurt, for example, includes internal garden terraces every eight floors, giving workers a sense of community.
It is paradoxical that the most innovative skyscrapers of recent years have been built outside the United States. But the challenge of rebuilding Lower Manhattan creates an opportunity to redress the situation.
It gives us the chance to rethink how we build tall buildings, making them functionally and environmentally superior, conserving energy, providing a humanized environment in which to live and work, and encompassing an assortment of uses as varied as the city itself. Not taller, better.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Vacancies, Yes, but Guarded Optimism

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
HOTEL, gambling and cruise-line companies have been hit hard as thousands of would-be vacationers decided to stay home after Sept. 11.
 As the leisure-time industry moves into what is traditionally one of its busiest periods, bookings are down and prices are being cut. 
 The stock market, however, is not emphasizing those numbers. Investors have bid up prices of these stocks in recent weeks, apparently assuming that the worst is already over. 
Jason Ader, a leisure-time analyst at Bear Stearns, took some time last week to talk about trends in the industry. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. What is the holiday outlook for hotel, gambling and cruise-line companies?

A. Things have stabilized, but bookings are still well below last year's levels. The leisure market has been price-driven. Individuals are worried about traveling and are actively seeking the best deals they can get. They are also waiting until the last minute, which is a real problem for these companies.
The good news is that a lot of people were nervous traveling last year as well, and as a result the performance in 2000 was lackluster. Also, since Thanksgiving, when there were no reports of terrorism and no major glitches in the system, travel agents have seen a surge in bookings for the post-Christmas period.

Q. You seem to be taking a cautious view about these companies, but their stock prices are solidly above their post-Sept. 11 lows. Has the market overreacted?

A. Business has not come back nearly as much as the stock prices have. The stocks are reflecting a very optimistic recovery and are saying that earnings estimates are too low. We are expecting a 2003 recovery, but the stocks are a bit more optimistic than that.

Q. P & O Princess combined with Royal Caribbean late last month. Is the business worth an investment?

A. Financially, it was a good deal for both sets of shareholders. It will create a much stronger company with a lower cost of debt.
With this merger, there are now going to be two major companies in the business. Carnival Cruise Lines is the other. 
But the business is fraught with oversupply. The fact the industry has had to discount prices to drive sales volume is evidence of that. From an investment perspective, the industry will be a lot more interesting in a couple of years, when the industry has absorbed these new ships. 

Q. Are there sections of the leisure business that you prefer at the moment?

A. The best area right now is riverboat gambling, which after defense and health care has probably been the third-best segment of the American economy in terms of consumption since Sept. 11.
The riverboat business is very resilient, and more states will legalize gambling over the next few years. In 2002, 31 states are facing budget deficits. We expect a number will legalize gambling to help address that problem.

Q. Which companies have significant riverboat operations?

A. Harrah's Entertainment, Argosy Gaming and Penn National are my favorite stocks in this area.

Q. Do you favor hotel stocks?

A. The only hotel stock we are recommending is Starwood, which is still cheap relative to what its assets are worth. They have an asset value of $37 to $40 a share, and the stock is currently trading in the high $20's.
We think Four Seasons is overpriced. The high end of the hotel market is the segment that is the slowest to recover. Most corporations are discouraging luxury business-related travel. Much of the company's growth prospects are in properties in the Middle East, which doesn't look like it is going to be a popular destination for some time. And it is trading at twice the valuation of Marriott, its closest peer. 
Marriott is a great company, but it is very fairly priced.

Q. Over the last few years there have been a number of mergers in your business, including the cruise deal announced last month. Is it reasonable to assume that the leisure-time industry will see further consolidation?

A. The gaming industry will continue to consolidate because there are a limited number of riverboat licenses out there, and Sept. 11 taught the Las Vegas companies that it may make sense to diversify into areas of gaming that are less dependent on air travel.
There will be more acquisitions in hotels. The U.S. industry will consolidate with the Europeans to create global lodging companies. The question is how they will pair up.

HEADLINE: After Sept. 11, A Rise in Gun Sales 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "As Shooting Spate Persists, 15 Police Leaders Face Transfers" (news article, Dec. 5):
 A major cause of the increase in shootings is the spike in gun sales after Sept. 11. 
Nationwide, sales increased by 21 percent, and reports indicate that the increase may have been greater in New York. 
 Under increasing economic and psychological pressure (prescriptions for antidepressants increased by 22 percent in New York at the end of September), arguments once defined by angry words can escalate when guns are available. Guns kept in the home for self-protection are used 22 times more often to kill somebody you know than to kill in self-defense.
Terrorism has already caused untold misery. We need not add more deaths to the toll. People need to think before buying a weapon. If they buy one, they need to store it properly: unloaded, locked, with the ammunition stored separately and securely.

ROBERT SELTZER
Executive Director
Doctors Against Handgun Injury
New York, Dec. 5, 2001

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Warming Up, aBit, to Stock Offerings

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
INVESTORS have resumed dipping their toes into the market for initial public offerings. But with little prospect of making a fortune overnight, the buyers are more likely to be long-term shareholders than short-term opportunists. 
 The situation contrasts with the frenzied atmosphere of the late 1990's and early 2000, when shares of initial offerings were known to multiply in price on their first trading day, and many investors cashed out with quick profits. In those years, many institutional investors, from mutual funds and pension plans to hedge funds and private equity pools, were eager to buy hot new offerings at any price, regardless of how well they knew the balance sheet of a company or whether it had any profits. 
 But this year, jitters about stocks and the economy have led 160 companies to cancel their initial offerings. By comparison, only 78 have gone public, according to ipo.com, a firm in New York that tracks the market for public offerings and venture capital.
Not only are investors wary of risky companies, but the issuers and underwriters of public offerings are taking a hard look at which investors might be coming aboard. 
As a result, said Mark R. Tercek, global co-head of equity capital markets at Goldman Sachs, bankers are being particularly careful as underwriters in assessing how well an investment firm's analysts and fund managers understand an issuing company's financial statements, industry and competitors before they allocate stock to potential buyers. "In this market, there is a greater effort to work with and attract well-informed investors," Mr. Tercek said.
HPL Technologies, a software firm based in San Jose, Calif., had its lead underwriter, UBS Warburg, peruse trading data and regulatory filings on investors' holdings to help select buyers in the weeks before its $66 million initial offering on July 30.
Potential investors were screened by how long they had held individual software stocks in the past and what market news had led them to sell. Those using a quantitative approach, focused on movement in stock price and trading volume, were deemed less desirable than those using fundamental analysis of company finances.
"You wouldn't have seen this process a year or two ago," said Y. David Lepejian, president and chief executive of HPL. Mr. Lepejian and UBS Warburg declined to name investors who received reduced allocations, or none at all, as a result of the vetting.
During the boom in initial offerings that symbolized the dot-com frenzy, investment bankers, eager to sell stocks in young companies, knocked on the door of just about every potential institutional investor. "You used to take a 'turn over every rock' approach," said Mark Connelly, head of United States equity capital markets at UBS Warburg. Now, he said, "the road shows are more targeted and more focused on fewer institutional buyers."
To be sure, some investors, burned by investments in dot-coms that later went bust, have been passing up the new offerings. "There are some institutional investors sitting on the sidelines," said Wade I. Massad, managing director for United States capital markets at RBC Capital Markets in Minneapolis. He said some investors were more interested in buying depressed shares in companies that were already public than stock in companies trying to enter an uncertain market. 
NO new companies went public from Aug. 14 to Oct. 2 -- the longest halt in the business since the recession of 1973-74, said Kyle Huske, a marketing analyst at ipo.com.
Still, the business of taking companies public is showing signs of life, despite an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into questionable practices by some investment banks. Regulators are investigating whether banks allocated shares to investors in exchange for stock trades by the investors through the banks' brokerage arms at high commissions.
The 78 companies that have gone public this year, raising $34.9 billion, is far below the numbers of the last two years, according to ipo.com. In 1999, 527 companies raised $69 billion, while in 2000, 415 companies raised $100 billion, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. In dollars, this year is more in line with 1998, when 357 companies raised $36 billion. 
And the returns are much tamer. This year, the average new company has posted a gain of 12.88 percent on its first day of trading, versus 53 percent last year and 68 percent in 1999, ipomonitor.com said.
There is another big difference. "We haven't seen investors willing to go up the risk curve and purchase a good story with no earnings," said Jay Chandler, managing director of equity capital markets at Merrill Lynch. Since Sept. 11, the offerings have been mainly from established companies with solid earnings records. Examples are Weight Watchers International or the Principal Financial Group, the insurance company -- a contrast to the dot-coms of previous years. 
Valuations, or the prices at which the new shares are set, are considerably lower, and many stocks have held up well after their first day of trading, Mr. Chandler said.
This week is to be the busiest this year. Nine offerings are in the pipeline, including Prudential Financial, the insurer, which plans to raise $3 billion on Wednesday. On Monday, Aramark Worldwide, a food and uniform services company, is set to raise $645 million, and Converium Holding, the reinsurance arm of Zurich Financial Services, plans to sell $1.7 billion. 
But some bankers say the new-offerings market cannot regain solid footing until it broadens to include companies in other sectors. "Things are not yet back," Mr. Massad said. "That would be an overstatement."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Trucking Awaits the Next Boom

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH KELLEHER 

 BODY:
TRUCKING company profits have been weak for close to two years, but share prices have begun to rise, as investors anticipate a payoff from an eventual economic recovery.
 The trucking business is highly cyclical, and share prices reflect expectations for the economy six months from now, said Jason Seidl, an analyst at ABN Amro. 
 Generally, analysts say, companies that haul full loads for a single customer are more promising than those that fill trucks with partial loads for several customers. The full-load side of the industry has moved along on low profit margins, they say, and is therefore likely to benefit more when demand returns. Tonnage hauled has declined by nearly 8 percent since late 1999. 
The full-load trucking business is very fragmented, with the top 10 companies accounting for only 5 percent of the segment's $280 billion in annual revenue.
Bankruptcies across the industry in 2001 are estimated to be four times the 1999 level, according to research by A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. Analysts say more consolidation may be ahead, helping stronger companies build market share.
Donald Broughton, transportation equity analyst at A. G. Edwards, said solid investment choices included Swift Transportation in Phoenix, Werner Enterprises in Omaha and J. B. Hunt Transport Services in Lowell, Ark. Werner has zero debt, he said, and the others' balance sheets are in good shape as well. 
Thom Albrecht, senior vice president for transportation research at BB&T Capital Markets, said he favored Landstar System of Jacksonville, Fla. Its stock now trades at $72.27, below its high this year of $81.14. The company consistently generates much free cash flow, Mr. Albrecht said, and has used it for stock buybacks. 
Ed Wolfe, a logistics analyst at Bear Stearns, recommended Knight Transportation of Phoenix, Covenant Transport of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Heartland Express of Iowa City, Iowa. Both Knight and Heartland managed double-digit increases in earnings per share in the difficult third quarter, versus the quarter a year earlier. While Covenant's earnings are not performing as well, he said, he believes that the company is at a turning point. 
"Covenant has really focused on the cost side," he added. "Because it has suffered from weak demand, it reduced the fleet size" and improved the efficiency of its routes.
When demand picks up and shipping rates improve, he said, its earnings and share price should rise.
Mr. Broughton said he thought shares of Knight and Heartland were now expensive. Knight closed on Friday at $29.16, near its high for the year of $30.46. Heartland closed at $29, just under its high of $30.90. Knight trades at 37 times earnings for the previous 12 months, while Heartland's multiple is 25. "These are great companies," he said, "but they are trucking stocks, not microbiology." 
Kevin Knight, chief executive of Knight Transportation, said it is, in fact, a growth company. It has expanded from the West into the Midwest and the East. "We are anticipating more expansion depending on how the economy does," he said. 
Daniel Moore, an analyst at Stephens Inc., recommended P.A.M. Transportation Services of Tontitown, Ark. It is in line with Knight in size and revenue, he said, and its earnings are growing, but it is trading at just eight times earnings.
Mr. Albrecht is bullish on the entire group, including Knight and Heartland. "It is only going to get better," he said. Share prices of a representative group of eight full-load trucking companies have risen 41 percent this year.
Mr. Seidl advised investors to stay on the sidelines for now. A post-holiday lull in demand for haulers is likely, he said, and winter delays may lower stock prices during the first quarter. When prices dip, he would move in and buy.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
Onthe Home Front, a Welcome Economic Kick

BYLINE:  By JANE TANNER

DATELINE: WADEVILLE, N.C. 

 BODY:
TO this rural town, population 400 and an hour east of Charlotte, Afghanistan may seem far away. But not the war effort.
 Two days after the terrorist attacks, as the United States prepared for military action against the Taliban, Victor A. Karam, president of McRae Footwear here, got a call from Theresa Scheetz, a federal government liaison for military suppliers. 
 Ms. Scheetz, in Philadelphia, told Mr. Karam that tens of thousands of military combat boots would be needed -- fast. Within a few weeks, the supply order came through: 100,000 pairs by February. 
Mr. Karam immediately began revving up McRae for night shifts -- the plant now makes about 1,200 pairs of boots a day, an increase of 60 percent from its normal workload -- and adding workers. 
And the company started buying more leather, rubber compounds and boot laces that go into the thick-sole boots.
McRae Footwear is one of four United States companies that assemble combat boots for the Army, Navy and Air Force. It has made them under government contracts since 1967 in an old converted elementary school here next to the volunteer fire department, the Wadeville Baptist Church and a cemetery. The company is one of the area's few large employers.
The surge in demand was welcome news to the town and surrounding Montgomery County, where the unemployment rate has risen to about 8 percent, compared with 5.7 percent nationally, partly because of layoffs at a pine tree mill and the shutdown of two hosiery mills. "If we had tried to hire additional people a year ago," Mr. Karam said, "it would have been impossible." 
Instead, about 350 people lined up to apply for jobs. So far, the company has added about 50 people to its regular payroll of 130.
Longtime workers are putting in long hours. Larry Baldwin, an employee for 26 years, said he was working 13-hour shifts but did not mind. "It helps me double up on my mortgage" payments, he said, placing a leather boot upside down onto a metal mold. He then slid it into a hot chamber where melted rubber was molded into a thick sole. 
The workers, who are paid by the piece and have no union, make about $7.50 to $8.50 an hour, although fast, skilled workers can make $11 an hour.
The combat boot order was welcome news for the footwear company's parent, McRae Industries, based in Mount Gilead, N.C., five miles south. It lost $697,000 in its 2001 fiscal year, compared with earnings of just under $1.4 million the previous period; revenue was $57.1 million each year. The company, which also makes cowboy boots, leases office equipment and supplies bar-code readers, needed more business. Its shares, now at $5.35, have risen 45 percent since Sept. 11.
The combat boot order should add $2 million to $4 million in revenue for fiscal 2002, said D. Gary McRae, 51, the chief executive.
This is not the first time that the deployment of American troops has given the company's business a lift. 
Mr. McRae was 17 and working part time at his father's shoe factory when it got its first military contract. His father, Branson McRae, started the company in 1959 by making sturdy play shoes for children. Seven years later, it had more than $1 million in debt. "We were on the ropes, looking for an answer," Mr. McRae said. "The Vietnam War brought the answer. It was a savior." 
The Army liked the technique McRae and a few others were using: molding rubber soles directly onto the leather of the boots, rather than the prevailing method of stitching. The molded soles lasted longer and did not separate from the shoes. That is just what soldiers needed when stomping around in Vietnam's rice paddies and jungle muck. Water had been rotting their boot stitching.
"We had the machinery and know-how to bid on those boots," said Mr. McRae, who took over as president in 1997, after his father died. In 1967, McRae Footwear and 13 other companies shared the boot contract, and McRae has made boots for soldiers almost continuously since.
The industry has consolidated considerably. Besides McRae, only Wellco Enterprises in Waynesville, N.C., Belleville Shoe Manufacturing in Illinois and the Altama Delta Corporation in Roswell, Ga., make combat boots for the government in this country. The armed forces must have domestic suppliers under federal law.
American combat boots have their own style history. The Corcoran Jump Boot, first made for the armed forces by the Joseph Corcoran Shoe Company in the 1940's, has long been favored by paratroopers. The Vietnam era brought the Vietnam jungle boot -- green leather and canvas uppers with thick green rubber soles. The Persian Gulf war brought a new design, the desert boot, made with tan suede leather. This winter, some soldiers in Afghanistan will wear a cold-weather boot.
McRae Footwear has adapted to changing styles, but other problems are harder to solve. In mid-1985, finding enough labor was so difficult that Mr. Karam recruited Laotian refugees. As an inducement, the company put 20 mobile homes on one- and two-acre lots on a hillside near the plant.
Today, a visitor might mistake part of Wadeville for a transplanted Laotian village. Laotian families toil in big vegetable gardens. Flocks of chickens and ducks run around in yards. About one-quarter of McRae Footwear's workers in Wadeville are Laotian. 
Vone Thpphalath, 20, who lived in a refugee camp in Laos for eight years before she came to the United States a decade ago, inspects leather cutout boot sections for defects. Before the order increase, she inspected about three cases of leather sections an hour. Now, she looks at five cases an hour. "It is tiring," she said. 
The added work has had ripple effects on McRae's suppliers. Boot-making begins with large sides of cowhide. Mr. Karam, 56, pressed for quick delivery of big loads of hides from the S. B. Foot Tanning Company, based in Red Wing, Minn., and a large supplier of leather for military combat boots. 
S. B. Foot, however, had laid off workers in May and June because business had slowed. But when its president, Silas Buck Foot, saw the World Trade Center collapse in September, he said, he sensed that a military conflict would follow. He called Pentagon procurement officers and asked about the possibility of large orders. 
"We started gearing up immediately without the actual order for the product," Mr. Foot said. He had no trouble getting his hands on additional cowhides, but his staff had to put in six- and seven-day workweeks to send enough raw material to North Carolina. "We had people putting in difficult hours," he said. But, he said, he was happy to have the business.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Phone Samsombath, left, at work at McRae Footwear. Two days after Sept. 11, Victor A. Karam, above, McRae's president, began preparing to increase its combat boot production. (Photographs by Tracy Wilcox for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Brighter Holiday (If the Goods Hold Out) 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
IF you visit garnethill.com, the online arm of the catalog retailer Garnet Hill, don't expect to buy those cute suede slippers from Italy. Every size but 7 is sold out. The same goes for those handsome suede shirts, one of the company's recommended holiday gifts.
 Lands' End, that paragon of mail-order retailing, won't have any of its hot new all-weather moccasins until spring. Its reversible down jacket is on back order for most children's sizes, scheduled to ship by Dec. 18, almost the last day it can ensure delivery by Christmas. 
 Spin Masters, manufacturer of the popular retro toy Shrinky Dinks, expects all 400,000 it made this season to have sold out of stores by now, and Amazon.com is already sold out of Epson's popular Stylus Photo 870 printer. 
In short, this holiday just might not be the bust it was cracked up to be, and therein lies a different sort of problem. Only halfway through the holiday selling season, inventory -- whether stores have too many goods, too few or just enough -- has emerged as perhaps the defining issue for retailers and manufacturers. 
Long before the government made it official last month that the country was in a recession, retailers from Federated Department Stores to J. C. Penney to Gap Inc. sensed a sharp economic downturn coming. They scaled back their holiday orders last spring. The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 further discouraged merchants, causing many department stores and large specialty retailers to cancel or return orders and toss out plans for reorders.
Now, some hit products are selling out. Though the examples cited may be isolated ones, it is rare for merchandise other than toys and extremely high-end fashion goods to be unavailable at this point in the season, particularly from mail-order companies. It suggests more, and more widespread, shortages over the next two weeks, and it presents a new obstacle for retailers in a year in which shoppers are already finicky.
For a vast majority of retailers, the Grinch visited long before the season began, officially the day after Thanksgiving. Sales are weak, with consumer spending shifting away from flashy big-ticket merchandise like designer handbags and jewelry in favor of simpler, homier fare like Ping-Pong tables and fuzzy slippers. Still, with corporate America cinching its purse strings, even with extremely low interest rates, the consumer's role in getting the economy back on its feet is bigger than ever. 
A true merchant hates to lose a potential sale, which is what often happens when inventories are lean and most merchandise is ordered from factories in Asia and other far-flung points. The idea of losing a sale because of not having ordered enough, in a season when any sale is hard to come by, is almost unbearable.
"You are at the beginning of what will be a frantic season, for retailers and for consumers," said Walter F. Loeb, head of Loeb Associates, a retail consulting firm. "Retailers are just not prepared for any unusual spike in demand. They've cut back on merchandise, they've cut back on people, they've cut back even on light bulbs."
INVENTORIES, of course, are always a vital issue; every year, retailers must walk a fine line. Wall Street applauds the companies that keep inventory tight -- on the theory that markdowns, which eat away at profits, will not be necessary. 
But this year, many are cutting it close. Most retailers would rather err on the side of falling short of a few popular products than having piles and piles of unsold goods to mark down. "In my speech this year to the troops, I'm telling them that no one ever filed Chapter 11 because their inventory turned too fast," said Michael Gould, the longtime chief executive of Bloomingdale's.
He conceded that inventories were leaner in general but said that posed no problems. "You're always going to have an item here or there that you can't replenish," he said. "But we've all learned better merchandise planning and better replenishment."
Manufacturers, though, say they are also keeping inventories lean this year. "We asked them to call early if they needed to replenish stocks," said Jeff Cove, a vice president at Panasonic Consumer Electronics, the United States sales arm for Matsushita's televisions, video and DVD players and one of the biggest consumer electronics suppliers in the country.
Mr. Cove skirted the issue of whether products ordered today would be available for Christmas, although he did say that merchandise priced promotionally, like basic TV's and DVD players, might run short. "Things are going to be tight at Christmastime," he said. "There are going to be some spot shortages."
No one is expecting consumers to storm the malls. Retailers, especially the department and specialty stores that trade in more fashion-sensitive merchandise, may end up with too much of some products because business is so weak. But they may also run short of goods that customers crave, which could alienate shoppers and leave stores with little to sell later.
"If the fears about running short come true, they will really get killed in January, which has been a very big month in the last few years," said Walter K. Levy, managing director for retail trends and positioning at Kurt Salmon Associates.
LANDS' END is one retailer that increased inventories for the holidays, buying more of its classic turtlenecks, dress shirts, coats and other popular items than last year -- although apparently not enough of popular new ones like the moccasins and reversible jackets. "We've made a commitment to these items, and we're willing to take the risk that they don't sell in order to make sure we have what our customers are looking for," said Emily Leuthner, a Lands' End spokeswoman.
But Lands' End is in a small minority. Steve Blatt, owner of Searle Blatt, a fashion coat maker that operates five boutiques in Manhattan and sells to department stores nationwide, said retailers placed smaller orders this year and pared them even further as the year wore on. "I've increased my own inventories on the theory that other people are maintaining too little inventory and will disappoint their customers," he said. "The big stores have cut back on inventory drastically."
Depleted inventories not only reduce sales potential but also discourage traffic, which is one reason retailers are so reluctant to discuss the issue on the record. Garnet Hill refused to talk about inventory at all, and those retailers willing to discuss it usually spoke only in general terms and through spokesmen.
Peggy Palter, for example, a spokeswoman for Sears, Roebuck & Company, said, "We anticipated a slowdown in the economy in the second half of the year, and our inventories reflect that." 
Retailers, it seems, are damned if they do and damned if they don't. Too much inventory means big discounts and investor accusations that they are failing to protect profit margins; too little means potential sales lost.
Generally, Wall Street prefers inventories that tend toward the lean side. Richard N. Baum, senior retail analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, is actually pleased that retailers have ordered less this year. "I think inventory is less of an issue than last year," he said. "At least this year, they had some notice that the fourth quarter was going to be weak and could trim back orders."
Last year, retailers blinded by the fast-growth economy entered the holiday season with shelves and warehouses bursting at the seams, only to see sales evaporate after the first week. Excluding Gap Inc., which had such a disastrous Christmas in 2000 that it skews comparisons, the net income of some 20 specialty apparel and jewelry companies fell 12.5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year from the previous year, after being higher in every other quarter, according to Credit Suisse First Boston. 
This year, Mr. Baum predicts that the same group's profits will decline by only 2 percent because most retailers, forewarned by economic stagnation in general and then by a sharp drop in sales after Sept. 11, kept their orders on the low side. "They've definitely averted disaster pretty much across the board," he said.
Discounters are more insulated than the rest of the retail industry because their merchandise is largely basic, so that the khakis and coats that do not sell before Christmas have a good chance of selling later. Sales at the three big discount chains, Wal-Mart, Target and Kmart, were up 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter of last year and are expected to rise an additional 6.4 percent in the period this year, according to Credit Suisse First Boston.
Analysts predict that department stores, with their more seasonal, trend-sensitive merchandise, are most likely to be whipsawed this holiday season. Last year, sales at seven big department store companies, including Dillard, May and Federated, fell 14.9 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, but Credit Suisse estimates that sales for the group will be down only 5.1 percent this year.
In addition, even with inventories tight, markdowns appear plentiful already, although merchants and analysts say the discounts are largely the normal enticements that stores make at this time of year to move fall merchandise.
Some are skeptical about that. "Maybe retailers were planning these promotions all along, but they're extending the promotion period so things are on sale sooner and longer and the discounts are deeper," said Doug Bade, leader of the supply chain strategy and operations practice at Deloitte Consulting.
Even retailers that pared their orders this year may find that demand is even lower than they originally expected. Federated, which operates Macy's and Lazarus, among other chains, ordered 3 percent less merchandise for this holiday quarter than for the same period last year. But the company is expecting sales to fall even more sharply, by 7 to 10 percent. So, after Sept. 11, Federated cut the number of orders not yet in warehouses by 5 percent. Reorders of particularly strong merchandise are being considered case by case, said Carol Sanger, Federated's spokeswoman. "It's definitely leaner this year," she said. "The early bird will get the pick."
Gap, which has been struggling for the last year, was also cautious. In its third quarter, which ended Oct. 30, the value of inventory for sale in a square foot of floor space fell to $70 from $83 in the period a year earlier. For the current quarter, Gap expects that value to be down 10 to 12 percent from last year, when it was $59. 
Gap, which is both a manufacturer and a retailer, also set aside a $52 million reserve for orders it canceled to reflect its business conditions. Stacy MacLean, a Gap spokeswoman, said the cancellations were not related to Sept. 11.
But many retailers were wary after the attacks, and a flood of companies reportedly canceled or deferred orders and shipments.
Paul R. Charron, chairman and chief executive of Liz Claiborne Inc., an apparel maker that also has retail outlets, said diplomatically that although no orders were rescinded, "we understand that universally that may not be the case."
He said many merchants overreacted to Sept. 11, adding that in several important areas, business at Liz Claiborne had actually improved since the attacks.
"Where business has been more challenging, for example, on the West Coast, we have been working out inventory issues month by month on a case-by-case basis," he said in a written response to questions. "Other retail businesses have outperformed their original expectations, resulting in requests for more product, and we have successfully chased fill-in product in many instances."
But other manufacturers do not have the inventory to replenish retailers' stocks.
The toy industry is always the most extreme indicator of holiday sales patterns, and lean inventories are quite obvious there.
"When my mother asked me how Sept. 11 would affect business, I didn't think the impact would be that much," said Anton Rabie, president of Spin Masters, which makes Shrinky Dinks, a crafts toy brought back to life this year after having a good run in the 1970's. "But it has had a large impact, not because people aren't shopping but because retailers were so, so cautious."
SPIN MASTERS filled orders for 400,000 Shrinky Dinks kits but figures that it could have sold 200,000 more had retailers been more optimistic. Getting the toys from Asia now, even by air, is next to impossible. "I've had vice presidents at several retailers screaming at me on the phone for inventory," Mr. Rabie said, echoing the comments of other toy makers. "Any product I've got coming in at all is being used to fill in all the rain checks retailers issued before the season began, not going on to store shelves."
Spin Masters has cut back on its publicity efforts for the toy and is now talking up its radio-controlled airplane, the Intruder, which is also selling well.
"But let me tell you," said Harold Chizick, Spin Master's publicity chief, "we have three other items we could fill a landfill with."
