HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
When, Oh When, Will Rates Rise Again?

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
RIGHT now, the bond market is expecting the economy to rebound smartly next year and is forecasting that the Federal Reserve will raise its short-term interest rate benchmark by next spring.
 But it is more likely that the Fed will wait. 
 The Fed's interest rate benchmark, the federal funds rate, is at 2 percent and is expected to drop another quarter-point when policy makers meet on Tuesday. The yield on the Fed funds futures contract for January is 1.74 percent, reflecting the expected reduction. 
But the yield on the contract for July is 2.2 percent, signaling a rate increase no later than the end of June. Until Friday's report that the November unemployment rate rose to a six-year high of 5.7 percent, investors thought the Fed would act even sooner.
On Wednesday, the yield on the May Federal funds contract surged to 2.01 percent after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index for the service sector surged in November. That news came after some positive economic reports for October and November, involving car sales, retail sales and durable-goods orders. The reports appeared to confirm the belief among many investors that the economy might have hit bottom.
The jobs report dampened hopes for a quick rebound a bit. But July is still too early for a rate increase.
For four reasons, the Fed is likely to hold the line longer than the market expects. The first is history: after the last recession, in 1990-91, the Fed funds rate on overnight loans between banks stayed at its low, 3 percent, for 17 months. John Youngdahl, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, says that since the 1950's, the rate has not been raised until after the unemployment rate has peaked. The median lag time after such peaks is three and a half months. Mr. Youngdahl does not see an unemployment peak until the second half of next year; that would mean a rate increase might not come until 2003.
Second, inflation is low and expected to decline, even as the economy gets back on its feet. As measured by the Consumer Price Index, the inflation rate was 2.1 percent in October, down from May's 3.6 percent.
Much of that decline came from the fall in oil prices, so the core consumer price index, which excludes food and energy, gives a better sense of current inflation. That measure rose at a pace of only 2.6 percent in the 12 months through October -- still below its 3 percent-plus rate in 15 of the 17 months from September 1992 to February 1994, when the Fed held its benchmark rate at 3 percent.
The Fed is likely to find it hard to move interest rates higher, even with the economy growing, if inflation is in check. That has always been a difficult move politically, and 2002 is a Congressional election year.
Housing offers the third reason. A healthy housing market is crucial for economic recovery because it spurs consumer spending as houses are bought, sold and renovated. At the same time, a vibrant housing market provides support for that spending, as homeowners refinance their mortgages to take out some of their gains in equity.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, recognizes that, as he made clear in testimony in July. "We're also beginning to find," he said, "that as home ownership rises and as the market value of homes continues to rise, even in a period when stock prices are falling, we're observing a rather remarkable employment of that so-called home equity wealth in all sorts of household decisions." To preserve that growth stimulus, the Fed will keep a cap on interest rates as long as possible.
Finally, central bank policy makers have said recently that they think recovery will be slow.
In this environment, Richard W. Waugh, executive director and chief economist at Principal Capital Income Investors, which manages about $40 billion in bonds, is cautious. Although he thinks that the economy has hit bottom, he said, he does not see a rapid recovery next year, and he expects economic data to be mixed, keeping the bond market and the Fed on edge. "The Fed is not going to be in a rush to start tightening interest rates again," he said. He does not expect a rate increase until late 2002 or early 2003.
Like most other fixed-income managers, Mr. Waugh is not making many bets in the Treasury market, preferring instead the higher yields offered in other sectors, including corporate bonds, mortgage-backed securities, agency bonds and, in some cases, junk bonds. He says he believes that Treasury yields will rise next year as the economy recovers but that rates will not move up as much in the other sectors of the fixed-income market.
IN long-term bonds, Mr. Waugh is snubbing Treasuries in favor of 30-year agency bonds, which offer three-quarters of a percentage point of additional yield. He prefers higher-rated investment-grade corporate bonds, like Cingular Wireless 10-year notes with a yield of 1.5 percentage points higher than Treasuries. Enron, the most recent corporate implosion, is a lesson he is not ignoring.
Mr. Waugh is not running after the big returns in junk bonds, where average yields, according to Merrill Lynch, are more than 12 percent. But he is using them to enhance his portfolios here and there. He will pick a junk bond, like IMC Global, a fertilizer company, yielding 9.40 percent, over a lower-rated investment-grade bond because he considers the junk bond's yield high enough to pay for the added risk. But aside from such exceptions, he said, "it is not a good time to buy below the top levels."

HEADLINE: Troops Need Boots, So Closed Mill Will Reopen 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: BERWICK, Me., Dec. 3 

 BODY:
In the blink-of-an-eye downtown that passes for the business district in this river town, the Prime Tanning leather factory is almost all there is. There is no doctor or supermarket to serve the 6,400 residents, and the town only just snared its first bank branch.
 "We're the mill in the mill town," said Kenneth R. Purdy, Prime Tanning's president and chief executive. "This is it, baby." 
 Prime Tanning's boxy white and green factory is so embedded in Berwick, in fact, that the company holds its quarterly meetings at the town hall. It was at one of these meetings in August that people here learned that after 68 years of making shoe leather in Berwick, Prime Tanning would be closing its doors, cutting loose 250 employees here and another 300 at a plant in nearby Rochester, N.H. 
Now, in an unusual side effect of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Prime Tanning has changed its mind. 
The war in Afghanistan means more American soldiers need combat boots, which are required by federal law to be made from American shoe leather, the kind that only Prime Tanning and a few other companies produce. 
Mr. Purdy is also gambling that shoemakers and retailers will be looking for more domestic suppliers, because security measures will generate delays and red tape for imported goods. And he is counting on consumers, too, saying the surge in patriotism will make people "want to buy American." 
So, on Jan. 2, just two months after it closed, the Berwick plant will reopen. It will be a scaled-down operation, making less leather and using just 150 workers to accomplish what used to be done by the Rochester and Berwick factories combined. Some returning workers will take pay cuts at the plant, which is not unionized. Even longtime veterans have to apply for their old jobs, and if they are hired, they will start with entry-level vacation and sick leave benefits. All workers will be expected to learn at least two other skills in addition to the job they already know how to do. 
But in a flagging economy that has seen the undoing of dozens of manufacturers, the return of even a featherweight version of Berwick's largest employer and by far its largest taxpayer is, for most people, welcome news.
"I'm thrilled," said James McMahon, Berwick's town manager. "This is just about the only major business in town."
Conrad Nadeau, the plant manager who will now have his old job back, grew emotional talking about the roller coaster of the last few months. 
"It's been a difficult period for all of us," said Mr. Nadeau, 41, who started on the factory floor in the 1970's and whose father and brother both worked at Prime, which over the years has employed generation after generation of families. "There's a passion to this business, something about getting your hands in the leather. And the chance to be able to help out the cause by making leather for the military, you feel a sense of pride."
No one expects Prime Tanning to lead a revival of New England manufacturing. "Prime Tanning is essentially capitalizing on the fact that military boots have to be made from American-made leather," said Charles Colgan, a professor of public policy at the Muskie School of Public Service at the University of Southern Maine. "But I don't see a large call-up of reserves, a large change in military posture, which will guarantee them success. I think they are taking something of a risk, and I think they know that."
Prime Tanning, which conditions and dyes leather and sells it to companies like Nike, Reebok, Timberland and Coach, is one of the last holdouts of an American shoe-leather industry that once had tanneries on virtually every New England river. About 97 percent of the industry's operations have moved to places like Taiwan, Mr. Purdy said. Prime, started 95 years ago by the Kaplan family of Woburn, Mass., which still owns it, now has plants in China, Taiwan and Mexico. 
But the robust 1990's New England economy allowed the company to make a go of it in Berwick. "This was an area with 2 percent unemployment," Mr. Purdy said. "If they were breathing, you'd hire them."
As a result, when the company decided to fold here, people were surprised. "We were stunned," said Dennis Dupuis, who owns a T-shirt monogramming shop and is on Berwick's economic development committee. "Here we are trying to keep jobs in town and bring people to Berwick, and you lose someone that big."
Bill Thurber, 60, a manager in the conditioning department, where machines that look like gigantic pancake presses stretch and dry cow hide, said he was "devastated," adding, "It's been like a home to me for 37 years."
Prime gave severance packages of one week's pay for every year worked. By November, when the factory closed, about half of the Berwick and Rochester employees had found jobs. 
Still, within three days after the announcement in late November that Prime was reopening, some 240 people had applied, the vast majority previous employees. Mr. Nadeau, who a few weeks ago was helping laid-off employees find work elsewhere, has found himself interviewing people whose reference letters he wrote.
Inside the cavernous factory this week, pallets of wet-blue leather hides, which become powder blue after being tanned with chromium salts, awaited the dyeing process. Two color wheels, the large drums where the leather is dyed, were running, and a skeleton crew was breaking down obsolete machines. The factory plans to produce about 10,000 "sides" (half a cow hide) of leather a week, down from about 35,000 before it closed. 
Many employees, like Stephen Young, 34, will have additional responsibilities. Mr. Young is rising from color house manager to manager of the entire "wet end," the dozen or so steps leather goes through before being dried and conditioned. He is not making any extra money, but seems happy to be back, toting his brown-bag lunch of peanut butter and marshmallow sandwiches every day. 
"We work hard, we get dirty," said Mr. Young, who could have had a job at the Portsmouth shipyard. "It grows on you."
Not everyone is sanguine about the reincarnated company. 
"The way they're doing it now is bad," said Virginia Ruland, 65, a waitress at Diane's Diner, which is across the Salmon Falls River in Somersworth, N.H. Ms. Ruland, whose great-grandfather, grandfather, father and uncles worked for Prime, bristled at the fact that longtime employees would start with no seniority and possible pay cuts. 
So did Francis Ames, 47, a color wheel operator for 23 years, who also questioned the company's long-term health.
"The way the leather industry is in this country, I've got to have some security," said Mr. Ames, who found a job at a distribution warehouse. "It's a part of my life that's over." 
Mr. Purdy acknowledges that pinning Prime's hope on patriotism is "not a slam-dunk." But he says he is hopeful. 
"I think you'll see a lot of footwear being made for specific needs -- police, fire, security -- as a result of this tragedy that you didn't need before," Mr. Purdy said. "And I believe you'll see the fire boot as a fashion statement."

HEADLINE: Cleaning the Hudson 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The decision by Christie Whitman, the Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, to go ahead with dredging the Hudson for PCB-rich sediment (news article, Dec. 5) is great news for the Hudson River ecosystem and for citizens of New York State. The E.P.A. has already successfully dredged a major Superfund site on the Hudson near West Point with no apparent ill effects. 
There is no reason to believe that dredging for PCB's will have more than minor and ephemeral effects. 
 It is worth noting that, unlike President Bush's administration, Gov. George E. Pataki did not take advantage of recent events or the current recession as an excuse to backpedal on the protection of our environment. We will all benefit from his vigilance and the persistence of many citizen groups in New York State.

JEFFREY LEVINTON
Stony Brook, N.Y., Dec. 5, 2001

The writer is a professor of ecology and evolution, SUNY at Stony Brook.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Through a Prism of a Latin Past

BYLINE:  By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
THE novelist Isabel Allende was recently asked what came to mind when she heard the date Sept. 11. Without hesitation, Ms. Allende said she thought of Chile, her native land, and what happened there on Sept. 11, 1973. That was the day the military toppled the democratically elected government of Salvador Allende, causing his death. Ms. Allende, a second cousin of Mr. Allende, fled soon after. 
 That two barbaric events in the Americas happened on the same date is an eerie coincidence that startles Ms. Allende and other Latinos now living in the United States. But what resonates with many is not so much that violence has chased them to a new, democratic country. Instead, they are dreading what could come after -- and in their homelands often did. 
 Latino immigrants -- Chileans, Peruvians, Argentines, Uruguayans, Bolivians, Panamanians, Cubans, Venezuelans, Hondurans, Salvadorans, Guatemalans, Dominicans and Nicaraguans -- fled countries where ardent nationalism was often one step toward an increasingly authoritarian government; and where the military, at one point or other, ruled at will. Ideologies of the right and left were able to trump democracy repeatedly in the 20th century.
Apart from economics, this is a crucial reason that many Latinos have emigrated to the United States, a country where, they know, an Army general would not attempt a coup d'etat, nor would citizens allow it. In fact, the fastest rate of growth among Latino immigrants in the last decade was not among Mexicans, as in the past, but among Central and South Americans, who suffered the brunt of the hemisphere's most repressive regimes and bloody civil wars in the last three decades. Their numbers nearly doubled to 10 million by the year 2000, the Census shows.
With a growing population of 35 million, Latinos will soon be the largest minority in America. Many of them are just now learning about their new home and its government, and view Washington's recent actions through the prism of their past. From the lands they fled, they know about men in uniforms detaining people for no apparent reason. They know about government officials secretly wiretapping conversations, interrogating "suspicious" college students and intimidating professors who question the system. They know about authorities instilling fear in a segment of the population for the good of the country.
Now, safe in cities in California, New Jersey and Florida, many Latinos are reading in the morning papers stories that resonate in uncomfortable ways. Their common and often recent experience of violence in their native lands allows them to view what has happened here since Sept. 11 in a harsher light than many other Americans do. 
They remain critical of any abuse of power or attempt at censorship from those who think a united, unquestioning country makes a nation stronger. They know, they say, because they have lived it. And though they are careful not to equate the brutality of Latin American dictatorships to the Bush administration's measures to restrict civil liberties, they remain vigilant to the warning signs.
In the last two months, the administration has sought increased power to wiretap, search and detain immigrants. President Bush issued an order approving the use of military tribunals to try suspected terrorists. More than 1,000 people have been detained. And it was revealed last week that the Immigration and Naturalization Service can now hold immigrants it deems dangerous, even after a judge orders their release.
"Violence engenders paranoia, and paranoia can change the culture of a country," said Tomas Eloy Martinez, a writer who fled his native Argentina in 1975 after a death threat, and did not return until 1984, shortly after democracy was reinstated.
In Argentina, like many countries in Latin America, dictatorial and democratic governments succeeded each other for much of the last century. The erosion of civil liberties reached a critical point in 1976, when a junta took over and initiated the "dirty war." By 1980, the Inter-American Human Rights Commission documented the abduction and disappearance of more than 6,000 people in Argentina.
"Censorship and erosion of liberties are a destructive spiral that can lead to a radical change in any country," said Mr. Martinez, who now directs the Latin American program at Rutgers University. "Few countries can recover from that."
Unlike most countries in the hemisphere, the United States has the means to guard against any threat to individual freedoms. Already, some members of Congress question the administration's actions, and hearings were held last week. Wednesday, the American Civil Liberties Union filed suit against the Justice Department, charging its detentions violated the Constitution and federal law; other groups have said they are prepared to challenge recent measures. The press is examining the government in ways not always possible -- or safe -- in Latin America.
Anthony D. Romero, the new executive director of the A.C.L.U., is focused on the impact new laws will have on immigrants. And no group, he said, with the exception of those from Arab countries, will suffer more than Latinos. This is true not just in terms of detentions but also in the increasing talk about placing restrictions on immigration. 
"Unfortunately, the war against terrorism is turning into the war against immigrants," he said. "The impact on the Latino community can be devastating. What we are doing is undercutting the basic system of checks and balances. We are putting aside the power of the judicial branch to oversee the powers of the executive branch. That's precisely what has happened in Latin America."
IN Cuba, for example, Fidel Castro chipped away at civil liberties in 1959, by claiming that threat of attack from the United States forced his government to take extreme measures. Eventually, in a speech, Mr. Castro delivered his coup de grace, "Elecciones, para que?" -- "Elections, what for?"
Mabel Morana, a Uruguayan professor who fled in 1975 and now teaches Hispanic languages and literatures at the University of Pittsburgh, experienced a similar pattern from the right. The military seized power in Uruguay in 1973 and held it for 12 years, allegedly protecting the country against leftist guerrillas.
Professor Morana said she worries that a strong nationalistic discourse -- the beginnings of which she says are evident in the constant display of American flags and patriotic slogans -- can help generate support for a government that will then feel empowered to curtail individual liberties. 
"Those of us who have lived through it understand that fear is often manipulated to get backing," she said. "An outsized sense of nationalism is not the answer to fear. The answer is to keep freedom alive, and a relentless, critical eye."

HEADLINE: Why Grade Inflation Is Serious 

 BODY:
Harvard, long a center of excellence in so many forms of study, is becoming known as a pioneer in grade inflation, too. A recent report by the dean of the faculty of arts and sciences revealed that half the grades awarded to undergraduates in recent years have been either A or A-. The school is hardly the only institution of higher learning that has been troubled by nagging doubts about whether the line between mediocrity and real achievement is being blurred. The grading systems at American universities deserve to be re-evaluated, but it is important that the work be done on the basis of real data rather than guesswork. 
 The distorting effects of grade inflation at Harvard were uncovered earlier this fall by a Boston Globe investigation, which disclosed that an astonishing 91 percent of Harvard graduates received honors last in June. The faculty has since begun a vigorous debate about what's going on. Some argue that the quality of students is simply better. At least one veteran professor suggests that white professors are reluctant to give bad grades to black students and go easy on everyone as a result. But evidence across the country indicates that the problem has occurred even at second- and third-tier schools and in places where the minority populations are infinitesimal. 
 Potential causes for grade inflation abound at the nation's colleges. More than half of all college courses are now taught by part-time teachers, and it would be interesting to see if those faculty members, who are underpaid and overworked, award more high grades to keep their jobs and keep their charges quiet and happy. While Harvard does not have to worry about attracting students, there are certainly some colleges that discourage teachers from giving low grades that might drive tuition-paying customers off campus.
Fifty years ago, students probably gnashed their teeth about C's but kept their mouths shut. Now, in addition to simply haranguing their teachers, students can exact revenge through student evaluations that play a role in whether junior faculty members are retained and given raises. The universities have encouraged students to gripe with consumer-driven appeals committees that allow them to seek changes in their transcripts.
A forthcoming book by Valen Johnson, a Duke University statistics professor, argues that lax grading is distorting the course selection process as well. Mr. Johnson contends that the expectation of high grades in humanities classes is swelling enrollment in those subjects and draining university resources from science departments. He has proposed restructuring the lopsided grading systems to remove the incentives that he says drive people out of sciences and into the soft areas. Those ideas have drawn catcalls from his colleagues. But the recent reports out of Harvard and elsewhere suggest that grade inflation is not necessarily a laughing matter.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Was That the Future We Just Passed By?

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND 

 BODY:
FOR those who can remember it, the future was a time of unrivaled wonder. Oh, you remember the future, don't you? Not the hokey old future of flying cars and teleportation, but the future of just a couple years ago -- before Sept. 11, before the crash of the Nasdaq. It was in all the papers. With the stock market following a 1999 best seller called "Dow 36,000" and an e-book in every lap -- there was never a future like it. 
 Magazines like Wired and The Industry Standard sprang up to describe it. A new class of consultants, speaking a strange lingo and calling themselves futurists, mapped its every contour, enlightening a populace that might otherwise be mired in the present. 
 And what a future it was. Electronic communication allowed workers of all stripes to telecommute from anywhere on the globe, eliminating the need for urban centers. Web retailers put "bricks and mortar" stores out of business, but there were plenty of jobs delivering all the groceries and pet food bought online. Television sets were interactive marvels, allowing users to alter plots and characters from their armchairs. The "knowledge capacity" of the Web, marshaled by education visionaries like Seymour Papert of the M.I.T. Media Lab, replaced classrooms and books with richer, more creative on-line learning. 
New paradigms glistened like money; old paradigms receded into musty obscurity. Best of all, unlike the old future, which was always decades away, the new future was no more than a few years off. 
That, at least, was the idea. But even before Sept. 11 that future was history. Not only is there no e-book revolution; there is no longer, as of last summer, an Industry Standard. Overnight, the future was kitsch. 
Leaving the question: amid all the other irrational exuberance, why the bull market in hype?
The errant projections were to be expected, said George Forrester Colony, chief executive of Forrester Research, one of many firms that blossomed during the Internet boom by offering luminous pictures of the future. "The technology industry is driven by thunderstorms," Mr. Colony said, working the argot. "We can't be sure where the next thunderstorm will hit, or what it will look like." At the same time, he said: "There's tremendous incentive to be the first person to take advantage of a thunderstorm. You see poor predictions magnified and enlarged. Asinine ideas like e-books -- so much air gets pumped into them."
Mr. Colony owned up to his own flawed visions. He predicted that the personal computer, and with it Intel and Microsoft, would be passe by 2000, and that the sprawl of the World Wide Web would overwhelm America Online. "I predicted that twice," he said. 
He defended his overall track record, while conceding the field's inherent kitsch quotient -- a risk for futurists in any era, but especially acute in the age of the Internet, which collapsed the time it took for a bold prediction to fail. The space travel of Arthur C. Clarke's "2001: A Space Odyssey," at least, had 33 years before its author was held accountable. The new book "Radical E: From G.E. to Enron, Lessons on How to Rule the Web," has a shorter grace period, at least among people holding Enron stock.
The nature of prognostication itself changed in the dot-com boom, said Clifford Nass, author of "The Media Equation: How People Treat Computers, Television and New Media Like Real People and Places" and a professor of communication at Stanford University. For most of the last century, futurists looked at sweeping, slowly developing social change: how family structures might evolve, for example, or whether societies could push toward utopia. The credibility of their predictions rested on how persuasively they could account for the past. 
"You used to look for a trend, then extrapolate," Professor Nass said. "Now, because change is so fast, you don't have time to wait for trends. Now futurists are ahistorical. This allows you to get away with anything. And if you're wrong, who cares, because by then we'll already know what happened." 
The problem, he said, was that while technologies change very rapidly, the people who might use them adapt much more slowly. Many of the predictions failed not for technological reasons, but for social ones, said John Carey, a professor of new media at Columbia University who has studied the success rates of various types of prognostication.
Professor Carey cites telecommuting, or using computer modems to work from home or other remote sites. Though it is technologically feasible, recent surveys show that even as more workers get 
Internet connections at home fewer are telecommuting to a significant degree. The problem, Professor Carey said, was that people felt that if they didn't go to the office, they couldn't schmooze their way to a raise.
E-books arose to meet a consumer need that did not exist. Interactive television, on the other hand, has not panned out technologically, despite the efforts of Microsoft, which in the mid-1990's added a second campus just to work on it.
Some of these failed technologies may emerge again in a new form, just as a failed heart medication resurfaced as Viagra. The fax machine, as Professor Carey pointed out, was invented in the 19th century as an adjunct to the telegraph, and failed several times before finding its niche in the 1970's. 
Such is the unpredictable march of technology, said Tim Lenoir, who teaches the history of science at Stanford. He points to cryogenics, a field that has extended many science fiction fantasies, but no lives. Though cryogenics failed, he said, "It has been replaced by a new imagination based on stem-cell research."
Of course, even the old future had a dark side. Testifying before Congress in 1993, the science fiction writer Bruce Sterling described a near future in which "violent conflicts between virtual and actual communities have become a permanent feature of the cultural landscape." Yet this prediction now feels even more misguided than its shinier cousins, especially with the Dow creeping back over 10,000 last week. In hard times and soft, we like our lenses rosy.

HEADLINE: Radicalism: Is the Devil in the Demographics? 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FROM Casablanca to Kabul, the statistics are stunning.
 Well over half the populations of Egypt, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Iran and Iraq are under 25 years old, according to the International Programs Center at the Census Bureau. In Pakistan, the number is 61 percent; in Afghanistan, 62 percent. 
 The boom in young people coming of age in a broad swath of territory where terrorists recruit might seem to pose one of the United States' most daunting national security threats. But the picture is more complicated than that. 
People who study statistics say the danger posed by such bulges actually depends, sometimes in surprising ways, on how rigidly countries are governed. And the effect on feelings about America can be even more surprising.
For example, the threat of instability is greater in a partly free society like Egypt than in a rigid dictatorship like Iraq. And in Iran these days, the rise of young people actually plays to, not against, America's interest in seeing that country become more democratic.
Historically, there's reason for some concern on the part of those who hold power. France experienced a "youth bulge" in the 1780's, which increased demand for scarce food supplies; that, in turn, drove up prices, hurt the business classes and helped to create conditions for its revolution in 1789. Iran was in the midst of a youth bulge before its 1979 revolution, when young people took to the streets, helping to bring down the monarchy in favor of a virulently anti-American theocracy.
The political scientist Samuel P. Huntington argues that the large number of unemployed males between the ages of 15 and 30 is "a natural source of instability and violence" throughout the Muslim world. But the connection is not that direct. Demographers are fond of saying "demography is destiny," but in doing so they unsually mean the economic health and social needs of nations, not necessarily riot and rebellion.
"I would describe demography as a challenge that the state needs to meet, whether it's developing countries with a youth bulge or developed countries with a graying population," said Jennifer S. Holmes, a political scientist and author of "Terrorism and Democratic Stability" (Manchester University Press, 2001). "It is not going to predetermine the outcome. In general, governments have the upper hand. If they reach out and make a half-hearted effort at placating the masses with economic and social programs, they can usually do it."
And societies at the political spectrum's extremes -- either open or closed -- are less susceptible than those in between. "Youth cohorts are more likely to cause conflict in countries with intermediate regimes than in countries with fully autocratic or democratic regimes," wrote Henrik Urdal of Oslo's International Peace Research Institute in a recent study.
Among the "in-betweens" are Algeria, where high unemployment, inadequate education, over-dependence on the oil economy and authoritarian rule have produced an explosive environment in which armed Islamic groups maneuver.
EGYPT, with 69 million people, is the Arab world's most populous state. Unemployment, especially among college graduates, is rising, reform of the planned economy has failed and one-third of the work force earns $70 a month. Meanwhile, the military gets most of the $2 billion in annual American aid. 
The countries in the region most vulnerable to the wrath of their youth, according to American intelligence analysts, are Pakistan and Afghanistan. Pakistan, whose population will probably swell from 140 million to about 195 million by 2015, "will not recover easily from decades of political and economic mismanagement, divisive politics, lawlessness, corruption and ethnic friction," a Central Intelligence Agency report concluded a year ago. And Afghanistan has known only occupation and war for two decades. The result is a lost generation, much of it indoctrinated in the Taliban's repressive version of Islam.
The classic profile of a suicide bomber has been an impoverished, uneducated, rootless young man with nothing to lose. But there are exceptions. Most of the Al Qaeda terrorists who struck the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on Sept. 11 were middle-class Saudis. The Palestinian who blew himself up in East Jerusalem on Wednesday was in his mid-40's and had eight children.
In some cases, politics affects demography as much as demography affects politics. In 2015, Israel's population is expected to increase by only 20 percent, compared to 56 percent in the West Bank and 72 percent in the Gaza Strip. The Palestinian birth rate is so high that if it continues at current levels, in a decade Jews will be a minority in the combined population of Israel, the West Bank and Gaza.
Paradoxically, because of generous United Nations refugee programs, Palestinian children and adolescents have one of the highest levels of education in the Arab world; most Palestinians live in cities with good health care and have one of the lowest mortality levels in the Arab world. All these factors should contribute to a decline in fertility. But fertility is also a weapon in the Palestinians' national struggle, and it remains high.
AND then there is Iran. There, a generation of young people were indoctrinated following the 1979 Islamic revolution to become Islamic warriors for God. "My soldiers are still infants," Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said, as he encouraged mothers to breed. The official annual growth rate soared to 3.2 percent until the ruling clerics concluded the late 1980's that the population increase was disastrous for the economy and launched a massive family planning program. The birth rate plummeted.
Today, Khomeini's generation is not ready to die. In fact, many have rejected their fathers' revolutionary ideals and strict religious rules. They have been an important part of the reform movement personified by Iran's elected president, Mohammad Khatami, and his struggle to create a civil society based on the rule of law.
Even anti-American fervor has waned. While some Pakistani youths demonstrated in support of Osama bin Laden after Sept. 11, upper middle class Iranian youths held a candlelight vigil to condemn the attacks and mourn the dead.
In the end, it is not just the number of young people but the degree of their exclusion from economic and political participation that rouses them politically. "What makes the demographic explosion dangerous is the perception by young people that their elders have failed them, that authority has failed them in all aspects of their lives," said Farideh Farhi, an adjunct scholar at the Middle East Institute. "We live in a world that celebrates self-expression and individuality, and when there's only political despair and humiliation, that's when the potential for explosion is created."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: DECEMBER 3-7; 
DowRises Above 10,000, and Stays There

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Investors cleared some important psychological hurdles this week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average above 10,000 and the Nasdaq above 2,000 for the first time in months.
 What is more, the indexes held those levels on Friday, despite some backtracking. 
 One impetus for the market's rise has been hope for a robust and imminent economic recovery. Big technology companies, including I.B.M., Microsoft and Intel, pulled the market higher, as did a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management that showed surprising growth in the services sector.
 Those gains dimmed on Friday, when the government reported that more than 300,000 jobs were lost last month. Stocks fell and bonds rose, but the indexes did not drop below their benchmark numbers.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 197.9 points, or 2 percent, to 10,049.46. The Nasdaq composite index rose 90.68 points, or 4.7 percent, to 2,021.26. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 18.86 points, or 1.63 percent, to 1,158.31. Bond prices fell, pushing up yields. The yield on the benchmark 10-year note rose to 5.16 percent from 4.76 percent. MICHAEL BRICK

HEADLINE: Labor Runs Into Hard Times As It Negotiates for Raises 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
Detroit's mayor has scrapped his offer of a raise to 17,000 municipal workers, saying the city can no longer afford pay increases. 
 In Middletown, N.J., a judge jailed more than 200 teachers who went on strike after the school board insisted that they pay more for health insurance. And United Airlines has told 15,000 members of the machinists' union, who are angry about not receiving a raise since 1994, that the company might not be able to give them a raise this year either because it is losing so much money. 
 For the nation's labor leaders, gathered here for the A.F.L.-C.I.O convention, the climate for collective bargaining has turned far chillier in recent months because of a confluence of negative factors: the war against terrorism, the recession, rising unemployment, soaring health care costs and slumps in many industries, most notably airlines. 
Tens of thousands of union members who just a few months ago were expecting large raises find themselves fighting demands to accept pay freezes. A period of relative labor peace is giving way to tensions and strikes.
"The worsening economy has certainly created challenges for unions," said Richard Hurd, a labor relations professor at Cornell University. "It will be especially tough for public employees because government budgets face tightening revenues."
In Riverside, Calif., teachers are fuming because the city reduced its offer of a 4 percent pay increase that the city's 1,500 teachers had voted to approve. The city said it had to lower its offer to 3 percent because Gov. Gray Davis was cutting the state's education budget by $844 million, reducing aid for school districts. 
In New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized the union representing the city's 80,000 public school teachers, accusing it of being selfish for continuing to ask for the same raise -- 23 percent -- that it had sought before Sept. 11. The damage from the terrorist attacks helped swell the city's budget deficit, which is expected to climb to $4 billion next year. The union argues that the city needs to give a 23 percent raise to attract enough certified teachers. 
At the convention, many labor leaders were reluctant to discuss the wintry negotiating climate, fearing that acknowledging it could give management an advantage in bargaining. Instead, they prefer to dwell on instances in which unions navigated around obstacles and emerged with impressive contracts. But those contracts usually resulted from unusual circumstances.
For example, nine major Boston hotels agreed last weekend to a five-year contract that gives 3,000 workers an increase of 5 percent a year in overall wages and benefits. Hurt by the drop in travel since Sept. 11, the hotels were in no mood for a strike. 
In New York, the real estate industry awarded a pay increase averaging 3.8 percent a year over three years, as well as improved health benefits, to 30,000 building service workers at 1,000 office towers. James F. Berg, the industry's chief negotiator, said that building operators were generous partly because they wanted to avoid a walkout, especially when many companies were thinking of leaving New York after Sept. 11.
Such generous contracts, union leaders acknowledge, are becoming increasingly rare. One factor sharpening tensions is the sense among union members who last negotiated a contract three or four years ago, when Wall Street and the economy were booming, that they missed out on the good times. These workers are looking to the current round of negotiations for a large contract to get their share of the boom, but now management is telling them it is time to bite the bullet.
"A lot of unions feel we've shared the pain without sharing in the gain," said Andrew Stern, president of the Service Employees International Union. 
The nation's airlines laid off nearly 100,000 workers after Sept. 11 and are now taking a tougher line in wage talks. Teachers' unions are seeing school boards driving harder bargains as some cities have started dismissing teachers. For instance, Buffalo plans to lay off 550 teachers this month. 
Fearing a wave of layoffs, some unions have dug in to protect job security. In Connecticut last week, 5,100 workers went on strike against Pratt & Whitney, the jet engine manufacturer, asserting that the company was trying to weaken the contract's job security language.
Skyrocketing health costs are often serving as tinder in today's bargaining. In the Middletown strike, the teachers are protesting because the school board wants them to contribute up to $860 each a year toward health insurance, up from the current $250. The strike ended on Saturday when the teachers agreed to honor a court back-to-work order and return to their classrooms without a new contract. 
The union representing 3,600 teachers at Roman Catholic elementary schools in New York is threatening to strike, complaining that the archdiocese wants to place teachers into a less expensive health plan.
Sarah Palmer Amos, executive vice president for collective bargaining at the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, said health costs were soaring by more than 12 percent a year after rising by less than 5 percent annually under President Bill Clinton, who pushed the industry to contain costs.
"Companies are saying you're going to have to choose between benefits or wage increases," Ms. Amos said. "That's a choice we shouldn't be forced to make."
Some labor leaders say that employers are taking advantage of the war and the recession to demand bigger concessions than are actually needed. And many of the leaders acknowledge that the war has made them more reluctant to strike for fear of being accused of undermining the fight against terrorism. 
But management says events demand tougher bargaining. "It's obvious than when times are tougher employers are going to be more careful about the levels of wages and benefits they offer along with every other cost," said Randy Johnson, vice president for labor policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce.

HEADLINE: Aspen Journal; 
Snowy Playground for Rich Resists U.S. Woes

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 5 

 BODY:
Terrorist attacks? Fears of flying? Bad economy?
 So what. This is Aspen, playground for the rich, richer and richest. 
 O.K., so the Prada store on Galena Street that opened last Sunday was under construction for almost a year. It still opened. The latest issue of Aspen magazine is a fat 280 pages, loaded with advertisements. And if the economy is so bad, why is Jonas Weil, an entrepreneur from St. Louis, starting Aspen Air this month, offering first-class round-trip service on private jets from Teterboro, N.J., near New York City; Chicago; Dallas; West Palm Beach, Fla.; and Burbank, Calif.? Prices start at $3,300, and Mr. Weil is confident seats will sell. 
"Absolutely," he said.
For all the nation's woes, Aspen seems pretty resistant to them. Hotel operators and condominium leasing companies are reporting near sellouts through the holidays, the unofficial opening of the ski and snowboard seasons. With some slopes open now, traffic is building. Just try finding a parking space downtown near Aspen Mountain.
Still, the approaching winter is filled with uncertainties that have little to do with snowfall. For the first time since the Persian Gulf war a decade ago, town leaders are wondering if Aspen's bubble might burst after the last glass of New Year's Champagne.
"We've taken our flu shots in a sense," said John Norton, chief operating officer of the Aspen Skiing Company, which manages Aspen's four major mountains. "The indications right now are that we're going to suffer the fallout of the economy and Sept. 11 but a lot less than other places. We're not totally immune."
Thanks to early snows and World Cup ski races held over the Thanksgiving weekend, optimism abounds here for a sustained high-occupancy winter. Tom Yoder, who sells cowboy boots and Stetson hats in a popular shop called Kemo Sabe, said: "I'm shocked that since Sept. 11 our business is actually up. Maybe it's people taking pride in America; in our country there's nothing more American than cowboy things that are not exorbitantly priced."
But exorbitantly priced goods are what Aspen is all about. That's why concerns lurk. The same hotels and condominium managers who boast of robust December sales also say reservations for January and beyond are off as much as 7 percent from last year. Local stores, which are usually begging for sales help this time of year, are not hiring. Real estate sales are sluggish, even for "modestly priced" houses in the $1 million to $5 million range.
Jere Rood, director of Lift Up, a local provider of emergency food, clothing and housing, said the response to the organization's annual fund-raising drive, which began last month, was slower than usual.
"It may be that people are giving to New York causes as their charities of choice this year," he said.
Town leaders, like Mr. Norton and Mayor Helen Klanderud, acknowledge the anomalies but frame them in the context of a renewed town spirit, a rah-rah-sis-boom-bah mentality that began around the time of the World Cup races.
Ms. Klanderud said: "We're optimistic but cautious. There's a lot of uncertainty out there."
To offset what they fear most -- events that would leave hotel rooms and ski-lift seats vacant after New Year's -- the local chamber of commerce has decided to focus its marketing efforts on two cities, Dallas and Los Angeles, each with many wealthy people. The idea, said Christine Nolen, president and chief executive of the chamber, is "to identify the kinds of customers who are not as susceptible to the tremors" that might turn others away from an expensive vacation.
The city is also ballyhooing the ski company's decision to open Aspen Mountain this winter for the first time to snowboarders, ending the last ban against snowboarders in Colorado.
But even those efforts have not dispelled the feeling around town that this winter could be different from those of recent years. 
Bill Tomcich, president of Stay Aspen Snowmass, a reservations service, said there has been "more uncertainty surrounding this winter than I've ever seen." But he was heartened, he said, by a recent surge in calls.
Mr. Norton explained the optimism this way, in a tip of the hat to the moneyed classes who have always kept Aspen buoyant: "We have a tremendous repeat and loyal clientele, people who come here to get away from it all. They know it's a special, spiritual place, not one of those crowded roadside highway resorts. That's a promise to them that we don't want to break."

HEADLINE: Group Plans Asian College For Women In Poverty 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
With the women of Afghanistan, Cambodia, Vietnam and other poor nations in mind, an international group of leaders in education and development have begun raising money to establish a new private university for women in Asia that would be accessible to the poor.
 The proposed university, initially with the size and curriculum of a small liberal arts college, would bring together students from all Asian cultures, many on scholarships, said Lone Dybkjaer, a member of the European Parliament and former Danish environment minister who is a co-chairwoman of a group that announced plans last week for the new institution. 
 Her co-chairwoman is Prime Minister Khaleda Zia of Bangladesh, who has offered to donate the land for the new university. Her government is also considering an act of Parliament to ensure the college's independence in a part of the world where private universities are rare and government-supported schools are subject to political pressures. 
"I see this as a sort of role model, to stress the importance of higher education for women," Ms. Dybkjaer said in an interview in New York last week, while meeting with American foundations being asked to contribute. She said that traditionally, what focus there has been on the education of girls has often stopped with primary and secondary schools.
Dr. M. Osman Farruk, a former World Bank economist who is now education minister of Bangladesh, was also in New York last week to meet with potential donors. The university needs to raise $100 million to cover start-up costs and the initial endowment, its organizers say.
Dr. Farruk and Kamal Ahmad, a corporate lawyer in London who is acting as a pro bono administrator of the university until a staff can begin to be selected next year, said that they hoped to have the school open by September 2005. Hiring an administrative staff and a faculty will begin by the middle of 2002, they said. They hope to attract Asian women for both academic and administrative jobs.
Ms. Dybkjaer said that Bangladesh would be a good site for the new school, to be called the Asian University for Women. Bangladesh, an Islamic country, "has a good attitude toward women," she said. "There is a strong civil society." English is the country's official second language, after Bangla, a combination of Bengali and Urdu. Until 1971, Bangladesh was part of Pakistan.
Bangladesh, though not without political violence, has been generally receptive to outside development organizations and has many strong private agencies of its own, working on environmental issues and women's health among other areas. Dhaka, the capital, has an international center for research on diarrheal diseases, and its generally good experience in dealing with successive governments provides an example for the new university, Dr. Farruk said.
He is hoping to send Bangladeshi women to the college. The country has a system of subsidies to keep girls in school by rewarding their families. It already has a private college for women, but it is devoted to home economics.
The founders of the new university have met some resistance in Europe, Ms. Dybkjaer said, because private universities and especially colleges solely for women are considered unacceptable by many educators. But she said that she had been told in Asia that many women need what they call an "unthreatening" environment for study, where a dominant male society cannot intrude.
Dr. Farruk said that the university should be focused on the rural poor, on women who would not otherwise have a chance at higher education and could form their own international networks like those shared by Asian elites. He would like to see 50 percent of the budget devoted to a scholarship fund. "Otherwise," he said, "you will be accused of having another rich women's club."
Other members of the support group for the Asian University for Women are Mark Malloch Brown, an administrator of the United Nations Development Program; Mamphela Ramphele, the managing director of human development at the World Bank and a former vice chancellor of the University of Cape Town; Mary Robinson, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights; Thoraya Obaid, the executive director of the United Nations Population Fund; and Stephen J. Friedman of the New York law firm Debevoise & Plimpton, a former chairman of the board of the Overseas Development Council in Washington.

HEADLINE: Newark's Plan for an Arena May Rise Again 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
A deal that would allow the construction of an arena here for the New Jersey Nets and New Jersey Devils has been considered dead since it failed twice in recent months to advance in a State Assembly committee. But some of its backers said Friday that it might yet emerge from a lame-duck legislative session.
 Those backers said that in an intense round of talks, aides to Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco; James E. McGreevey, the governor-elect; and Assembly Speaker Jack Collins are trying to draft a measure that is stripped of many of the other projects that were tacked on to previous bills to try to broaden support for the arena proposal among suburban and South Jersey lawmakers. 
 At one point the cost of those sweeteners approached $1 billion, drawing criticism from the two gubernatorial candidates and prompting scores of arena backers to withdraw their support.
The proposal for the $355 million arena would allow the creation of a sports and entertainment district in Newark in which a portion of the sales tax revenue would be pledged to repaying $190 million in bonds issued by the state to aid the construction. Some $115 million of the cost of the 18,000-seat arena would be contributed by the YankeeNets, owners of the Nets and the Devils, which now play at the Meadowlands and would operate the arena under a long-term lease. The remainder of the cost would be borne by the city and Essex County governments.
One of the leading optimists about a revival of the proposal is Newark's Democratic mayor, Sharpe James, who said that most of the costly amendments that had been added to the arena measure would be dropped within a few days if the current negotiations succeeded. This would clear the way, he said, for the Legislature to consider a bill "without the fat and pork" that had sunk previous measures -- although it was likely to contain some smaller amount of economic development for South Jersey.
Meanwhile, the chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee, Richard Bagger, a Republican, said negotiators were also considering an arena bill that would be stripped of all grants. That measure would serve as an incentive by instead authorizing three sports and entertainment districts in other communities to aid development there, with the same kind of financing mechanism envisioned for the Newark arena. Those districts could help finance a Nascar racetrack in the Millville-Vineland area, a soccer stadium in Harrison and a family entertainment complex at the Meadowlands.
But it was not immediately clear whether the pared-down plan described by Mayor James would meet Mr. McGreevey's demand that the Legislature halt any new spending in light of decreasing tax revenues and ballooning deficit estimates. Nor was it clear whether Speaker Collins would go along with the other proposal to trim all grants to South Jersey projects in favor of a mechanism to aid financing of future development. Mr. Collins did not return repeated calls for comment.
There are only two chances left for an arena proposal to get a hearing before the new governor and a new Legislature take office: Appropriations Committee hearings on Dec. 13 and 20. But by the end of Friday, the deadline for scheduling new business for the Dec. 13 meeting, the agenda had not been amended by Mr. Collins to include an arena measure.
Still, a Republican official close to the negotiations said that Mr. Collins was reassessing his earlier position. "There is some indication that he might be satisfied with less," the Republican official said.
Mayor James, who also represents Newark in the State Senate, said that Mr. Collins had appeared to be "a changed man" in his recent conversations on the proposal and seemed willing to pare down his list of South Jersey projects to a $20 million appropriation for an athletic building at Rowan University in Glassboro.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Proponents of a new arena for the New Jersey Nets and New Jersey Devils want it built in downtown Newark. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: RESETTLEMENT; 
U.N. Doubtful That Refugees Will Rush Back

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
About 10,000 Afghan refugees have trickled back to the capital of Kabul, but United Nations officials said today that they did not expect large numbers of people to return to Afghanistan until next spring.
 The coming winter weather, drastic food shortages and lingering security concerns will keep most Afghans in neighboring countries from venturing home, said Kamel Morjane, assistant commissioner of the United Nations refugee agency. 
 "Today we cannot say how many will go back and when," Mr. Morjane said, hours after arriving in Islamabad from Kabul.
An estimated four million Afghan refugees have fled to neighboring countries, primarily Pakistan and Iran, in two decades of fighting, and another one million are living outside the region. Refugee officials said a multiyear rehabilitation program would be required to accommodate any large number of returning people. In the initial stages, the United Nations can offer only meager supplies.
Mr. Morjane said increasing incentives for refugees to go home and laying the groundwork for an international rehabilitation program would be on the agenda next month when donor countries assemble in Tokyo to develop a strategy for restoring a semblance of normalcy to a country ravaged by 22 years of war.
Pakistan and Iran are expected to step up pressure on refugees to return now that major fighting appears to have ended, but the United Nations officials said they did not expect large numbers of Afghans to be forcibly returned.
Security problems have slowed efforts to ship food into Afghanistan and reopen aid offices. Mr. Morjane said the refugee agency office in Kabul was still working with a small staff and that many United Nations workers had been unable to go back to Afghanistan because of the continuing danger.

HEADLINE: M.T.A. May Have to Raise Fares 50 Cents in 2003, McCall Says 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority may be forced to increase subway and bus fares by 50 cents in 2003 to help close a steep budget gap, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said in a report released Friday.
 But Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the transit agency, said yesterday that while he could not rule out a fare increase in 2003, he called such speculation "premature." 
 "Obviously, because of the current economic climate, it is premature to discuss what will need to be done in 2003 and 2004." 
Mr. McCall, a Democrat who is running for governor, has predicted that the M.T.A. could face an operating budget gap of as much as $927 million in 2003, and as much as $1.2 billion in 2004, because of declining ridership and increased capital costs since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. 
The M.T.A. has an annual operating budget of about $6 billion.
"A gap of this magnitude would require a 50-cent increase in subway and bus fares, and higher fares on the commuter railroads, unless the M.T.A. acts quickly to implement alternative actions," Mr. McCall wrote in the report.
Mr. Kelly said that Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who is running for re-election, had asked the transportation agency more than a month ago not to raise fares next year. Mr. Kelly said the agency has already started taking such internal steps as trimming expenses and reducing overtime costs.
Subway and bus fares last increased in New York City in 1995, from $1.25 to the current $1.50.
Frank Sobrino, a spokesman for Mr. McCall, said yesterday that the M.T.A. report was released as part of Mr. McCall's regular oversight of city and state government agencies. 
"He's just doing his job as the chief financial officer of New York," Mr. Sobrino said. "The numbers speak for themselves. All Comptroller McCall is saying is the M.T.A. needs to do something about them as soon as possible."

HEADLINE: Recession Is Stretching the Limit on Welfare Benefits 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
Although the 1996 welfare law set a five-year limit for benefits, the economy is in recession at the very time the benefits are set to end, and many states are setting the deadlines aside for more and more recipients.
 The law was intended to get people off welfare and into jobs. But for some people in communities with chronic unemployment, relaxed deadlines mean that welfare remains as they have always known it. And advocates for the poor say the safety net of welfare checks for families with children under 18, food stamps, disability insurance and Medicaid insurance looks stronger than they feared when Congress enacted the law. 
 "If we really adhered to the five-year limit, we'd be in worse shape," said Wendell E. Primus, income security director at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities here and formerly a welfare official in the Clinton administration. "But the safety net is not in as bad shape as I would have thought." 
In Washington State last month, Gov. Gary Locke ordered permanent exemptions for all but 120 of 3,200 families for whom welfare would have been stopped when the state's five-year limit first takes effect next August. Kansas exempted 270 of the first 300 families likely to hit the deadline in the next year.
With unemployment rising, some states have decided to exempt recipients in communities where the jobless rate exceeds a specified level. In Virginia, the level is 10 percent.
Illinois stops the clock for recipients who are working at least 30 hours a week and earning too little to get out of poverty, are in college and earning at least a 2.5 grade point average, or are caring for a sick child who is dependent on life-support equipment. 
In September the state expanded the provision to cover recipients providing full-time care for any sick child or spouse. Because of such measures, Illinois expects fewer than 100 recipients to reach its five-year deadline next July, when it first takes effect. 
States stretch deadlines in part to help new workers get along better in minimum wage jobs. And more and more, states grant them a full welfare check, typically $200 to $500 a month, for six months or a year while they work. 
Deadlines are still essential, many welfare officials say. In tours of state welfare offices, Wade F. Horn, an assistant secretary in the federal Department of Health and Human Services, said, "Almost no state agreed that we should do away with time limits." Mr. Horn said the threat of being cut motivated recipients and their caseworkers, whose performance is often measured by the people they help get jobs. 
Ohio's administrator for welfare policy, John Potts, said, "We haven't seen any indication that time limits are a mistake." The threat of the deadline "has meant more people working and fewer living in poverty," Mr. Potts said. 
The number of families receiving cash assistance nationwide fell to a low of 2.1 million by June this year from 4.4 million in August 1996, when the law was enacted. But welfare rolls have started to rise this year for the first time since the law took effect, according to state welfare officials. 
With the more relaxed deadlines and rising applications for welfare from people who have lost jobs, populous states like California, Texas, Florida, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Ohio have reported recent increases in the number of welfare cases.
Indiana has reported one of the sharpest increases, of 22 percent, to 47,073 families in September from July 2000. Through September, New York's and New Jersey's caseloads were still declining but leveling off. 
States can relax deadlines quite freely because the welfare law permits caseload exemptions of up to 20 percent due to various hardships. Because of the strong economy of the 1990's and the abundance of jobs then, far fewer than 20 percent of recipients have stayed on welfare for five years and therefore are not approaching a deadline. 
That means that unless unemployment rises sharply, states say they can grant exemptions at the current pace and not reach the 20 percent for two or three years. By then, proponents of the welfare law say, the economy should be generating jobs again and leaving few people exposed to deadlines. 
Sheila Zedlewski, a welfare analyst at the nonpartisan Urban Institute, is skeptical. "It's definitely true," Ms. Zedlewski said, "that time limits aren't going to be a big huge disaster at one point in time." But as more recipients are exempted and states approach the 20 percent, she said, deadlines will matter more in two or three years.
The states do not have uniform requirements and experiences. New York, for example, is a special case. Regardless of the federal law, New York's constitution requires that the poor be protected. More than 38,000 people who have been on welfare for five years will be dropped from the rolls in December. 
But Brian J. Wing, commissioner of the New York State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, said all should be able to qualify for a state program that covers their needs by directly paying their landlords and the merchants they use. 
Other states set much earlier deadlines, of two or three years, but even in those situations there have been exceptions to the deadlines. Connecticut's, the shortest, is only 21 months, but the state routinely exempts families. A few states, like Vermont and Michigan, do not use deadlines.
But deadlines and the welfare law face their toughest tests in the poorest communities with the highest unemployment, like those of the Mississippi Delta. 
In Greenwood, Miss., Dynetha Thornton, director of the Leflore County office of the state's Department of Human Services, said the county unemployment rate is 10 percent. Some clients go to heroic lengths to work, Ms. Thornton said. 
Six Leflore County mothers are picked up in vans at 3 a.m. for a ride to jobs in faraway chicken processing plants where they earn about $6 an hour, or $12,000 a year. With stops to deliver children to sitters, the trip takes three or four hours.
The women still collect a welfare check because the pay does not lift them above the poverty line, and the state pays for their child care and the van, and gives them $5 a day for lunch and a $3,000 bonus for working for two years. 
But not many of the Greenwood office's clients will go to the poultry workers' lengths to work. Of 438 welfare recipients, Ms. Thornton said only 151 are fulfilling the law's required participation in a work program -- working, or training and looking for a job. The others, still collecting welfare checks, can have their benefits extended for 12 months because of scarce jobs, and they can be extended again. 
"This is telling me that we still have individuals who believe it's not true that we have ended welfare as we knew it," Ms. Thornton said. "They think, 'I've been allowed to sit down and not do anything, so I'm going to test them.' They've already been granted a 12-month extension, so you tell me who's winning."

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 The Tasks Ahead

EVOLVING STRATEGY -- When Afghanistan's transitional government takes power in two weeks, it will inherit a capital full of blaring horns, busy markets and a nearly universal desire for peace. But real peace will have to wait, for the unusual war that has wrested every last Afghan city from the Taliban is not over. The most complex and potentially perilous tasks the United States has assigned itself lie ahead -- including imposing enough law and order to allow medicine and food to reach an ill and starving population, and to prevent a resurgence of violence. A1

The Relief Effort

FRIENDSHIP BRIDGE -- After weeks of diplomatic pressure from the United States, the President of Uzbekistan, Islam Karimov, agreed to open a crucial bridge that could help speed urgently needed food and medical supplies from this Central Asian country to war-ravaged Afghanistan. The decision to open the Friendship Bridge should free international relief organizations to move millions of tons of humanitarian aid into Northern Afghanistan and could enable United States forces based in Uzbekistan to resupply units in Northern Afghanistan. A1

UNICEF -- The executive director of the United Nations Children's Fund, Carol Bellamy, said the organization is striving to provide the basics of food and water to ensure the survival of an estimated 1.5 million Afghan children under 5 years old at the greatest risk. Of those, 150,000 are considered seriously malnourished, Ms. Bellamy said, adding that they need food, water, winter clothes, blankets and heated tents. A22

After the Taliban

THE DEVASTATION WITHIN -- As the Taliban retreat, the full weight of the devastation they wrought is becoming apparent, especially in places like Bamian, in remote central Afghanistan, the scene of some of the most devastating fighting between the Taliban and the Northern Alliance. The region was also home to the two giant 1,500-year-old statues of Buddha that the Taliban destroyed last spring. Tribal natives of the region, the Hazaras, are slowly returning to mountainside homes, but as the first snow fell last week, some wondered whether hunger or cold would be first to claim their children. A1

A FAMILY'S DESTINY -- In 1761, King Ahmad Shah Durrani, the founder of Afghanistan, received some free land from a powerful local clan where he built the city of Kandahar. Last week, the clan's latest leader, Hamid Karzai, said he had secured an agreement to reclaim Kandahar from the Taliban, and he is expected to lead Afghanistan's interim government starting on Dec. 22. The Taliban's surrender ended two decades of exile for the Karzais, whose fate, perhaps more than any other Afghan family's, has been intimately tied to the ups and downs of Afghanistan's tumultuous history. B1

A TRAIL OF DEATH -- With the Taliban gone, Mazar-i-Sharif hums with the joy of a city set free. But human rights groups say thousands of people died in the bloodletting, and mass graves wreathe this ancient city bearing the grim evidence of its central role in Afghanistan's civil war. As Afghanistan seems set to embark on a new Western-backed political experiment, the town stands as a somber warning. B1

ROUGH JUSTICE -- The Northern Alliance, demonstrating a willingness to impose harsh order over the largely lawless territory it captured from the Taliban in northern Afghanistan, attacked a band of highway robbers last week and hung the bullet-riddled body of a man it had killed from the barrel of a tank for two days to deter bandits. The interim government that starts in Kabul on Dec. 22 should eventually wield enough influence to impose law and order, but the Northern Alliance has shown that until then it is willing to resort to ancient elements of civic rule. B4

THE REFUGEES -- About 10,000 Afghan refugees have trickled back to the capital of Kabul, but United Nations officials said they did not expect large numbers of people to return to Afghanistan until next spring. B5

The View in Washington

THE PRESIDENT -- Dozens of friends and advisers of President Bush said in interviews that while he still could not resist a joke or two, he had conducted himself far more seriously since Sept. 11. While events have left Mr. Bush little choice but to rise to the challenge, many loyalists say they are nevertheless struck by how much more comfortable and engaged he seems now. B7

THE INVESTIGATION -- The United States is investigating intelligence reports of contacts between Pakistani nuclear weapons scientists and the Taliban or Al Qaeda and asked that two nuclear engineers, Suleiman Asad and Muhammed Ali Mukhtar, be questioned. Pakistani officials said their government is resisting American efforts to question their scientists for fear this may be a ploy to learn details of its nuclear program. While much about this dispute is unclear, it shows that the two countries remain at odds over vital issues despite recent cooperation. A1

DEMOCRATS' STRATEGY -- With President Bush's popularity rating in the stratosphere and the country solidly behind the war on terror, Democrats have adopted a delicate strategy for winning control of Congress next year and positioning themselves for challenging the president in 2004. While they express support for the war effort and refrain from the slightest personal criticisms of Mr. Bush, they are increasing their attacks on the president's economic and social policies -- on taxes and spending, on health care, on education and, especially, on the administration's response to the recession. B7

SECRET EVIDENCE -- In the 1990's, immigrants' groups, several federal courts and some politicians criticized immigration officials for using secret evidence against those they wanted to detain or deport. The practice had nearly ceased in recent years, but legal experts say that since Sept. 11, the government has shown a desire to resume it. The Bush administration, however, denies it intends to break the president's campaign pledges not to use secret evidence against immigrants. B1

Aftermath of the Attacks

ISLAM IN AMERICA -- After unusually high bail of $500,000 was set for a Yemeni man held on an immigration violation, Muslims in San Diego promised to provide it. But that sign of unity has become a symbol of division, as many Muslims have backed off after realizing their names would be publicized. B6

THE PENTAGON -- For the families who lost loved ones in the attack on the Pentagon, Cmdr. Yvette C. BrownWahler of the Navy has offered a tonic mix of maternal compassion and executive resolve as the head the Pentagon's Family Service Center. Now Commander BrownWahler is preparing to become a rarity in the Navy -- a woman in command of a warship, the guided missile destroyer Chafee, which is being built in Maine. B6

THE HOME FRONT -- While the Army investigates, the family of Pvt. Giovanny Maria, who was one of the first United States military deaths in the war on terror, is wondering if his death was accidental, or if he took his own life. B6

GROUND ZERO -- The Giuliani administration has abandoned plans to replace a city agency with a private construction company to run operations at the World Trade Center disaster site. B6 --

NEW LIFE -- In an unusual side effect of the attacks, a leather factory in Maine that closed last month will reopen on Jan. 2 and 150 workers will regain their jobs, because more American soldiers need combat boots, which must be made with American shoe leather. A49

COLLEGE ADMISSIONS -- Contrary to predictions that high school seniors would choose colleges closer to home and avoid cities after Sept. 11, college admissions officials say early applications are up and reflect the same geographic patterns as in past years. A50

HEADLINE: A Health Maze: Which Way Out? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses for Sickest Workers" (front page, Dec. 5):
 You report that the big insurers' "new kind of health plan" will be less costly for employers, but workers who have the bad luck to get seriously ill or injured will have to pay substantially more. 
 You quote one corporate health plan director as saying the higher costs will make patients avoid unnecessary treatments. Other experts note that most people don't know what is and what isn't necessary and predict that lower income participants will simply avoid treatment. 
It will surely worsen the health care gap between the haves and have-nots. The Princeton economist Uwe E. Reinhardt is right to call it "a very dubious social policy."
Most other advanced countries have universal health systems financed by more equitable taxation. We need the same here, to end the worsening health care apartheid that belies our American traditions of freedom and equality.

JOHN GLASEL
Hoboken, N.J., Dec. 5, 2001

The writer is secretary, Health Care for All, New Jersey.

HEADLINE: A Health Maze: Which Way Out? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The "cost-saving" measure for health insurance (front page, Dec. 5) will drive the horrific 70 percent unemployment rate for people with disabilities even higher. As an employed person with a disability, I and my family would be punished for my extra medical expenses. 
Most of these are for preventive care that enables me to keep healthy and working. 
 Under the new scheme, those who have a family member with a disability would forgo needed medical treatment if their salaries were not high enough to pay up to $5,000 out of pocket once their "annual allowance" was exhausted. What a concept -- medical insurance that only covers the needs of healthy people and discourages people with disabilities and their family members from pursuing healthy and independent lives (and jobs)!

SUSAN SCHEER
New York, Dec. 6, 2001

The writer is executive director, Center for Independence of the Disabled in New York.
