HEADLINE: IN BRIEF; 
Riverhead Stops Residential Subdivisions

BYLINE:  By John Rather 

 BODY:
Deluged by development, the Town of Riverhead has approved a six-month moratorium on residential subdivisions.
 The 3-to-2 town board vote last week will delay about 18 building projects involving more than 1,000 new housing units. 
 A one-year moratorium had been under discussion but was put aside before the vote.
The moratorium will give the town additional time to complete and enact a master plan that is expected to include zoning and planning measures to limit future growth.
A majority of the agricultural land and a large part of the remaining open space on the East End are in Riverhead.
The town supervisor, Robert Kozakiewicz, a Republican accused by environmental groups of being a supporter of development, voted for the moratorium. Mr. Kozakiewicz narrowly won election to a second term in November against a Democratic opponent supported by the New York League of Conservation Voters.
Eve Kaplan, the Riverhead coordinator for the North Fork Environmental Council in Mattituck, said the moratorium was an important step for the town.
"It remains to be seen whether this will really curb growth in Riverhead," she said. "But symbolically it's very important and it raises expectations about what the current administration will do."
Richard Amper, the executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, said he supported the building pause. "Anything that allows anyone time to plan Riverhead's future is welcomed," he said. 
Farms, farm stands and wineries are drawing increasingly large numbers of visitors and are recognized by town officials as vital to the town's economy.
In Southold, Supervisor Jean Cochran, a Republican, proposed zoning that would allow no more than one house on every five acres of farmland. Mrs. Cochran was defeated in the November election by Joshua Horton, a Democrat who opposed the plan. John Rather

CORRECTION-DATE: December 23, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A brief article on Dec. 9 about a six-month moratorium on new residential subdivisions in the Town of Riverhead misstated the vote of the town supervisor, Robert Kozakiewicz. He voted against the measure, not for it. It was approved 3 to 2.

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
HomeGoods Opens Second County Store

BYLINE:  By Merri Rosenberg 

 BODY:

 As a division of the off-price retailer TJX, the Framingham, Mass.-based parent company of apparel discounters like T. J. Maxx and Marshalls, among others, HomeGoods features items in areas like dinnerware and glassware, bath and bedding, lamps, rugs, housewares and seasonal merchandise. Merri Rosenberg

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
In Search of Forever, Shoppers Return to 47th St.

BYLINE:  By LAUREN WEBER 

 BODY:
DENNIS MARLOW leaned across his jewelry counter on 47th Street in Midtown Manhattan and told what is becoming a familiar story. Last month, he said, "a guy just walked in and bought an engagement ring he's been promising his wife for 10 years." When they were planning their wedding, the customer explained, he didn't have enough money.
 "He just said, 'It's time,' " Mr. Marlow said. And so the customer, a china and crystal salesman from New York City, plunked down $8,000 for a 1.5-carat diamond ring. 
 Mr. Marlow, the owner of Solitaire Creations, surmised that his client had been motivated on some level by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. "A lot of people are being spurred by the feeling that you never know when something's going to happen," he said. 
Many merchants along 47th Street, the heart of New York's diamond district, as well as others around the country, are reporting a surge in sales of diamond jewelry this holiday season, whether to people seeking long-overdue engagement rings or those merely splurging on themselves. The gain follows a slump immediately after Sept. 11.
But buyers should not let emotion alone drive their shopping. Diamonds are a complicated product, with many gradations of quality and price. And buying one in or near 47th Street, the source for many people around the world, can be daunting, to say the least.
The district -- the largest diamond market in the United States -- fills the entire block of West 47th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues and encompasses parts of West 46th and 48th Streets. About 400 retailers are there, all vying for a piece of the nation's nearly $30 billion diamond jewelry market.
Many people strolling through the neighborhood, especially those from outside New York, see only the street-level retail shops. But above them, often in cramped, dingy offices, are more than 2,000 other small businesses -- wholesalers, diamond polishers, jewelry manufacturers -- that serve the global jewelry markets.
Many of the diamonds sold by jewelers on 47th Street are of comparable quality to those at Fifth Avenue salons like Tiffany & Company or Cartier. But diamond experts say shoppers can sometimes find better deals with diamond district merchants -- by some accounts as much as 50 percent savings -- because of the intense competition and their close proximity to jewelry manufacturers and diamond dealers.
"The people on 47th Street try to make as much as they can, but everything they do is negotiable," one veteran diamond importer said. "There are bargains you can create yourself." 
But creating them can be a challenge. "There is no consistency" with prices, the importer said. Markups vary widely -- the average at many established jewelers is 100 percent, but it can be higher for lower-end diamonds and lower for more expensive ones. 
These days, many diamond district merchants have been cutting prices further -- by an estimated 5 to 10 percent, according to dealers there -- to help prop up sales, which had been hurt by the weak economy as well as the terrorist attacks. For some merchants, sales dropped as much as 70 percent in the first few weeks after Sept. 11, and even now are down 15 percent, said Howard Herman, a fourth-generation diamond merchant and chairman of the 47th Street Business Improvement District.
"It's a very good buyer's market," Mr. Herman said.
Low prices are not always a guarantee of a good deal. Among the so-called bargains may be many overpriced and misrepresented gems, experts say. The best way to ensure a good deal is to go comparison-shopping. That, of course, is easy to do in the diamond district, where shops are bunched together. After speaking to a few merchants, shoppers will have a sense of a reasonable and realistic price for what they want. For higher-priced stones, though, experts advise buyers to get at least one independent opinion from a certified appraiser.
Amid the competition, some jewelers are more aggressive than others. The 47th Street Business Improvement District says consumers should avoid merchants who try to pressure them into making fast decisions. 
Although a good jeweler will explain the basics of diamond shopping, buyers should do some research on their own, at least to become familiar with the four C's -- carat, color, clarity and cut. (A flawless, colorless stone is considered the most valuable, and is, therefore, the most expensive.)
Many district merchants sell diamond jewelry with certificates that give the stone a grade for color and clarity and list the carat weight. The certificates come from independent laboratories like the Gemological Institute of America or the American Gem Society.
Consumers are entitled to a detailed receipt that includes the price and a description, as well as an accurate diamond grade and the carat weight information. It should also disclose any treatments or enhancements to the stone. And money-back guarantees are important; the improvement district says buyers are entitled to at least 20 days to make returns.
Web sites of trade groups and companies can provide useful primers for consumers, as well as tips on finding a reputable jeweler. Among the sites, Mondera.com, based in the diamond district, has a learning center with information about diamonds, colored gemstones, pearls and precious metals. Another, Buyarock.com, is designed with male buyers in mind. The Diamond Registry (www.diamondregistry.com), also in the district, has articles about buying diamonds. Visitors to the site can list the specifications of the diamond they want and then get prices.
PERHAPS another "C" should be added to the diamond-buying process -- conflict. The diamond industry has come under scrutiny during the last few years for its connection to "conflict diamonds," stones that are mined in rebel-held areas in Africa and sold to finance civil wars. Some dealers, like the Diamond Registry, say they have asked their suppliers to verify that all the diamonds they buy are "conflict free."
Late last month in Gabarone, Botswana, representatives of the industry, human rights groups and more than 30 governments agreed that all shipments of rough stones must contain certificates of origin. And the House of Representatives has passed a bill that gives the president authority to bring sanctions against countries that refuse to adopt a tracking system for diamonds. The issue gained momentum after reports that Osama bin Laden and his terrorist network, Al Qaeda, had bought diamonds from African rebels and sold them in Europe at a profit.
Consumers who are concerned about the issue should talk to their jewelers "and use the opportunity to say, 'I want to know that the jewelry industry is doing everything it can to end this trade,' " said Deborah DeYoung, an aide to Representative Tony P. Hall, an Ohio Democrat who was a sponsor of the measure.
Richard Winick, owner of Manny Winick & Son on 47th Street, said consumers were choosing "classic" products -- diamond stud earrings, anniversary bands, and engagement rings in a traditional four-prong setting. "Anything that was classic in the 50's and 60's" is selling well, he said.
On a recent afternoon, Mr. Winick showed Dale Cahner, 43, some three-stone engagement rings. Never mind that Mrs. Cahner has been married for nearly 13 years. Every five years, she and her husband, David, 42, renew their wedding vows, and in 2003, they will go to Venice to be "married" for a fourth time.
"We were talking about the trip and planning the trip," she said, "and my husband said, 'We must get engaged before we get married.' " So he told her to pick out a ring.
Mrs. Cahner slipped a 5-carat diamond ring onto her finger. "Right now, I'm shopping for size and shape and to see what I like," she said. After she makes her choice, Mr. Cahner will buy it and then "surprise" her someday with the ring and another marriage proposal.

Looking for a Quality Diamond? Homework Can Help

IS a diamond on your holiday shopping list? Here are some buying tips from experts:

DO SOME RESEARCH -- Plenty of publications and Web sites offer useful information, including guidance on finding reputable dealers. Sites include the Jewelers of America, www.jewelers.org; the Jewelry Information Center, www.jewelryinfo.org; and the 47th Street Business Improvement District, www.diamonddistrict.org.

LEARN THE FOUR C'S -- Carat refers to weight. Color, for traditional white diamonds, is graded on a scale of D to Z, with D through F considered colorless and thus the most valuable. Clarity refers to a stone's flaws, or inclusions, which usually can be seen under magnification. The highest ratings are "flawless" and VVS-1 or -2 (very very slightly included). Cut refers to the angles of the diamond's facets, which determine the amount of light, or brilliance, reflected out of the stone.

COMPARISON SHOP -- It is easy to compare prices if you can visit an area where jewelry stores are clustered, like New York's diamond district on 47th Street. If you can't, check out a few stores in your hometown or look at reputable diamond Web sites.

DON'T BE PRESSURED -- Avoid jewelers who try to push you into a quick purchase -- you are probably spending a lot of money, so you should take all the time you need. Avoid stores that employ "hawkers" who try to lure you inside the store from the street.

GET IT IN WRITING -- Many jewelers sell diamonds with certificates from independent laboratories like the Gemological Institute of America. The certificates list carat weight and give a stone a grade for color and clarity. They should also provide a receipt with price information, the diamond's grade, guarantees and return policies.

NEGOTIATE -- If you're looking at an expensive diamond, you may be able to bring down the price. You can pay substantially less if you buy diamonds that are slightly under the standard weights -- for example, 0.97 carat instead of a full carat, or 0.47 instead of a half-carat.

HEADLINE: The Dangers Behind a Leap of Faith 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
TRUST me.
 They are two of the most common -- and dangerous -- words on Wall Street. 
 Trust-me companies are companies whose financial results gallop ahead of their businesses, companies with seemingly perfect control over their quarterly sales and profits. Companies whose financial statements are loaded with footnotes, companies that short-sellers often attack but rarely dent. Companies with executives who sell their stock every quarter even as they encourage investors to buy more.
They are companies like Enron and Providian Financial -- and Calpine and Tyco International and, maybe, General Electric. This year, Enron was on track to post $200 billion in sales with only 21,000 employees. That works out to revenue of almost $9 million a worker, far more than at other large companies. How did Enron generate such huge sales? How did Enron's energy trading operations make money? What was the relationship between Enron and the web of off-balance-sheet partnerships it created to finance its investments? 
Trust me, Enron's chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow said. "We don't want anyone to know what's on those books," Mr. Fastow told Fortune magazine in March, seven months before he was forced out. "We don't want to tell anyone where we're making money." 
That explanation was good enough for Wall Street. Between the end of 1997 and the beginning of this year, Enron's shares quadrupled, and the company won praise for its aggressive management and fast growth.
But when a trust-me story goes wrong, shareholders may find their investments vaporized. Amid questions about the truth of its financial statements, Enron has filed for bankruptcy protection; its stock has fallen 99 percent this year.
Investors in these companies are particularly vulnerable now. Because trust-me companies often depend on easy financing, they are especially dangerous when the stock market or economy turns sour, said Douglas Cliggott, the chief investment strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities.
"We're in a global recession, and it's in recessions where stretched accounting hurts you," Mr. Cliggott said. "I don't think it's a coincidence we're seeing examples of stretched accounting running into problems, where two years ago, we didn't."
Trust-me companies are often strongly supported by Wall Street, because they pay investment bankers hefty fees to raise money for them or advise them on mergers, said Howard Schilit, president of the Center for Financial Research and Analysis, a firm in Rockville, Md., that breaks apart balance sheets for institutional investors. "Wall Street likes things that will make them a lot of money," he said. "The game is always doing transactions."
Every public company depends to some extent on the trust of its investors. The largest companies, like Home Depot and AT&T, have hundreds of thousands of employees and tens of billions of dollars in annual sales. Even medium-sized public companies often have offices and sales around the world. No shareholder could personally check all of their operations or be certain that they have fully disclosed all of their investments and debts. Some companies use off-balance-sheet partnerships to raise money or to buy assets without ever telling their shareholders in their financial statements.
"It's difficult for any investor, even a good investor, to see what's happening," Mr. Schilit said, "because you're not doing an audit, you're simply relying on published information."
CERTAIN companies, and certain industries, are more likely to tell trust-me stories. Financial services companies and technology companies, especially software companies, like Computer Associates, bear special scrutiny, analysts, short-sellers and others say, because they can manipulate their earnings more easily than other companies.
Electricity and natural gas companies like Dynegy and El Paso Electric, many of which have moved rapidly into the volatile business of trading energy, bear close watching, too, they add. Tyco and G.E., both giant conglomerates, have also drawn the attention of some skeptics, because their operations are so large and complex as to be essentially unfathomable to outsiders.
Poorly understood businesses and footnote-filled financial statements are not the only warning signs, Mr. Schilit said. He pointed to companies that seem to rely heavily on acquisitions for earnings growth, like Tyco, which is based in Bermuda.
Short-sellers, who make money when stock prices decline, took aim at Tyco two years ago, accusing it of stretching accounting rules by taking big restructuring charges when it made acquisitions. The Securities and Exchange Commission opened an investigation, and Tyco's stock plunged almost 50 percent.
But L. Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco's charismatic chairman, fought off the accusations, saying his accounting was proper. In July 2000, the S.E.C. ended its inquiry without taking action against the company. Tyco's stock has since hit a new high and remains a favorite of Wall Street. According to Bloomberg, the company has the highest rating from each of the 15 analysts who cover it.
Tyco has grown consistently for more than a decade, and its cash flow is strong, said Jack L. Kelly, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. As a result, he said, he has confidence in Mr. Kozlowski and Tyco's management.
Still, David W. Tice, the short-seller who initially complained about Tyco's accounting, said he remained skeptical about Tyco. "The underlying growth rate in the future is going to be less," Mr. Tice said. Tyco uses "acquisitions and charge-offs," he said. "It reads like a laundry list of the way companies can play games."
General Electric does not depend as heavily on acquisitions as Tyco, and it is renowned for its strong management. But Mr. Tice said G.E. was worth watching because of its huge financial services division and because it seems to be able to meet or just beat its earnings targets every quarter, no matter the economic environment.
In addition, like many trust-me stocks, G.E. trades at a premium to the market and its competitors because of its fast earnings growth. Having a high price-to-earnings ratio increases the pressure on management to perform, as well as increasing the risk for investors if the company falls short. G.E. is valued at about 24 times its expected 2002 earnings, compared with a multiple of about 23 for the average Standard & Poor's 500 stock. And almost half of G.E.'s earnings come from its financial subsidiary -- yet big banks like Citigroup and Bank of America trade for 13 to 17 times next year's earnings, much less than G.E.
Mr. Schilit says another sign of a trust-me company is a rapidly changing business model. "You transform the company into something that is much more sexy," he said. "Enron was transformed from a pretty boring energy company with modest growth, low price-earnings ratio, to a newfangled energy trading company." The same is true of many of Enron's competitors, including Dynegy, El Paso Electric and Calpine, which have moved aggressively into the business of trading power.
OF course, not every high-growth company is a trust-me story. With Wal-Mart opening stores around the world, the company's rising sales are as visible on the ground as in its income statements. Microsoft's high margins are no mystery, and the company's $31 billion cash hoard proves how lucrative a monopoly can be.
But Mr. Kelly, the Goldman, Sachs analyst, said he was wary of companies whose growth rate suddenly accelerates. "A lot of these shooting stars that we've seen over the last couple of years -- it's the new model, the new paradigm, which turns out not to be the new paradigm at all," he said.
Earnings that are rising more quickly than cash flow are particularly worthy of scrutiny, in Mr. Kelly's view. There are "a number of accounting techniques which will allow a company to report a certain earnings-per-share figure which might be noncash earnings," he said.
Enron, whose earnings per share nearly doubled between 1998 and last year after hardly budging between 1994 and 1998, is just one example. In the late 1990's, Coca-Cola was a classic trust-me story. The company's earnings almost tripled from 1992 to 1997, even though its sales grew much more slowly. Much of that growth came from one-time gains as Coke restructured and sold local bottlers to Coca-Cola Enterprises, a supposedly independent bottling company that is 38 percent owned by Coke.
Coke said the money earned from selling the bottling business was real and should be considered as part of its operating earnings. Despite complaints from short-sellers, who said growth in Coke's core business of selling soft drinks had slowed, Wall Street agreed, bidding the company's shares up fourfold, to a high of $87.94 in July 1998.
The shorts were right. In the last three years, fierce competition and slow growth have cut Coke's profits to barely half their 1997 level. Its stock has followed, closing on Friday at $46.60, down 23.5 percent this year.
FOR years, Computer Associates also had profits that outran its cash flow, as it booked as revenue contracts for which it would not be paid until many years in the future. Today, the company's reported sales and profits have plunged as it works off the backlog of sales it made years ago.
"Reported profits can be confusing," said Chris Galvin, a software analyst at J. P. Morgan. Some software companies, like Microsoft, use conservative accounting, while others are much more aggressive. "The devil is in the details," he said.
Mr. Cliggott advised investors to be wary of financial services companies, which can hide loan losses by extending repayment or rolling unpaid debts into new loans but can run into trouble if the economy sours.
Shares in Providian, a credit-card company that specializes in lending to borrowers with poor credit histories, have fallen from $60 in July to $3.20 today because of sharply rising write-offs on its cards.
"There's a lot of judgment as to when you want to be provisioning for the recognition of bad credit," Mr. Cliggott said.
Michael Freudenstein, a brokerage and specialty finance analyst at J. P. Morgan, disagreed. Mr. Freudenstein said that financial companies must disclose losses quickly and that analysts and investors would punish them if they tried to skimp on their loss reserves. "Finance companies are clear as day," he said.
But Mr. Freudenstein, who had a buy recommendation on Providian until mid-October, when he downgraded the stock to long-term buy and then to hold within a week, acknowledged that Providian's problems had surprised him. "Do I wish I had downgraded it sooner? Yes I do," he said.
Other finance companies that specialize in lending to weak borrowers, like Metris and AmeriCredit, may face problems similar to Providian's, said M. W. Montgomery, partner in a hedge fund that has sold those stocks short. "The amazing thing about the financial services industry," he said, "is the recurring times the market buys everything to be O.K. on the way up."
On that, you can trust him.

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about companies whose complex financial reports force investors to rely heavily on their managements' word misstated the name of one such business, which has moved rapidly into energy trading. It is the El Paso Corporation; El Paso Electric is an unrelated utility.

HEADLINE: Carrying Sticks and Hugging Trees 

BYLINE:  By Richard Brookhiser; Richard Brookhiser is the author of the forthcoming "America's First Dynasty: The Adamses, 1735-1918."

 BODY:
 THEODORE REX
By Edmund Morris.
Illustrated. 772 pp. New York:
Random House. $35.
 Among the many things that Sept. 11 will change is our view of the past. Even as the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq have been jolted, so has the market in the reputations of dead presidents. It seems safe to say that the John Adams boom, so carefully nurtured by David McCullough and Joseph J. Ellis, is over. The lovable and passionate crank who couldn't administer a bridge game is simply not the man for this hour. The great Virginians of the first Republican Party -- Thomas Jefferson and James Madison -- so sublime in their principles, so incompetent in their diplomacy and warmaking, will also be trading at a discount. 
Who looks more interesting? All the general-presidents, from Washington to Eisenhower; Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was president during the original day of infamy; and Franklin's brave and bumptious older cousin Theodore. Two books that were planned to appear after the centennial of Theodore Roosevelt's first inauguration, in September 1901, acquire a grave relevance. 
"Theodore Roosevelt" (Times Books/ Holt, $20, to be published next month), Louis Auchincloss's contribution to the American Presidents series, surveys Roosevelt's not-long life -- he died at the age of 60 -- in under 200 pages. Better, however, to take a deep breath and dive into "Theodore Rex," Edmund Morris's sequel to his 1979 masterpiece, "The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt." Morris's new book begins at the moment when an assassin's bullet elevates Vice President Roosevelt to the White House and ends, seven and a half years later, when he leaves office. Another volume will be needed to cover his last, eventful decade, which included a failed attempt to regain the presidency and World War I. In the fashion of modern megabiography, Morris devotes several hundred pages to a relatively brief period of time. But unlike many of his peers, he writes with a breezy verve that makes the pages fly, and that perfectly suits his subject.
Roosevelt was six weeks shy of his 43rd birthday when he became president, following the death of William McKinley, thus making him the youngest man ever to occupy the White House (John F. Kennedy, who was 43 years and 5 months old on Election Day in 1960, was the youngest man ever to be elected). The air of youth clung to him throughout his administration. Morris quotes the famous judgment of the British diplomat Cecil Spring Rice: "You must always remember that the president is about 6." Equally telling is the 1904 birthday greeting to Roosevelt from Secretary of War Elihu Root: "You have made a very good start in life and your friends have great hopes for you when you grow up."
Roosevelt had a boy's egotism and brutality; the "bully pulpit" (his phrase) was often the bully's pulpit. But he was also curious, eager, outgoing, energetic. "Isn't it a fine thing to be alive when so many great things are happening?" one lunch guest recorded him saying. Add to the mix his nimble intelligence -- one breathless interlocutor called him "a perfect flying squirrel" in conversation -- and it is no mystery that so many people found him so winning. He was like Rudy Giuliani with charm, Bill Clinton with principles.
Roosevelt made his most constructive contribution in the realm of foreign policy. Together with McKinley, he ushered America into the ranks of the world's great powers. As McKinley's assistant secretary of the Navy, he had pushed for a program of shipbuilding, which he continued as president. At the end of his administration, he sent the expanded Navy, painted white, on a cruise around the world. To facilitate the Navy's movements between oceans, he encouraged a revolution in the Colombian province of Panama. Morris's chapter on the Panamanian adventure skillfully uses a favorite device of his -- short, intercut minisections -- to suggest the fog of ignorance and chance in which high-stakes power plays of this kind always occur. After Roosevelt had won, Philander Knox, his attorney general, told him that "it would be better to keep your action free from any taint of legality." Many Americans condemned Roosevelt's assertions of national strength. But he understood that there had never been a moment of Arcadian apartness in our history. America had been an imperial venture from colonial times. He wished to continue the process in the modern world, and he hoped it would work to the nation's, and the world's, benefit.
But Roosevelt's foreign policy showed finesse as well as muscle. In 1904 a Greek-American named Ioannis Perdicaris was kidnapped from his Moroccan villa by Ahmed el-Raisuli, a bandit chief, and held for ransom. A phrase from a telegram drafted by Secretary of State John Hay -- Perdicaris alive or Raisuli dead" -- electrified the Republican convention that was nominating Roosevelt for president. What has dropped from our collective memory of that threat is that it was addressed not to Raisuli but to the sultan of Morocco, whom Roosevelt was urging to treat with the kidnapper (Perdicaris walked as soon as the sultan met Raisuli's terms). Roosevelt could cut deals as well as hurl thunderbolts.
Sometimes he acted silently. In 1902 he warned Germany against forcibly collecting debts owed it by Venezuela, and he backed up his warning with a naval exercise off Puerto Rico. He conveyed his message discreetly, however, so that Germany would lose no face by backing down. So discreet was he that many historians have doubted that Roosevelt brought any pressure to bear. Morris argues that he did (here, as elsewhere, his footnotes are worth reading). Roosevelt adopted and popularized a West African proverb, "Speak softly and carry a big stick." Cartoonists naturally focused on the stick, but soft speaking was an equally important tool. "We are too big a people," Roosevelt wrote, "to be able to be careless in what we say." 
When it comes to Roosevelt's domestic policy, Morris has to try to make sense of that vague and earnest force, the Progressive movement. Roosevelt's most original contribution to its agenda was to push for conservation of natural resources. He offered the arguments of good stewardship, but his was the sensibility of a hunter and an outdoorsman who had seen firsthand two decades' toll on the American West. His record on race was mixed, which makes it better than that of the gross racist Woodrow Wilson. In 1903 a black man accused of rape and murder was seized from prison and burned alive -- not in the Deep South, but in Wilmington, Del. Roosevelt condemned the outrage: "There are certain hideous sights which when once seen can never be wholly erased from the mental retina. The mere fact of having seen them implies degradation." Still, in his second term, he let the soldiers of a black Army unit be railroaded on trumped-up charges of rioting in Brownsville, Tex., and he nearly got into a shouting match at a Gridiron dinner with a Republican senator who vainly tried to defend them. 
Roosevelt made the most noise, however, by picking a fight with the nouveau riche industrialists. Roosevelt himself was a brownstone Knickerbocker, whose caste marks included Groton, Harvard and the Porcellian club. He turned against his class, Morris suggests, in part because he found rich men boring. "You expect a man of millions," Roosevelt said, "to be a man worth hearing; but as a rule they don't know anything outside their own businesses." But his chief motive in taking on the great debut de siecle industrial combinations was a growing conviction that they were taking unfair advantage of their competitors and customers. "I am not deeply interested in" economic issues, he admitted as his administration wound down; "my problems are moral problems, and my teaching has been plain morality." Roosevelt's friend Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. warned that "no part of the conduct of life" would be safe from government interference on such vague principles. But Roosevelt and his fellow Progressives were off to the races. 
Roosevelt's perfervid self-confidence would bear fruit in 1912, outside the scope of "Theodore Rex," when the ex-president split the Republican Party and ran on the Bull Moose ticket. The aftershocks of that campaign would include the New Deal -- for if Wilson established all the administrative precedents for Franklin Roosevelt, cousin Theodore anticipated the moral fervor. Morris is not as enamored of flags, war and big government as Roosevelt was, but he too feels the tug. A combination of diffidence and enthusiasm allows him to write of our past -- which looks like our future -- with energy and clarity.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS: A TO Z.; 
Blame The Brokers

BYLINE:  By Richard Siklos

 BODY:
When the irrational exuberance has vanished, taking with it $4 trillion of capital from the nation's stock markets, who is to blame? A growing army of bellicose investors has come to believe that the culprit is not impersonal market forces or their own excess greed -- it's the brokers who are to blame. Aggrieved investors argue that the way reputable Wall Street firms like Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston pumped up Internet and technology stocks was no better than the notorious schemes of small-time "boiler rooms," and they've filed an array of class-action lawsuits against major Wall Street firms and a record number of individual claims with the National Association of Securities Dealers.
 According to the Fordham University securities-law professor Constantine Katsoris, a veteran N.A.S.D. arbitrator, a burst in client complaints always follows a slide in the market. This year's suits, however, make a specific and often compelling claim: Wall Street analysts hyped the very Internet stocks whose dubious I.P.O.'s their firms were underwriting. The other new twist is that some investors are actually collecting: a New York doctor, Debasis Kanjilal, captured Wall Street's attention in July when Merrill settled his arbitration case for $400,000. Kanjilal claimed, among other things, that he lost his life's savings by following the firm's star analyst, Henry Blodget. Merrill has said it did nothing wrong; Blodget announced in November that he was taking a buyout from the company estimated to be $2 million. 
 If every investor who lost big on tech stocks was recompensed for his trouble, Wall Street -- itself bleeding and slashing jobs -- could face liabilities on the scale of big tobacco's. But this is not likely to happen. In August, U.S. District Judge Milton Pollack dismissed several suits brought only weeks earlier by shareholders in Amazon.com and eBay Inc. against the Morgan Stanley analyst Mary Meeker, calling them an example of "abusive litigation" based on "a collection of market gossip" from media reports.
Still, angry investors aren't likely to give up their claims anytime soon; they're taking one last stab at cashing in on the Internet bubble. Richard Siklos

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
The Industrial Genius Who Hated Difference

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
AFTER reading Neil Baldwin's latest book, one might be forgiven for thinking that Henry Ford was nothing but a loon.
 Mr. Ford kept 50 investigators on the Ford Motor payroll to monitor employee homes for any hint of what he considered moral decay, riotous living, poor hygiene -- and boarders. The last taboo had sprung from his conviction that "next to liquor, dissension in the home is due to people other than the family being there." 
 He welcomed immigrants in his factories but expected them to quickly assimilate into the ranks with a nutty graduation ceremony involving a giant papier-mache melting pot. While their families picnicked and a brass band played, they would climb into the pot garbed in their native costumes, singing their national anthems, and climb out wearing derbies and singing "The Star-Spangled Banner." 
Of course, as easy as it would be to label Mr. Ford as just another eccentric genius, he was more than that. A folk hero whose influence extended beyond Detroit, he ran one of the country's most respected and biggest employers, and had the money and inclination to buy printing presses to disseminate what these days are considered bigoted views.
Hitler certainly used Mr. Ford's published tirades about Jews as part of his own propaganda when trying to rid the world of a group that Mr. Ford had vilified as the scourge of civilization.
Fifty-four years after Mr. Ford's death, it is still worth pondering how someone of his gifts could have become so consumed by hate as to let it taint all he had accomplished in life. The question is as timely today as ever, even if the particular hatemongers and scapegoats have changed.
Mr. Baldwin, a noted biographer, provides a partial answer in "Henry Ford and the Jews: The Mass Production of Hate" (Public Affairs Press, $27.50). The book builds on earlier efforts to examine Mr. Ford's obsession with Jews and is heavily documented in footnotes. And yet, Mr. Baldwin's book is less lively than Albert Lee's 1980 book, "Henry Ford and the Jews," and still hasn't cracked the riddle. 
Too often, the author and reader are left wondering what was going on inside the man's head as he spewed anti-Semitic vitriol. Did he buy it? Was he parroting others? Were there hidden motives? And what about those later retractions, like the published apology on July 8, 1927, in which he said "the righteous indignation entertained by Jews everywhere toward me" was justified? Had he even read the apologies?
As fascinating as it is to have Mr. Ford's and his mentors' words about Jews faithfully quoted, it is numbing after a while. Far more interesting than what he said is why.
His legacy should have been secure. A Michigan farm boy who grew to be a tinkerer and dreamer, he gave consumers wheels they could afford and operate. "Anybody can drive a Ford," he liked to brag.
As his Ford Motor Company prospered, he was also revered for his management style, delighting employees in 1914 by trimming the workday and raising pay. 
But Mr. Ford's penchant for social engineering also got him into trouble. Just as he had standardized production to ensure that a reliable car -- invariably black -- rolled off the assembly line every few hours, he seemed to believe he could mint picture-perfect Americans. 
Any signs of otherness obviously had to go. Mr. Ford harbored a special lifelong mistrust for all things Jewish. This aversion, Mr. Baldwin says, dated back to Mr. Ford's school days, when he was reared on the moralistic teachings of William Holmes McGuffey, whose booksharped on sources like Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice." 
Anti-Semitic stereotypes might have been hard for the boy to challenge because there is no evidence he ever met anyone Jewish before adulthood, according to the author.
By 1914, Jewish immigrants had begun to move west, drawn by Detroit's factories and the promise of jobs. They were hired at Ford on the proviso that they attend classes given by the much-feared Sociology Department, a vice squad responsible for turning new hires into proper Americans.
But the boss was not content simply molding the Jews who worked for him. He felt he had much to say about national woes and what he called "the Jewish problem" at their core. 
Some of his hate seems fueled by a need to blame someone for deepening problems at home, as the country was drawn into World War I, and he was quick to use the words "Jew" and "profiteer" interchangeably. A fledgling Zionism movement may have raised his suspicions that Jews had divided loyalties.
Mr. Baldwin makes the case, too, that Mr. Ford's aversion to Jews was entwined with a mistrust of bankers and financiers whom he feared had conspired through loans to wrest control of other men's companies.
"Henry called all the moneylenders of the world 'Jews,' " the book quotes his sister Margaret Ford Ruddiman as saying, "regardless of their religion." 
In 1918, seeking a soapbox from which he could speak his mind unencumbered, Mr. Ford bought The Dearborn Independent, a newspaper that was soon billing itself as the Chronicler of the Neglected Truth. 
One particularly vicious series, "The International Jew: The World's Problem," which ran for 91 weeks, began on May 22, 1920. It was followed by a decision to reprint portions of the "Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion," a grand forgery that alleged that Jews were plotting to take control of the world.
To this day, Mr. Baldwin says, there is some debate over who was pulling the strings at the newspaper, as Mr. Ford's minions took pride in "amplifying" his often murky views. 
But Mr. Baldwin's narrative convincingly shows readers that Mr. Ford was his own man. He not only advised presidents and prime ministers but had himself flirted with higher office. Though described by the author as an indifferent student of history, Mr. Ford once famously muttered, "History is more or less the bunk," a comment many took to mean that history was whatever Henry Ford said it was.
As sensational as the articles in The Dearborn Independent were, circulation was uneven and the paper might have gone the way of the Model T had Mr. Ford not ordered his army of car dealers to sell the paper as they would any other Ford product. They did. 
FINALLY, in 1927, after years of failing to heed those around him and watching his business weaken -- too many black cars, perhaps? -- Mr. Ford finally sought to mend his reputation lest a serious boycott of his products make things worse.
He reached out to Louis Marshall, a prominent Jewish lawyer, who drafted a general letter of apology to Jews everywhere that one witness recalled Mr. Ford had signed without reading. More telling, Mr. Baldwin says, Mr. Ford refused to sell his printing presses, just in case the Jews someday forced him to "go after" them again. 
A grateful Mr. Ford offered his ghostwriter a brand-new Model A, which Mr. Marshall declined, saying he was "devoted to pedestrian locomotion," Mr. Baldwin reports.
Ever since, Mr. Ford's descendants, who are now running the company again, have had to answer questions about the sincerity of that apology and others that followed. Ford has also made serious amends, by, among other things, making investments and offering favorable financing in Israel and by sponsoring movies like "Schindler's List" on television. But for better or worse, Ford the company will have an image forever linked to Ford the man.

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 729 words

HEADLINE: A Stimulus Not Worth Passing 

 BODY:
If President Bush truly wants an "economic stimulus" package on his desk this year, he needs to do more than exhort Congress to get moving. He and the Republican leaders in the House and Senate should drop the pretense that tax-break giveaways to corporations and the wealthiest Americans are the key to reviving the economy.
 On Friday, Republicans broke off bipartisan negotiations on stimulus legislation, raising doubts about whether any measure to help the economy can be enacted this year. But in a slump like the one right now, an ineffective and lopsided bill is worse than no bill at all. Congress has to decide this week whether it wants to provide a real stimulus and help those hurt by the downturn, or give handouts to the people who need them least. 
 The country would be better off with no stimulus package than with one that abolishes the minimum corporate tax, as Republicans demand. Part of the sweeping tax reforms of 1986, the minimum tax is a sensible rule requiring corporations that have used loopholes and deductions to reduce their tax bills to zero to pay at least something to the federal Treasury. With the prospect of deficits stretching out to the horizon, and the administration claiming that it cannot afford to spend more money on homeland security, the idea of permanently eliminating this source of revenue is outrageous.
Republicans initially also wanted corporations to get refunds based on the repeal of these taxes, retroactive to 1986. The outcry over that proposed giveaway forced them to back down a bit from that idea. But tax law is infamously tricky, and the measure remains structured so companies could use it to recoup past taxes. The positive effect on the economy would be negligible, and the federal Treasury would be the loser. The winners, beneficiaries of huge and unnecessary windfalls, would include General Electric, General Motors, I.B.M. and even Enron, the bankrupt energy concern.
The Bush administration and Congress did enough damage to the government's long-term financial health with the tax cuts enacted last June, and the country is now seeing the results in the future deficits. The stimulus package backed by the White House would accelerate the high-end tax cuts that were approved earlier this year but are not scheduled to take effect for several years. These particular cuts will almost certainly be reconsidered and perhaps repealed by Congress when it starts wrestling with deficits and the need to make drastic spending cuts next year. Sticking them into the stimulus package is just a ploy to nail down a benefit to the wealthiest 1 percent of America before the country realizes it cannot afford the bill.
Last week, Republican leaders agreed to include in the stimulus an extension of unemployment benefits for nearly eight million Americans out of work. They took that step to secure Democratic votes for a separate bill to grant Mr. Bush expanded trade-negotiating authority. Republicans have also accepted the concept of tax breaks for those low-income Americans left out of the tax cut earlier this year. But these are only half-steps, hardly worth trading for the budget-wrecking effects of the other provisions. Extended unemployment benefits under the Republican plan would still go only to white-collar workers, not to part-time or recently hired people who were laid off. At a minimum, the stimulus bill needs to help all Americans who need jobless and health benefits.
There can certainly be room for tax breaks for business in a stimulus package. One sound approach would be to expand business tax deductions for future expenses and depreciation. Such steps would truly encourage new investment and also focus their benefits on the small and medium-size businesses hit hardest by the economy today. Congress should also include a measure to help the states close their budget deficits.
There is an impasse in Congress now on the stimulus, and Republicans favoring a bill for rich and big corporate taxpayers apparently think they do not need to make concessions. They simply plan to blame the Democrats if nothing is passed. That is why Mr. Bush needs to stop his exhortations and do the dirty work of negotiating with Congress. The presidential bully pulpit goes only so far. More welcome would be some tough decisions to get a bill that can not only be passed but can also do some good. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: German Chancellor Shores Up His Shaky Coalition 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, by playing active host to the negotiations forming a new government for Afghanistan, has shored up his shaky coalition by putting Germany on the side of postwar reconstruction.
 Just a few weeks ago, his Green Party partners, with their roots in pacifism, nearly imploded over a vote in the German Parliament supporting the deployment of German troops in a support role in and around Afghanistan. 
 But last week, as Mr. Schroder and his Green foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, beamed at the closing ceremony of the 10-day Afghan conference near Bonn, German officials were talking happily about how Germany had become an important actor for peace, enhanced its position inside Europe and even put down a marker for any future expansion of the United Nations Security Council. 
"This is a historical agreement," Mr. Schroder said at the former German government guest house, the Petersberg. "This is a great day for Afghanistan and the United Nations."
As Berthold Kohler wrote astringently in the Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper, Mr. Schroder's "assessment likely came easily to him since it also reflects on the host of the talks on Afghanistan's future."
But in political terms, Germany's involvement has been a shrewd boon to Mr. Schroder, who was aided by the swift progress of the war itself. Since Sept. 11, Mr. Schroder has put himself firmly on the side of Washington, but he has also tried to use the war to convince Germans that it is time to get over the hesitancies of the past and to act like the big European power the reunited Germany has become -- and with all the instruments of state, from foreign aid and diplomacy to the military.
Still, Mr. Schroder needs to find a balance between military solidarity with allies and the struggle for peace, and that is what the Bonn conference enabled him to do.
"It helps the government that the foreign-policy headlines every day were about what was going on in Bonn, rather than whether German soldiers were being sent to war," said Bernhard May, deputy director of the German Council on Foreign Relations. "This was very important to the government."
The Afghan authority decided upon in Bonn is hardly perfect, as even the United Nations negotiators acknowledged, and it may fracture or be unable to assert its authority outside Kabul. But the conference produced a success, the first peacefully negotiated, internationally supported government for Afghanistan in more than 20 years -- made possible by the American-led war against Osama bin Laden and his own hosts, the Taliban.
With elections next autumn and an economy in recession, and with unemployment rising toward four million and the Greens anxious about their souls, Mr. Schroder had pushed the United Nations and the United States hard to be able to play host to the conference, German and American officials say.
Germany already is the current chairman of the Afghanistan Support Group, which has been raising Western aid to reconstruct Afghanistan and held a financing conference last week in Berlin, almost simultaneously with the closing of the Bonn conference. Germany is also pushing for a German diplomat to be named the European Union's representative to Kabul.
But to support the new authority in Kabul, scheduled to take office on Dec. 22, the Afghan delegations also requested the United Nations to authorize a peacekeeping force to improve security in Kabul and create a neutral political zone there for opposition politicians to feel more at ease.
The United Nations and the United States clearly want a European core to any such force, and discussions are continuing. The British could organize it, but given British colonial history and participation in the war against the Taliban, some Afghans are nervous about too prominent a British role. There is talk about French participation -- and German.
Mr. Schroder has been coy on this question. "It's up to the U.N. to decide on the mission's composition," he said. "In case a German role is sought as part of a European solution, Germany will neither want to, nor be able to, decline its participation."
Asked about German participation in such a force, a senior United Nations official said, "We haven't asked them, exactly, and they haven't asked us not to ask."
But not all Germans would be happy with a new deployment of German forces, even for peacekeeping, when they already serve in Bosnia and Kosovo, lead the force in Macedonia and need more budget support. The weak defense minister, Rudolf Scharping, said German interests in Afghanistan are unclear, and "above all, we have limited military and financial resources."
Christoph Schwennicke, writing in the Suddeutsche Zeitung, warned about German heads becoming dizzy with flattery.
"Everyone is full of praise now for the hosts of the Afghanistan conference," Mr. Schwennicke said, suggesting that "he who can put together so successful a diplomatic arena for arranging a new order in the Hindu Kush must also be capable of taking over the military flank when a provisional government is established in Kabul."
Mr. Schroder should resist such flattery, Mr. Schwennicke said. "A German Army operation in Afghanistan is a perfectly appropriate way to overstretch their endurance," he added. But what seemed to bother him more was the potential for danger, noting that the revolt of the Arab Taliban in Mazar-i-Sharif shows that "a peace mission in Afghanistan will by no means be a peaceful mission."
But for Mr. May, of the German Council on Foreign Relations, Afghanistan represents "another step in a long learning process for the German public about how assertive the government can or should be in foreign policy." The country has come a long way since reunification in 1990, he said. At that time, he noted, a poll found that two-thirds of Germans felt the model for their foreign policy should be neutral Switzerland.

HEADLINE: For Britain, Euro Is Invasion It May Have to Invite 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BATTLE, England, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
Deep in southeast England, this ancient village of turreted towers and beamed cottages was named for the Battle of Hastings, when William, the Norman conqueror from across the channel, overwhelmed the forces of King Harold in 1066 to begin the conquest of olde Englande. These days, some suspect another intrusion from roughly the same direction could be in the offing.
 In less than four weeks, 280 million Europeans living in a swath of land from the Arctic to the Mediterranean will adopt the notes and coins of the euro single currency, jettisoning their francs and marks and drachmas and pesetas. Britain, along with Sweden and Denmark among the 15 members of the European Union, will not adopt the new currency. 
 However much Britons may sniff at the new money -- formally in existence only in electronic transactions since Jan. 1, 1999 -- its use in continental Europe seems certain to spill over to a land whose people mainly reject it, but whose businesses are already converting telephone booths, invoice forms and store tills to accept it. 
"There may be those who want to keep Britain out of the euro," said Simon Buckby, head of the pro-euro Britain in Europe advocacy group, "but you can't keep the euro out of Britain."
That, in turn, has long-range implications for Britain's broader relationship with the rest of Europe. In recent months, those ties have undergone a quiet change as Prime Minister Tony Blair has gathered enhanced status and authority as America's leading ally in the war against terrorism.
Indeed, some of the continent's most important figures say privately that British membership in the euro -- a deeply contentious issue in Britain, but crucial to greater British influence in the continent's affairs -- is no longer in doubt. "The only question is when," said a French diplomat, insisting on anonymity.
Traditionally, the British harbor a deep mistrust of continental Europe as a place apart, exemplified by Winston Churchill's remark: "We are with Europe, not of it. We are linked, but not comprised."
It is that sense of divergent destinies -- and the maneuvers that have flown from it -- that Mr. Blair now seeks to redefine.
"The history of our engagement with Europe is one of opportunities missed in the name of illusions and Britain suffering as a result," Mr. Blair told an audience in Birmingham last month in what his aides had flagged as a keynote speech. The change he seeks, he said, is to make British influence felt, not as a tag-along nation playing catch-up to French and German initiatives, but as a leader.
"The argument is simple," Mr. Blair said, forgoing Churchill's caveats. "We are part of Europe. It affects us directly and deeply. Therefore we should exercise leadership in order to change Europe in the direction we want."
European diplomats insist, though, that the inevitable entry price for this exalted status is membership in the euro zone, which is where Mr. Blair's grand strategic vision, and his personal ambitions, collide with the realities of politics.
The peoples of the existing nations in the euro zone accepted the currency virtually at the decree of their political elites. By contrast, Britain has promised not just a referendum, but a referendum based on an assessment of the currency's economic advantages overseen by Chancellor Gordon Brown, a hard-nosed economist and political rival to Mr. Blair.
Opinion surveys, moreover, show consistently that two-thirds of Britons are opposed to adopting the new currency. Consider, for example, Alastaire Riy, a butcher and purveyor of venison on Main Street in Battle whose customers are so committed to their tradition that they would prefer to buy his chops and sausages in the pounds and ounces of the past, not the metric weights of the present.
"Most people here are against the euro because everything is very traditional here," said Mr. Riy (pronounced rye). "They don't like it because they think Europe is taking over. They feel they fought a world war and now everything is being taken away."
With the anti-euro Conservative opposition still weakened by a second successive electoral thrashing last June, and given Mr. Blair's status as Europe's main interlocutor with Washington after the Sept. 11 attacks, the British leader might begin openly now to persuade people like Mr. Riy to change their minds.
As in the past, however, the politically attuned prime minister has remained elusive about a referendum date and cautious about the likely outcome of any economic assessment. With the opinion polls against him, said Charles Grant of the pro-euro Center for European Reform, "there is a limit to his messianic powers."
While Mr. Blair may have emerged strengthened as a war leader, that may not carry through to persuading Britons to abandon their cherished pound. "Churchill was a great war leader," Mr. Grant said, "but he didn't win the election in 1945."
Nonetheless, on Jan. 1, 2002, the European currency will come to rival or even surpass the dollar as the single most important foreign currency for Britons. The country conducts over half its trade with the 12 euro member states.
Major department stores including Harrods, Harvey Nichols and Selfridges have said they will accept payments in euros, although change will be given in pounds and pence. 
Banks, exchange booths at airports, and the Eurostar train station are preparing to switch from converting 12 currencies -- marks, pesetas, francs, escudos and so forth -- to accepting only euros from some of the 13 million visitors from the euro zone who spend the equivalent of over $5.5 billion a year in Britain.
Britons in turn make an average 40 million trips a year to euro zone countries. "Half the population will see the euro, feel the coins, use the coins," said Peter Hain, Britain's minister for Europe, who has been touring Britain to try to soften the skepticism about the euro. "That is going to turn the euro from an object of some mystery, some suspicion, fear and ignorance to something that is real."
Indeed, while Britons have been talking, conducting opinion surveys and generally postponing a final decision, the euro has already been creeping up on them. Some companies like the Japanese automaker Toyota -- whose plant at Derby in the British Midlands exported 80 percent of the 170,000 cars it produced this year to the European Union -- already send out their invoices to suppliers in euros. "We have to be Europe-minded," said Graham Hillier, the manager of planning and communication at Toyota Manufacturing.
Even on Main Street in Battle, a local bank offered customers a hologramlike conversion card so that they could figure out how much a euro would be worth in pounds. (Currently, about 62 pence or 89 United States cents equals one euro.)
Kay Hunting, the president of the local chamber of commerce, noted, "We haven't quite caught up with it in Battle."
Carolyn Bell, owner of a tea shop called Tea on the Green in the shadow of the battlements of the 800-year-old abbey here, said shopkeepers like herself had only just decided that "we need some schooling" in the euro.
But, as elsewhere in Britain, there was no unanimity when it comes to actually joining the euro. "I would rather stay out and have my own money, like the U.S.A.," Mrs. Bell said.
"I'm all for the euro," said Ray Woollard, a local picture framer and art dealer. "We are either going to be in Europe or be under the wing of the Americans. And I think we want to be in Europe."

(Photographs by Heidi Bradner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Canada Relies On Discipline As Economy Slows Down 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
Finance Minister Paul Martin will present his budget to Parliament on Monday, and it is expected to demonstrate that the Canadian government is choosing a different way than the United States to deal with tough economic times.
 Even as talk in Washington revolves around a stimulus package of tax cuts and higher government spending, Mr. Martin has sent a clear signal that his emphasis will be on fiscal discipline. "It's very, very important that we stay out of deficit, and we've got to do everything within our power to do that," Mr. Martin said on Friday. 
 Most Canadians are unlikely to disagree, at least for now, even though their economy is in recession and unemployment is rising. Mr. Martin has worked hard to put the government's finances on a more solid footing in his eight years at the finance ministry.
"Credibility is a newfound luxury we've got in fiscal policy here," said Craig Wright, chief economist at Royal Bank of Canada in Toronto. "It was a hard-fought battle to gain that credibility, and you can lose it quickly."
Economists are virtually unanimous in predicting that Mr. Martin will loosen the purse strings only enough to provide a few billion extra dollars for domestic security and the military, and to improve infrastructure, like roads, bridges and customs offices, along the United States border. Foreign aid may increase modestly. Tax cuts are out of the question.
"I'm not looking for a great deal in new initiatives," said Mr. Wright.
Derek Burleton, an economist at Toronto-Dominion Bank, said, "The government has made it very clear that they're going to target a balanced budget for 2002-03."
Edward Carmichael, the chief economist at J. P. Morgan in Toronto, predicted in a note to clients on Friday that "spending on new priorities will need to be offset by some combination of increased revenues and reduced spending in other areas." Mr. Carmichael said plans for a national high-speed Internet network would be delayed, and proposed spending on university and health research would be pared. Canada's finances have improved significantly under Mr. Martin's stewardship. The federal budget swung from a $18.2 billion deficit in the fiscal year that ended March 31, 1996, to a $10.9 billion surplus last year.
The turnaround has enabled Canada to allocate an ever bigger slice of tax revenues to debt repayment. The ratio of government debt to gross domestic product, an important measure of a country's financial stability, has fallen to about 50 percent from a peak of 71 percent in 1996.
Many political analysts believe that Mr. Martin's determination not to tarnish his reputation for fiscal prudence is compounded by his political ambitions. Eleven years ago, he lost the race for the leadership of the Liberal Party to Jean Chretien, now the prime minister. Mr. Martin has made little secret of his wish to have another crack at the top job when Mr. Chretien, 67, decides to step down.
But the recession and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks have interrupted Mr. Martin's good news. A slump in corporate profits will reduce tax revenues, while rising unemployment is certain to lead to higher welfare and other social spending.
One hundred and seventy-four Canadian companies surveyed by The Globe and Mail newspaper reported a combined loss of $952 million in the third quarter, compared with $5.6 billion in profits a year earlier.
Statistics Canada, the government's reporting agency, said on Friday that the jobless rate rose to 7.5 percent in November, its highest level since mid-1999.
For the time being, Mr. Martin appears to be relying on lower interest rates and an early recovery in the United States to come to Canada's rescue.
The Bank of Canada has lowered short-term rates nine times this year, with banks' prime lending rate now at 4 percent. According to J. P. Morgan's Mr. Carmichael, Mr. Martin's commitment to balanced budgets or "modest" surpluses should see the ratio of debt to gross domestic product maintain a gradual decline.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: DEC. 8, 2001; 
Opening a Gateway, Closing In on bin Laden and Setting the Priorities

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Supplies of food and medicine may soon be flowing into northern Afghanistan over a long-closed bridge from the former Soviet republic of Uzbekistan. Colin L. Powell, the secretary of state, who is visiting central Asian republics to say thanks for helping America in the war on terrorism, and the Uzbek president, Islam Karimov, announced in Tashkent that the so-called Friendship Bridge, a Soviet-built span closed since 1996, would be reopened today.
 SHIFT IN FOCUS -- The focus of the war shifted from fallen Kandahar to the eastern mountains around Tora Bora, where Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda fighters were believed to be dug in. A day after Taliban forces abandoned their last stronghold at Kandahar, pockets of resistance led to isolated skirmishes near the city. While fighting among victorious factions inside Kandahar quieted down, rivals claimed control of key parts of the city and tensions were running high. 
 Hamid Karzai, designated leader of the government that is to assume power in Kabul soon, called on fellow Afghans to help capture Mr. bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, who slipped away during Kandahar's chaotic surrender, and he promised to deliver both to "international justice."
Mr. Karzai, who appointed a tribal commission to run Kandahar and seek some compromises among the feuding warlords, also laid out the priorities for his administration: peace and security for the Afghan people, economic opportunity for all, good relations with the world, and an end to terrorism.
SO FAR, SO GOOD -- With Kandahar's fall, Taliban forces that held 90 percent of Afghanistan just two months ago have been defeated. But the war is far from over. Two of three United States goals remain: to dispose of Mr. bin Laden and his thousands of Al Qaeda fighters, and to restore stability so terrorists can no longer find a haven in Afghanistan.
Looking back, the campaign -- a strange blend of 21st Century air attacks and 19th Century calvary charges -- has been quite successful. America has committed no large ground forces, suffered no extensive casualties and let its allies do the hard fighting. Besides sweeping the Taliban out, the campaign has destroyed a network of Al Qaeda camps, opened the way for a new government in Kabul and perhaps brought the dawn of a new era for the Afghan people.
COMING STRUGGLES -- But tracking Mr. bin Laden and his diehard followers will be tough. The rugged mountains around Tora Bora is their turf. Casualties could be heavy, and the results iffy. Bombing alone may not work, and a siege may be required. Even then Mr. bin Laden could escape across the border into Pakistan.
In Kabul, the streets are strangely normal. But getting a stable government going could be harder than the military campaign, given centuries of rivalries among groups who will share power. Reconciliation may depend on Mr. Karzai. A bit of bio: He is descended from a clan whose fate has mirrored the tumultuous history of Afghanistan. It gave the nation's 18th century founder land on which Kandahar was built, and its men were national leaders until Communists seized power in 1978 and the clan was exiled. Mr. Karzai did not fight, but funneled covert American aid to rebels who beat the Communists in 1992. He returned as deputy foreign minister, but quit in 1994 when the Taliban seized power.
CRIMES OF HATRED -- With the fall of the Taliban, the extent of its crimes of hatred, especially against Mongol-featured Hazaras, is becoming apparent. The destruction of two 1,500-year-old Buddha statues near Bamian last spring was only the most visible of the crimes. The ones nobody heard about included the massacre of thousands of people, many of them hung upside down for slaughter, the burning of whole villages and the destruction of crops and wells.
In recent days, some former residents have been drifting back to Hazara mountain villages, but not to one called Qezelabad, near Mazar-i-Sharif. It was there, three years ago, that Taliban soldiers swept in and destroyed nearly everyone and everything. Now, all that is left there are shallow graves. 
WARTIME PRESIDENT -- In the 13 weeks since Sept. 11, President Bush has matured as a wartime leader, interviews with dozens of friends and advisers suggest. He has tended to be far more serious, restraining natural jocularity, but also has tried to strike a balance so as not to seem gloomy. ROBERT D. McFADDEN

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DEMOCRATS; 
The Challenge: Criticizing Bush's Policies Without Attacking Bush

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
With President Bush's popularity rating in the stratosphere and the country solidly behind the war on terrorism, Democrats have adopted a delicate strategy for winning control of Congress in next year's elections and positioning themselves for challenging the president in 2004.
 They express unwavering support of the war effort. They refrain from even the slightest personal criticism of Mr. Bush. But they are stepping up their attacks on the president's economic and social policies -- on taxes and spending, on health care, on education and, especially, on the administration's response to the recession. 
 This is how Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, made the case this week: "I have absolutely the greatest respect for the president personally, admire him in many ways. I happen to differ with him on many of his domestic proposals, but I generally share his view about foreign policy currently and what he's attempting to do in Afghanistan. So it's an easy distinction for me to make. I think that most of my colleagues feel the same way."
So, Mr. Daschle was asked, is the president to blame for the recession?
"I don't think the recession is his fault," Mr. Daschle said. "I do believe that efforts that have been made in this administration over the course of the year have contributed to the economic slowdown and to the problems we're now having. I don't think there's any question that the deficits have been created in large measure because of the tax cuts that were passed at the insistence of the administration."
Three prominent Democratic tacticians -- James Carville, Stanley Greenberg and Robert Shrum -- described the strategy in detail in an 18-page memorandum, "Politics After the Attack."
"It is important to support the president and set a tone that lacks a sharp partisan quality," the strategists wrote. "Democrats," they declared, must be "committed to fighting terrorism but also committed to addressing the economy and jobs, health care and education."
Weekly polls and focus groups conducted since Sept. 11, they said, indicate that Democrats have a strong hand on pocketbook issues and that "Republican economic policies are oddly out of sync with the national mood currently sweeping America."
Paradoxically, the notion of supporting the president while attacking his policies is exactly the opposite of the Republicans' approach during most of Bill Clinton's presidency. Often reluctant to attack Mr. Clinton's policies, which were generally popular, Republicans concentrated on attacking him personally.
"The Democrats are taking a page out of the Republican playbook and turning it upside down," said Tony Coelho, the former Democratic congressman who ran Al Gore's campaign in the 2000 presidential primaries.
Marshall Wittmann, a political scientist who specializes in Congress and the presidency, said, "Bush is now the anti-Clinton."
The closest a leading Democrat has come to an outright attack on the president since Sept. 11 was when Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester County, chairwoman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, was quoted in USA Today referring to the "Bush recession."
In an interview, Ms. Lowey said what she meant was that Mr. Bush would ultimately be judged on the way he handled the recession, and that Mr. Clinton could not be held responsible for it.
When Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, was asked in an interview this week about Mr. Bush's responsibility for the recession, he stuck to the party line: criticize the policies, not the president.
"I don't know that you can ever say one figure in history caused a recession," Mr. Gephardt asserted, "but in the last year, his budget, tax and economic policies have been misguided, have been wrong."
The Democratic strategy of focusing on domestic issues seemed to have borne fruit in last month's elections. Democrats won the only governorships at stake, in New Jersey and Virginia, and the races for mayor in Los Angeles and Houston. The only consequential Republican victory was Michael R. Bloomberg's election as mayor of New York, and that race was not fought on partisan ground.
"The American public absolutely will accept well-founded criticism of Bush's domestic policies," said James Jordan, executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. "The elections last month settled that forever."
By a one-vote margin this week, the House voted to give Mr. Bush expanded authority to negotiate trade agreements. But the rest of his domestic agenda remains stalled in Congress, including an economic stimulus package based on corporate tax cuts, education legislation and energy policy. 
In an odd way, Mr. Bush has abetted the Democratic strategy by opting to stay out of the political fray in the interest of preserving unity on the war against terrorism. This could work to Mr. Bush's benefit in 2004, many political experts say, but it could hurt his party's chances of retaining control of the House and Senate.
By staying clear of partisan politics, Mr. Wittmann said, Mr. Bush has effectively made Representatives Dick Armey and Tom DeLay, the House majority leader and whip, the leading voices of the Republican Party. Mr. Armey and Mr. Delay, both Texans, are ardent conservatives whose style may seem strident in the swing states and districts that will be decisive in the elections.
"The Democrats are lucky to have DeLay and Armey to shoot at," he said.
