HEADLINE: Reading Putin's Mind 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: MOCKBA 

 BODY:
Last week, I induced the 19 NATO countries to count themselves as 20. That makes Russia officially part of the NATO military organization set up to defend Europe from Russia. We will soon have access to all the West's defense plans, and a strong say (in reality, a veto, though they cannot yet admit it) in every action it plans to take. 
 That also transforms the West's military alliance into a boiled-cabbage political bureaucracy that I can "consult" into impotence. No more attacks on Serbs over our objections -- we'll consult nyet and disrupt the consensus. 
 I read in The New York Times that my friend George and my friend Colin agreed to this Russian diplomatic triumph despite the protest of the warrior Rumsfeld. (Why doesn't George shut down that paper? I would in a minute. Revelation of internal struggle encourages opposition.)
Now I will permit NATO to welcome the Baltic states. I will pretend this is against the desires of my generals (hmm -- maybe that Rumsfeld protest was a trick) and by so approving, solidify my unwritten veto power. Of course, the other 19 nations don't need my approval, but the useful idiots of the West don't realize that. 
That came on top of what my generals call "Bush's Surrender at Crawford." The strategic deal I had agreed to with Bush beforehand in Shanghai was this: George would reduce his missiles all the way down to the number we could afford to equal, and in return, I would let him amend the ABM treaty so he could test a limited antimissile system. 
But at his ranch in Texas, smiling through all the strange food, I got the U.S. to cut its missile force down below 2,000 -- but didn't give the Americans an inch on ABM. I blamed my generals, which was disinformation, but how could Colin complain publicly? Wasn't I letting the Americans fly over Russia to get to Uzbekistan in our joint war on terror? 
Ah, the war. The world now forgives me for wiping out our Chechens because all those Muslims are terrorists. And didn't I score yet another personal triumph by sending our people into Kabul just after it surrendered, ahead of the Americans and British? The Russian people, who saw our return on TV, now believe we finally won our war in Afghanistan, with a little U.S. help at the end.
But George had better not carry this antiterror business too far by attacking Primakov's friend in Baghdad. Iraq owes us $8 billion for our arms shipments, and we'll never get that money if Saddam is out of power. Currently he's paying us for new weapons out of his oil smuggling, and if he uses our SAM's to bring down American gunships, that's not my fault. 
Oil. That has been the key to my economic success. After the Saudis, we are the world's largest producer of oil and gas, and have never been part of OPEC. George was so happy to see us pumping away, breaking the monopoly and bringing down prices. This fall's drop in oil prices was equivalent to a huge tax cut, helping stimulate the U.S. out of its recession.
But last week, I made a deal with OPEC to cut our production by a symbolic 150,000 barrels a day, and we're ready to reduce our output much more to help our Arab friends push up world prices. As the capitalists taught us: Sorry, George, business is business.
I felt I could do that without troubling the new personal trust between George and me. At the Crawford summit, he complained a little about my sale of nuclear materials to Iran, and he wished we would stop sending the best and hungriest Russian scientists to help the Iranians develop their bomb and multiple-stage rockets. I sympathize, but why stop? The ayatollahs pay in cash, and if Iran and Iraq -- and Israel -- want to fight wars, let them be equals.
Nothing beats an antiterrorist pose. I crushed my media critics. I neutralized NATO. My obliteration of Grozny is forgotten. I'm bringing prosperity to Russia by arming America's enemies and fixing prices with the oil cartel.
My friend George may be a little ahead of me in our nations' popularity polls, but I have this advantage: he's not president for life.

HEADLINE: Tourists Staying Away From Capital 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 

 BODY:
Despite efforts to revitalize the tourism industry in the nation's capital, the closing of many federal buildings and monuments for more than two months has kept some visitors away and caused the loss of thousands of jobs at hotels, restaurants and airlines.
 One step toward addressing the problem came this weekend, when tours of the Capitol resumed. Tours had been scheduled for Wednesday, but the Capitol Police canceled them abruptly on Tuesday night. 
 Charlene Jarvis, the chairwoman of the Washington Convention and Tourism Corporation, said that opening the Capitol and the White House to the public would be "evidence that Washington, D.C., is welcoming to visitors." 
The White House is closed to the public indefinitely. This time last year the White House had about 3,500 visitors a day, officials said. 
While the Tourism Corporation reported last month that hotels were working at 68 percent of their capacity, outpacing the national average by 10 percent, many hotels had to take immediate action after Sept. 11 and lay off workers. 
About 24,000 workers in the area are now unemployed, said John Boardman, an executive for hotel and restaurant union employees. At a meeting of the workers' rights board this week, members of Congress and the City Council came together with charities to talk over solutions to help the unemployed.
Even at this time of year, when Washington is usually a big draw for tourists, the drop in the number of visitors has been so great that an official of Teamsters Local 922, Aaron Sawyer, said, "Over 75 percent of the work force at Tourmobile, which ferries tourists around town to view the monuments, have been laid off." 
Reagan National Airport, which was closed for three weeks, was the last airport to reopen after the attacks. It is offering flights to 20 percent of the usual destinations. Employees at rental car agencies, food servers and hotel employees are suffering from the dropoff. 
"I've lost everything I had," said Dorothy Hilliard, an employee of SkyChefs Flight Kitchen, who lost her job in September. 
Local efforts to increase tourism, like a recent tax-free shopping week, which resulted in a 1.7 percent increase in sales, may not be enough to save the tourism industry or help workers who have lost their jobs, city officials said. 
"Where I'm from, family and friends chip in support when you need it," said Kwesi Oginga, a bellman from Guyana who was laid off at the Washington Hilton. "Here in the U.S., I don't even know my neighbor." 
The Smithsonian Institution had fewer visitors, in part, said a museum spokeswoman, Vicki Moeser, because many people assumed incorrectly that it had been closed. 
Last month numbers were down by 46 percent, she said. Since many school groups visiting the White House and Capitol have been forced to cancel trips, Ms. Moeser said, they have also canceled their tours of the Smithsonian.

HEADLINE: States Calling For More Help With Medicaid 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 

 BODY:
New York is helping to lead states in a nationwide effort to persuade the federal government to provide billions of dollars in additional aid to help the states cover the cost of Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor.
 The nation's governors are predicting that because of the slumping economy, at least four million more people will go on the Medicaid rolls in the next six months, even as states face budget shortfalls that are forcing them to reduce other services. 
 The federal government sets general Medicaid policy and pays for part of the program, with the states paying for the rest.
Medicaid is the largest, fastest growing part of nearly every state budget; on average, it accounts for about 20 percent of state budgets nationwide, according to analysts for the National Governors Association. 
Put another way, states spend nearly as much on Medicaid -- about $87 billion in the current fiscal year -- as they do on elementary and secondary education combined, the budget analysts say. The federal government contributed about $112 billion.
While it is too early to say how the federal government will respond, the governors and their allies see some encouraging signs. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, included a provision increasing Medicaid funding for states in the economic stimulus package his committee approved.
In the House, Gov. George E. Pataki is working with Republicans and Democrats on a similar plan to provide more federal Medicaid dollars for the states, according to his aides. The governors are seeking at least $5.5 billion in additional federal Medicaid funding for the coming year, with nearly $500 million of that for New York. Another version of the plan, being developed in the House, seeks even more money and would set aside about $1.5 billion for New York.
The issue is critical to New York, which has long had among the most expensive Medicaid programs of any state. The current price of Medicaid in New York is more than $30 billion annually, with the federal, state and local governments sharing the cost. The program serves about 2.8 million people.
In a measure of how seriously Mr. Pataki is taking the issue, he plans to travel to Washington this week to urge Congressional leaders to provide more Medicaid money.
"The growing state budget shortfalls in nearly every state will continue to be a major drag on economic recovery," Mr. Pataki said in a letter to members of Congress. "I urge that the final economic stimulus package build upon the existing federal-state partnership by including a temporary increase" in federal Medicaid funding.
The executive director of the National Governors Association, Raymond C. Scheppach, said that additional Medicaid dollars would be crucial for governors and state legislatures given that unemployment is expected to rise sharply in the next few months, even as tax revenues are declining in many states.
He said that the additional funding was the only proposal that the governors were pushing in the current Congressional debate over how to fashion an economic stimulus package for the nation. The effort to get more money -- which would require tinkering with the arcane Medicaid funding formula -- was recently endorsed in a letter that governors of both parties agreed to send to Congressional leaders, Mr. Scheppach said.
"The fiscal crisis in states is growing every day," he said, "and this change is the only federal policy that will provide relief to both the states and the millions of new Medicaid recipients we expect."
The nation's governors have considerable sway here in Washington. Policies advocated by the governors association resulted in the 1996 law that overhauled the nation's welfare system and moved millions of recipients off the public assistance rolls.
President Bush is a former governor of Texas, and Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary for health and human services, whose agency oversees the Medicaid program, was governor of Wisconsin.
Medicaid began in 1965 as a health program for the most desperately poor. But over the years, it was expanded to cover people with higher incomes, particularly in New York, which recently broadened its eligibility requirements to allow even more people to qualify.
The lobbying effort comes as the economic picture is growing increasingly bleak for many states. The states project budget gaps totaling $30 billion in the current fiscal year, according to budget analysts for the governors association.
"It's real bad out there," Mr. Scheppach said, adding that the looming increase in the Medicaid rolls would only make things worse.
In New York, which is reeling from the attack on the World Trade Center, the fiscal outlook may be even bleaker. Mr. Pataki's budget office estimates that the state may lose $9 billion in revenues over the next 18 months because of the attack, and he took the remarkable step of asking the federal government to compensate the state for such losses.
But Washington lawmakers have been cool to this proposal, saying that the federal government has never compensated localities for lost revenues in previous disasters. In that context, New York's senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, says that the additional federal Medicaid money would be a way to offset New York's revenue losses without calling it a bailout.
"This proved to be a great alternative," he said. "This is another way to skin the same cat."
The states are bracing for even more bad news. The governors predict that the Medicaid rolls, totaling about 36 million people, could grow by 3 million people within six months if the unemployment rate reaches 6.5 percent, or 4 million if the jobless rate climbs to 7 percent. On Friday, the Labor Department reported that the national jobless rate had climbed to 5.7 percent last month from 5.4 percent in October.
In the worst-case scenario contemplated by the governors, the new wave of 4 million Medicaid recipients would include 1 million adults, 2.6 million children and nearly 400,000 disabled people.

HEADLINE: French Bank to Buy United California 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
BNP Paribas of France agreed today to buy United California Bank from UFJ Holdings Inc. of Japan for $2.4 billion to expand its retail banking business in the Western United States.
 BNP Paribas, which is already acquiring the 55 percent of the BancWest Corporation of Honolulu that it does not already own, will become one of the biggest banks in the region after the acquisition, with 1.5 million customers, 370 branches and a staff of 8,000, Paribas said in a statement. 
 Japanese banks have been selling overseas assets over the last two years to bolster finances as they write off record bad loans and try to weather a deepening recession at home. UFJ is the world's sixth-largest bank, formed by a merger between Sanwa Bank, Tokai Bank and Toyo Trust and Banking. 
United California Bank, which is based in Los Angeles, has 117 branches and $11 billion in assets. The banks plan to complete the transaction by the end of March.

HEADLINE: Australian Miner Accepts Offer 

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
The board of Normandy Mining, Australia's largest gold producer, accepted an offer from the Newmont Mining Corporation today that values the company at about $2.2 billion. The deal could be the final piece of a three-way merger with the Franco-Nevada Mining Corporation of Canada, which would create the largest gold producer. 
 The deal points to the continued consolidation in the mining industry at a time when commodity prices have slipped and the quest for economies of scale has taken on increasing significance. 
 Newmont, based in Denver, added $367 million in cash to its offer, topping the latest bid from a rival bidder, AngloGold, by about 15 percent. Normandy's board recommended that shareholders accept Newmont's offer. 
By sealing the deal, Newmont obtains access to rich and relatively low-cost gold mining operations in western and northern Australia and exposure to a country seen as politically less risky and operationally less complex than other gold mining regions, like South Africa. The company plans to complete the deal early in 2002. 
Once the merger was complete, the company would be one of the largest in terms of gold reserves, with 97 million ounces. Its annual production would swell to 8.2 million ounces a year. 
Normandy's board had been expecting Newmont's next move in the takeover tussle to come this week. The directors, who had delayed responding formally to AngloGold's latest offer, told the Australian Stock Exchange that they expected to advise shareholders by Dec. 13. 
Newmont's proposal values Normandy at about 1.90 Australian dollars (98 cents) a share. The winning bid is near the top of the value range set by an independent report from Grant Samuel & Associates.
That price makes it less likely that either AngloGold or another suitor will try to top it, said Stuart Dodd, portfolio manager at Rothschild Australia.

HEADLINE: In Louder Voices, Iranians Talk of Dialogue With U.S. 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Iran, Dec. 8 

 BODY:
For 22 years, and as late as this week, chants of "Death to America" have been used to rally the Islamic revolution's faithful at the Friday Prayers. 
 But in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States and the subsequent war in Afghanistan, a rhetorical countercurrent is gathering strength here. 
 Talk to America.
For the first time since the United States severed relations with Iran in 1980, officials here are openly pushing for a resumption of dialogue. For now, they say, it should be over Afghanistan, but they also describe Afghanistan as only a means to the end of eventually resuming relations. 
In the press and on the street, there is an increasing boldness about arguing the merits -- seen as primarily economic -- of talking. Members of Parliament openly discuss their desire for a dialogue, and have established a parlimentary committee to push for one. An adviser to President Mohammad Khatami wrote an article calling for him to sit at the negotiating table with President Bush over Afghanistan. 
Even a leading conservative, Moshen Rezai, the secretary general of the powerful Expediency Council, has acknowledged the two countries' common interests in Afghanistan and obliquely suggested that better relations might be possible were the United States to take the first step. 
"There is a new discourse for relations with America," said Ahmad Bourghani, a member of Parliament. 
But discourse is both everything and nothing here. It can signal a fundamental policy shift. But given the country's consitutional structure, in which appointed clerics have far more power than elected representatives, it can demonstrate the powerlessness of those seeking such a shift to effect it.
Relations with the United States have become one more political weapon in the pitched battle between reformers, who tend to favor relations, and conservatives, who at least publicly oppose them. As reformers intensify their calls for dialogue, conservatives step up their opposition, and some reformers say conservatives may try to stall any improvement in relations to prevent reformers from getting credit. 
Similarly, there is resistance in the United States to any improvement of ties with Iran. The United States believes that Iran is developing weapons of mass destruction including, with Russia's help, nuclear weapons. While it is not clear whether Iran still harbors terrorists, the country has not disavowed support for groups like the radical Palestinian group Hamas and Hezbollah in Lebanon.
Iran, which bristles every time it makes the annual State Department list of countries that support terrorism, argues that it does not define such groups, which it sees as engaged in a struggle against an occupying force, as terrorist.
Iranian reformers are also ruffled by the rhetoric of those American policy makers implacably opposed to improving ties with the current Iran. Richard Perle, a Pentagon adviser, recently said: "We should be doing everything we can to encourage the centrifugal forces in Iran that, with any luck, will drive that miserable government from office." 
Mahmoud Shamsolvaezin, a journalist and political analyst, likened the ties between Washington and Tehran, which was ruled for decades by a pro-American shah put in place with the Central Intelligence Agency's help, to a long-lost marriage in which both partners harbor lingering tinges of passion.
"The relationship between Iran and the United States is like the relationship between two lovers who've broken up 20 years ago," he said. "Just based on ideological reasons, the two countries seem unable to resolve their problems." 
Before Mr. Khatami traveled to New York last month for the United Nations General Assembly, for example, Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, delivered a harsh attack on those calling for closer ties with the United States, saying anyone who did so was unfit to hold office. Many people interpreted that as a warning to Mr. Khatami not to talk to American officials. 
Soon after, the leader of Iran's judiciary created a legal committee to deal with members of Parliament and other political officials if they call for starting dialogue with the United States, although it is not clear whether anyone has actually been called before the committee yet. 
There is certainly a radical faction of conservatives who see opposition to the United States as essential to their political survival. 
Others are believed to fear that a renewal of economic ties, and the resulting influx of American products it would probably bring, could undermine the economic control they have amassed since the revolution via government-controlled monopolies. 
Some conservatives, on the other hand, secretly favor closer ties, believing that they would profit economically.
Close watchers say that even Ayatollah Khamenei's position is more complicated than it might appear. Two recent developments, they say, almost certainly had his approval: a dinner meeting between Iran's representative to the United Nations and members of the United States Congress, and the dispatching of Khamal Kharrazi, the foreign minister, instead of his deputy, to the second meeting of the six countries bordering Afghanistan, the United States and Russia. Yet another sign: Mr. Kharrazi shook hands there with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.
Some say that were Ayatollah Khamenei to allow any talks with the United States, it would mean conceding the failure of an Islamic revolution built in large part on opposition to the "Great Satan." As the writing outside the former American Embassy here says, "On that day when the United States of America will praise us, we should mourn." 
And yet, the chants of "Death to America" were temporarily halted in the two weeks after Sept. 11.
Such abrupt shifts have been made before. Most notably, in 1988, Ayatollah Khomenei ended the Iran-Iraq war after previously vowing that Iran would fight to the death. That reversal was made more palatable by the fact that public opinion strongly favored ending the war. The same may hold true now, since conversation suggests that most Iranians favor talking to the United States.
That does not mean, of course, that they have forgiven the United States for what they see as its sins, most notably the downing of an Iranian civilian aircraft in 1988, killing all 290 people on board. Attitudes in Iran may have progressed from animosity to aggrievement, but the aggrievement is strong. 
Iranians believe that they have been given too little credit and no reward for their behavior toward Afghanistan. They point out that they opposed the Taliban from the start, and have borne the burden of some two million refugees and the flow of drugs from an unstable neighbor.
When the American bombing began, the Iranians sealed their border to prevent a new flow of refugees, certainly, but also to close off a potential Taliban escape route. They have provided the coalition with intelligence on the Northern Alliance, played a constructive role at last week's conference in Bonn on forming a new transitional government, and want to participate in Afghanistan's reconstruction. 
In return, officials here thought that they would at least hear talk of sanctions being lifted, or of the Caspian Sea oil pipeline being allowed to pass through Iran. "There was and still is the expectation that the United States would take more significant steps because Iran has taken steps totally in the interests of the Afghan people," Mr. Bourghani said. 
There is a sort of stunned disbelief here that Pakistan, which so clearly backed the wrong horse in Afghanistan, is now reaping the benefits of reversing its stance. Indeed, the events after Sept. 11 have done much to feed Iran's sense of injustice. 
Iranians resent being repeatedly placed on Washington's list of states that sponsor terrorism. "It is very obvious which countries have been sponsoring terrorism, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates," said Abdullah Ramazaanzadeh, who sits in President Khatami's cabinet, and wrote the article calling for Mr. Khatami and Mr. Bush to negotiate over Afghanistan. "If America had close relations with these countries, what is the reason not to have them with Iran?"
If Iran is such a strong supporter of terrorism, even ordinary Iranians ask, why was it that 15 of the 19 hijackers on Sept. 11 came from Washington's ally, Saudi Arabia? Why is that Iranians, and not Saudis or Pakistanis, who travel to the United States are fingerprinted like criminals? 
Iranian officials are also angry that American courts have allowed former hostages in Lebanon to bring cases against Iran. In response, the government has set up its own special court, at the former American Embassy, to open cases for Iranians who say they were damaged by the United States-backed coup in 1953. 
Reformers also say Iran should be given more credit for being a Muslim country with a democratic movement and a populace that, despite its leadership's rhetoric, has evidenced little anti-American sentiment. Some reformers say that American officials see the push for more democracy in Iran as a threat to their military and economic interests in countries like Saudi Arabia, where greater democracy would likely mean a turn against the United States.
The problems posed by rapprochement can be seen in the new, tentative closeness between Iran and Britain. Since Sept. 11, the British foreign minister, Jack Straw, has visited Tehran twice -- the first visits by a British foreign minister since 1979. 
While the two countries did not agree on everything, Mr. Straw and Mr. Kharrazi have since maintained a cordial dialogue. President Khatami and Prime Minister Tony Blair have also spoken by phone, and last week Mr. Khatami spoke warmly about the improving relationship between the two countries.
Then came Mr. Blair's comment, in response to a question in Britain's Parliament on Wednesday, that countries like Iran would have to renounce their support for terrorism before they could think about a new relationship with Britain. The comments caused a furor here, with the foreign ministry summoning the British charge d'affaires to express displeasure. 
Ayatollah Khamenei made a blistering attack on Britain at this week's Friday Prayers. No country, he said, "has had such a terrible or bloody record in this region." Having lost its political credibility, he said, Britain had become a puppet of the United States.
"Death to America," the crowd chanted.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: BUSINESSES; 
RIPPLES OF SEPT. 11 WIDEN IN RETAILING

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
On West Eighth Street in Greenwich Village, shoe salesmen stand forlornly on the sidewalk in front of Leather&Shoes.com, smoking cigarettes and staring blankly into the distance, wondering where all the customers have gone. 
 Down the block, Raja Chaani, the manager of India Imports, and two of his employees sit on stools in a sprawling space chock-full of leather jackets, silk scarves and Indian curios -- but devoid of customers. 
 Across the street, at Man Plus, Sonny Shahani and three other salesmen spend their time rearranging sweaters and calculating how much their commissions have fallen. And at House of Nubian, no one but a few Internet shoppers is buying Negro League jackets and hats, or buttons with pictures of black leaders like Malcolm X and Haile Selassie.
While it was expected that small businesses near the site of the World Trade Center would suffer from the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, which displaced 100,000 potential customers from office buildings in the area and thousands more from their homes, wider economic damage from the attack is still rippling outward from ground zero. 
The national economy, of course, was already slowing before Sept. 11. But the attack sent shudders through small businesses, not only in New York City but also across the nation. Some economic forecasters say they believe a wave of business failures in New York and elsewhere could come soon after the first of the year, as retailers and other entrepreneurs succumb to the continuing lack of new business in what is traditionally their busiest season.
"I've been on this street for 15 years, and it's never been this bad," said Kawal Bhatia, whose family owns Leather&Shoes.com, a shoe and leather goods store at 22 West Eighth Street which, despite its name, does not have a Web site. "In past years, no matter how bad it was the rest of the year, at least you knew you would cover all your losses with the holiday shoppers." But on a recent Friday, he said, "I did $25 worth of business."
Last week, Mr. Bhatia put up a new sign: "Store Closing."
Small businesses, including many retail establishments, account for two of every five jobs in New York City and roughly half of all jobs statewide, so the drought among small-business owners presages economic pain that is likely to spread far beyond Lower Manhattan. And while numerous grant and loan programs have sprung up to help small businesses recover from the disaster, business owners have complained, in a growing chorus, that the grants are too small to stem their losses and that loan agencies are not approving loans.
On Eighth Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, for example, roughly two miles north of ground zero, businesses that depend on people who travel into the city to shop have been devastated. The block, the professed shoe district of Manhattan, has for decades served as a crucible for small businesses, a place where shoe and leather goods shops have mixed with funky clothing emporiums serving an eclectic mix of college students, tourists and New Yorkers in search of bargains. But tourists have stopped coming, and retail sales not just in the Village but across the city have been suffering.
Economists say it is too early to tell just how many small businesses are likely to end up closing or in Bankruptcy Court, but they say that the signs are not good. 
"I think there is a strong likelihood that come the first quarter, small businesses that are holding on by the seat of their pants may not be able to hold on anymore without some outside assistance," said Ian E. Novos, senior director for economic consulting service of KPMG. 
A report assessing the economic impact of Sept. 11 that was prepared for the New York City Partnership, by KPMG and SRI International, another consulting firm, predicted that for the next two years, small businesses' sales would continue to fall short of what was expected before the trade center attack. Employment among small businesses will continue to fall through the first quarter of next year, the report said.
During the recession of the early 1990's, in a downturn that was short-lived by historical standards, business failures in New York State peaked at more than 6,000 companies per year, according to Dun & Bradstreet. The failures involved less than 1 percent of the small businesses operating in the state. In 1997, the most recent year for which data is available, there were roughly 1.2 million small businesses operating in New York State, according to state statistics. (Federal data on small businesses, using different measurement criteria, put the number at about half that.)
The 1990's recession lacked some of the ingredients of today's problems -- most important a cataclysmic event that sent jobs streaming away from Lower Manhattan, immediately closed off spigots of corporate spending and sent consumers into a kind of anti-spending shock.
Since the disaster, the United States Small Business Administration has approved only about one in three applications for disaster loans. Those loans have provided $164 million to more than 2,000 businesses so far, but the approval rate is well below the rates of 50 percent to 64 percent that have followed other major disasters over the past decade.
Hector V. Barreto, the administrator of the S.B.A., told the House Committee on Small Business on Thursday that the loan approval statistics were a result of what was a very different disaster. But he also agreed to review all loan applications that had been rejected in New York so far, to see if the agency's loan standards, which often rely on cash flow and the value of tangible property, had been applied too rigidly.
Unlike earthquakes, hurricanes and floods, which inflict property damage mostly on homes and homeowners, the World Trade Center attack did most of its property damage in a small area around ground zero. Most of the loans requested and made have been for economic injury to businesses in a far wider geographic area, stretching over several counties near New York City.
Economic disaster loans to businesses account for three-quarters of the disaster loans approved so far, compared with 20 percent after events like the flooding of the Red River of the North, in North Dakota in 1997, and Tropical Storm Allison in Texas and Louisiana earlier this year. Economic injury loans require more documentation of losses and of a borrower's ability to repay them than property damage loans do. 
A bill that would ease eligibility rules for disaster loans as well as create a grant program to go with the loan program was recently sent to the full House of Representatives by the House Committee on Small Business.
Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, whose district includes parts of Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens and who is the ranking Democrat on that committee, said the current loan program needed to be revised as the bill would require because the existing loan program "is not suitable for the new reality of this disaster."
Some businesses that have been turned down for loans say they cannot fathom whom the loan program is supposed to help, if not them. Carla Behrle, who designs, manufactures and sells custom-made leather clothing from a shop on Franklin Street in TriBeCa, said she was told by S.B.A. officials that her application would be rejected because her business did not have enough cash flow to make the loan payments of $143 a month. 
"Some people spend more than that on cigarettes," said Ms. Behrle (pronounced BURR-lee), who does not smoke. She said the agency did not seem to take into account her plans for the money, which included relocating her business, which had revenues of about $125,000 last year, and shifting her focus to wholesale sales, eliminating her retail store. 
"I spent hours and hours filling out all this paperwork," she said. "If I had known what I know now, I would have put my energies elsewhere."
Other entrepreneurs complain that the city and state efforts to restore the economy are tailored to the needs of large corporations rather than to small businesses. They note that when Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed members of the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation last month, corporate and political interests were well represented, but no representatives of small business from downtown Manhattan were included.
Asked what he would say to people who operate small downtown businesses that are ailing, John C. Whitehead, the newly appointed chairman of the group, said: "I don't know what we say to them, but we want to keep them and we don't want them to be discouraged. I think there is assistance available for them."
Carl Weisbrod, president of the Downtown Alliance, which represents businesses in the financial district and around the trade center site, said the redevelopment agency's "primary mission is going to be repairing the infrastructure" and creating a physical environment that will draw customers back to small businesses downtown.
Whether small businesses downtown can wait for those improvements, which could easily take years, is uncertain. On West Eighth Street, merchants up and down the block who are not covering their expenses say their landlords have so far refused to give them a break on their rents.
At Mofa Shoes, Moses, the manager, who would not give his last name, spoke woefully of the outlook. "This used to be the shoe capital of the world," he said. "We'd get customers who came to Eighth Street from Italy, Brazil, Spain. Now, well, you see. The street is empty."

ARTS E1-8

Apartheid Revisited
The grim building rises like a fortress, all gray stone and rusting steel. Visitors pay their admission and flinch as they are arbitrarily assigned a racial classification: blankes (whites) or nie-blankes (nonwhites). They are entering South Africa's first apartheid museum, which opened two weeks ago as a biting reminder of a past that many would prefer to forget. Visitors get a card denoting their racial identity and are directed to one of two revolving doors, one for blacks, one for whites. It is the beginning of the museum's separation experience. E1

Trying to Tame Texas
A new Texas law is requiring county governments to either regulate or prohibit the ownership of "dangerous wild animals," including lions, tigers, bears -- and alligators. While most Texas cities have ordinances controlling or banning the possession of wild animals, many counties have not. The law is creating problems for animal rescue centers and frustration among people who moved from cities into unincorporated areas of counties to avoid such rules. A19

Bloomberg, ignoring a State Department advisory urging Americans to stay away, made a pilgrimage of solidarity to Jerusalem, visiting sites of terrorist attacks. They vowed that Israel and America were shoulder to shoulder in the fight against terrorism. "We're together with you," Mr. Giuliani said. "We are bound by blood." F1

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Shift in Medical Benefits
Employers nationwide are requiring workers to pay a larger share of their medical costs, according to a national survey to be published today. Some health economists say the added costs will make consumers more cautious about medical spending. But the cost shift has had little discernible effect yet on surging health care inflation. Forty percent of large employers, those with 500 or more employees, said they would require workers to pay a higher portion of the total cost in 2002, the survey found. C6

'Ally McBeal' Losing Appeal
The Fox comedy series starring Calista Flockhart that in its first four seasons generated big ratings, numerous male-female sociological discussions and a Time magazine cover story, is now generating mostly shrugs. Its overall rating is down 23 percent -- bad news for Fox, which considers the show one of its premiere attractions for the younger-adult audience advertisers covet. C1

National Steel and its main shareholder, the NKK Corporation of Japan, announced that they they were in talks to sell National Steel to U.S. Steel. The sale, if completed, would be part of a plan announced last week to allow a half-dozen large United States steel makers to merge into one company. The plan would need the support of the Bush administration and Congress. C2

HEADLINE: Chile's Leader Remains Socialist but Acts Like Pragmatist 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LOTA, Chile, Dec. 6 

 BODY:
President Ricardo Lagos is known as a formal man who keeps his feelings and thoughts to himself. But tears welled up in his eyes as he listened to a young woman tell her story at the opening of a state-run bank office.
 "A few months ago all I could look forward to was a life selling fish door to door," said Vitalicia Ulloa, 37, tears falling down her face as she spoke to an audience of 400 people. "Thanks to you President Lagos I am now going to sell insurance!" 
 This was no small miracle in a town that a generation ago was rife with labor unrest and Communist and Socialist agitation, leading Salvador Allende, then the president, to nationalize the local coal mines. After Gen. Augusto Pinochet overthrew Dr. Allende in 1973 in a coup supported by the United States, the mines were privatized and finally closed in the 1990's, leaving Lota depressed, hungry and angry.
As the first Socialist to govern Chile since Dr. Allende, Mr. Lagos did not forget Lota. One of his first acts as president last year was to order the Banco Estado to put its national Internet and telephone sales office in Lota to create 160 jobs.
"With globalization, distances do not exist anymore and opportunities are there for those who know how to seize them," Mr. Lagos told the crowd here. "We need to adjust to the new economy, or history will pass us by."
In his nearly two years in office, President Lagos has tried to heal a lot of old wounds in a way that does not threaten the stability of a country that is still sore from ideological conflicts that led to the deaths of 3,000 people and the torture and exile of many more from 1973 to 1990.
Mr. Lagos, 63, has become a firm ally of the United States and has pressed negotiations for a free trade agreement between the two countries. Managing an uneasy peace with the Chilean military, he has quietly moved toward buying a new fleet of fighter jets. He has expanded political freedoms by pushing Congress to repeal a law that punished journalists for criticizing or insulting judges, military commanders or cabinet members. 
Mr. Lagos has lowered tariffs and kept government deficits in check to control inflation, even if big businesses are not happy with his efforts to strengthen unions and crack down on tax evasion.
The image Mr. Lagos tries to convey is one of a national father figure. Once scheduled to become Dr. Allende's ambassador to the Soviet Union and then jailed for leading the opposition against General Pinochet, Mr. Lagos now chooses rhetoric that is soothing and unifying.
"A Socialist today understands that the fall of the Berlin Wall means we live in a world in which the market is not leftist or rightist," he said in an interview on his presidential plane. "It is simply an instrument to be used."
But the achievements of Mr. Lagos's government have so far been modest, as even supporters concede.
The military has fallen far short of its promises last year to account for people who disappeared during its rule, and critics say Mr. Lagos has been far too timid in pressuring the high command. Improvements in health care that Mr. Lagos promised on the campaign trail two years ago have yet to be instituted. Reform of the Constitution, which still gives the military independent powers, has stalled.
Unemployment has increased over the last two years, and the economy will achieve only 3 percent growth this year -- far below the performance of the last 15 years, although far better than Chile's slumping neighbors like Argentina.
Mr. Lagos's government also often seems to lack a clear agenda, in part because members of his coalition cabinet of Christian Democrats and Socialists often go their own way, publicly voicing divergent policies. A shake-up in the cabinet is expected after congressional elections later this month.
"Lagos has made no change," said Alfredo Jocelyn-Holt, a historian at the University of Chile. "He has unconditionally accepted the Pinochet model, even though he is a man of the left and struggled for years to overthrow the Pinochet dictatorship." 
Mr. Lagos has faced two major distractions. A slowdown in the world economy, causing a slump in export prices for copper and wood products, crimped his ability to address social problems. In addition, a long judicial process over whether to force General Pinochet to stand trial for human rights violations complicated his relations with the still powerful military.
Only days before Mr. Lagos took office in March 2000, General Pinochet was freed from house arrest in Britain but faced hundreds of criminal complaints here in Chile. The general's lawyers fought to avert a trial, arguing that the former dictator was too infirm to stand trial, opening the way to more than a year of court appeals. 
As judges first stripped General Pinochet of his senatorial immunity and then ordered his house arrest, top military commanders put heavy pressure on Mr. Lagos to intervene. Mr. Lagos repeatedly said in public that he would allow the courts to work independently, but a top Socialist Party activist who is close to the president said Mr. Lagos worked quietly to assure that General Pinochet would not stand trial, because of his poor health and failing memory. 
At a meeting with the military high command last year in the Defense Ministry, Gen. Ricardo Izurieta, the chief of the army, told Mr. Lagos that he did not want his successor to have to deal with the politically delicate situation of a Pinochet trial.
"The president reached across the table and shook General Izurieta's hand, and it was understood," said the confidant of Mr. Lagos. "It was not an explicit deal but it was implicit." 
Mr. Lagos continues to publicly deny that he played any role. But the confidant said aides to Mr. Lagos had associates indirectly alert Supreme Court judges that the president did not want a trial. The Supreme Court ruled earlier this year that General Pinochet was not well enough to stand trial, a decision it may well have made without any outside direction.
Despite Mr. Lagos' efforts, military-civilian relations remain touchy.
Just last week, after Mr. Lagos installed a new commander of the Carabinero national police, a police colonel who disagreed with the choice led 300 officers in a violent eviction of the Communist Party headquarters, arresting 40 people and injuring 10, without consulting civilian officials.
On the economic front, Mr. Lagos, facing a recession, took an uncommon course for a Socialist. He cut government spending earlier this year to control inflation, therefore allowing the Central Bank to sharply cut interest rates. The government also allowed the peso to slip in value, boosting the competitive advantage of such exports as wines, fruits, vegetables and salmon.
"We have devalued our currency 30 percent with almost no inflation," Mr. Lagos said. "I did that with tough fiscal policies. A left-wing politician has to be tough enough to say no."

HEADLINE: ON COLLEGE FOOTBALL; 
The National Title Is a Computer Game

BYLINE:  By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Opinion polls, confusing computers, bitter partisanship, crass commercialism and the occasional disputed election are all part of the American scene in the early 21st century. Why should college football be any different? It isn't.
 The sport reflected the general culture like a fun-house mirror yesterday when the Bowl Championship Series chose Nebraska to play Miami in the Rose Bowl for the national championship on Jan. 3. 
 There was no tournament. The Hurricanes went undefeated this season and almost everyone agrees they deserve a berth in the title game. But the Cornhuskers have not played since the day after Thanksgiving, when they lost to Colorado, 62-36. The victorious Buffaloes went on to win the Big 12 Conference championship. Although Nebraska was ranked second in the country in the B.C.S., Oregon finished second behind Miami in the coaches and news media polls, which make up 25 percent of the B.C.S. formula. Colorado finished third in the polls; Nebraska was fourth. 
But once the computers were added to the equation, Nebraska moved up to second in the total B.C.S. evaluation, while Colorado finished third and Oregon fourth. Colorado and Oregon are therefore sentenced to meet in the Fiesta Bowl while Nebraska goes to the Rose Bowl. Supporters of Colorado and Oregon, obviously, are not happy.
"I understand that frustration," said John Swofford, commissioner of the Atlantic Coast Conference and coordinator of the B.C.S. "I'm sure I would feel the same way. You've got three, four, maybe five teams who feel they're as good as anybody and deserve to play. Would it be nicer if everything was simpler and everyone agreed? Yes."
When someone asked whether the perception of chaos is good for the sport, Swofford replied, "It depends on what you consider chaos." 
One factor in the confusion is a B.C.S. element called strength of schedule. It can make all the difference. For instance: Because Texas Christian beat Southern Mississippi, 14-12, on Saturday, it helped increase Nebraska's strength of schedule because Nebraska beat T.C.U. in August. That moved Nebraska from 18th to 14th in strength of schedule, perhaps accounting for the .05 margin over Colorado. Is that clear? If not, please contact Knute Rockne on a Ouija board. 
The results were announced on national television in midafternoon during a show sponsored by a company that makes salty snack food. The host of the show kept mentioning the communications company that sponsors the Rose Bowl and the retail chain that sponsors the trophy. All the telecast needed was Vanna White turning over the cards and Regis Philbin asking, "Is that your final answer?"
The show included a split screen displaying Gary Barnett, the coach of Colorado, and Frank Solich, the coach of Nebraska, the way cable news channels show opposing politicians and pundits during the evening shout-outs. Barnett's frown trumped Solich's placid demeanor.
Barnett insisted that his team played more contending teams than Solich's. Solich declined to point out that Barnett's team lost more games, but he did say, "You're going to have controversy" under a system like this.
"We won 11 games in a row," Solich said. "We're very proud." Nebraska finished 11-1; Colorado was 10-2. Miami was 11-0. 
Barnett's Buffaloes almost qualified thanks to a big assist from his fellow coaches, who tried to run an end-around past the computers and perform some rough justice yesterday morning by changing their votes from last week. The coaches moved Colorado ahead of Nebraska, flipping the third and fourth places.
Despite the fact that neither team played, Colorado got better in the opinion of the coaches and Nebraska got worse.
But various computed components, including the strength of the respective schedules, left Colorado in third place in the B.C.S., slightly behind Nebraska. This computer factor amounts to revenge of the nerds, the triumph of the guys from the high school math club who could not get the attention of the girls watching football practice.
Cynical people may suggest that the B.C.S., in its fourth year, is a convenient arrangement among six major conferences to control the millions of dollars paid by the four major bowl games and their television sponsors.
There were even murmurs of antitrust challenges last week from Brigham Young, grumbles that lessened when B.Y.U. ruined its perfect record by losing in Hawaii on Saturday, 72-45. Skeptics may also suggest that some of the student-athletes are not enrolled at their institutions of higher learning primarily to advance their education.
Potential conflicts with classes and examinations are often cited for the absence of a playoff system to determine a champion. 
Others suggest it has more to do with preserving the economic fiefdoms of the big bowl games. None of this is to imply that recent regular-season games have been devalued or lack excitement.
On the contrary, the last few weeks have featured a string of entertaining upsets that prevented top teams like Florida, Oklahoma, Texas and Tennessee from playing in the title game when all they had to do to get there was win. The scores have been close, the participants heroic, the plays memorable, and the fans in their painted faces and school-colored garments have been screaming their fool heads off.
This Rose Bowl could be a classic, pitting the modern passing offense of quarterback Ken Dorsey and Miami against the old-fashioned option attack run by Eric Crouch, the Nebraska quarterback who won the Heisman trophy Saturday in another much-debated decision. It is an archetypal American match pitting a city-slick team from an ocean coast against plodding farm boys from the heartland.
In a time of real-world fears of war and terrorism, a big debate about football and a little anticipation of a tainted but intriguing championship game may not be such a bad thing.

HEADLINE: Enron Made Payments in Bid To Hold Top Energy Traders 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
As it rushed to reach a merger agreement with Dynegy last month, Enron paid about $50 million to 75 employees who worked as natural gas and electricity traders. The payments, made in the first week in November, were meant to keep the company's most profitable energy traders from leaving before the merger, an Enron official said.
 That remuneration was separate from $55 million in bonuses paid to about 500 employees just days before Enron sought protection from creditors in bankruptcy court on Dec. 2, after Dynegy called off the merger. 
 Enron, after those payments were disclosed last week, said they were made to make sure "critical" workers stayed at the company for at least 90 days and that the bonuses primarily went to middle-level employees. 
Of the $55 million paid out before the bankruptcy filing, 11 executives received bonuses rangingfrom $500,000 and $5 million, a person close to the matter said, with a handful of senior officials receiving more than $1 million each.
Coming just as the company dismissed 4,000 employees -- including about half of its headquarters staff in Houston -- the total of $105 million in payments is sure to fuel resentment among workers who think that Enron took care of its higher-ranking employees at their expense. New details of the payments were reported by The Houston Chronicle.
The laid-off workers, who in some cases have already had up to 90 percent of their 401(k) retirement money evaporate as Enron's stock plunged this year, may receive no more than $4,500 in severance pay.
That compares with an average of almost $200,000 paid to each of more than 550 employees during the last month Enron was solvent.
An Enron spokesman defended the payments, saying they are not significant compared with the company's annual payroll of more than $2 billion, and that they were meant to retain employees needed for Enron to continue operation. Without those employees, he said, many Enron businesses might shut down completely, throwing even more people out of work and leaving less value for creditors.
Bankruptcy experts have said the payments are likely to come under scrutiny -- and may even be challenged -- by the hundreds of lenders and other companies who are Enron's creditors.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
A buyout company mayplan some tough love for two telecoms, and holders of their debt and stock.

BYLINE:  By Simon Romero 

 BODY:
EVEN though the crisis in the telecommunications industry was well under way a year ago, XO Communications and McLeodUSA were well received by some investors. How quickly things change.
 The stocks are below $1, and both XO and McLeodUSA are mired in debt. Saying there is no other way for the companies to avoid bankruptcy filings, the buyout firm Forstmann Little has announced huge restructuring plans the last two weeks for both XO, a telephone and Internet company based in Mclean, Va., and McLeodUSA, a telephone company in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. 
 Forstmann, led by the New York financier Theodore J. Forstmann and known for turning around companies like Gulfstream Aerospace and General Instruments, previously sank large sums into these companies and appears to be taking a long view for the industry.
The firm's austere proposals, though, which largely plunder shareholders and bondholders, have sent a chill through a part of the telecommunications industry already in tatters. Analysts and executives at competitive local exchange carriers, the start-up phone companies known as CLEC's (pronounced SEE-lecks), say the Forstmann plans have heightened the fears of investors.
Stock analysts say companies with large debt loads, like ITC Deltacom of West Point, Ga., and Mpower Holding of Pittsford, N.Y., are particularly vulnerable. ITC and Mpower remained in penny-stock territory last week. ITC closed the week at 99 cents, while Mpower finished at 45 cents. Less vulnerable are Allegiance Telecom and Time Warner Telecom, whose capital structures are not burdened by so much debt. These companies' stocks have remained relatively strong, with Allegiance gaining 94 cents last week, to $8.95, and Time Warner Telecom gaining $4.46, to $18.66.
"This is clearly not the right sector for public shareholders to put their money," said Glenn Waldorf, a telecommunications analyst who covers CLEC's at UBS Warburg. "A psychological threshold has been crossed showing it's no longer a mark of shame to take your pain and move on."
Some analysts are warning investors that other companies could wind up in situations like that of XO and McLeodUSA. Mr. Waldorf of UBS Warburg envisions a "game of restructuring dominoes" for other CLEC's.
The Forstmann restructuring plans are particularly painful for investors in XO, once known as NextLink Communications. XO's equity investors, whose holdings were valued at nearly $17 billion at the height of the technology bubble, will be completely wiped out. Shareholders in McLeodUSA, whose market value was once $16 billion, will be diluted to 30 percent from 79 percent of outstanding shares.
Bondholders will also be hit. In XO's case, they will get about 11 cents on the dollar for the $5 billion of debt securities they hold. That is about how much the debt traded for at the end of last month, traders say. McLeodUSA's bondholders will get about 19 percent of face value for holdings worth $2.9 billion on paper, in addition to 14 percent of equity in the company. According to traders, McLeodUSA's bonds were trading at 15 percent of face value at the end of last month.
The stocks of each company had already fallen by more than 90 percent for the year, punishing big investors including Forstmann, which had invested more than $1 billion in XO stock, and Craig O. McCaw, the cellphone pioneer.
Stull Stull & Brody, a law firm specializing in shareholder complaints, filed a lawsuit last week on behalf of XO shareholders, accusing the company misleading investors about its financial condition.
XO and McLeodUSA, with the help of their investment bankers, each raised $450 million from investors last January. Both companies needed the capital to pursue aggressive growth plans. XO, backed by Mr. McCaw, had recently expanded its business in Europe. McLeodUSA had recently expanded into the Texas telecommunications market with the acquisition of CapRock of Dallas.
Forstmann had already invested of $1.5 billion in XO and $1 billion in McLeodUSA. Now it is offering to put $400 million in cash into XO. It is also offering to buy McLeod's commercial-directory business for $535 million, convert its $1 billion in preferred stock into common stock and invest $100 million more in McLeod common shares. Some observers wonder why the buyout firm is dedicating even more funds to its telecommunications gamble in hopes of salvaging its investments.
"This is a spectator sport for us," said Royce Holland, chief executive of Allegiance Telecom of Dallas. "It'll be a while before we know whether Forstmann can pull these things off." 
What does Forstmann see? For one thing, the companies have growing revenues and could eventually become profitable if their debt loads were reduced.
Forstmann also has patience. Its turnaround of Gulfstream, the maker of corporate jets, took nearly 10 years. A person close to the buyout firm said XO and McLeodUSA are considered long-term investments. Mr. Forstmann declined to comment.
If the plans are approved by bondholders, Forstmann effectively gains control of the companies.
Another intrigue in the restructuring dance involves Carlos Slim Helu, the billionaire chairman of Telefonos de Mexico, whose company agreed to match Forstmann's $400 million pledge to invest in XO. Mr. Forstmann, a close friend of Mr. Slim's, invited him and Mr. McCaw to participate in the restructuring plan but only Mr. Slim accepted.
Mr. Slim will end up with 39 percent ownership of XO, as will Forstmann. Mr. Slim has a close relationship with SBC Communications of San Antonio, one of the nation's largest local telephone companies. Could SBC eventually acquire his holding in XO?
Whitney Johnson, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, wrote a report speculating that Mr. Slim could eventually sell his stake to SBC. "A possible exit strategy for Telmex?" she asked.
SBC declined to comment. Adolfo Cerezo Perez, Telmex's chief financial officer, said the company was taking a long-term approach with its XO investment. "We see this as an opportunity to buy into one of the premier telecommunications assets at a very attractive price," Mr. Cerezo said in a telephone interview from Mexico City. "It is far too early to be talking about exit strategies."

SUBJECT: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (94%); BUYINS & BUYOUTS (92%); LOCAL TELEPHONE SERVICE (90%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES (90%); SHAREHOLDERS (89%); CORPORATE RESTRUCTURING (89%); BONDS (89%); INDUSTRY ANALYSTS (88%); INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (78%); ECONOMIC BUBBLE (78%); BUSINESS FORECASTS (78%); BUSINESS INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY (77%); BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS (77%); INTERNET & WWW (76%) TELEPHONES AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS; CREDIT; MERGERS, ACQUISITIONS AND DIVESTITURES; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET; STOCKS AND BONDS 

COMPANY: MCLEODUSA INC (90%); XO HOLDINGS INC (58%); U S TELEPACIFIC CORP (55%); TW TELECOM INC (54%); UBS INVESTMENT BANK (53%)

HEADLINE: Official Says Resisting Bill On Terror Puts Britain at Risk 

BYLINE:  By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 9 

 BODY:
The country's chief law enforcement officer said today that Britain's alliance with the United States made it the likeliest European target for international terrorists like Osama bin Laden and that "naive" parliamentary resistance to the government's antiterrorism legislation was increasing the risk. 
 "Because of our close relationship with the Americans and total support for the U.S. and the robust way we have joined in on driving out bin Laden and the Taliban, we have a much higher profile than other European countries," the official, Home Secretary David Blunkett, said in a telephone interview from his Yorkshire parliamentary district. 
 "In the past, I have sought to damp down fears of a terror attack and not increase tensions," he said, "particularly around public parts of London, so as not to be detrimental to our economy.
"But when people say three months have lapsed and we can all have amnesia, we can forget about the threat, I remind them that terrorist organizations we host in our own communities plan their attacks months and years in advance, and so we have to be constantly vigilant until we have rooted them out." 
Mr. Blunkett made his remarks in response to action in the House of Lords last week adding seven limiting amendments to hard-line antiterror legislation the government is rushing through Parliament. He said the peers had "disemboweled" the proposed law and were acting in ignorance of the threat to national security. 
"God willing, there won't be an attack on us over Christmas and New Year," Mr. Blunkett said in the immediate aftermath of the Lords' rebellion. "Because all those who tell me we are not under threat are the ones who do not have the security and intelligence information which, for my sins, I carry."
A powerful member of Prime Minister Tony Blair's cabinet and known for his combativeness, Mr. Blunkett vowed to restore the disputed sections with only minor adjustments this week in the House of Commons, where the government has an overwhelming majority. 
Most European countries have tightened security measures in response to the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, but Britain has gone the furthest with its proposed law that would give prosecutors the right to detain indefinitely and without trial foreigners suspected of terrorist links. To do so, Britain had to invoke an article of the European Convention on Human Rights allowing countries to opt out of restrictions on such detentions.
The peers in the House of Lords maintained that they were acting to protect basic rights from government eagerness to impose draconian new police powers unrelated to the fight on terror. Among the amendments the Lords passed were ones calling for swift judicial review for interned terrorist suspects and limiting new information access provisions, which they claimed would allow the police to pry into almost anyone's personal bank accounts, tax returns and e-mail messages.
The Lords' intervention was welcomed by civil liberties and legal groups. "The amendments, if accepted, would give a proper focus to the fight against terrorism whilst avoiding measures that could impinge unfairly on the liberty of nonterrorists," said David McIntosh, president of the Law Society, a British counterpart to the American Bar Association. 
But Mr. Blunkett said he suspected the motivation of the peers in the House of Lords, where the Conservatives still wield power. "The demolition and sabotage was led by Tories whose interest is in giving the government a bloody nose and by others who are extremely naive and muddled," he said. 
Mr. Blunkett said he appreciated the concerns of civil liberties groups but contended that they had to be squared with the reality of the menace. "They are being terribly naive about the people we are dealing with," he said. 
He drew a parallel to the post-World War I government in Germany that was forced by events to yield to Hitler. "The Weimar Republic showed us that well-meaning and liberal-minded people can easily be swept aside by the evil that exists around us," he said. 
The House of Lords has the power to delay enactment of legislation passed by the House of Commons but not to overturn it. When the government disclosed the terms of the bill last month, it said it intended to have it be law by Christmas. Under that timetable, parliamentary action must be completed by Thursday. 
Mr. Blunkett said he would keep the House in session all Wednesday night if he had to, but he pleaded instead for a compromise to speed its passage. "I say to those who have questions about it to please come ahead with positive amendments to address them, but don't seek to destroy it," he said.

HEADLINE: Hewlett's Chief Is in a Battle For Her Deal and Her Career 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Shortly after she arrived at Hewlett-Packard two years ago, Carleton S. Fiorina invited the heirs of the founders over one afternoon. It was a pleasant couple of hours of talk over drinks, just a social get-together. The family members appreciated the gesture from the outsider who had come to take charge at the company that has their names on the door.
 "When she first became chief executive," one family member recalled, "she made a real effort to meet and get to know the family." 
 Ms. Fiorina, the nation's most prominent woman executive, understood the legacy of Hewlett-Packard. It is regarded as the entrepreneurial birthplace of Silicon Valley, founded in 1938 in a garage in Palo Alto, Calif., by William Hewlett and David Packard with $538. 
Her job was to revitalize a corporate icon, one with a rich past yet an uncertain future, sluggish and slipping behind in crucial computing markets. The renovation task, however, would be particularly delicate, because the founders' heirs control a total of about 18 percent of Hewlett-Packard shares.
Now, the heirs have united to stop her. They fear that Ms. Fiorina's plans for Hewlett-Packard's future are too risky for them to stomach. 
Last Friday, the Packard family delivered the most severe blow yet to Ms. Fiorina, her plans for the company and her career. The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, the company's largest shareholder, declared it would vote against Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq Computer. The Packard foundation has joined Walter Hewlett and David Woodley Packard, the two oldest sons of the founders, who last month said they and their foundations would vote against the deal. 
Facing unified opposition from the families, the largest merger in computer history is in danger of a humbling rebuff.
To rescue the deal, Ms. Fiorina and her company must win the backing of major investors who have been skeptical so far. Page C1. 
If the deal collapses -- as many analysts predict -- Ms. Fiorina, who has championed it as the bold step Hewlett-Packard needs to become more competitive, will likely depart. 
In a lengthy interview last week at the company's Palo Alto headquarters, Ms. Fiorina, 47, stopped just short of confirming that.
If the shareholders take the unusual step of vetoing the deal, she said, "It would say a lot about the board and management's credibility."
In the interview, her first since the initial family opposition arose in early November, Ms. Fiorina defended the deal and her tenure at Hewlett-Packard. The interview came before the Packard foundation vote on Friday, but afterward she and the board said they would press ahead. She expressed confidence that they could still garner enough votes to have the merger approved.
"It's going to go through," she said. "It will."
The interview was in her second-floor office -- a kind of first-among-equals version of the classic Silicon Valley cubicle, a large corner space marked off by beige, shoulder-high partitions.
Her manner was direct, often combative, her handshake firm. She never criticized the families directly, but a theme of her comments was that her program of change is truer to the founders' vision than the stance of her opponents.
"This company has never been about looking in the rear-view mirror, though some people are more comfortable doing it," Ms. Fiorina said at one point.
Later, she declared, "To say that the status quo is a strategy is absurd. It's never been a strategy in this industry." 
The Compaq merger has been controversial since it was announced on Sept. 4. The immediate reaction from Wall Street was skeptical, as investors drove down the shares of both companies.
The skepticism is understandable. Big mergers in the fast-moving computer business have a poor track record. Corporate cultures clash, and integrating the operations of two big enterprises often turns out to be a time-consuming distraction. While the merging companies dither, markets -- and rivals -- move on.
A big merger would also be a striking departure from tradition at Hewlett-Packard, a company that has grown organically and nurtured a close-knit culture emphasizing trust, openness and consensus, known as the "H.P. Way."
Such concerns fueled the family opposition to the deal, led by Walter Hewlett, the one family member who is a company director. 
Ms. Fiorina sees things very differently. Based on her two years as chief executive, she is convinced that the company needs more than a strategy of evolution from within.
She has worked hard to modernize the company's culture. Leadership, she says, is a performance art. "Change has to be led from the top," she said. "People have to understand what you are trying to do and buy it." 
A determined, energetic performer, Ms. Fiorina traveled 250,000 miles in her first year to company facilities worldwide, urging employees to quicken the pace.
She reorganized to shear away layers of bureaucracy. And she engineered a new marketing campaign with a simplified "hp" logo, dropping the family names.
For her task, Ms. Fiorina intentionally adopted a personalized style of management. Young and articulate, with stylishly cut blond hair, she became a business celebrity. As the first woman to lead so large a company, her actions were inevitably scrutinized closely in Silicon Valley and beyond.
The star turn did not sit well with many Hewlett-Packard veterans and some family members. They noted the lucrative pay package required to lure her from Lucent Technologies in 1999 -- mostly stock once valued as high as $85 million, though now less than $35 million -- and the fact that she expanded the corporate jet fleet.
"Why do people comment on my flying a corporate jet when virtually every other chief executive in Silicon Valley does the same?" she replied with exasperation when asked about it. She offered no explanation herself. "I'm just saying you should ask yourself that question," Ms. Fiorina replied.
Later, though, she suggested that being a newcomer to Hewlett-Packard and to the valley, invited resistance. "I knew that coming in as an outsider and moving a 60-year-old company with a grand heritage, and all the crosscurrents that implies, was not going to be easy," she said. 
As the computer industry's slide accelerated this year, Ms. Fiorina decided that a more drastic step was needed -- and the Compaq merger became that step. 
She begs to differ with critics who say big mergers in the computer business are doomed to failure. "Where mergers do work -- in banking, chemicals, pharmaceuticals and other industries -- is where they are fundamentally focused on consolidation and not diversification," she said. Hewlett-Packard and Compaq have several overlapping, complementary businesses, making them ideal candidates for efficiency-enhancing consolidation, she explained.
Melding the personal computer operations of both companies, Ms. Fiorina said, will give the combined company the economies of scale it needs to better compete against the industry leader, Dell Computer.
Both companies, she added, have sizable positions in the market for the larger computers that are the engines of corporate office networks and the Internet. Greater size, she said, will give the new Hewlett-Packard more influence with corporate customers against rivals like I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems.
With the heady growth days of the late 1990's only a memory, Ms. Fiorina believes that the industry itself is ripe for consolidation. Moving quickly, with the Compaq merger, is a way to guarantee that Hewlett-Packard is a leader, instead of an also-ran. "The technology industry is widely viewed as not mature," she said. "But I think it is maturing," and thus ready for a cycle of mergers. 
She may be the public face of the merger, but she is by no means alone in advocating it. The boards of both companies support it (with the notable exception of Mr. Hewlett) and reiterated that support to each other yesterday in a conference call. 
"It's not simply my view," Ms. Fiorina noted. "That's important to remember. These are people with a lot of collective experience and knowledge."
A member of the board and a frequent adviser is Richard A. Hackborn, a retired Hewlett-Packard executive, who worked for the company for 33 years and built its printer business, the corporate crown jewel. Mr. Hackborn was a principal architect of the strategy that brought Ms. Fiorina to the company and led to the Compaq merger. 
As Mr. Hackborn envisioned it, corporate customers want companies that can offer them technology solutions -- complete with hardware, software and services -- to business problems, not just pieces of equipment. Compaq, Mr. Hackborn said, improves Hewlett's chances of becoming just such a supplier, more like I.B.M.
"I don't think we'll get there incrementally, on our own," he said in an interview. 
The Compaq merger, however, was not something Ms. Fiorina rushed into. In boardroom strategy sessions, she said, it had been regarded as a "distinct possibility" since December 1999. Yet the merger talks only began last June. 
Her main concern all along, she said, was the "integration challenge" of blending the two companies and their disparate cultures.
To solve those problems, she points to joint teams of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq workers who are preparing a single corporate Web site, a single customer service operation, unified teams for corporate customers and pay checks for all that say Hewlett-Packard. 
"None of this suggests it is easy," Ms. Fiorina said. "It suggests we understand what we're doing."

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Politics and War

ON THE GROUND -- The brutal five-year rule of the Taliban came to an official end as the last Afghan province, Zabul, slipped from their control. Their fractious opponents, due to start governing in two weeks, agreed to bury some of the many feuds that could jeopardize peace. A1

THE LAST STAGE -- The American military campaign in Afghanistan has been remarkably successful, but the siege of Tora Bora may be different. The 30 or 40 fortified caves that are the last bastion of Osama bin Laden's supporters -- and perhaps the hide-out of the terrorist mastermind himself -- have long been a safe refuge for Afghan fighters. B3

The Money Trail

Disillusioned Warriors

But many state and local governments are balking because of the costs and the frustration over what they see as the federal government's confusing stream of intelligence information and security alerts.
