HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Madison Ave. Grapples With Post-Sept. 11 Era

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Three months after Sept. 11, Madison Avenue continues struggling to determine the right tone, approach and content for post-attack campaigns. The result has been advertising that is often strained or off-putting, even inappropriate.
 Only a handful of ads have managed to strike evocative chords by walking the fine line between exploitation and empathy. 
 Compared with the high-minded work that agencies created during World War II, much of it demanding sacrifice from citizens, today's advertising relies far more on reassurances that victory is achievable through sybaritism. The mantra of the booming economy of the 1990's, "Shop till you drop," has been replaced with a millennium mutation: "Shop till Osama drops." 
Consumers, moreover, could be excused for thinking they are shopping in a parallel universe, or perhaps more accurately, a series of parallel universes.
In one universe, patriotism is paramount as marketers paint their brands red, white and blue and proclaim, "My country, right or wrong" -- usually wrongly.
Who will ever forget, try as they may, when the Miller Brewing division of Philip Morris ran a commercial in which people held up signs with messages like "We are all New Yorkers" and "I will not be terrorized!" or the day Kmart ran an American flag as an ad, which urged readers to "embrace freedom" by tearing out and displaying it ("This side up").
In this universe, the product being peddled in a jingoistic spot or star-spangled banner ad can be patriotism itself, in the form of tasteless American flag Post-it Notes from 3M; tacky "Promise of Freedom" eagle figurines from Franklin Mint, a unit of Roll International; or tawdry "patriotic thong panties" from Frederick's of Hollywood, festooned with flags and the words "America the Beautiful."
In another universe, the mood is somber, and no commerce can be transacted without a nod, respectful or unctuous, to the victims of the attacks and their families. "We will never forget," promises a bizarre newspaper ad for General Electric by the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, owned by the Omnicom Group. The ad shows a defiant Statue of Liberty striding off her pedestal and rolling up her sleeves, as if brought to life by poltergeist in the finale of a movie called "Ghostbusters Go to War."
A commercial by the same agency for Visa made a similar point more subtly. Meant to encourage people to resume buying theater tickets, the spot presents an elegiac version of "Give My Regards to Broadway" sung by Judy Collins as scenes appear of actors getting ready for a performance.
In still another universe, doing well by doing good is the operative scheme, centered on pledges to contribute to Sept. 11-related charities and causes. For instance, a print ad for the Discover credit card lists merchandise from coffee beans to garden hose to movie tickets and asserts, "Just by doing what you do every day, you can help the families and victims of Sept. 11."
The ad, by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, also owned by Omnicom, goes on to explain that "every time you use your Discover Card" -- either the regular version or the "Discover American Flag Card" -- the company will donate to "America's relief efforts, until we reach our goal of $5 million." Welcome to Sacrifice Lite: no muss, no fuss, no messy commitment. Discover is a unit of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
In other instances, it is donor beware, as the budget for self-congratulatory ads to promote the philanthropy can be larger than the actual sum being given away.
In a final universe, the determination has been made to resume the routine as if nothing has happened; ads maintain their normal funny, cloying or annoying attitudes. In this universe, populated primarily by beers, video games, fast food and snacks, the smiles seem forced, the enthusiasm too enthusiastic, not unlike the laughter at a cocktail party to divert attention from a guest's faux pas.
The reason for those confusing multiple realities is not difficult to determine. Never before have agencies and advertisers had to figure out how to aim sales pitches at a public grappling with simultaneous situations of domestic terrorism, recession, biohazards and war.
Moreover, the intertwining of the fate of the nation with the fate of the economy has brought a blurring of the distinction between altruistic public service advertising, which Madison Avenue traditionally produces during national crises, and campaigns capitalizing on Sept. 11 for capitalistic purposes, intended to keep commercial interests afloat.
Take for instance the campaign for General Motors carrying the theme "Keep America rolling," which sought successfully to stimulate automobile sales after Sept. 11 with zero-percent loans. The first print ad spent two paragraphs recounting how "the world as we knew it came to a halt" and how the attacks "shook us to our very core."
Then the ad shrewdly took a brisk U-turn: "Now it's time to move forward. For years, the auto industry has played a crucial role in our economy. General Motors takes that responsibility seriously." The ad, by the Troy, Mich., office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, concluded with this deft blend of selflessness and self-interest: "This may very well be the most serious crisis our nation has ever faced. In this time of terrible adversity, let's stand together. And keep America rolling."
How? Why, by spending tens of thousands of dollars on a new G.M. car, truck or minivan.
Another unsettling example of this peculiar interweaving of national and commercial interests is a spot from the New York office of McCann-Erickson, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, for the Travel Industry Association of America. 
The spot, tellingly titled "The President's Own Words," uses film of President Bush addressing a joint session of Congress, much as public service announcements for nonprofit causes from the American Red Cross to the Harvard Alcohol Project feature a president's appearance.
This time, though, the scenes of the president are interspersed with scenes of employees of travel-related businesses -- profit-making enterprises -- who repeat his words to "live your lives, do your business around the country, take your families." They include pilots, flight attendants, crews of cruise ships, hotel workers and chefs, representing travel industry giants like American Express; Hertz, a unit of Ford Motor; and Marriott International, which are contributing an estimated $20 million to run the spot.
In fact, McCann-Erickson is also the ad agency for Marriott.
President Bush is joined by a cadre of elected officials in campaigns commingling public service and commercial promotion, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and Jean Chretien, prime minister of Canada. Those efforts seek to rebuild the New York City brand by encouraging tourism, shopping and dining out to help local businesses.
The campaigns, by BBDO New York and the New York and Toronto offices of the Wolf Group, work more effectively than the travel commercial because they mask their intent to benefit private companies with a burst of feel-good emotionalism tapping the reservoir of good will the city has earned the last three months.
Mr. Giuliani is by far the best performer of the bunch, particularly in the delightful BBDO New York spots carrying the theme "The New York miracle. Be a part of it." 
The humorous pro bono commercials present well-known residents like Robert De Niro and Barbara Walters, each pursuing an improbable "New York dream" from taking part in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade to being in a Broadway musical.
Don't be surprised if after Mr. Giuliani leaves office, he appears in a Super Bowl commercial by BBDO New York for one of the agency's paying clients like Pepsi-Cola.

HEADLINE: For Many Generation X'ers, Grass Is Greener at Home 

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON 

 BODY:
Generation X'ers, the workers known for job-hopping, aren't as footloose in the employment market as they are reputed to be.
 Nearly half of professionals 26 to 37 years old would be very happy to spend the rest of their careers with their current companies, according to a study released today. The survey involved 1,300 men and women and was carried out in late 2000, before the economic downturn made job hunting harder for all ages. 
 The survey dispels the myth that this generation is not loyal, said Sheila Wellington, president of Catalyst, the research group that conducted the study. While Generation X came of age during the country's longest economic boom and pioneered the dot-com revolution, she said, the survey shows that many in this cohort have old-fashioned goals. 
"There are a lot of seeming myths and assumptions about 26- to 37- year-olds," Ms. Wellington said. "But GenX'ers are attracted to their organizations for utterly traditional reasons: reputation of the organization, opportunities to advance -- pretty much the reasons that most of us would assume worked for the generation that preceded them."
Still, Catalyst and other research organizations that have studied Generation X caution that this age group has high demands for employers that, if not met, could prompt employees to depart, downturn or no.
"They're highly sensitive to being treated as the wonderful people that they are," said Dr. David L. Stum, president of Aon Consulting's Loyalty Institute, a division, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., of the Aon Corporation. "The GenX'er who believes the employer is not making a commitment to him will leave."
That's how 30-year-old Colleen Galle, a vice president at the J .P. Morgan investment bank, views her career so far. During nearly nine years with the company, Ms. Galle has turned down job offers with higher pay, she said. She has stayed because she has had varied jobs within the firm, good benefits, and now, as the mother of a 4-month-old, flexibility in her work.
"I've explored moving," said Ms. Galle, who lives in Short Hills, N.J., "but there is a comfort, there is a loyalty. I have got to give them a chance to meet my demands, but if they can't, I'll go elsewhere or I'll quit work." She was not part of Catalyst's survey.
Catalyst carried out the survey in September 2000 at eight United States and two Canadian companies. Seventy percent of the respondents were women, and more than half were college graduates. Catalyst works with companies to advance women in business, and it chose to focus on Generation X'ers to explore their attitudes as future business leaders.
The study found that more than 70 percent of the workers, born between 1964 and 1975, rated companionship, a loving family and enjoying life as extremely important. In contrast, fewer than 20 percent of the workers said earning a lot of money and becoming an influential leader were extremely important goals.
Asked about their commitment to their companies, 47 percent of the respondents said they would be very happy to spend the rest of their careers at their current organizations.
Not surprisingly, corporate loyalty is rising in the current economic climate, according to recent surveys done by Harris Interactive.
Among 25- to 39-year-olds, nearly 60 percent said in 1999 that they would be likely to leave their jobs voluntarily in the next five years, compared with 45 percent who said that this past October, in a survey commissioned by Spherion, a recruiting firm based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Among workers of all ages, the number who said they were likely to leave fell to 42 percent in the October survey from 50 percent in 1999.
While job insecurities play a part in this shift, said Robert Morgan, president of Spherion's human capital consulting group, employers have worked hard at retaining good workers in recent years as labor shortages intensified.
"Because of the war for talent," Mr. Morgan said, "employers had to get better to compete in the market. A lot of mentoring, professional development, career development programs were started. They've done that out of necessity."

HEADLINE: The Veiled Resource 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan 

 BODY:
I was in a burka shop the other day, chatting with the male proprietor, when two women walked in to browse the latest fashions (powder blue, gold embroidery). They observed silently as the two of us men discussed whether women want to wear burkas. It seemed a bit ridiculous, so I asked the women: "What do you think?"
 Scandalized, they raced out of the shop. 
 Over the last week I've been rebuffed by dozens of Afghan women. To find out how much of the repression of women in Afghanistan was the result of the Taliban and how much was culture, I thought I should consult the real experts: ordinary women. But men are not supposed to talk to women here except when absolutely necessary, and accosting a female stranger to interview her is a shocking breach of protocol.
While American outrage at mistreatment of women has focused on the Taliban -- partly because of clever media work by the Bush administration to bolster support for the war -- the inequity goes far deeper. The war may be ending, but the effort to bring opportunities to Afghan women should be just beginning.
Here is where the United States can play a leadership role. During the United States' occupation of Japan after World War II, we wrote a constitution for Japan that guaranteed equal rights for women, and similar nudging by us in the coming years can help all Afghans, men and women alike.
The Taliban are gone from Kabul, but women are still fifth-class citizens. Women are no longer required to wear the burka, but they do anyway. Every woman on the streets in Kabul still looks like a shrouded ghost, and as in Japan in 1945, there is little internal pressure for equality.
"We obey our husbands, and our husbands have more rights than us -- that is our culture," Wahida Kamily, a 23-year-old high school graduate, told me through the mesh of her burka. I asked her what she thought of the many Afghan husbands who beat their wives. "If a wife doesn't listen to her husband," she said primly, "it's right for him to beat her."
In the Dari language, a man who does not beat his wife is sometimes dismissed with the phrase "to nadari," which suggests that he is a eunuch. And in Pashto, there's a phrase "khezi pa kor ka ya gor ka." That means: "A woman belongs in the house -- or in a grave."
Much has been made of the missed opportunities of all these women, but there is another important cost: the missed opportunity for Afghanistan as a whole. Afghanistan has one resource of far greater economic value than oil or diamonds: the half of the population that has been largely excluded from economic life.
History has repeatedly shown the economic advantages of education and autonomy for women, and indeed the West pulled ahead of the rest of the world beginning in the 1400's partly because it was educating more girls. David S. Landes, the economic historian at Harvard, argues in his magisterial "The Wealth and Poverty of Nations," "The best clue to a nation's growth and development potential is the status and role of women."
Across Asia, the fuel for economic expansion has been literate women workers churning out toys, shoes and clothing. The owner of a Kabul raisin factory I visited said that girls are more careful workers than boys, and now that the Taliban is gone he plans to fire most of his 50 male employees and hire female replacements. Perhaps the revolution is beginning.
Encouraging more opportunity for Afghan women is not cultural imperialism, any more than are our efforts to bring Afghanistan a central bank, modern roads or free elections. These are all simply elements of nation-building. 
So for the sake of all Afghans, we should gently prod the new government to improve education, health care and job opportunities for women, and also direct our aid in that direction. In an auspicious start, Afghanistan's interim government has two women ministers. Even the most chauvinistic men I talked to -- including one who said he would beat his wife if she so much as asked for permission to remove her burka -- accepted this.
"It's good to have women ministers," said Wali Mohammed, a 29-year-old man standing among the bombed-out buildings of western Kabul. "Women should be allowed to vote," he added magnanimously, "and if a woman has no husband, she can decide for herself who to vote for."

HEADLINE: New Pentagon Debate Over Stealth Plane 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
A fierce struggle is under way among senior Pentagon officials over whether to restart production of the most expensive aircraft in history, the B-2 stealth bomber, administration officials said today.
 The debate pits the senior leadership of the Air Force, which adamantly opposes building more of the bat-winged planes because of their high cost, against policy analysts close to Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, who view the B-2 as the kind of advanced weapons system that could transform the way the United States wages war. 
 At stake is a proposal by Northrop Grumman, the manufacturer, to reopen plants in California and build 40 more of the jets over the coming decade for about $30 billion. Northrop built the existing fleet of 21 B-2's for about $44 billion, which included research and development costs that would not be part of the new price. 
The proposal, which was first floated by Northrop last spring only to be knocked down by the Air Force, has been resurrected by its advocates inside the Pentagon because Mr. Rumsfeld is preparing to submit the proposed 2003 Pentagon budget to the White House by early January. Mr. Rumsfeld has said that he wants to use the 2003 spending plan to resolve debates on many major weapons programs.
The bomber debate has also been reignited by the war in Afghanistan, with both sides arguing that the high-tech bombing campaign that successfully demoralized and dispersed the Taliban forces has bolstered their positions. 
Mr. Rumsfeld has tried to stay above the fray while the Air Force and his policy advisers have wrestled in classified analyses and closed-door meetings. But Mr. Rumsfeld, who in 1995 signed a letter with six former defense secretaries urging the Clinton administration to buy more B-2's, is widely thought to admire the plane, which can fly very long missions, deliver precision-guided bombs and avoid radar detection.
Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense, was also an outspoken advocate of the B-2 before joining the Bush administration, and might be willing to support buying more planes if a strong military and economic case could be made for them, people familiar with the debate said.
On Tuesday, President Bush is scheduled to give a major address on the war at the Citadel, in Charleston, S.C., that his advisers said would reprise some of the themes of a 1999 campaign speech at the same school. In the earlier speech, Mr. Bush praised "long-range aircraft" capable of striking with "pinpoint accuracy," code words, the speech's authors said, for the B-2 bomber. 
This time, it is not clear whether Mr. Bush will address the bomber issue, since it remains so hotly contested within the Pentagon. "No decisions have been reached," an administration official said today.
The fight over the B-2 in many ways exemplifies the issues Mr. Rumsfeld is grappling with as he tries to reshape the armed forces for new kinds of conflicts in the post-Soviet world of global terrorism, cyberwarfare and proliferating chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. 
Advocates, who include Andrew Marshall, a senior civilian analyst at the Pentagon and close adviser to Mr. Rumsfeld, maintain that radar-evading bombers like the B-2, which are capable of delivering satellite- and laser-guided bombs, are necessary to maintain America's battlefield edge in far-flung future conflicts. 
The difficulty in obtaining basing rights in Central Asia for short-range fighter jets during the Afghan campaign underscored the need for long-range aircraft, those advocates argue. Based at Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri, the B-2 flew a small number of bombing missions over Afghanistan early in the campaign, with aerial refueling. It also flew nonstop bombing missions from Missouri to Yugoslavia in the 1999 Kosovo campaign.
"Air Force strike fighters played a small role in the Afghan war," said one advocate of the B-2. "Yet the Air Force is scheduled to buy 2,200 short-range tactical aircraft in the coming decades, and zero bombers. For some of us, their portfolio seems unbalanced."
But the Air Force has staunchly opposed buying more B-2's, in large part because the immense cost would almost certainly force it to slash other programs, including its highest-priority acquisition, the F-22 Raptor stealth fighter jet. Even the secretary of the Air Force, James Roche, a former Northrop executive, has strongly opposed buying more B-2's. 
Senior Air Force officers contend that upgrades to B-52 and B-1 bombers that enabled them to drop precision-guided weapons in Afghanistan had reduced the need for additional B-2's. "I think we've proven that we've got not only the right airplanes but pretty much the right mix," Gen. John Jumper, the Air Force chief of staff, told reporters recently. 
The Pentagon, which conceived of the B-2 as one leg of the nation's nuclear force, originally planned to buy 132 of the planes. But the program was plagued by cost overruns and production delays, and with the collapse of the Soviet Union, Congress stopped production after the 21st plane in the 1990's. 
The plane is not only expensive to buy, but to maintain, since every nick or dent on its specially designed skin must be repaired with particular kinds of tape and epoxy that require as long as 80 hours to cure. For those reasons, buying more B-2's is likely to stir opposition among lawmakers worried that this would drain money from their districts.
"If there is a decision" to restart the production line, said a person close to the debate, "it will require a significant amount of political capital on the part of both Rumsfeld and the president, not only to get it through the Air Force, but to sell it on Capitol Hill."

HEADLINE: Willamette to Pursue Acquisition to Try toThwart Hostile Bid 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The timber company Willamette Industries authorized its management yesterday to start talks to buy a large unit of the rival Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a move seen as another major defense against a year-old hostile bid from the Weyerhaeuser Company. 
 An acquisition of the building products business -- which had revenue of around $7 billion last year -- would make Willamette a leading maker of wood panels and lumber and a big distributor of other building material products. 
 Willamette took the initiative to start talks in what could be described as the final snub to Weyerhaeuser's $5.5 billion offer last year. 
 A large Willamette acquisition would create an entirely different company, and essentially invalidate Weyerhaeuser's offer. That means Willamette's stock could decline on fears that Weyerhaeuser could pull its offer.
 Weyerhaeuser declined to comment but Willamette's shares showed early signs of decline, shedding 60 cents in after-hours trading at $44. Georgia-Pacific was one of the most actively traded issues in after-hours, losing $1.52, to $28.95.
 Willamette's board, which includes three Weyerhaeuser directors, gave the go-ahead yesterday afternoon for talks with Georgia-Pacific.
 The board of Georgia-Pacific, based in Atlanta, also authorized management to start a dialogue with Willamette on combining the two businesses.
 Weyerhaeuser's last offer on the table was at $50 a Willamette share, which closed at $46.40 yesterday. Two months ago, Willamette indicated it was willing to discuss an offer closer to $60 a share but it was turned down by Weyerhaeuser.
 "They publicly slammed the door shut on that overture in less than two hours without so much as a phone call," said Duane McDougall, president and chief executive of Willamette Industries, "and we made it clear that we intended to pursue our strategic plan. That's what we are doing." 
 A potential deal would give Georgia-Pacific the opportunity to sell a business that has been experiencing much slower growth compared with the rest of the company's consumer paper, packaging, and container-board business lines.
 Georgia-Pacific has been considering several options on this business and its chairman and chief executive, Pete Correll, said yesterday that one option being considered was splitting the company in two.
 An economic downturn has hit the building products business recently and most of the products had a sales decline in the third quarter.
 Gypsum wallboard sales fell 27.6 percent; lumber sales dropped 18.8 percent; particle-board sales fell 12.6 percent; and plywood shrank 7.4 percent.
 The company was recently forced to slow down production to match demand. It recently decided to run its gypsum plant on a one-shift, five-day basis.
 A possible divestiture of the business would be the latest in a string of transformation deals that Georgia-Pacific has done recently. In 1997, it spun off its timberland assets. Last year the company bought the Fort James Corporation, which turned Georgia-Pacific into the world's largest maker of tissue paper.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Gauges Are Down as Many Energy Issues Are Hammered

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday as investors cashed in on the recent run-up and cast a cautious eye toward the Federal Reserve's meeting today.
 Economists expect the Fed's policy makers to cut short-term interest rates a quarter of a percentage point. Such a move would bring the benchmark federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to 1.75 percent, its lowest since the early 1960's. If the Fed acts as expected, it will be the 11th rate cut this year. 
 Analysts said the stock market had already priced in a quarter-point reduction, and they noted that trading in futures contracts on the federal funds rate reflected a 100 percent chance of such a cut. As such, they said, investors were expected to place greater emphasis on the Federal Reserve's statement about the strength of the economy. 
"What the market would like to see is the Fed indicate that this is the last cut," said Peter Cardillo, chief strategist and director of research at Global Partner Securities, formerly Westfalia Investments. "That would boost investors' confidence in the sense that investors would feel comfortable that the Fed feels confident that the economy is about to turn."
With no economic news yesterday and few announcements from corporate America, each of the three major indexes lost ground. 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 128.01 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,921.45. The technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index dropped 29.14 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,992.12. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 18.38 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,139.93.
Investors punished the energy sector as fresh concerns about the industry, initially stoked by the collapse of Enron, swept the market.
Calpine, the country's largest independent power producer, fell $3.58, to $17.79, after a Morgan Stanley analyst downgraded it to neutral from strong buy.
An article on Sunday in the Money & Business section of The New York Times questioned Calpine's ability to maintain its growth rate and cited its recent shift to trading energy. The article also pointed to some financial and accounting similarities that Calpine has with Enron and its extensive dealings with Enron.
After the close of trading, Calpine's chief executive, Peter Cartright, called the article misleading and said "the comparison between Calpine and Enron is ridiculous."
Investors' cool treatment of Calpine spread to other independent power producers. NRG Energy fell $1.19, to $14.11; Orion Power dropped 27 cents, to $25.67; Aquila fell 47 cents, to $16.80; Reliant Resources plunged $2.14, to $14.71; Dynegy tumbled $2.48, to $27.80; and El Paso slumped $1.86, to $41.90. 
Shares of Halliburton, one of the world's largest oil field service companies, bounced back yesterday after falling 42.5 percent on Friday when a jury in Baltimore awarded $30 million to plaintiffs in an asbestos lawsuit. Salmon Smith Barney and UBS Warburg downgraded the stock. Halliburton jumped $2, to $14, after company executives said they planned to appeal the verdict.
Compaq Computer fell $1.62, to $9.70, after the company's proposed takeover by Hewlett-Packard appeared to be in jeopardy. Members of the Hewlett family have opposed the deal since it was announced in September. On Friday, the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, which holds 10 percent of Hewlett's stock, said it would not back the merger, leading many analysts to believe that the deal was near collapse. Shareholders are to vote on the deal early next year. Hewlett lost only 52 cents, to $23, as investors bet it was in a better financial position to absorb the aftershock if the deal fell through.
Despite the market's pullback, analysts said the day's activity did not represent a major downward trend.
"We had a significant move when the Nasdaq broke through the 200-day moving average," said Rod Smyth, chief investment strategist at First Union Securities. "This is just a consolidating day." --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices rose yesterday as a three-month high in yields on the most widely traded two-year notes lured investors.
Some people bought government debt anticipating that the Federal Reserve will accompany an interest rate reduction today with a statement indicating it may cut rates again in January. 
The price of the 10-year Treasury note rose 14/32, to 99 7/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.10 percent from 5.16 percent on Friday.
The 30-year bond rose 17/32, to 97 11/32. Its yield fell to 5.56 percent from 5.60 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: COMPENSATION; 
Holding the Victims' Purse Strings, Uneasily

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Washington mediator in charge of the multibillion-dollar federal fund set up to compensate the families of those killed and injured in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, had just taken his first close look at ground zero in New York, the smoking pit where the twin towers once stood.
 Mr. Feinberg's brash, can-do optimism about his new task seemed to falter for a moment last Tuesday. "I'm confident, very confident, that the system ultimately will be perceived as fair," he said as he rode uptown from the site. "But I do not really expect to ameliorate anybody's pain. A check won't do that." 
 But as the special master of the new federal fund, Mr. Feinberg will be the man who writes those checks, the architect of the process that produces them and the final arbiter of their size. If he recognizes that the checks will not erase anyone's pain, he fully realizes that they will provide comfort and most likely provoke controversy. 
His awards, based in part on the victims' lost earning power, could well exceed $1 million per family and are apt to be the single most important source of long-term financial support for thousands of victim families. Those who file a claim with the fund waive their right to sue, and the awards cannot be appealed to any court.
By some Congressional estimates, Mr. Feinberg could ultimately pay out as much as $11 billion in compensation, but official estimates must wait until the fund's rules are written.
Until those formal rules are released, he will discuss only the questions he faces, not the answers he might have reached. But the questions are imposing enough.
"How do you define who is eligible?" he asked, as if leading a law seminar at Georgetown University, where he teaches part time. "The statute covers those killed or injured in the attacks or its 'immediate aftermath,' but how do you define immediate aftermath? Hours? Days?"
That just scratches the surface. There are additional questions of what it means to have been injured, and whether psychological hurt might be compensated, or what should happen if no will exists and there are different family members filing claims.
But perhaps no question hangs over Mr. Feinberg and his every decision more ominously than the matter of fairness. A large part of each award will be calculated by using estimates of a victim's lifetime earnings, and so differing assumptions will have to be made about the earning power of a bond trader and a dishwasher. The former earned more but might have retired or burned out earlier; the latter earned less, but almost certainly would have worked most of his life.
These disparate employment histories will necessarily require awards of vastly different sizes -- a fact that may not be palatable to the public, Mr. Feinberg acknowledged. But he must somehow ensure that people in similar circumstances are treated similarly. 
Mr. Feinberg has indicated that one possible partial solution to the question of fairness could be to make sure the damages for "pain and suffering" are calculated to ensure that every family gets some minimum amount, regardless of its lost breadwinner's paycheck. Mr. Feinberg agrees that the equity hurdle is daunting, although he will not yet commit to how he will try to overcome it.
As if that were not enough, Mr. Feinberg also has to wrestle with the decision of whether whatever funds a family has received from charity should be deducted from their federal award. "The charities have made it very clear that they do not like the idea, but we're looking at all the options," he said.
Seeking answers to these questions, Mr. Feinberg has been consulting a remarkable cross section of people: a Nobel economist, aviation disaster lawyers, victim families, political leaders, investment bankers, arbitration specialists and labor statisticians.
But economic calculations are not his primary concern, he said. "The Achilles' heel of this program is the emotional force associated with these deaths," he said. "The emotional forces are the key to this whole thing."
With an anonymous process based on paper filings and formulas, "there would be no expiation," he added. "You need to let people explain why they believe they are victims, and why they are different from every other victim."
As that concern suggests, there is nothing uncomplicated about Mr. Feinberg.
Asked about his hobbies, he always gives the same answer: opera and classical music. But if that conjures up an image of studiousness and high-brow tastes, ask him how he first discovered these sedate pastimes. 
"Oh, I remember it perfectly," he said with a grin. "When I was 9 years old, I saw Groucho Marx in 'A Night at the Opera.' I was hooked for life."
Part grand opera, part Marx Brothers, he defies easy labels. He built his legal reputation by negotiating settlements, not by winning cases. A former top aide to the liberal Democratic Senator Ted Kennedy of Massachusetts, he has won the confidence of Attorney General John Ashcroft, the conservative Republican who appointed him. And asked about the logistics and rule-making involved in his new job, he talks instead about the storms of the heart, the freshness of the survivors' grief.
Mr. Feinberg, known as much for his resilient optimism as for his blitzkrieg brain, is not daunted by the complexities he faces. Indeed, when he first learned about the fund, Mr. Feinberg said, he thought, "This sounds like something I've been training to do all my life."
At 56, he has been a lawyer for 31 years, having been the court-appointed mediator in a number of disputes, beginning in the mid-1980's with injury claims over the Agent Orange defoliant used in Vietnam and continuing through cases over asbestos, the Dalkon Shield birth control device and the dispute over the shutdown of the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island. Logistically and legally, he said, the new compensation fund was much simpler than any of those. "You don't have hundreds of thousands of claims, as you did in the Agent Orange case," he said. "And you don't have the causation disputes; here, there is no question about causation."
But that simplicity is counterbalanced by the speed that Congress demanded, he said. Litigation over injuries or wrongful deaths usually takes years, he explained, "and time has a way of dampening emotions; but we don't have that luxury."
By law, the fund must open for business on Dec. 21 and, after a claim is filed, the special master has 120 days to reach a decision.
"In tort terms, that is virtually overnight -- it is so soon after the injury and the loss," he said. "So the hearing process needs to be staffed by people who can deal effectively with individuals -- not just number- crunchers, but people with a humanistic side."
The statute's pace has accelerated Mr. Feinberg's naturally frenetic pace. Last Tuesday, in less than 10 hours, he squeezed in four meetings in three locations, his first reluctant look at ground zero, a long interview and, finally, a concert version of Bela Bartok's one-act opera, "Bluebeard's Castle," at Carnegie Hall.
"His natural talent is cutting a deal that everybody can live with," said John C. Coffee Jr., a law professor at Columbia University. 
He has not always won unanimous praise for the deals he has cut. Some Vietnam veterans, for example, complained that the settlement in the Agent Orange case was too little and far too late. 
Mr. Feinberg says he still thinks of the Agent Orange case as a success, and has argued that the veterans faced an uphill fight and a very uncertain outcome in court. Indeed, he suggests that the families pondering whether to sue over the terrorist attacks face very similar odds. 
"I question whether anyone who opts out of this system has a meaningful alternative remedy," he said. "With the liability caps that Congress put in place for the airlines, the delay in getting to trial, the roll of the dice that you would face in court -- that is not a meaningful alternative."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kenneth R. Feinberg at a memorial across from the World Trade Center. (Richard Perry/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 2001 Bonuses On Wall Street Decline 30%, To $10 Billion 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
It's official: this year's bonuses for Wall Street workers will plunge by about 30 percent, to $10 billion, according to State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, whose office annually estimates bonus payments.
 The $4.3 billion decline -- the first since 1998 and far steeper than that year's drop -- means that some investment bankers may not be able to afford the new Jaguars of their dreams, and that their spouses may not find baubles from Harry Winston in their Christmas stockings. 
 But it has far broader implications for city government (that $4 billion got taxed at the highest rate) and for a lot of people whose jobs are far from Wall Street. Taxi drivers and florists, baby sitters and busboys, golf pros and travel agents, real estate brokers and antiques dealers: everyone who has benefited from the flood of Wall Street profits washing through the city may now be hurt by the turning tide. 
"It has a very big ripple effect for the employment and income of a lot of ordinary people who depend on it for their livelihoods," said Marcia Van Wagner, chief economist for the Citizens Budget Commission, a fiscal watchdog group.
And, she noted, the drop in bonuses comes on top of the dot-com bust, the national recession and the fallout from Sept. 11. "It may be a quadruple whammy," she said. "We're really getting it from all sides."
Mr. McCall's estimate of bonus payouts is based upon data that include industry profits and tax collections.
It is possible that the bonus pool could shrink even more than the comptroller's office has estimated. Complaints are seeping out from some big brokerage firms about bonuses that are half the amount of last year's.
And companies that traditionally pay out the bonuses in December and January still have time to cut them further, depending on what their fourth-quarter profits look like, said Frank Fernandez, chief economist for the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's trade group. At one large firm, the total bonus pool has shrunk by roughly 60 percent, he said.
Though not unexpected, the decline follows a decade of almost uninterrupted increases in Wall Street bonuses, which in 1991 totaled $4.1 billion. Turmoil in the bond market in 1998 trimmed bonuses slightly, to $9.7 billion from $11 billion, but they quickly rebounded to last year's record $14.3 billion, according to data from the comptroller's office.
Bonuses last year accounted for about a third of the pay on Wall Street, according to Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist of The New York STAT, a newsletter focusing on the city's economy.
And even though Wall Street jobs make up only 5 percent of the city's employment base, Wall Street workers pay about 15 percent of the city's main tax revenues, she said. City revenues per employee on Wall Street are almost three times the amount of those from workers in other industries.
Still, Ms. Denham said, "The bonus pool is really gravy, as opposed to meat and potatoes. Job retention is much more significant."
But the news there is not so good, either. Since its peak employment of 190,100 in August 2000, Wall Street had been slowly cutting jobs. That is, until October, when it lopped almost 16,000 positions, sending the number of jobs at securities firms to 165,400.
Some of those jobs -- the association estimates as many as 9,000 -- were simply moved to New Jersey. And perhaps half of them will return.
But Wall Street firms are still cutting. Mr. Fernandez said that his organization had heard of 8,000 or so more layoffs in the industry, and that the pattern had shown "that 95 percent of U.S. securities job losses have occurred in New York City."
None of this is good news for a city that is facing, next fiscal year, a $3.5 billion gap between revenues and spending. Nor is it good news for the housing market, especially the market for million-dollar-plus co-ops in Manhattan.
"The long and short of it is that this is New York City's key industry," said Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New YOrk. "And when there are problems in a key industry, it typically has a disproportionate effect on the economy."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Spending on Ads Is Down Sharply

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Advertising spending in major media fell 7.8 percent in the first nine months of 2001 as cutbacks by marketers accelerated, according to a report yesterday from CMR in New York, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.
 The 7.8 percent decline, to $68.8 billion from $74.7 billion in the period a year earlier, compared with a decline of 5.2 percent in the first quarter and 5.9 percent in the first half. 
 The medium affected the most by the spending decline in the first nine months was newspapers, down 21.5 percent, followed by national spot radio, down 18.6 percent, and spot television, down 17.9 percent.
The two advertisers spending the most on advertising so far this year -- General Motors and Philip Morris -- reduced spending by large amounts, 28.4 percent and 20.6 percent, respectively. Two advertisers in the top 10 increased ad spending: AOL Time Warner, up 11.9 percent, and Ford Motor, up 5.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Fiat Auto Chief Resigns in Midst of a Revamping 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
Roberto Testore, the chief executive of Fiat Auto, resigned today as Fiat S.p.A., the parent company, announced a restructuring plan.
 The restructuring by Fiat, the world's eighth-largest automaker in terms of vehicles sold, reflects the continued struggles of the global auto industry as economic conditions worsen. Fiat will close or overhaul 18 plants and lay off 6,000 workers worldwide by 2004 as part of the moves. 
 The Italian auto giant is in a situation somewhat similar to the Ford Motor Company. Ford and Fiat Auto have dismissed chief executives this year, and the two companies are expected to report annual net losses. Ford executives are also at work on a turnaround effort to return to profitability. 
The health of Fiat, by association, affects General Motors, since G.M. owns a 20 percent stake in Fiat Auto and Fiat owns 5.6 percent of G.M. as part of a relationship that extends to sharing power-train and purchasing operations in Europe.
Mr. Testore will be replaced by Giancarlo Boschetti, the chief executive of Iveco, a trucking company owned by Fiat S.p.A. Fiat Auto includes the Fiat brand, in addition to Alfa Romeo and Lancia, a European luxury line. None of the three brands' vehicles are currently sold in the United States, though there are plans to bring back Alfa Romeo to the United States in 2005. Fiat S.p.A. also owns the Ferrari brand and Maserati as part of a separate operating unit. 
Fiat said its restructuring plan would result in a charge of 800 million euros this year ($712.6 million using current exchange rates).
Fiat Auto will be broken into four distinct operating groups, the company said, in an attempt to reinforce its various brands. Fiat also projects that divestments from noncore businesses will be worth more than $2.2 billion. Fiat also said it would close two United States plants operated by its CNH unit, which makes farming and other machinery. 
Fiat S.p.A.'s auto sales in Western Europe fell 4.6 percent through the first 10 months of the year, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a data service. The company is expected to lose about 56 cents a share this year, according to Morgan Stanley, and its net debt soared in the third quarter from roughly $6.2 billion to $8.4 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roberto Testore, who resigned as chief executive for Fiat Auto. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Firm of Reagan Adviser Raises $1.4 Billion Fund 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 10 

 BODY:
Heartland Industrial Partners, a private equity firm started by a former Reagan administration official, David Stockman, finished raising a $1.4 billion fund with an investment from a Canadian pension plan. 
 The Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board said it would invest $150 million in the fund over six years. 
Heartland, which two years ago sought to raise $2 billion for the fund, aims to make acquisitions in auto parts and other manufacturing industries. In February, the firm paid $260 million for 60 percent of the Collins & Aikman Corporation, a maker of car interiors. 
 "These are capable people," Mark Weisdorf, vice president of private market investments for the Toronto-based board, said in an interview. "They are focusing on old-economy industrial, which fits in well with the portfolio we're developing." 
Mr. Stockman declined to comment on fund-raising. 
Heartland, with offices in Greenwich, and Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has nine partners, including a former Penske Corporation president, Timothy D. Leuliette, and the former Chase Securities leveraged-finance executive Daniel Tredwell, and 11 associates, according to its Web site.
Other investors in Heartland's fund include the state of Michigan's pension plan, J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, and American International Group Inc. 
Weisdorf said the Canadian pension plan, with private equity commitments of $700 million out of total assets of about $7.6 billion, will get the chance to make direct investments in Heartland acquisitions alongside the private equity firm.

HEADLINE: Delphi Automotive Will Cut 1,400 More Jobs 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Dec. 10 

 BODY:
The Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, the maker of auto parts, said today that it would eliminate 1,400 more jobs, on top of 11,500 cuts announced in March, as it reduces costs and as vehicle production slows.
 The job reductions will cost $150 million to $200 million, the company said. 
 The additional laid-off workers, representing less than 1 percent of the work force of 198,000, will leave in March and April through voluntary retirements and buyouts, Alan Dawes, the company's chief financial officer, said in an interview. 
Profit next year excluding those expenses will be $275 million, compared with a forecast of $200 million to $225 million for 2001, as sales decline about 2 percent, to $25.5 billion, the company said.
Delphi's biggest customer, the General Motors Corporation, its former parent, and other automakers expect consumers to buy fewer cars and trucks as no-interest loan offers end next month and the economy slows.
Shares of Delphi, based in Troy, fell 76 cents, to $13.39. 
Delphi said it was still considering selling or closing businesses with about $3.4 billion in annual revenue, including its instrument cluster and sensor unit and its Harrison Thermal Systems division. Together, the two units have about 12,130 workers in the United States, Mexico, Europe, South America and Asia.
The company said it was in talks with several potential buyers for some or all of its instrument-cluster business, which has annual sales of $500 million, and expects a sale in the middle of next year. The business has about 1,780 workers in plants in the United States and Mexico.
Delphi is also looking to restructure its Harrison Thermal Systems division, with about 10,350 workers, to improve profitability and productivity. The company reached a local agreement in Lockport, N.Y., last month that allows it to cut costs through productivity improvements, exit some older product lines and combine some operations including closing a warehouse.
The company recently agreed to sell its $500 million generator business to Delco Remy International Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Delphi said it expected the sale to close at the end of the year and will result in a book loss of $130 million to $150 million.

HEADLINE: Big Steel: An Invalid That Can Roar In Washington 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
Trying to keep their long downward slide from becoming a death spiral, the nation's old-line steel makers are pressing the federal government for special treatment granted to almost no other industry.
 They are almost certainly overreaching, analysts say. And even if the industry succeeds in getting what it wants, the plan would do little more, critics say, than put off the day when it succumbs to subsidized foreign rivals and a nimble new breed of domestic competitors that oppose granting big steel makers the concessions they are seeking. 
 The steel makers want trade protection from low-priced imports. They want the United States to put pressure on other nations to scale back their steel-making capacity. They want billions of dollars in taxpayer money to help pay health and pension benefits. And they want assurances that their proposal to merge many of the American industry's biggest companies into a bigger, more efficient competitor will not run into antitrust problems. 
While unlikely to get everything they want, the big steel makers are getting enough encouragement in Washington to make it worth the effort. That reflects their political power as well as an environment after the September attacks in which nearly any industry that can associate its plight with national or economic security can get a hearing from the two parties.
Aware that President Bush's re-election hopes in 2004 could hinge on his success in steel-making states like Pennsylvania, which went for Al Gore last year, and West Virginia, which went for Mr. Bush, the White House has encouraged the industry on several levels.
Despite his strong stance in favor of free trade, Mr. Bush has actively pursued sanctions against nations judged to be dumping steel in this country below cost, and is expected to impose tariffs and quotas on them in the next several months. His economic team will again press other nations to end government subsidies and shut down excess steel-making capacity during a round of international talks this week.
Even before the USX Corporation and a number of other major steel makers said last week that they were considering merging, the White House had been quietly encouraging the industry to consolidate, industry executives and union leaders said.
But the administration signaled after the announcement that it was wary of embracing some other elements of the consolidation plan, including the call for billions of dollars to help pay a huge bill for retiree health and pension benefits.
It would be hard enough for the administration to reconcile what amounts to an expensive bailout with its professed free-market principles and its stated disdain for government handouts to business.
Moreover, supporting the full plan would be tricky because it is opposed by a newer and smaller class of steel companies known as mini-mills, which are no longer so small and are usually far more efficient than the operations of the older companies. Big consumers of steel are also wary of the plan.
And if the consolidation plan were to involve large-scale layoffs, it could also lose the support of steel workers' unions.
"The president is aware of the serious problems facing the steel industry," a White House spokeswoman, Claire Buchan, said. "We're listening to USX and to others involved in the industry, including unions and consumers. There is a range of views among those involved in the industry."
The help they are seeking, companies like the US Steel Group of USX, Bethlehem Steel and Wheeling-Pittsburgh say, would provide the industry time to whip itself into the kind of shape needed to survive and prosper, and allow the United States to maintain the steel industry, a core element of its industrial base.
The American industry today is a shell of its former self. In the last few years, 25 steel companies have filed for bankruptcy protection. Employment in the last two decades has fallen to around 150,000 from 450,000.
While steel making remains an economic force and a way of life in states like Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Indiana, it has largely faded in other places.
A century ago, Birmingham, Ala., was so proud of its steel-making prowess that it commissioned a 56-foot statue of Vulcan, the god of fire and metal-working, and for nearly 100 years the statue overlooked the city from a 124-foot pedestal atop Red Mountain. But the Birmingham Steel Corporation suffered the indignity this fall of having its shares delisted from the New York Stock Exchange for failing to maintain required levels of financial strength. And Vulcan, tarnished and rusting away, was taken down and sent off for repairs.
Still, Rust Belt politics remain compelling for both parties, giving Big Steel and its workers an opening in Washington. To push their case, the big steel makers have hired a number of the best-connected Republican lobbyists, including Ed Gillespie, who advised the Bush campaign and has close ties to the White House.
A bill introduced in the House earlier this year by Representative Peter J. Visclosky, Democrat of Indiana, would give the industry much of what it wants from the federal government.
One provision would grant the steel makers $2.4 billion over the next three years to pay 80 percent of the health care benefits promised by the big companies to retirees, many of whom stop working before they become eligible for Medicare at 65.
Mr. Visclosky's bill picked up 226 co-sponsors from both parties, a majority of the House, though the Republican leadership has so far kept it from coming to the floor.
In contrast to the Clinton administration, which angered steel companies and unions by refusing to pursue the antidumping trade case aggressively, Mr. Bush has handled the case much as the industry is seeking. And the industry has allies both among Democrats sympathetic to union pleas to preserve jobs and from Republicans who cast the issue in other terms.
"This is an industry that has significant national security implications," said Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania. "It's important from the whole basic concept of maintaining manufacturing in this country. It's important to have a vibrant domestic source of steel."
Allowing the industry to be liquidated, Mr. Santorum said, "would put this country on a path to overdependence, similar to oil, on foreign sources."
Some analysts, and the competitors of the big steel companies, said the industry was simply looking for corporate welfare.
"The large companies who are talking about consolidating are marching down death row," said Robert W. Crandall, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "This is not going to revive them. We're really talking about how to continue the orderly decline of these big producers who are now down to half the capacity of what they were 25 years ago."
The argument that the old-line steel companies are vital on national or economic security grounds is "absolute baloney," Mr. Crandall said. One or two mills, he said, could provide all the steel plate needed for armor or shipbuilding.
The trade group for the mini-mill industry, the Steel Manufacturers Association, is trying to develop some political influence of its own as it battles the big steel makers, pointing out to the administration and Congress that its members operate in 126 of 435 Congressional districts and employ 120,000 people.
"The majority of our industry is not in favor of bailing out a few steel companies that mismanaged their assets," said Thomas A. Danjczek, the association's president. "Combining several companies that failed to earn their cost of capital doesn't mean the new company will be able to do it. It's like two garbage trucks colliding."

HEADLINE: Tom Daschle Isn't the Problem 

 BODY:
The closing days of this year's Congressional session have brought forth a wild Republican campaign to demonize Senator Tom Daschle. It almost seems as if the G.O.P. is holding a contest to see who can most often use the word "obstructionist" to describe him. The attacks -- including ads in Mr. Daschle's home state of South Dakota featuring side-by-side photographs of him and Saddam Hussein -- are a sure sign of the Senate majority leader's effectiveness in blocking President Bush's hard-right agenda. Today Mr. Bush meets with Mr. Daschle at the White House, where they can move beyond vilification to legislation. 
 The word "obstructionist," voiced over the weekend by Vice President Dick Cheney, has an unreal ring. Perhaps Mr. Cheney was in a remote, secure location when, after Sept. 11 and with Mr. Daschle's help, Congress passed a use-of-force resolution, a $40 billion emergency spending bill, an airline bailout, a counterterrorism bill and an airport security bill. The Senate has also passed 13 appropriations bills and its own version of education reform and a patients' bill of rights. The two things that Mr. Cheney cited that the Senate had "obstructed" were legislation to drill for energy in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and a "stimulus" bill to give out huge tax breaks to corporations and rich people. 
 Mr. Cheney and Mr. Bush have called for bipartisan cooperation in Congress. Yet when asked, the vice president declined to disavow the attack ads running in South Dakota that accused Mr. Daschle of helping the Iraqi dictator by blocking the destruction of the Alaska reserve. 
The suspicion is growing in some quarters in Washington that Mr. Bush may not really want economic stimulus legislation. How else to explain that the White House is sticking with a bill, passed by the House, that many Republicans say privately they would just as soon abandon? The effect of spending less than $100 billion to jolt a $10 trillion economy is likely to be small, and the unnecessary tax breaks aimed at corporations and the wealthy would make the nation's upcoming deficits even worse. But there are some good ideas in some versions of the stimulus bill that should be passed, irrespective of their large-scale economic impact. These pieces would provide unemployment and health benefits to laid off workers who desperately need help after Sept. 11.
If Mr. Bush continues to be inflexible on the economic package, Mr. Daschle should switch tactics and attach the health and jobless benefits to some other bill before Congress adjourns near Christmas. It would be a travesty to ignore the real needs of the most vulnerable Americans at a time like this one. You might even say it was obstructionist.

HEADLINE: Social Security Panel Presents Options but No Unified Plan 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 

 BODY:
Bedeviled by the arithmetic and politics of putting the retirement system on a sound footing, President Bush's Social Security commission will take up its final report on Tuesday without having reached a consensus on how to implement the administration's goal of allowing workers to invest part of their payroll taxes on Wall Street.
 A draft of the commission's final report, made public late today, set out a menu of options for adding personal investment accounts to the retirement system, including one that would do little to address Social Security's long-term financial problems and two others that would rely on substantial cuts in the current guaranteed benefit. 
 The commission's chairmen, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the former Democratic senator from New York, and Richard D. Parsons, a Republican who last week was named the next chief executive of AOL Time Warner, suggested another approach in their introduction to the report. 
They said the government could set up a voluntary system in which workers contributed one percent of their earnings beyond their current payroll taxes, matched by an equivalent amount from the government, to be paid for out of general revenues at a cost to taxpayers of $40 billion a year. 
Such an approach is similar to one advocated by the Clinton administration several years ago. In putting it forward again, Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Parsons appeared to be acknowledging the political difficulties of moving forward anytime soon on the types of plans the current administration has favored, which are based on using current levels of payroll taxes.
Critics of Mr. Bush's approach said the report showed that it was impossible to create personal accounts without some combination of deep cuts in guaranteed benefits or additional revenues that would ultimately come from taxpayers.
Peter R. Orszag, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, the liberal-leaning research group, said that in the report's fine print was an assumption that the commission's plans would rely in part on benefit cuts not just to Social Security's retirement benefits but also the disability insurance program. If anything, the disability program has been considered more politically sacrosanct than the system's old-age component.
Members of the commission said they expected to approve the report on Tuesday and send it to the White House at the end of the week after some final technical revisions.
Whether anything will come of the report, the latest in a long line on the issue from inside and outside the government, is unclear. 
Republicans in Congress said they had no intention of taking it up next year, when the midterm Congressional elections will be held, out of concern that Mr. Bush's support for personal accounts would bring intense attacks from Democrats. 
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said Social Security might not be at the top of the legislative calendar next year, as the president had originally hoped, "given the fact that we now have a recession and a war." 
But he said Mr. Bush was not backing off his approach on either substantive or political grounds.
"The president believes very much that one of the reasons he won the presidency was because he took a bold position on Social Security," Mr. Fleischer said.
The commission members defended the report as providing Mr. Bush and Congress with an array of choices that could be the basis for a broader national debate over how to prepare Social Security for the financial strains caused by the aging of the population and longer life spans. 
"It's true the commission didn't coalesce around one of these plans," said Estelle James, an economist at the World Bank and a member of the commission. "But this is an important social choice. We need to have a broader discussion about which way we want to go. I hope we've moved the ball forward by clarifying the choices and tradeoffs."
In laying out a variety of approaches rather than a single comprehensive recommendation, the panel's 16 members appeared to have fudged on the president's original charge to them.
Introducing the members of the commission in May, Mr. Bush said their goal was to take his basic principles -- including putting Social Security on sound footing for the long run and creating personal investment accounts that would allow workers to accumulate wealth -- and turn them into "concrete reforms."
"What we were really trying to do is lay out methods of designing, establishing and implementing personal accounts in the context of improving the fiscal sustainability of Social Security," said Olivia S. Mitchell, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School and a member of the commission.
"What we've all come to after intense study and analysis is that it's feasible to do that," Professor Mitchell said. "Some people have charged that personal accounts of necessity make the problem worse. We argue that there are many ways to design a personal account and improve the fiscal sustainability of Social Security."

HEADLINE: A Sales Tax Holiday 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Recovery and the Reluctant Consumer" (Business Day, Dec. 10):
Without an increase in consumer confidence, the recession might linger like a bad case of the flu that we just can't shake. 
 Congress is considering a bipartisan proposal that could help: a national sales tax holiday. This is a simple, proven proposal, used by several states, including New York. 
 For a designated period of time in January or February, one of the slowest spending periods of the year, state sales taxes could be suspended. The federal government would reimburse states for lost revenue. This idea has strong bipartisan support. Suspending this tax will give families and businesses a welcome boost.

DARRELL MCKIGNEY
President
Small Business Survival Committee
Washington, Dec. 10, 2001

SUBJECT: SALES TAX (92%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); TAXES & TAXATION (90%); LETTERS & COMMENTS (90%); RECESSION (90%); TAX RELIEF (90%); CONSUMER CONFIDENCE (88%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (87%); TAX LAW (87%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (74%); SMALL BUSINESS (73%); INFLUENZA (71%) TAXATION; UNITED STATES ECONOMY; SALES TAX

HEADLINE: How Low Will They Go? 

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER

 BODY:
LAST year when the Hudson Cafeteria opened, no one blinked an eye at the $28.50 macaroni and cheese with seared foie gras. No, New Yorkers waited in line for it like horses at a trough. Diners, by then, had grown used to $32 roast chicken and $15 shrimp cocktail. It was the price of admission to the newest restaurants, even when the chef was just out of cooking school.
 But this season, things seem to be shifting. The restaurants that are opening share the ambition typical of a new place, and something else, too. They are all markedly less expensive, many with entrees that dip into the high teens and rarely inch above $24. The days of breaking the $30 price ceiling seem, for the moment at least, to have vanished. 
 That doesn't mean, however, that fine cooking is going with it. At Moda, the menu is sprinkled with tempting dishes like fennel-crusted pork loin for $18 and grilled quail with polenta for $24. You can have strip steak at SQC on the Upper West Side for $23 and turmeric-scented striped bass at TanDa on Park Avenue South for $24. 
There is also Marseille, which recently opened on Ninth Avenue. The owners hired Alex Urena, a chef who won wide acclaim at Blue Hill and trained with Ferran Adria in Spain. Mr. Urena has turned out a menu that feels like a vibrant weave of Jean Georges and El Bulli, with a finely layered vegetable terrine and peanut butter tart with celery ice cream and celery foam for $7 each, and poached foie gras for $1 more. The most expensive dish is the bouillabaisse. Ample pieces of rouget, shrimp, mussels and cod are neatly arranged in the center of a bowl, and the warm broth is poured over at the table. All for $24. 
A new, more tame menu, said Josh Moulton, an owner of Moda in Midtown, is a visceral reaction to the price creep that had been infecting menus throughout the city. 
"I felt like every ambitious opening that had occurred over the past two years had just upped the ante," Mr. Moulton said. "Prices were getting higher and higher, and the $30 entree was becoming the norm, not the exception, and frankly I know how much chicken costs. And I understand that when people stuff it with truffles and foie gras it gets up there, but a great roast chicken is a great roast chicken and it doesn't go for more than three bucks a pound." 
(In fact, what some chefs consider the best chicken of all, from Four Story Hill Farm in Pennsylvania, was only $3.29 a pound last year, Mr. Moulton said.)
"I think there's sort of an emotional impact when an entree is over $30," Paul Bolles-Beaven, a partner at Union Square Cafe said, "and everyone knows you're not paying more because the fish or the foie gras costs more."
Restaurateurs pay close attention to food cost, which is the percentage of a dish's price spent on ingredients. Most restaurants aim to keep it under 30 percent, which tends to be easier for Italian restaurants with lower-cost ingredients like pasta. According to a study last year for the New York State Restaurant Association, the average food cost of more than 1,000 higher-end restaurants in New York City was 30.91 percent.
Tolerance for the emotional impact of inflated prices, even without a lagging economy, was bound to wear thin. And despite an enormous push for status items like truffles and caviar on menus a few years ago, restaurateurs have found that most diners do not necessarily want foie gras to sustain them. "I find it so interesting that at the same time that American dining ambition and food knowledge has risen," Mr. Moulton added, "people still want to have a good, nourishing meal."
This has been proven by more expensive restaurants like Babbo, which took flavorful parts like beef cheeks, goose liver and head cheese and gave them the stylish urgency of foams. Since Tom Valenti, an owner of Ouest, began braising lamb shanks, they probably had not enjoyed such attention since the Middle Ages. Now it's hard to find a bistro or brasserie without them.
Cooking with these cuts of meat, though, is also a way to save money. "You can do a rib-eye steak," Chris Russell, an owner of TanDa, said, "which is a delicious piece of meat, instead of filet mignon. You can use a lamb shank instead of a rack of lamb. You can do a similar preparation, and the flavor will still be delicious, but the food cost will be 80 percent less." 
It is no surprise then to find sauteed calf's liver with Swiss chard for $18 as an entree at the Harrison, or beef cheeks with Israeli couscous for $18 at Marseille. 
Sometimes it is just a matter of responding to the mood of diners. When Mr. Russell owned Moomba, for instance, prices were higher across the board. He charged $8 for a bottle of San Pellegrino sparkling water at Moomba; at TanDa, it's $7. And at Hudson Cafeteria, the price of that macaroni and cheese with foie gras is now $26.
There are other techniques for curbing prices that give you the option to spend a lot if you so choose. At SQC, Scott Campbell, an owner, said the menu "is deconstructed where food is at different price points."
"There are people who don't want to spend more than $16 for an entree," he said, "so there's an intermediate category." While the strip steak is $23, most other dishes hover around $20. If you don't feel like splurging for the steak, you can still have beef, in the ravioli with oxtail and marrow for $16.
Right after you are seated at Marseille, a waiter encourages you to order a "mezze" while you are still choosing appetizers and entrees. Each mezze consists of three tiny plates of tastes like piquillo peppers, zucchini blossom with basil and white bean bruschetta. Most are about $8. What you may not realize, though, is that what they are doing essentially is asking you to pay for your amuse-bouche. It's fair enough, though, since you are being charged as little as $16 for a main course of poached duck. 
The appetizers at Marseille, which range from $7 to $12, and desserts, which are $7, also give strength to their efforts. It is not that common. Mr. Bolles-Beaven added, "I've been to restaurants where it's obvious they've increased their appetizer prices as much as possible to make up for not having entrees over $30."
In many cases, though, it's not about being clever. The lamb with white beans and escarole at Moda is just $27. "Let's face it," Mr. Moulton, a partner, said. "Beans and escarole are not that expensive. So the only thing I'm really paying for is the lamb."
Mr. Moulton said Moda looked to other restaurants as a model. "When you look downtown, you're getting people like Wylie Dufresne at 71 Clinton, where you're getting really high-quality food and good service in a less precious setting."
Mr. Dufresne, who opened 71 Clinton in 1999, has never charged more than $26 for any dish. But he also works with higher costs. Most restaurants aim for a 27 to 28 percent food cost; his is 31 to 32 percent.
"Part of the $30 entree," he said, "goes into the plate itself, and the glass and silver. I don't see that as the future. I think the grand restaurants will endure, but I think what people want is they want to eat that kind of food in a casual kind of atmosphere."
Mr. Dufresne was not the only pioneer. Before the economy started to slip, other restaurants began adopting a similar approach. After Anne Rosenzweig closed the Lobster Club, she opened Inside with her chef, Charleen Badman. Much of the food is in the same style as a the Lobster Club, but with a more focused, less expensive menu. 
As these restaurants proliferate, though, a distinction needs to be made. Many people associate welcoming, reasonably priced restaurants with comfort food. 
"Either you feel welcome and you're taken care of, or you're not," said Jimmy Bradley, an owner of the Harrison. "Somewhere along the way someone needs to work on rephrasing comfort food. I don't think people are all that interested in comfort food. I think they're interested in being taken care of and perceived value."
They would like to eat well, and not go home with a knot in their stomach. Perhaps it's not that much to ask of places created to feed one's hunger.

(Photographs by Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)(pg. F16) Drawing (Salih Memecan)(pg. F1)
