HEADLINE: A Temple Where Wine and Food Are the Deities 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: NAPA, Calif. 

 BODY:
THE good life is a religion in Northern California. Now, it finally has a temple.
 With profundities etched in limestone and all-organic grounds inspired by the kitchen gardens of a Loire chateau, the world's most wildly ambitious cultural institution devoted to wine, food and the arts opened its doors last month in this gritty river town. In nonabundant times, the 80,000-square-foot museum -- founded by Robert Mondavi, who gave $20 million -- bears the name Copia: The American Center of Wine, Food and the Arts, after the Roman goddess of abundance. 
 Copia is not America's first museum devoted to food and drink. The proud heritage includes the Nut Museum in Old Lyme, Conn.; the Catfish Capitol museum in Belzoni, Miss., and the Museum of Pez Memorabilia in nearby Burlingame. But Copia is a new invention entirely -- a "conceptual museum," in the words of its director, Peggy A. Loar, that aims to be a sort of Museum of Modern Art for eaters and drinkers. Even the restaurant, with organic vegetables and herbs from the museum garden, has a quasi-educational function (if you can manage to get a table). 
The $55 million center inhabits 12 acres along the Napa River and was designed by James Stewart Polshek, the New York architect whose work includes Bill Clinton's presidential library in Little Rock, Ark. It has an outdoor cooking pavilion, an amphitheater for classes on sparkling wines or how to cook hoppin' John, a vast exhibition space and an extensive edible garden that will probably become a destination in itself.
It is stunningly ambitious in concept and, judging by its opening exhibitions, extremely tricky in execution, veering from the down-to-earth to the esoteric and the wacky. It is probably safe to say that only at Copia would a two-piece Han dynasty stove cohabit with mannequins dressed in two-piece suits weighed down with a hundred pounds of plastic grapes.
Already, just three weeks after opening, it has its detractors, among them the working-class residents of the town of Napa who feel trod upon by their richer Napa Valley neighbors. Others have been concerned about the possibility that those connected with the museum could use it to promote their food and wine. 
Copia's emergence in these parts seems apt. Perhaps only in Northern California do family garages double as wineries and neighborhood potlucks as culinary gridirons.
"There is nothing in Europe like Copia, except for a crummy little museum in the South of France," said Julia Child, who at age 89 recently became a full-time Californian and has donated her copper pots -- every shrine needs relics -- to the museum. "I think it's wonderful we're the people who thought of it," she added. "But you couldn't have it in North Dakota."
Rising in an unfashionable stretch next to a Beverage Warehouse, the center was conceived not only as a highbrow cultural institution but as a linchpin for the revitalization of Napa, a city of 73,000 that has long been the handmaiden to the upper valley's plutocratic glamour. Its more subtle aim is to market fine wine to the 4.5 million tourists who come to the wine country each year.
ALTHOUGH still a work in progress -- think of it as a two-minute egg -- Copia's reach is difficult to overstate. Its peculiar zen is inscribed in limestone: "Wine and food speak not only to the palate, but to the mind and the deeper domain of the heart."
Mr. Polshek's building is a pull-out-the-stops architectural statement, with a fieldstone wall recalling old-school Napa wineries and an abstract undulating metal roof. Mr. Polshek, who also designed the Rose Center for Earth and Space in Manhattan, calls his contemporary form, which echoes a bend in the river, "a great croissant."
The gardens are three and a half resplendently edible organic acres set into gridded parterres. It's hard not to be moved by the sight of 40 varieties of lavender, 30 varieties of wine grapes, 20 varieties of carrots, olive groves, aromatic wine gardens and ethnic vegetable gardens dedicated to Asians, Italians and other American pilgrims. It is California writ small.
But things get more complicated inside. You are greeted by the Circle of the Senses, flashing video images of cascading cornflakes and other foods set to jazz. Nearby a holiday exhibition of vintage tableware includes turkey-shaped chocolate molds -- on loan from Martha Stewart. 
To Ms. Loar, the center's director, the museum's purview is no less than "the whole spectrum of civilization, including abundance and scarcity." (She fought for the short, "poppy" name). "I think of this place as a conceptual museum, a museum of ideas," she said. "It's about agriculture and material culture, about earth to table." The food curator, Daphne Derven, calls it "intellectual nourishment."
Begin, say, with a half-hour lecture on the Meyer lemon, a segment of which is arranged at 3 o'clock on your plate. Then move on to "Making Scents of Wine" -- a sort of "Northern California for Dummies" -- a seminar on aroma by the museum's wine curator, Peter Marks, formerly chief wine merchant at wine.com. Learn about retronasal passages in the back of the mouth and how to detect a burnt rubber smell in your pinot noir.
Wander upstairs to "Active Ingredients," a temporary exhibition for which conceptual artists created works examining our contemporary relationship to food and drink. Notice the sculpture of molten caramel by a San Francisco sculptor, Gay Outlaw -- her real name -- whose previous work includes a 34-foot-long serpentine wall of encased fruitcakes. (She studied pastry at La Varenne in Paris.) Her work here, meant to evoke the optical patterns of vineyards along the highway, is composed of 1,300 pounds of melted sugar and 80 gallons of corn syrup suspended on springs, suggesting, we are told, "the temporal nature of perception and even existence."
More accessible perhaps is the core exhibition, "Forks in the Road," an interactive exploration of attitudes toward food.
On a recent afternoon, many museumgoers lunched first at Julia's Kitchen, the museum's main restaurant, which is named for Ms. Child, an honorary trustee of the center. The menu, with prices up to $26 for grilled Black Angus New York steak, includes numerous wines and seared foies gras and doubtlessly accounted for the elevated noise level and palpably jolly mood. Ms. Child, incidentally, said, "I didn't do anything at all to develop the restaurant," including supply any recipes or dishes. It is run by Seasoned Elements, a branch of a San Francisco catering company.
The exhibition includes poignant recollections of family gatherings by ordinary people and numerous interactive kiosks, including one with cascading beads resembling a hippie voting booth in which visitors are asked to identify foods prized elsewhere that they'd prefer to hide under their napkins. (Seal blubber? Calf brains?) Another asks visitors to identify cross sections of candy bars. "I know the C.E.O. of a very large software company who will do anything for a Reese's," said Angel I. Ferrer, a software developer from Alexandria, Va.
Serious issues concerning hunger, genetically altered foods, agribusiness and body image are addressed, but fleetingly. In a not-so-subtle bit of lobbying, the wisdom of restricting wine consumption to people 21 and over is also raised as a question.
The center, 12 years in the making, has been the consuming passion of Mr. Mondavi, a son of Italian immigrants, who founded it with his wife, Margrit Biever Mondavi, a native Napan. Some 40 vintners have also become major donors. At lunchtime, the din of clattering silverware wafts past the Wine Spectator Tasting Table in the Beringer Vineyard Atrium.
Mr. Mondavi, who has also recently donated $25 million to the University of California at Davis for a wine and food science institute and a performing arts center, each bearing his name, makes no bones about his motives. "We wanted to have a place where you could enjoy life and learn how to enhance your life," he said. "We wanted the center to combine all three -- wine, food and art -- to show that in moderation, wine is healthy and good for you, going back to the Egyptians and Romans."
Critics, many of whom have not yet visited, have expressed initial concern over whether the museum will maintain its independence from its backers. "There could be a strange fuzzy line between the supporters who've put in a ton of money and the museum itself," said Patricia Unterman, who is the chef and an owner of the Hayes Street Grill in San Francisco and a food writer.
Fears by some competitors that the high-profile museum might star the wines of Mr. Mondavi and other donors prompted an esoteric piece of legislation, which became law last year. Sponsored by State Senator Wesley Chesbro, who represents a wide swath of wine country, it prevents Copia from pouring or selling private-label wines in its gift shop, Cornucopia, or pouring them in its educational programs. It can dispense wine only under a generic Copia label. Part of the bill's purpose was "to prevent Copia from promoting those vintners who serve on its board of directors," Senator Chesbro said. "Museum ethics always require an arm's length between donors and your artistic purpose," said Kurt Nystrom, the center's deputy director. "It's a minefield every museum has to tread across."
More contentious perhaps has been the museum's reception among longtime Napans. Now the glittering centerpiece of a $300 million flood control project, financed by the federal government and a local sales tax, Copia has served as a symbol of change and a flash point for resentment in a town where the goddess of abundance has spent precious little time.
The cultural divide between this blue-collar city, which is 30 percent Hispanic, and "upvalley," with its $350-a-night country inns and charmed sybaritic life, is "strong and powerful," said Moira Johnston Block, founder of the Friends of the Napa River, which campaigned for Copia. An invisible psychic line has long separated laborers, many of whom live in Napa, from the Valley. Last summer 10 emergency yurts were erected to house migrant workers in Yountville about a mile from the French Laundry.
NAPA grew up along the river, which flooded regularly. Many residents were shipyard workers who commuted to Mare Island, about 20 miles away. When the shipyard closed in the early 1990's, it devastated the community. "We kind of lingered," said Ed Henderson, the mayor.
The city's riverine lifeblood became a repository of wrecked autos, chemicals, tannery wastes and other pollutants. Like many people here, George A. Elicker, whose great-grandparents came from Scotland in 1868, views the center, with its $12.50 admission fee, as "a monument to Mondavi, definitely not for the common people." At the local Mervyns discount store, a former forewoman at the Mondavi winery, who did not want her name used, put it this way: "Those who have money are for it. Those who don't are against it."
The center is a fork in the road. To Ms. Johnston Block and others, Mr. Mondavi's decision to put the museum in downtown Napa -- as urged by his second wife, Margrit, who raised her children here -- created "an anchor tenant for a revitalized Napa." Though the museum was not predicated on river restoration or flood control, the measure passed by residents in 1998 will restore the river to health and create seven miles of riverside trails.
Others are following suit: Francis Ford Coppola, a fellow vintner, is restoring the city's 1937 movie palace, the Uptown Theater, with a partner, and Mr. Mondavi has contributed to both the Oxbow School, a private art school for high school students, and the restoration of the 1879 Napa Valley Opera House, to be renamed, much to the chagrin of Mr. Elicker, the Margrit Biever Mondavi Opera House.
All this serves up some major challenges and opportunities for the museum. It must not only bridge the local divide but also, in changed economic and social times, walk an increasingly fine line between abundance and indulgence.
"There's a message that sometimes emanates from Northern California that the way to do good for the world is to eat gourmet food," said Warren Belasco, a food historian and a professor of American studies at the University of Maryland at Baltimore. "Maybe we have to give up stuff."
Since the terrorist attacks, said Barbara Haber, curator of books at the Schlesinger Library at Harvard University, "people want to be together more -- they're cherishing the everyday." Food and drink, she said, are inherently populist subjects. "Done well," she said, "the center can be meaningful and full of human sentiment, especially after an overabundant 1990's. It's not just a palace of gastronomy."
Ms. Loar said she is committed to tackling "not hoity-toity" subjects. For example, the museum might collaborate with economists from the University of California at Davis, one of three institutional partners, on an exhibition to help ordinary people shop more economically at the grocery store.
Right now there are some empty calories. Forthcoming exhibitions include a major show on teapots and "Sweet Tooth," which will feature paintings and sculpture related to desserts, materials to include gnawed chocolate. Next month, the Asian influence on the American table will be explored in cooking classes in the Asian garden and in seminars on subjects like sake and haiku.
Clark Wolf, a New York restaurant consultant, called the opening of Copia "a moment of record." But, he added, "it does have to prove itself."
"The key will be keeping it grounded and unpretentious," he said. "I'm nervous about someone out curating tomatoes."
In the end, it may be important to bear in mind that Julia Child's favorite food is baked potatoes.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
An Economic Recovery Will Tell in the Classroom

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE relation between family circumstances and a child's academic proficiency is well known, but policymakers usually assume that if all children can be held to the same standards, the achievement gap between rich and poor will eventually disappear. We pay too little attention to how social and economic forces themselves influence learning.
 Unemployment has now risen to 5.7 percent, up from less than 4 percent in October 2000. The biggest downturns have been in low-wage industries like hotels and restaurants. More job losses are expected. 
 If the past is any guide, rising unemployment will cause children's school performance to decline, but commentators will attribute the drop entirely to poor teachers, low standards or overcrowded schools. Educators will watch from the sidelines as Congress debates unemployment insurance or the timing of a stimulus package.
But these debates are not only about the economy. They will affect education. And steps to soften the recession could aid school performance.
Social science supports the common-sense idea that family stress has an impact on children; few stresses are as dangerous as a parent's job loss. Glen H. Elder, a professor at the University of North Carolina, found that unemployment in the 1930's often led to a deterioration in child-rearing practices. Some fathers who lost jobs became irritable, tense and moody. Their disciplinary styles became more arbitrary and punitive. Their children's aspirations and school performance then fell. The effects were even worse when job loss led to conflicts between husband and wife.
Studies of youth since the Great Depression confirm Dr. Elder's findings. Adolescent boys in families suffering sudden unemployment are more likely to be delinquent and use drugs. Girls are more likely to lose self-confidence and be depressed. In the already difficult middle school years, children of the unemployed are more likely to get into fights and refuse to complete schoolwork.
Unemployment also affects younger children, perhaps more than older ones. Under economic pressure, some mothers rely less on reasoning and more on threats, hostile comments and physical punishment. These can lead to children's emotional problems and lower academic performance.
The psychological impacts of job loss are compounded by more material ones. Nutrition and health care can suffer, especially for children of the low-income unemployed who are without the resources to cushion sudden hardship. These setbacks can harm cognitive ability. Loss of housing can force children to change schools, losing continuity of instruction. If families move to smaller apartments, or even to shelters, loss of study space can result.
In contrast, students probably do better when family incomes go up. School leaders take pride in the test-score improvements of recent years for low-income children. But school reforms may not have been entirely responsible for such gains in the strong economy of the 1990's. Some children may have had better nutrition and health care, more adequate and stable housing, and more patient parents, all of which nurtured learning.
A conclusion that economic security affects achievement is backed up in a new analysis by a team led by Eric Dearing, a Harvard researcher, showing that when poor families' income increases, their young children's readiness for school also goes up. Typically, low-income children enter school with fewer social and literacy skills than other children. But it is hard to say how much of this stems from income itself. Perhaps poor children do worse because their mothers have less education. If so, then raising family income would not in itself lead to more learning.
What is unusual about Dr. Dearing's work is his showing that school readiness improves in poor families whose incomes go up in comparison to the readiness of children who are similar in other respects except for the income gain.
Dr. Dearing's conclusion buttresses findings of studies done of mothers who move from welfare to work. These show that children's achievement improves if family income increases but may not when mothers do not gain substantially higher income. These analyses also reinforce the results of experiments conducted by the Nixon administration more than a quarter-century ago. Then, poor families were randomly selected to receive income supplements and their children's school performance improved.
It would be comforting to think that schools alone could raise achievement for low-income students, but such a shortcut is illusory. As shepherds of schoolchildren, educators have a stake in promoting a federal economic policy that focuses on immediate income support for the unemployed, because this in itself could make instruction more effective.

HEADLINE: Text of Federal Reserve's Statement 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, its monetary policy panel, said it would lower interest rates for the 11th time this year: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 1.75 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 25-basis-point reduction in the discount rate, to 1.25 percent. 
 Economic activity remains soft, with underlying inflation likely to edge lower from relatively modest levels. To be sure, weakness in demand shows signs of abating, but those signs are preliminary and tentative. The committee continues to believe that, against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future. 
Although the necessary reallocation of resources to enhance security may restrain advances in productivity for a time, the long-term prospects for productivity growth and the economy remain favorable and should become evident once the unusual forces restraining demand abate. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved the requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Chicago and San Francisco. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Another Rate Cut From the Fed 

 BODY:
An economic recovery may be on the horizon, but don't expect things to get frothy any time soon. That was the Federal Reserve Board's message to financial markets yesterday, as it cut overnight interest rates yet again, this time by a quarter of a percentage point. It was the 11th cut this year, bringing the rate down to 1.75 percent, below the rate of inflation and its lowest level in more than four decades. While noting that the economy remains soft, the central bank also indicated, for the first time, that it sees signs that the slump may be ending. 
 Once the current recession is over, Americans may be in for a period of lackluster growth. Lingering hopes for a dramatic "V-shaped" recovery, whereby the economy rockets back to its torrid late-90's pace, seem unrealistic. In an effort to stem the recent rise in longer-term interest rates, the Fed noted that inflation is likely to edge even lower. 
 The current recession is unusual because it was precipitated by a slowdown in capital spending by overextended businesses, instead of by weakening consumer demand. Indeed, under the circumstances, consumer spending has held up relatively well. Capitalizing on interest-free loans offered by car makers, consumers made October the best month ever, improbably enough, for vehicle sales.
All this means that the recovery anticipated by Wall Street, when it comes, may be lackluster. Business investment may pick up, but there will not be the kind of pent-up consumer demand associated with robust recoveries. The economy may drift, even as it ceases contracting. 
Last Friday the Labor Department reported a loss of 331,000 jobs during November. The jobless rate rose to 5.7 percent, the highest level in six years. Even forecasters who expect a rebound in the first half of next year anticipate the number of jobless to grow further.
The Fed's rate cuts this year did not stave off a recession, but they most likely made it less severe. Congress, distracted by the Republican agenda to cut taxes on the very rich, has so far failed to provide an equally meaningful stimulus. When it does, its first priority ought to be relief for the unemployed and low-wage earners, those who may be in for a rough "recovery" in 2002.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CHARITIES; 
Those Who Lost Homes or Jobs Are to Get $2,500 Grants

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
The Sept. 11 Fund, the second-largest charity formed since the terror attacks, will announce plans today to distribute $75 million by year's end to victims and their families, with most of that money going to those who lost homes or jobs in Lower Manhattan.
 The payment plan is significant because it represents the single largest disbursement of charity aimed specifically at the legions of newly unemployed and homeless, a broad category that is excluded from many of the charities responding to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. 
 Under the fund's plan, an estimated 20,000 people who lost jobs or homes will receive $2,500 each, or about two-thirds of the $75 million. Only those who lived or worked south of Canal Street will qualify, and only those permanently displaced from their homes will be covered, officials said. 
The rest of the $75 million will be distributed to the families of those killed or injured, with each family getting a check for $10,000 regardless of how much they have already received from other charities.
Franklin Thomas, chairman of the $340-million Sept. 11 Fund, which was created by the United Way and the New York Community Trust, said in an interview yesterday that the cash-distribution plan is an attempt to make sure that the unemployed and those made homeless by the collapse of the World Trade Center are not overlooked -- as some assert has happened -- in the distribution of more than $1.5 billion in charitable donations.
John Haynes, 44, who lost his job as a chef in the employee cafeteria at Windows on the World, said a $2,500 check would be a welcome change after months of frustrating and often fruitless attempts to obtain assistance from charities. Over and over, he said, he has been politely turned away, forcing him to dip into his meager savings because he cannot support two children on a $279-a-week unemployment check. 
"For a lot of people who really need this money, this is a godsend," he said, speaking of himself and the thousands of others who lost jobs after the attacks. "We have been overlooked, and when we voice our concerns we only get crumbs, while others get pies."
Mr. Thomas said that the Sept. 11 Fund plans to hold back on distributing tens of millions of dollars, in part as a reserve to pay for long-term needs such as mental health counseling. But the reserve could also be used, he said, to address potential inequities if -- after all the charity and government aid has been distributed -- some families end up with far less than others.
Questions of equity have become particularly divisive in recent weeks. Some families are openly resentful at the hundreds of thousands of dollars flowing to the families of the firefighters, police officers and other uniformed rescuers who were killed on Sept. 11.
Several police and fire widows have argued that their families deserve a larger share of the charity because their husbands sacrificed their lives to save others.
"There's no damn perfect way to do this," Mr. Thomas said, acknowledging the virtual impossibility of distributing money in a way that pleases everyone. 
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been accused by some victims' families of giving preferential treatment to the families of uniformed casualties, said yesterday it was his concern for families who "might fall through the cracks" that prompted him to establish a new city office to provide each victim's family with a caseworker.
"There is potentially a great deal of aid available for all of the legitimate victims, the families of the legitimate victims of the World Trade Center," he told reporters. "But people need to know how to find it, how to access it." 
Like several other charities, the Sept. 11 Fund has faced severe criticism from some victims' families for not distributing donations more quickly and with less paperwork. Indeed, several leaders of Families of Sept. 11, a victims' group that represents hundreds of surviving relatives, greeted the news of the $75 million plan with skepticism yesterday, with some calling it a public relations gesture, albeit a welcome one. 
"They've caused so much pain," Carie Lemack, president of the group, said of the Sept. 11 Fund and other major charities, including the American Red Cross, which has raised more than $560 million for victims of the attacks.
Ms. Lemack, a Massachusetts resident whose mother was on one of the jets flown into the World Trade Center, complained that the Sept. 11 Fund has yet to distribute money to her local United Way, which has been helping more than 100 families.
A spokeswoman for the Sept. 11 Fund said a grant would be made soon. Nonetheless, Ms. Lemack vowed that she would never again donate a single dollar to a major charity. "Never in my life," she said.
Mr. Thomas acknowledged that the $75 million plan is, at least in part, a response to criticism about the sluggish, bureaucratic nature of the relief efforts.
"You can't not be influenced by some of that pressure," Mr. Thomas said. He noted, for example, that the cash-assistance checks would be sent out automatically, making use of thousands of names and addresses already collected by Safe Horizon and the Red Cross, the two major charities that dealt directly with victims.
No new application will be required, he said. Victims who have not signed up with those agencies may call 1-866-689-HELP (1-866-689-4357) to register for the cash assistance checks, or apply at their local United Way.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Internet Piracy Is Suspected As U.S. Agents Raid Campuses

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 

 BODY:
Federal law enforcement agents seized computers and raided computer networks at M.I.T., the University of California at Los Angeles and other large universities today in shutting down what they described as one of the Internet's largest and most sophisticated software piracy networks.
 The Customs Service, which led the investigation, said that the network had distributed things like the latest Windows software and digital copies of the hit film "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." The ringleaders may include university students and employees and executives in the software industry, the officials said. 
 Duke and Purdue confirmed that raids had been carried out in dormitory rooms and that undergraduate students -- one at each school -- had been questioned by federal agents. At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, officials said, the raid was directed at computers in the economics department. The University of Oregon said a raid had been carried out on computer equipment at an unidentified "off-campus location." 
Customs officials said arrests were imminent, although none were made today while investigators reviewed computer hard drives and other material seized in the raids. Raids were also carried out at several computer and software companies around the country.
Investigators said that the piracy ring dubbed itself the DrinkOrDie network and that members were so brazen that they had their own public Web site. They appeared to be motivated more by the thrill of piracy than by the opportunity for profit, the agents said, adding that the activity crossed international borders. Raids were also carried out today in Britain, Australia, Finland, Norway and Sweden.
Customs investigators would not identify the software executives under suspicion except to say that they were all experts in programming or Internet communications.
The investigators said some were insiders who stole software from their own firms and handed it over to the pirates, apparently viewing themselves as "Robin Hood" figures who took from their rich employers so the software would be freely available to the poor -- and anyone else with an interest in it. The stolen software was then posted on Internet sites for easy distribution.
The Customs Service said it could not immediately estimate the value of the software distributed by the DrinkOrDie network, described as one of the better known of several large software piracy gangs using the Internet. The software industry estimates that it loses about $12 billion a year because of all types of piracy, though it is not known how many people who use pirated software would otherwise buy it.
Investigators said the computers and computer networks raided today were found to contain thousands of copies of pirated business software, including some of the latest and most popular word-processing and spreadsheet programs, as well as the code for Sony PlayStation and Nintendo games.
They said they also found digitized versions of several other popular Hollywood films released in theaters in recent weeks, including "Behind Enemy Lines," "Monsters Inc." and "Spy Game."
Customs officials said this was the largest Internet software piracy investigation ever conducted across international borders. 
"This investigation underscores the severity and scope of a multibillion-dollar software swindle over the Internet," said Robert C. Bonner, the customs commissioner, "as well as the vulnerabilities of this technology to outside attack."
The Customs Service said it had singled out DrinkOrDie because it was considered one of most sophisticated of the rings operating within a loose, global network. The groups sprang up in the early 1990's when computer hackers began organizing into competitive gangs that stole software, "cracked" its security protections and then posted it online.
Investigators said that DrinkOrDie was founded in 1993 in Moscow by a Russian who was known to other hackers only by the code name "deviator." The piracy ring had a worldwide membership by 1995, the agents said, and after what appeared to be one of its earliest pirating feats, it took credit for releasing the Windows 95 operating system over the Internet two weeks before Microsoft released it to the public.
The Web site of the network, www.drinkordie.com, was closed today. Only the home page stayed available for a time; it displayed an animated vision of two human eyes and long sequences of the numbers 1 and 0, representing digital code.
The Customs Service said that the five universities raided today had cooperated and were not considered targets of the criminal investigation. "The search was done with the Duke police and with someone from our student affairs office present," said David Jarmul, a spokesman for the university. He said the raid had been carried out on the dormitory room of a male undergraduate.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Plans to Raise Transit Fares 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 11 

 BODY:
Faced with a daunting deficit and falling government aid, New Jersey Transit today proposed its first fare increases in more than a decade.
 The state-run agency, apparently reversing a long reluctance in Trenton to raise fares, wants riders on its buses, commuter trains and the Newark subway to pay a 10 percent increase in the coming year, and additional increases pegged to inflation in each of the five years after that. 
 The proposal comes less than a week after New York's comptroller, H. Carl McCall, warned that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority might have to raise subway and bus fares by 50 cents in 2003 to help close a budget gap. The M.T.A. said such talk was premature, though it could not rule out an increase. 
New Jersey Transit's board of directors is to hold six public hearings on Jan. 2 on the fare proposal and is expected to disclose the locations at its meeting Wednesday, said James Weinstein, the state transportation commissioner and the agency's board chairman. If the board approves the increases, they will be the first since 1990 for the statewide system, supplementing fare revenues that have declined 29 percent in real dollars over the last decade while costs have risen 67 percent.
Exempted from the initial increase is the recently inaugurated Hudson-Bergen light rail system, since the fare structure there reflects current real costs, Mr. Weinstein said. After the first year of the fare increase, that line and all others would be subject to the inflation-driven increases, which would be automatic and not require approval by the board.
"It is no secret that N.J. Transit is facing a budget crisis," Mr. Weinstein said. "I believe this is the right time to advance this fare policy initiative."
Some mass transit advocates and state officials noted today that the timing of the proposal -- at the close of Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's administration and before a new Legislature and Governor-elect James E. McGreevey take office -- was likely to diffuse political blame for the fare increases and make their adoption more likely.
A spokeswoman for Mr. McGreevey declined comment tonight on the fare proposal. "We have not received any information from New Jersey Transit, and we have not reviewed the proposal," said the spokeswoman, Jo Astrid Glading.
Many New Jersey commuters, who often find standing room only on crowded trains and buses, are already angry about the level of service and can be expected to be vocal in the hearings.
Few rider advocates or others familiar with mass transit in the state question the agency's need for higher fares and increased aid to operate the nation's third-largest public transportation system. Fares have not budged as state and federal operating assistance to the agency has either stalled or declined in recent years. The result is an annual operating deficit of $500 million, said Martin E. Robins, principal writer of a report saying last month that the agency was mired in a "financial morass."
"This is a reasonable first step," said Mr. Robins, who heads the Alan E. Voorhees Transportation Center at Rutgers University. "But the next administration needs to create a blue-ribbon commission to look at transportation funding overall."
Jennifer Jaroski, New Jersey coordinator for the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a mass transit advocacy group, agreed that a fare increase was needed, but as part of a balanced plan that also raises the gasoline tax, which finances highways. Revenues from drivers and from mass transit fares have to be balanced to keep one from siphoning off funds from the other, she said.
"But I think this should be pushed back until McGreevey is in office," she added. "He did campaign as a pro-transit candidate, and it is his administration, after all, which will be stuck with the decision."
Ranking members of transportation committees in both legislative houses today welcomed the fare proposal, which they said should mute some of the agency's requests for subsidies. It should also enable some of the state's private bus lines to increase fares without feeling that they are putting themselves at a competitive disadvantage, said State Senator Andrew R. Ciesla, a Republican and chairman of the Senate transportation committee. "But I don't think that the automatic inflation increases in the other years are fair," he said. "There needs to be some analysis of the marketplace to see if it is necessary."
If adopted, the 10 percent fare increase would mean an additional $44 million for the agency, which has an annual budget of $1.138 billion. Mr. Robins said that the figure was just a small fraction of the agency's deficit,and that continued state subsidies would be necessary. 
In recent years, according to his study, New Jersey Transit has made up for the lack of increases in subsidies and fares by using federal and state funds intended for long-term capital investments to meet some annual operating costs.
This has been done, he said, with the willing assistance of elected officials, who saw this approach as a way of avoiding pressure on the state's general fund that might lead to tax increases or less financing for other politically popular programs.

HEADLINE: Only the Latest Blow for a Staggered Commercial Printing Industry 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Several inches of dust on the floor made it look as if a snowstorm had blown through the offices of Admiral Communications, a printing company four blocks south of the World Trade Center. That was bad for the hundreds of reams of paper that had recently been delivered, much of it for a big job for one of the Wall Street firms that made up the bulk of Admiral's customer base before Sept. 11.
 Worse, however, was the ink that dried in the presses. Admiral's employees ran for their lives when the twin towers collapsed, and then the printing plant was closed off for three weeks in the zone around the disaster, inaccessible even to Arthur Baron, whose father founded the company in 1946. So one morning recently, insurance adjusters were trying to estimate the value of those eye-high stacks of ruined paper and dozens of rollers that had to be pried from the presses, slathered in dried ink. 
"Our phone service was out for three weeks, and our clients thought we were just gone," Mr. Baron said. "Now, we're doing less business with fewer employees. My gut feeling is we're barely surviving right now." 
A slowing economy already had New York City's printing industry on its knees on Sept. 11, when the cloud of soot settled over the industry's traditional home in Lower Manhattan. Restrictions on bridge and tunnel crossings made things worse, halting deliveries of ink, paper and finished products, even for printers in the boroughs outside Manhattan. The blows followed years in which rising real estate prices and traffic bottlenecks forced printing companies, like many other manufacturers, out of Manhattan. 
Now, dozens of printing employees have been laid off across the city, and companies in related industries, like graphic arts, are suffering too. For many printing companies, the business of producing reports for stock offerings sank with the dot-com market. The cancellation of orders for trade-show brochures and advertising campaigns after Sept. 11 have them wondering if their futures are in doubt.
"Business has never been this slow for most companies since the 1980's," said Vicki Keenan, director of public affairs for the Association of Graphic Communications, a regional trade group for printers. "The logistics of the security measures around the city have had a huge impact on the ability of companies to deliver products, and the smaller printers have been hit particularly hard." 
Admiral's plight is shared by several printing companies near ground zero, most acutely Fitch Graphics, whose building at 130 Cedar Street was showered with debris from the trade center, including steel beams that crashed through the roof.
"We are very grateful that all our people got out," said John Fitch, the company's owner. But even operating out of a secondary print site on West 45th Street, he has only been able to bring back about 25 of 70 employees because of a lack of business.
Mr. Fitch said he had applied to several aid programs. He was told that the company has too many employees to qualify for the city's grant program for small manufacturers, and another aid program told Mr. Fitch that it could not make a loan big enough to suit his company's needs. 
"All we need is one little grain of sand in the billion-dollar bucket and we can put 50 people back to work," he said. 
Farther from the disaster site, business is moderately better, but is still suffering from the economic downturn and sharp limits on corporate marketing budgets.
"There has been a tremendous dip in advertising work," said Stuart Leventhal, owner of Lexicon, a printing company on Hudson Street north of Canal Street. "People are afraid to make a commitment and do things and spend money. For us, a little bit of fear equals a lot of business lost or shifted into the unforeseen future."
Anthony Caifano, secretary-treasurer for Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America union, said about 10 percent of the union's 2,000 members have been laid off since Sept. 11. The industry was particularly hurt by the attack, he said, because most printing jobs for the holidays take place in September and October.
City economic officials have taken some steps to help the printing industry. Last month, City Hall and the Economic Development Corporation selected Hudson Development to build a $25 million, 400,000-square-foot building specifically for printing companies in College Point, Queens. That followed the establishment in May 2000 of an $8 million relocation fund to help commercial printers and graphic arts companies move to new sites in New York City.
In recent years, many printing companies that were based in downtown Manhattan have moved to Long Island City, Queens, in part to take advantage of cheaper rent and more space. Many of them, however, had been all but forced out of their warehouse-type buildings when landlords converted them to commercial office space, allowing them to charge higher rents.
Alan Bergman, a co-owner of the Hudson Printing Company, moved the company to Long Island City 13 months ago after its rent was raised. 
Founded by Mr. Bergman's grandfather in Manhattan in 1922, Hudson Printing was able to retain most of its customers and all of its employees despite the move, Mr. Bergman said, as well as configure its printing and assembly lines more efficiently, thanks to more space. 
But business has slowed recently, he said, as companies have canceled trade shows and seminars, eliminating the need for brochures and other printed materials.
What bothers Mr. Bergman more, he said, is the fact that the city often sends printing orders for official government business to printers outside the city, the state or even the country. 
"Obviously, that hurts," Mr. Bergman said. "We think city printing business should stay in the city. Every small printer in New York City has excess capacity. I don't think it would be a problem for any of us to accommodate the city's work."
Warner Johnston, a spokesman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, said the city takes the lowest bidder for nearly all of its printing jobs. "As the guardian of public funds, we have the responsibility to use the contractor who costs us the least," he said.
The decision by NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau, to move up its midwinter tourism promotion to November from January appeared to be some balm. But then the rush order, for 450,000 copies of a new 24-page tourism brochure, went to a printing company in New Jersey.
Tourism officials said the requirements for quick turnaround of a large printing job required the greater capacity available only at bigger printers outside the city. 
"We certainly make every effort to print our stuff in the city," said Keith Yazmir, a spokesman for NYC & Company. "But our marketing efforts support a $25 billion industry. If we can get people to visit more quickly, then all those people are going to make a lot more money than just a single vendor on a relatively small printing project."
Mr. Yazmir added that a smaller one-page flier on tourism packages was printed in New York City. 
New York printers take cold comfort in that, however, and several said that the money saved on an individual printing job is offset by jobs lost in New York City. 
"There's a real malaise in the communications industry in New York," said Mr. Leventhal, of Lexicon printers. "It's definitely more difficult to be a printer here than it had been in the past."

HEADLINE: Should I Get a Mammogram? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Whether mammograms save lives or not (front page, Dec. 9; editorial, Dec. 10), one thing we know for sure: diagnosis and treatment can never end the breast cancer epidemic. That requires prevention. 
 The nearly threefold increase in breast cancer risk in the United States since the 1940's strongly suggests that environmental factors, which may be changed, are still to be discovered. Yet the entire budget of the National Institute for Environmental Health Science is $500 million, while the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation estimates the cost of breast cancer to the United States economy at $6 billion. 
 An investment in environmental research is speculative, of course, since we cannot anticipate where it will lead; but it is our daughters' best hope.

ELLEN PARKER
BEV BACCELLI
Newton, Mass., Dec. 10, 2001

The writers are, respectively, chairwoman, Silent Spring Institute; and president, Massachusetts Breast Cancer Coalition.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
KROGER TO LAY OFF 1 ,500 AFTER 33% DROP IN EARNINGS

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The Kroger Company, the supermarket chain, announced yesterday that it would cut about 1,500 jobs after reporting that third-quarter earnings had fallen 33 percent because of the sluggish economy and one-time expenses. 
Kroger also lowered its earning forecast for the fourth quarter. Its shares fell $3.38, to $19.92. Earnings for the quarter ended Nov. 10 were $133.1 million, or 16 cents a share, down from $200.9 million, or 24 cents a year ago. That included third-quarter expenses of $10 million for systems conversions, $110 million for store closings and $81 million for energy contracts in California. Sales in the quarter rose 3.8 percent, to $11.38 billion, from $10.96 billion last year.

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
For Some Professions, Thinking Small Can Pay Big Dividends

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

 BODY:
Engineers, architects and surveyors are well paid almost anywhere. But if they really want to make their paychecks go farther, they should consider moving to Corpus Christi, Tex.; Mobile, Ala., or Hickory, N.C. 
 That may seem surprising, but according to an analysis of compensation data collected by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for 1999, the most recent available year, they earned more than three times the average income in those cities, better than they could do anywhere else. Where did they fare the worst? Springfield, Mass., and New York City. There, their pay was only 41 percent and 47 percent higher, respectively, than the average. 
 The same analysis showed that lawyers were best compensated in Washington at 338 percent of the average working wage. They did not do nearly as well in Minneapolis-St. Paul, where they were only 66 percent above the average.
 Why such disparities? Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, said: "Strong demand for workers is most evident in industries and businesses that drive local economies. So, in Corpus Christi, home to much of the nation's energy exploration and development, surveyors are in high demand and their compensation reflects that."
 Whatever the reason, the numbers point to a time-tested workplace truth: go where they need you. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Overtime Becomes Class-Action Fodder 

BYLINE:  By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU

 BODY:
Chris Lyle was excited about her promotion from waitress to store manager at Pizza Hut in Northern California a few years ago, but soon wondered what her new title really meant. She said her duties were mostly making dough, mopping floors and taking orders, pretty much what an hourly worker would do -- except she was not paid overtime. "There were times my employees were making more money than me, when I looked at the hours I worked," said Mrs. Lyle, 30, who lives in Fairfield, Calif.
 Mrs. Lyle worked as a manager in several Pizza Hut stores from 1993 to 1998, including a full-service restaurant and take-out shops, starting at a salary of $18,000. "I thought it was a lot of money," she said. But the 50-hour week that managers were supposed to put in turned out to be more like 60, she said. 
 Mrs. Lyle, who now works at a mattress company, was a plaintiff in a class-action lawsuit against Pizza Hut by salaried workers who said they were misclassified under federal and state labor laws as exempt from time-and-a-half overtime wages. The suit was settled in May for over $10 million.
Pizza Hut's general counsel, Robert Millen, would not comment on Mrs. Lyle's case but said, "Our policy is always to pay our employees a fair wage for their work, in compliance with all applicable laws."
The debate about who is legally entitled to overtime pay has received more attention recently thanks to a flurry of class-action lawsuits seeking overtime pay at household names including Starbucks and U-Haul. One factor behind the trend was the team-building craze of recent years that blurred the lines between workers and managers, according to Jerry M. Newman, professor of organization and human resources at the University of Buffalo.
"In a team, there's a lot more sharing of responsibilities and less care is paid to who's the manager and who isn't," Mr. Newman said. In addition, recent labor shortages in some industries forced more managers to take on rank-and-file tasks. With the economy now in recession, companies are further fueling worker discontent with layoffs and reduced paid overtime.
Mark Cheskin, a Miami labor lawyer who represents businesses, says class-action lawsuits at his practice have gone up close to 10 percent over the last year. In one case, a store manager who was fired by a retailer Mr. Cheskin represents contends that he was not a manager, even though he supervised about 100 people and 4 departments. The former employee says he mostly helped customers, cleaned the work site and stocked inventory.
"We're seeing more people wondering about whether they are really exempt,"said Bill Coleman, senior vice president for compensation at Salary.com, a salary-comparison Web site. "The average employee doesn't know the ins and outs of overtime."
Indeed, Mr. Coleman said, the 1938 Federal Fair Labor Standards Act that governs overtime pay "is universally misunderstood." It outlines four types of employees who can be exempted from overtime-pay requirements -- executives who manage some part of a company's business and have the authority to hire and fire workers; administrators who perform nonmanual work and exercise some independent judgment; professionals like lawyers and accountants; and traveling sales representatives. While the act offers detailed descriptions, the actual decisions on who is really exempt are open to interpretation by the courts or by Labor Department investigators.
State labor laws can also come into play. For example, California, where many class-action overtime suits have hit the courts in the last few years, is thought to have the nation's most employee-friendly overtime laws. There, employees are exempt from the overtime rule only if they spend more than half their time on exempt duties that require them to use their own discretion and judgment, experts say.
One widely publicized California case involved claims adjusters at Farmers Insurance Exchange, a unit of the Los Angeles-based Farmers Insurance Group, whom the company classified as exempt from overtime. A jury ruled in July that Farmers owed $90 million for not paying its claims adjusters overtime, noting that the adjusters had "no formal advisory role" in managing business functions or making corporate policy.
Mary Flynn, a Farmers spokeswoman, said the company was appealing.
Such overtime disputes are popping up across the country. In Tennessee, 20 workers with managerial and administrative titles at the Tennessee Valley Authority, the largest public power utility, sued the company for eliminating overtime wages.
Steven Warren of Niota, Tenn., has worked for the company, based in Knoxville, for 15 years, holding a number of positions including shift supervisor and lieutenant. He said he typically worked 44-hour weeks, but if someone were on vacation he would have to work an extra 12-hour shift free.
Basically, he said, he was responsible for making sure employee training was up to date, but he did not have the authority to hire and fire workers or establish workplace policies. "We didn't have the power to do anything," he said.
In October, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit found that the shift supervisors at Tennessee Valley who were part of the suit "did spend some of their time supervising employees," but "this supervision was not managerial in nature because they had no control over the people they supervised." The appeals court upheld a lower court's decision in 1999 to award the workers more than $500,000 in back overtime pay.
John Moulton, a spokesman for Tennessee Valley, said that the agency did not think the employees were entitled to overtime and that it was considering an appeal.
In another case, the Labor Department investigated an overtime claim at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston in June and found that 92 respiratory therapists were entitled to a total of nearly $119,000 in back overtime pay.
A hospital spokesman said it had changed its policy but had also altered scheduling so that therapists did not work overtime because it could not afford to pay it.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Steven Warren, above, was part of a group of shift supervisors at the Tennessee Valley Authority who won $500,000 in back overtime pay. Chris Lyle and other salaried workers at Pizza Hut sued for back wages. The case was settled for over $10 million. (Dan Krauss for The New York Times); (Wade Payne for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Victims and Champions of a Darwinian Enron

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 7 

 BODY:
After an accounting scandal, a bankruptcy filing and mass layoffs, Enron has gone from model of management vision to case study for management obfuscation. Only one group of true believers remains: the people who worked there and just got burned there.
 They may be in a minority. After all, 5,600 people have been thrown out of work in the midst of a recession. Most employees lost a huge part of their retirement savings as the value of their Enron stock evaporated. Many are furious at what they view as bungling or worse by top management. 
 Even so, a surprising number of former employees lament the end of an entrepreneurial culture that more closely resembled a start-up than a Fortune 100 behemoth. That culture encouraged creativity and rewarded new ideas that worked, they say, even though its dark side, an almost manic drive to experiment with new methods and conquer new markets, resulted in its downfall. Where, they wonder, can they go from here? 
"Innovative is a cliche, but that's what Enron was," Brandon Rigney, who operated the company's Web site, said on Thursday. "This is four days gone from the place, and I'm already in withdrawal."
Enron, which began as a gas pipeline company and transformed itself into the world's largest energy trader in the 1990's, created an associate analysts program modeled after Wall Street investment banks. Each year, it tapped 450 college graduates, half of them M.B.A.'s, to spend three years in rotating jobs at all parts of its empire.
It also gave workers opportunities to start new business units. The company's energy trading platform, Enron Online, was created a few years ago by a 29-year-old gas trader. It quickly became one of the most profitable divisions.
In recent years, the company came to be dominated by young people like Jeff Shankman, a Wharton School graduate who joined the company at 24. By age 34, he had become president and chief operating officer of Enron Global Markets.
Mr. Shankman, who has just left the company, said Enron was special because it "didn't have a corporate hierarchy to encumber creativity."
Management experts like Gary Hamel praised Enron for breaking with convention and turning regular employees like the 29-year-old gas trader into corporate entrepreneurs. And Fortune magazine named it America's most innovative company for six consecutive years. The corporate makeover was largely the work of Jeffrey K. Skilling, who resigned as chief executive in August only six months after being promoted to the job.
Under Mr. Skilling, a former McKinsey & Company consultant, the company tested new strategies, like structuring its corporate culture to mimic the marketplace.
"You could come up with an idea and get people excited," said Janel Guerrero, 33, who worked in Enron's government affairs department, noting that a friend in the broadband unit went to top executives with an idea and Enron started moving on it quickly.
"You didn't ponder; it was about acting very quickly and it was about being a first mover," she added. 
Enron rapidly created ventures to trade everything from energy, paper, pulp and lumber to broadband and advertising. But quickness sometimes exacts a price. Some ventures went broke, like Azurix, its spinoff water company. The broadband unit lost about $1 billion.
"When top management got into broadband, metal, steel, pulp, we thought it was innovative," Mr. Rigney said. "When people said, 'We'll trade water and waste water -- that's the future,' we said, 'That's cool.' I didn't hear dissent in the ranks. But I drank the Kool-Aid with everyone else, even though it made my head throb."
Indeed, the expansion into new areas drained the profits of the successful energy trading operations, critics say. Undone by shaky accounting and too much borrowed money, the company collapsed last month. But even near the end, it was buzzing with new ventures.
"I just got here five months ago," said Fred Radvansky, 38, who was attending a Houston job fair. "I was part of a group of about 70 people. We were rolling out a new Enron model. We were going to start trading freight."
If inventiveness flourished at Enron, the freewheeling environment there also encouraged other and less agreeable impulses: cutthroat competition and management arrogance.
"It was kind of like a dot-com phenomenon," said Harvey J. Padewer, president of energy services at Duke Energy, a big utility. "They created a kill-and-eat culture."
Mr. Rigney, the former Web site operator, remembers it well. "People tried to take work away from you," he said. "There was a Darwinism for ideas, for projects."
That undermined the company's health, critics say. For example, it is widely believed that compensation for the people who negotiated deals with other companies was based on the size of the transactions rather than their long-term effect on the bottom line.
Annual reviews aimed at weeding out the least productive 5 to 10 percent of the work force damaged morale, and some longtime employees felt unwanted. "There were all these M.B.A.'s coming in and they were evaluating things differently," said Becky Cantrell, who worked on regulatory matters. "I was one of the oldest people at 55. When I saw someone my age it was a relief."
For all the doubts some employees harbored, others reveled in the derring-do atmosphere even after Enron's financial fall, and cringed at the prospect of being acquired by Dynegy Inc., a stodgy Houston electric utility.
"They bragged about being a meat-and-potatoes company with people who went to the University of Nebraska," one former Enron employee said. "We had all these hyperactive Harvard and Stanford types. It would have never worked."
After the merger fell apart, Enron filed for bankruptcy protection on Dec. 2 and laid off about 4,000 employees in Houston. Over the next few days, television crews filmed weeping employees streaming out of the headquarters and carrying boxes of personal belongings, even as construction workers put finishing touches on Enron's shimmering new 40-story headquarters office tower. Some got word of their dismissal via voice mail. Others are still packing up and wondering.
"I don't think Enron will ever be recreated," Mr. Shankman said on Thursday, sitting on a nearly empty trading floor that was built for 500 people at Enron. "Maybe we got into some businesses too quickly and too early."
Enron officials and management experts insist it was not the corporate culture that brought Enron down; it was accounting mistakes or the ballooning debt of hard assets, like projects in Brazil and India.
Those facts may now be plumbed by business school case studies. In the meantime, some former employees have created Enron alumni Web sites. Others are writing letters to The Houston Chronicle about how, for a brief time, they thought they were part of something special.
"Enron was what I thought epitomized a global 'American Dream' of sorts," wrote Kathy Walthall, a former Enron contractor. "By far the best days of my career were as a consultant for Enron. The environment was an extreme rush. Very busy, very progressive and innovative."
But Ms. Walthall said she was also outraged at the board for allowing the company to fall so swiftly.
"I really hope the company turns around," she wrote. "But I know it will never be the same."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Modest Rally Fizzles After Merck's Warning on Earnings

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks erased much of their gains yesterday, after a modest afternoon rally that followed the Federal Reserve's latest interest rate reduction faded when Merck & Company warned that it would not meet its earnings forecast.
 Merck's forecast weighed on other drug makers and helped to drag some major indexes lower. Technology stocks, however, eked out modest gains. 
 "First the Fed cut," said Arthur Hogan, chief market strategist at Jefferies & Company. But the statement "coming out of it was still pretty cautious and that keeps investors nervous," he said. 
"Merck was definitely the knockout punch for the day," he added.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.08 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 9,888.37. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 3.17 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,136.76. The technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index rose 9.81 points, or 0.5 percent, to 2,001.93.
Stocks initially moved higher after the Federal Reserve trimmed short-term interest rates for the 11th time this year, reducing the benchmark federal funds rate by a quarter percentage point, to 1.75 percent, its lowest level in 40 years. The Fed said, however, that some signs of economic weakness appeared to be abating.
"The text was much more important than the action itself," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at SG Cowen. "They're starting to make noises that what they've done already is enough."
Still, the Fed's policy makers said that those signs of improvement were preliminary and tentative, leading many analysts to believe that the central bank left itself room to reduce rates again when it meets in January.
As investors tried to sort through exactly what the Fed's statement meant, the late-afternoon earnings warning by Merck overshadowed any upbeat sentiment. The company, one of the 30 Dow industrials, said its earnings for 2001 would be lower than previous projections. In a meeting with analysts and investors, Merck executives said they were comfortable with earnings in the range of $3.12 to $3.15 a share. The company had previously forecast earnings of $3.12 to $3.18 a share. Shares of Merck tumbled $6.29, to $60.70, on the news.
Merck's news weighed on other drug makers. Eli Lilly fell $1.14, to $80.40; Pfizer dipped 99 cents, to $40.35, and American Home Products lost $1.44, to $58.75.
General Motors, another Dow component, also lost ground yesterday. Its shares fell $1.69, to $48.65, after its partner, Fiat Auto, sold more than $5 billion in five-year notes that could be converted into 32 million G.M. shares.
Technology stocks were among the day's few bright spots. Shares of Nokia, the world's largest cellphone maker, leapt $1.71, to $25.50, after the company said it would meet and possibly exceed its earnings guidance for the fourth quarter.
Other wireless communications equipment makers were buoyed by Nokia's upbeat forecast. Motorola advanced 17 cents, to $16.82, and Ericsson rose 19 cents, to $6.01. 
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Gain
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut the benchmark lending rate a quarter-percentage point and suggested it might lower the rate again to pull the economy out of recession.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 11/32, to a price of 99 18/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.06 percent from 5.10 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 97 20/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.54 percent from 5.56 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
The Man Behind the Curtain In the Hewlett-Compaq Merger

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
With its merger with Compaq in serious danger, Hewlett-Packard will increasingly turn to a leading member of its board to sell the plan to large shareholders, whose votes will make or break the deal.
 The board member, Richard A. Hackborn, a 33-year Hewlett veteran, is unknown outside the industry. But in the face of the rejection of the merger by the heirs of the Hewlett-Packard founders, he is probably the best person to lend credibility to the plan. 
 Mr. Hackborn, 64, tall and white-haired, pushed to bring the company's chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, in two years ago from Lucent Technologies. He has been her adviser and mentor. To ease her transition and coach her, Mr. Hackborn took the chairman's post for several months, before handing it off to her. He is the guiding hand behind a strategic rethinking at Hewlett-Packard that began even before Ms. Fiorina arrived, and that eventually led to the Compaq Computer bid. 
Now, both companies must convince investors and the industry that the combination is the best way forward -- a risk, yes, but a carefully calculated one that is well worth taking.
Mr. Hackborn began his career at the company in the HP Labs as an engineer, and he was soon heading research-and-development teams. In 1977, seeking new challenges, he moved to Boise, Idaho, and he proceeded to build the Hewlett-Packard printer business, the corporate crown jewel.
He was known for contributing thoughtful, detailed strategy papers on various subjects from Boise. "I did it when I was asked, and sometimes when I wasn't," Mr. Hackborn observed during an interview last week at his large, ranch home in Boise, with a waterfall and a pond on a wooded three acres.
Three times over the years, William Hewlett and David Packard, the founders, came to his home, urging him to return to the Silicon Valley headquarters. The last offer was to become chief executive.
Yet Mr. Hackborn and his wife, Sondra, a native Californian who moved north reluctantly at first, had grown deeply attached to the natural beauty of Idaho and their local network of friends. He turned down the offer.
Mr. Hackborn retired as an executive vice president of Hewlett-Packard at 56. Shortly afterward, he got a call from Bill Gates, asking him to join the Microsoft board, which he did until last year when his work on Hewlett-Packard matters became increasingly time consuming.
Throughout the industry, Mr. Hackborn is highly regarded as both a skilled technologist and a shrewd strategist. And he commands respect in Silicon Valley in a way that Ms. Fiorina, an outsider who is seen as a general manager instead of someone who deeply understands technology, cannot.
"I'm not a big fan of Carly's," said one venture capitalist, who worked at Hewlett-Packard for years. "But if Dick Hackborn really supports the deal, you have to take it seriously."
In 1998, in the midst of the technology boom, Mr. Hackborn said he became "really concerned" about what he saw as the festering troubles at Hewlett-Packard. The personal computer business trailed behind more efficient rivals, notably Dell Computer, and was losing money. The company's business in larger computers, mostly data-serving machines running the Unix operating system, was not making much money, even when industry demand was surging. And Hewlett-Packard was not really embracing the Internet.
The company, Mr. Hackborn said, had become sluggish at a time when speed was essential. The first step was to bring in Ms. Fiorina, someone from outside the traditional culture to shake things up. "We needed a much greater push for change at the top, with more urgency," he said. "We needed someone who could drive change and could articulate it."
He credits her with learning at "lightning speed" a wealth of detail about the industry, customers and products. Not every step has been sure-footed, but Mr. Hackborn said he and the board backed Ms. Fiorina wholeheartedly. "She's going through a massive learning experience," he said. "We knew it was going to be a learning experience."
The Hewlett-Packard board first discussed the possibility of acquiring Compaq at the end of 1999, but serious merger talks did not begin until last June. "None of us was convinced that Compaq was the exact right answer at the start," Mr. Hackborn conceded.
The deal's opponents contend that those initial reservations were the right instinct, and that the Compaq merger is a mistake. They say that the merger would reduce the size and profitability of Hewlett-Packard's most valuable franchise -- the printer business -- in the combined company, while increasing the shareholders' bet on the troubled personal computer business. And the critics point out that big mergers in the fast-moving computer business nearly always fail, as the two enterprises are distracted with internal matters as markets and rivals move ahead.
Mr. Hackborn, however, said he had come to believe firmly that the Compaq merger offered opportunities that Hewlett-Packard should seize now as the industry is consolidating in a slump.
First, combining with Compaq will help fix the PC business, giving Hewlett greater size and efficiency. The Dell model of selling PC's directly -- instead of through resellers and other middlemen -- is the way to go, he said. "Compaq is moving there rapidly," Mr. Hackborn said. "It's not Dell yet, but it's a lot further along than H.P."
Second, he believes that there is a "huge opportunity" for the combined company in the future generation of data-serving computers, based on the new Itanium chip, jointly developed by Intel and Hewlett-Packard. Server computers using the high-performance Itanium chips will start to ship in large numbers by the middle of next year. They promise to bring the lower-cost economics of the PC world into corporate data centers, a lucrative stronghold for mainframes and large Unix machines, where I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems are leaders.
Because it helped develop the Itanium technology, Hewlett-Packard will be given certain advantages over other computer makers. It gets a head start of several months in bringing its Itanium-based machines to market, for example. The largest market for Itanium chips is expected to be on machines running Microsoft's Windows NT operating system, though Itanium technology will also work well with Linux, a variant of the Unix operating system that is distributed free, and Hewlett-Packard's flavor of Unix.
Working closely with Intel and Microsoft, Mr. Hackborn says, Hewlett-Packard can be the leading designer of Itanium-based server computers and supplier of related hardware and services.
As such, Hewlett-Packard sees its future as being the lower-cost alternative to I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems in the lucrative market of supplying the data centers of large corporations. And Compaq is a leading maker of PC-based servers and data storage systems and has a large corporate customer base -- all of which, Mr. Hackborn insists, should accelerate that strategy. 
"This puts the new H.P. on a comparable footing with Intel and Microsoft," he said.
The opponents of the deal, Mr. Hackborn argues, have no plan for Hewlett-Packard's future. But should they prevail, he suggests, it will be a future without him. 
"If the merger gets turned down by shareholders," he said, "they will have to get a board and a management to fix the PC business and these other problems."

HEADLINE: Rating Firm Turns Negative About New Jersey's Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 11 

 BODY:
In the clearest sign yet of New Jersey's weakening fiscal condition, Moody's Investors Service warned today that the state is likely to face a significant downturn during the next 18 months, and assigned a negative outlook to the state's newly issued municipal bonds. 
 While the agency did not take the more drastic step of downgrading the state's bonds, which still have a high rating of Aa2, Moody's financial analysts said that the falling tax revenues and sputtering national economy had forced them to adjust their outlook for New Jersey's economy from "stable" to "negative." 
 The report also forecast that New Jersey was likely to exhaust its budget reserve fund of $1.2 billion this fiscal year, which ends next June, and could face a deficit of $2.4 billion -- or 10 percent of total state revenues -- for the fiscal year beginning in July 2003. Robert A. Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's, said New Jersey's economic performance was likely to be hampered by the national recession. 
New Jersey's dependence on the financial services industry, combined with the aftereffects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, have also contributed to a downturn in the state's economy.
News of the bond agency's bleak assessment of the state's finances intensified the running dispute between Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and Governor-elect Jim McGreevey, who takes office Jan. 15. Mr. DiFrancesco has accused Mr. McGreevey of exaggerating the extent of the state's budget shortfall in order to prepare state residents and legislators for strict austerity in the early days of the McGreevey administration.
But nearly as soon as he was elected, Mr. McGreevey began warning state residents that he was inheriting a budget crisis that could culminate in a $1.9 billion deficit in its $24 billion budget this fiscal year and a $3.7 billion gap the next year. 
The analysts at Moody's said they did not wish to take sides in the political disagreement between Mr. McGreevey and Mr. DiFrancesco. But much of its forecast seemed close to the bleak assessment Mr. McGreevey and his transition team have been giving, and the governor-elect pointed out those similarities today as he repeated his call for legislators to rein in their spending during the final weeks of the legislative term that ends Jan 7.
"Moody's corroborates and confirms to a large measure our projections," he said, "so you know, to ignore Moody's and budgetary realities while engaging in profligate spending is simply irresponsible."
The Senate Democratic leader, Richard J. Codey, responded to Moody's new assessment of the state's finances by withdrawing one spending bill he had sponsored, a $14 million proposal to equip the state's acute care hospitals with additional staffing and equipment to treat patients who suffer strokes. Mr. Codey also urged fellow senators to pull $100 million in new spending bills now being considered by the Senate budget panel. 
But it was unclear whether other lawmakers would follow suit. And Tom Wilson, Mr. DiFrancesco's spokesman, said that for all the McGreevey administration's discussion of deficits, the governor-elect had offered only scant suggestions about ways to cut spending or increase revenue.
"They've identified problems that are in the billions, and the solutions they've proposed are only in the millions," Mr. Wilson said.
Whether or not Mr. McGreevey makes detailed deficit-reduction proposals before his inauguration, it is clear he will face an array of unpleasant choices as he prepares his first budget in a time of austerity and growing economic uncertainty. During the last eight years, even as the state's economy enjoyed a record boom, New Jersey sharply increased its debt load, thereby limiting the amount of borrowing Mr. McGreevey will be able to do without hurting the state's bond rating and increasing its interest costs.
Mr. McGreevey has also narrowed his own options by making a campaign promise not to raise taxes. But keeping that promise -- amid declining tax revenues, a sputtering economy and an expected rise in public assistance costs -- will test Mr. McGreevey's creativity as a manger. 
Mr. Kurtter said that Moody's decided not to take the more drastic step of lowering the rating on New Jersey's bonds because the incoming McGreevey administration had promised to make deficit reduction its top priority and seemed intent on reining in the state's spending.
